There is a bit of a line, and one could argue its pricy, but honestly, there is a line out the door of 110% of all the ice cream places in SF. If I had to choose where to wait.. Smitten would be my top choice..

The last time I went I had the blood orange and pistachio.. It was great! The salted caramel is a staple and very good as well.. Staff is nice and friendly, and take advantage of the photo op of the nitrogen gas evaporating off the ice cream machine..
author: James S.

description:
I was so amused on how they make their ice cream! Never seen anything like that in any other ice cream shop. I got the mint with chocolate crispies or somewhere along those lines. Let me tell you, when they mean mint they meant mint! It was from pure mint leaves as I was told not mint extract but the difference is significant.

In the first bite I thought I ate a spring roll flavored ice cream so it was a bit overwhelming. But more bites in, it really started growing on me!

I love the look of the shop as well! Very old school with a modern taste
author: Rio O.

description:
So, it turns out that ice cream made using liquid nitrogen tastes basically exactly like ice cream.  The ice cream at Smitten has little more of a butterfat mouthfeel than the norm, but at the end of the day, ice cream is ice cream is ice cream.  

(That said, I don't know why I was expecting anything different, so maybe it's my bad.)

Smitten has 4 ice cream flavors at any given time. I ordered the tcho chocolate with their spicy caramel sauce.  I also tried my friend's order, maple brown sugar squash, which tasted of pumpkin pie.  The spicy caramel stole the night - the perfect balance of spicy and a delicate yet rich caramel sweetness.  Yum.

I feel like Smitten is a great place to take a visitor/someone new to SF - the Smitten experience is cute and quirky; the storefront is located within walking distance to a wide variety of amazing restaurants; and it's directly across the street from a park and some great interactive street art (sculptures, Candy Chang's "Before I Die" installation).

3 stars for the ice cream + 1 star for the experience alone = 4 stars.
author: Ophelia V.

description: It's the best ice cream in town if you ask me but I'm not a big fan of their recent price hike.  It use to be closer to 3$ for one scoop (which is a reasonable individual portion anyway). Now, the smallest size it's 4.5$ for 2 scoops.
author: Pierre-Luc B.

description:
The ice cream is superb! Creamy with delicious flavor. 

My family was smitten and will return.
author: Diane B.

description:
Liquid nitrogen made ice cream? Yes puhreeze.

My sister Lisa N. thinks that this place only deserves 2.5 stars because she thinks it's overpriced and too sweet... HERROOOOOO, IT'S ICE CREAM! It's supposed to be sweet and when it's made right in front of your eyes with fresh ingredients then I don't mind it being on the slightly pricier side.

They always have some sort of special seasonal flavor. When I first went, I tried the honey nectarine. It was pretty darn tootin' good. What made it even better was the brown sugar caramel sawse and their freshly made pistachio brittle. That brittle was frickin' money honey!

Second time I went, I got the salted caramel with TCHO chocolate sawse, TCHO crispies, salted peanut brittle, and cinnamon shortbread. The guy that took my order gave me this weird look when I started to name off the toppings I wanted. He kept repeating my order to me as if I had ordered a combustible combination or something. Why yes, I am fat and I'd like all the damn toppings. NOW BE KIND AND MAKE MY ORDER MR. ICE CREAM SERVANT!

The taste is amazing and you can just taste the fresh cream. It is a little bit sweet so be prepared to have about a few cups of water nearby. But I love the quality of the ingredients, the amazing array of texture in each bite with the additional toppings, and the smooth, creamy taste. This place really wants me to get some liquid nitrogen and start an ice cream lab. I'd make blue velvet ice cream and start calling myself Icenberg. WHAT'S MY NAME!?!?
author: Edison T.

description:
Ice cream made with liquid nitrogen sounds really cool, but I found it to be more of a novelty thing that's more about the experience of seeing the ice cream made than actually enjoying the product itself. My friends and I luckily beat the crowd on a Saturday afternoon before the line went around the block. I ordered the Fresh Mint Chip. 

First of all, the price is very steep. It's around $5 for a small, which is just two small scoops. The add-ons are also ridiculously expensive, so you can easily end up spending $7 for two measly scoops of ice cream. Second, the wait time was pretty long. It took us around 30 minutes to get our ice cream. I guess that's what happens when your ice cream is "made to order." The time you wait varies with your order since each flavor has its own station/line. My friends who ordered the THCO Chocolate got theirs a lot faster than I did.

Now onto the ice cream - they used real mint in the ice cream, so it had a very strong, herbal flavor. The aftertaste felt like I just brushed my teeth. The sensation quickly went away after a few bites however and just tasted bland. The ice cream texture was dense, smooth, and very crumbly, which made it hard to scoop. I felt like I needed to be very careful so that I don't drop a single piece of the ice cream, especially since each piece is like 50 cents. It also melts quickly if you don't eat it fast. 

As far as ice creams go, this was not my cup of tea. A 2.5 might be a more accurate rating for me. I think I'll just stick with Bi-rite from now on.
author: Lisa T.

description: This is my favorite ice cream place ever. I always go for the flavor of the month (strawberry rhubarb with strawberry prosecco syrup which was a rich man's strawberry sundae cup - y'know, the kind you got in grade school, nectarines n cream with cookie crumble, just to name a couple), and sit on the wooden bench while watching the machines at work. There's nothing cooler for me than awesome patented machines and fresh ice cream on a foggy day in San Francisco, especially after picking up some Warby's.
author: Natasha P.

description:
Probably the coolest ice cream places you're going to find and be interested in science as well. LIQUID NITROGEN ICE CREAM!! Whaaaaat

There are four flavors that they serve and you can pick a size you'd like with toppings with additional prices. I got a small, which comes with 2 scoops, that costs about $4-$5. In my opinion, a small is enough because the ice cream is so rich in flavor that you kind of get sick of it after a while. 

The ice cream is made in front of your eyes and it quite interesting to watch. The taste of the ice cream is quite interesting. It tastes like exactly the name of the ice cream. A very organic taste I'd have to say. For mint chocolate, it tasted exactly like the plant, mint. Tcho chocolate tasted like an overdose of chocolate, but with an organic taste.. If that made sense.. 

A definite must try because it's a taste you'll never forget
author: Vernice T.

description:
Absolutely fantastic! A real SF food landmark among the many that exist and in one of my favorite foodie neighborhoods...Hayes Valley. An adorable story and ice cream that seriously is worth the hype and whatever hype it's not getting.

The fresh ingredients, adorable location and hometown  story add to the charm that is Smitten!  The location is a semi-open oar shack that actually use to be one of the original drying containers! Just an adorable touch to the entire story and establishment.

I had the earl grey with chocolate chip and wow was it amazing! A small scoop is over $5 but welcome to SF that's normal for your trendy, ice cream or dessert spot! They have a few flavor at a time some of which were salted caramel, chocolate, vanilla. I bet all are delicious!
author: Priya S.

description: I think Smitten may be my favorite ice cream place in the world and I've eaten a lot of ice cream. The salted caramel ice cream is my favorite because the texture is perfectly creamy and the flavor is amazing. I also love that they use liquid nitrogen to make their ice cream because it's fun to watch. Parking in Hayes Valley is hard to find but it is totally worth it!
author: Karen L.

description:
I'm a bit torn but... This is a solid 3.5. 

We got there at night for some dessert and the line was long but not too long. We waited about 20-30minutes which isn't too bad. 

The way they make the icecream with liquid nitrogen right in front of you is super cool! it's a fun experience to see how they do it. 
I got the TCHO chocolate with some toppings like salted caramel sauce and whipped cream, and it was delicious. The texture was smooth and creamy too.

However, i just don't think that the ice cream was worth the price. It was pretty overpriced and they don't even let you get 2 diff flavors in one cup. 

I recommend this place if you haven't gone there before, and if you really like it, you can keep going. but I think you can get ice cream on that level or better for a better price elsewhere, like bi-rite.
author: Yong K.

description:
What a cool way to make ice cream! This place actually uses liquid nitrogen to make their ice cream right in front of your eyes. And it makes a difference in the quality and taste of the ice cream.

While this place only serves four flavors at a time, there are a bunch of different toppings you can add to your freshly made ice cream. The first time I was here, I got the Fresh Mint Chip ice cream with TCHO chocolate drizzle. This was no ordinary mint chip ice cream. Upon my first bite, I was shocked on how it tasted like a fresh mint leaf taken directly from the plant. With the addition of the chocolate drizzle, I enjoyed every single bite.

The only downside is that the ice cream can be pricey. I ordered a medium sized cup with 3 scoops that costs $6. There's also a $0.75 charge for each additional topping. However, I say it's worth it because of the fact that you're getting freshly made ice cream every time.

I definitely recommend this place if you are looking for ice cream with a fresh and organic taste!
author: Jason A.

description:
It is a running joke that there are trolls under the GG and Bay Bridges because there are no children in SF.

Case in point, have you seen an ice cream store where adults outnumber children 30:1?  At Smitten, everyone on line was an adult except for 1 girl with her dad.

Anyway, I have heard so much about Smitten and was really excited when I saw the mixers and liquid nitrogen.  I decided to get the local SF TCHO chocolate- could not decide how ot pronounce it... Cho?  Spell out the letters?  Cho?  Cho.

I got the small TCHO sundae.  It was very good but my sweet tooth is defective, so I couldn't finish it.  However, I was glad to try Smitten and to check out the hype!  By far the freshest ice cream I have tried.
author: Miran C.

description:
Yes, the liquid nitrogen method creates an intense flavor and nice smooth custardy texture but I feel like it's not really worth it. I would be more than willing to give up the technical process for some more creativity in flavors and also for standard options like tasting before buying (if you're spending $3+ on a single small scoop it's nice to taste first) or sharing a larger size with more than one flavor. Unfortunately since the ice cream is made to order you can't try anything first and every flavor must be ordered separately. I find this too annoying to really like this place.

I tried the squash with brown sugar (that's brown sugar topping) and tcho chocolate with waffle cone. Both were good but not great.

I guess in the end I'm glad I finally checked this place out but won't be making an effort to return anytime soon.
author: Jean K.

description:
The ice cream here took forever, was overpriced, and frankly not very good. We had the mint chip and there were way too many chocolate chip pieces in it. I ended up eating just the ice cream around the chip. (Maybe I had the bottom of the batch?)The ice cream also had a rich creamy flavor but not a real strong flavor of mint that I was hoping for. I felt like the highlight was the chocolate chip and not the ice cream itself. 

$4.75 for a single scoop is outrageously expensive in my opinion. I think other places use fresh, organic ingredients as well, right? While I think using liquid nitrogen is innovative and interesting, I don't think the difference in texture is that noteworthy. I will stick to Bi Rite, thanks.
author: Allison S.

description:
I'm so sad. I really, really, REALLY wanted to like this place. I love that it's made with liquid nitrogen, I love the name, and I love the concept. I had heard so much about this place, and I was ready to be blown away.

However, it was a huge let-down. I got the vanilla ice cream with brown sugar caramel, topped with salted peanut brittle. My brother (Edison T.) got the salted caramel with TCHO chocolate sauce, salted peanut brittle, TCHO chocolate crispies, and cinnamon shortbread (yes, he is a maaajor ice cream fiend).

I felt like both were way too sweet. I struggled to finish my small, and that was almost laughable. I always finish my ice cream, unless it's Coldstone! When I finished it, my mouth felt super sweet and I almost had a headache afterwards. I felt a little sick, but it was probably because we were swerving around the SF streets, trying to find parking for House of Prime Rib.

It wasn't the worst ice cream I've ever had. I really enjoyed the texture and the unique toppings they offered. The peanut brittle and the TCHO chocolate crispies were delicious! It was also pretty cool watching them make the ice cream right in front of you. I definitely want to come back to try some other flavors, because I still have some hope in Smitten. For now, I still prefer Ici in Berkeley and Bi-Rite because of the larger selection and the better price.

Don't disappoint me next time, Smitten!
author: Lisa N.

description: The price is a liiiittle steep for the amount of ice cream you get but the flavors are all just so delicious! The waffle cone crumbles beautifully and it's the cleanest ice cream cone I've ever had :) the creme fraiche and caramel pear was PERFECT. It wasn't too sweet but the bits of caramel added that intense flavor here and there. The fact that it's nitrogen is cool but really the flavors are usually pretty great/unique.
author: Nancy W.

description:
I only tried one flavor... So this review should not reflect the entirety of how I think for everything. 

They will have a few different (4-5) flavored to choose from. I got the salted caramel with their chocolate drizzle topping in a small cup. Small=two small scoops, very much so enough to fulfill an ice cream fix. 

They do the final churning process as you order. 

The salted caramel is a definite recommend. Flavorful and good with the chocolate drizzle. 
I just wish they have some actual walls and a couple more seats. 
Good for summer times :)
author: Teagan T.

description:
Smitten is serving up popular and excellent ice cream one scoop at a time.

You are basically paying for fresh ingredients, and fresh ice cream MADE right in front of you.

The menu always has a small list of what appears to be 4-5 flavours at any given point. And there's a reason.

Aside from every flavor holding the ingredients for tastiness, when you order your ice cream, you are going to get a personal experience of watching someone behind the counter pour out the proportion of ingredients to get your full order of ice cream. It's done in it's own bowl. And smacked and spun with liquid nitrogen into one of the most creamy personal confections ever.

That's right. They use liquid nitrogen to make your ice cream.  It's like the tastiest science experiment ever.

And honestly? I truly have never had such a creamy ice cream.

Now! They don't just smack it with a little nitro. No, no, no. This ice cream has the staying power of an ice cream that has been in the depths of a frozen hell. No quick melts here. The liquid nitrogen also only gives the ice cream the chance to develop very very small crystals, and that results in the amazingly creamy texture.

I forgot that a friend had done a birthday ice cream crawl for one of her friend's last year, but the moment I said "Smitten", her face lit up. This was definitely a good choice.

I tried the Honey Nectarine seasonal flavor, and it was excellent. I plan to come back to try a little more before my departure.

Liquid nitrogen for ice cream is definitely not a fad. It truly does produce a beautifully textured product, and these folks really bring this ice cream forward on a level of excellence.
author: Cate T.

description:
Came here on a rainy day and was the first ones in, despite it having been opened for a little while. Ha. Let's be real. Cold San Francisco PLUS rain...it was lucky customers even had customers. 

I was the first one to order ice cream at one of the machines, and it took forever. I guess it needed to 'cool down" (rather than warm up...), so it took a little bit. When the ice cream was done, the guy hands it over to my friend...who ordered the same thing. But he called her name. His colleague mentioned his mistake, but neither of them acknowledged the mistake with us. But since my friend had a larger size, and we knew they made a mistake with delivering us the ice cream, I went over to clarify the next one was the larger size. Which...it was. 

The first ice cream, delivered incorrectly, was really icy. Like nitrogen-y. I wouldn't have noticed a difference if my friend hadn't even gotten the same thing and I tasted hers. And the 2nd one was surprisingly creamy. I became the person I don't like and approached them to ask for a re-do of my ice cream. Because. That thing tasted like the nitrogen ice cream made at Picnic Day, UC Davis, with a wooden spoon and nitrogen. Its got the cold, but is all gimmick. 

The 3rd one I got (replacement for the 1st one). And that one was the first one that was gold. It finally combined the texture with the flavor I was looking for. Legitimately, my friends and I were tasting 1, 2, and 3 and judging the difference.

I'd normally give it a bit higher marks. But even though the staff were friendly, they didn't acknowledge their mistakes (point off). Also, for something that is made fresh per batch, I'd think it would be good for the staff to taste the ice cream. Or, at least identify when the texture is clearly different. I mean, batch 1 was icy. Think ice cream left in a freezer for 2 months. It was clearly flaking off...and the guy still served it.  

If you're coming by for ice cream, make sure they've at least gotten through 2 batches of your flavor before you order.
author: Lily W.

description: Hooray for liquid nitrogen ice cream! Definitely smooth stuff. Been here a few times, most recently got the olive oil ice cream with lavender shortbread crumbs embedded in the mix. The oil is drizzled on top, making for a very pretty presentation, although overall it's definitely not something I'd want more than a scoop of. Pretty light flavored overall, but the oiliness on top of the rich ice cream is a little too much after a while I think. Will keep coming back to try other flavors. :)
author: Linus W.

description:
I was honestly not going with high expectations or anything. BUT the ice cream was fabulous, the customer service was amazing, and considering how many people were there & the number of workers, I got my ice cream fairly quickly. 

I would honestly recommend everyone try it at least once! And this is coming from a past coldstone employee!
author: Meilyn O.

description:
What's the word again? Oh, high expectation. 

It was a warm Sunday afternoon, although it was still windy in the city, Smitten Ice Cream got a long line, including me standing in the line, looking at the magical moments (ice cream maker and fog)... I wonder how yum this ice cream would be. 

I got Salty Cinnamon, which I kinda like but it didn't blow my mind. Boyfriend got Olive Oil & Honey Lavender, he said and I quoted "It sounds nasty but let's try something other than vanilla." So he did, we took a chance and it was not bad.
Not bad, but not great enough to have me hand over 5 starts to Smitten Ice Cream as their fans do. The staff was super friendly, and with a cool mustache, I wish I can give 1 start for that mustache, but sorry I can't. It was creative ice creams, but it didn't wow me.
author: Leslie C.

description:
This was our third stop of ice cream Places to try while we were visiting SF. And was probably my favorite. The place is a little shack by a nice park. The day we went was perfect for ice cream. Even after all the ice cream I had that day, I had to try the handmade cone for an additional dollar. And boy was it worth it! Tasted like a sugar cookie waffle and went well with my ice cream. I got the rhubarb with brown sugar caramel (they have a note by the flavor to try it with that topping, so I did) on a waffle cone and it was delicious! 

They make the ice cream right when you order it with a machine that looks like it uses dry ice. It's pretty cool and different. It's like they slow churn it for you so it's more creamy and that it was! The flavors were perfect on the rhubarb. My friend got the classic vanilla with spicy vanilla and didn't seem to care much for it so I guess it depends on the flavor and your palette. 

Wait isn't as long as bi-rite either but the cost was doubled the price (because of the cone and the topping). Definitely would recommend coming here with friends and family. I'd visit again if I'm back in SF.
author: Stephanie T.

description: The ice cream was good but nothing really special. Saw that their sign saying cone was handmade daily so I bought one but it was soggy. I would not recommend getting the cone.
author: Bing H.

description:
Great taste and texture. Pricey but you're doing it for the experience. There used to be a place in burlingame that did the same thing but recently closed down (Cryo Cream). Big fan of the salted caramel - supplemented with whatever toppings that appeal to your bougie taste. I didn't like the mint chocolate because they use real mint - I know, how horrible! Yeah, I was so used to the taste of my fake mint-green colored mint chocolate chip that when I tasted the real mint I despised it. Personal preference, of course.

If you're remotely interested as to why the texture is different from regular ice cream - the liquid nitrogen freezes the ice cream so quickly that only small ice crystals form so you get a richer, denser ice cream rather than an icier, frozen one. Boom. Science.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Interesting, to say the least.

I saw the liquid nitrogen machines and was excited for a creamy, delicious treat, but I was half disappointed.

Perhaps I am not akin to the flavors of San Francisco yet, but we ordered the Mint Chocolate Chip and the Strawberry Balsamic. With the Strawberry Balsamic, I was actually surprised at how strong the balsamic flavor was. Not the biggest fan.

My warning to all newcomers: if you are looking for an ice cream that tastes like ice cream, stick to flavors you recognize, such as Vanilla or Chocolate. Not to say the other flavors are bad, but they are unusual.

I've had better ice cream, but if you need a refreshing treat in the Hayes Valley area then Smitten isn't a half-bad choice.
author: Kevin K.

description:
To be fair, I went during one of those cooler San Francisco weekends, you know, the ones where the wind is really starting to pick up. I didn't think I wanted ice cream, but I was with a group of friends and we were right near there, so we all figured we'd check out Smitten to see what the hype was all about. Even the cold can't stop people from eating ice cream. We went around 4:30pm and there was a line of about 9 people. 

I ordered the mint chocolate chip ice cream. I was definitely surprised, in a good way, about how the mint part of the ice cream really tasted like mint (almost like biting into some mint leaves). I also liked watching the whole liquid nitrogen thing. Made me feel like I was back in elementary school when our teacher would bring out the liquid nitrogen so that we could make ice cream and freeze, and then shatter roses. 

I wouldn't necessarily go again. If I had friends come and visit and they wanted to see the whole liquid nitrogen process and eat ice cream, I would take them here. But I don't think it is worth coming to this part of town just for the ice cream (it would take me 20 mins by car). It is one of those places that you come once to experience the special something, but you aren't excited enough to go out of your way to visit it again.
author: Carolyn Z.

description:
Smitten is a truly bespoke ice cream experience that's like watching a live recording of 3-2-1 Contact (for those of us who grew up in the '80s).

You choose among the flavors offered each day, and then you can watch the staff make your ice cream from scratch, on the spot. They use a proprietary "Kelvinator" machine that employs liquid nitrogen to freeze your ice cream at super-low temperatures - with frothy, steamy results. 

The real difference in the ice cream is its airy smoothness. It's very low in density, melts in your mouth quickly, and goes down fast - which doesn't quite give you enough time to savor the actual flavors. I've tried the salted caramel, which was a very good combination of saltiness and caramel (but, as another poster here mentioned, not as good as the impossibly high standard set by Bi-Rite), as well as the strawberry with peppercorn, which had a spicy kick to it.

Because of the made-from-scratch process, you can't mix and match flavors in one cup or cone. The cones themselves are homemade - not the typical brittle, crunchy kind, but, like the ice cream, very soft, light, low in density, somewhat fragile, and, above all, heavenly.

The ice cream is seriously expensive, but you pay what you get for, given the fresh ingredients, complexity of the process, and the somewhat labor-intensive, made-from-scratch, just-for-you nature of the operation. A nice treat when out in Hayes Valley on a beautiful day. Bring kids so they can press their faces against the windows and revel in the science-experiment quality of the whole operation. It's like going back to middle or high school without blowing up the entire lab. ;)
author: Vincent L.

description:
Smitten serves up some pretty damn good ice cream. If you dont know, this place serves up made-to-order ice cream by using liquid nitrogen making it very smooth and creamy. This concept is usually seen in fancy restaurants but the owner was able to bring it down to the street cart level and eventually open a little shop in Hayes valley. 

I've been here multiple times and I've tasted the TCHO chocolate, salted caramel and a few other flavors but the flavor that I will be talking about today is the SWEET CORN with berry topping!!! The sweet corn ice cream is by far, my favorite Smitten has ever put out. You can really take the sweetness of the corn. It reminds me of my childhood when I used to eat the asian corn puff snack in the blue bag (im sure some of you asian kids know I'm talking about!!!) My friend, Jennifer T, and I were shocked and surprised at how delicious it was. I wanted to buy a pint before I left, but Smitten was swamped that day since one of their machines broke. Next time I guess.
author: Marcus L.

description:
On a gorgeous sunny day, nothing hits the spot like some sweet, nostalgic ice cream in a waffle cone. 

On a gorgeous (rare) day in the City, we stopped over at Smitten for this very reason. After perusing the menu (Classic Vanilla, TCHO Chocolate, Strawberry White Balsamic, Fresh Mint Chip), I opted for the mint chip. Because a) you can have simple flavors any day, but most importantly, b) I've been on a HUGE mint chip kick lately and was stoked to keep it going.

I wasn't familiar with their fancy do-dinglies, but it looked cool. Five minutes after my order, my liquid-nitrogen-created concoction was ready. Handed to me in a waffle cone, I was stoked for the first lick (that's what he said).

Almost immediately, I realized that it wasn't the mint chip I was used to (and I don't mean that in a good way). It was utter spearmint and chunks of chocolate chip. Normally, I'm OK with this, that day I was not. I then realized that none of my friends had opted for that flavor either.

Me: "What did you get?"
Friend 1: "I asked the guy what he'd get: the mint chip or the strawberry. He told me he'd get the strawberry, so I did."
Friend 2: "I asked the guy between the mint chip or the vanilla which he'd get. He told me he'd get the vanilla, so I did."

So out of all the flavors, it seems the mint chip was the least favorite. I ended up taking a few more licks before dumping the spearmint ice cream into the trash bin. No need for extra calories, amirite?

Oh, well. Now, I know.
author: Adena B.

description: I got the cookie dough flavor with pretzels and chocolate chips promised. It had a creamy and delicious texture but no chunks of cookie dough and hardly any pretzels or chocolate chips. Ice cream texture and consistency was on point, but the flavor needed to be amped up.
author: Lucy D.

description:
My husband tried the Quince, which was described as a cross between a pear and an apple.  It was tasty but reminded me too much of apple sauce.  What really knocked my socks off was the TCHO Chocolate.  It was so smooth and creamy and deliciously rich without being overly sweet.

I saw they had a Vegan Salted  Caramel popsicle on the menu which I'd like to try someday (soon).  I was also told that the Salted Caramel ice cream has been requested a lot and should be back on the menu in Jan (excited!).

I love how the ice cream is made to order - nothing is pre-frozen.

So yeah...I'm smitten.
author: Rose A.

description: I've been to a few nitrogen ice cream shops and Smitten is by far the best! They only offer 4 flavors a day, but I have ALWAYS stuck to just chocolate. Okay, the 2 times I've been here I've gotten chocolate.. but my friends always made fun of me for being basic and not trying their other flavors haha but after they try their own and then they try mine, they've all agreed that its the best!! I tried a bite of my boyfriend's sweet corn and just wish the flavor was a bit stronger. In the case of the mint chip, they use fresh mint, but it's a bit too strong. Chocolate is the way to go!! It's creamy and is probably the best chocolate ice cream I've ever had! I love the owner's story behind her shop too!
author: Rebecca D.

description:
Passed by here a couple times and finally stood in line to check out what all the hype was about. We stood in line for about 15-20 minutes. They only had 4 flavors. The typical all American Flavors - Vanilla, Chocolate, Strawberry and Coffee. Very modern. They use an IPAd as the cashier. It was pretty neat. 

Another wait for the ice cream since they are made to order. Made with liquid nitrogen which is colder than ice. It makes less ice crystal hence smoother ice cream. 

It was smoother. Felt less like the typical ice cream and more like ice cream you get at McD. I got the vanilla which was alright. Nothing spectacular. My boyfriend got the chocolate which was a bit strong. 

I don't know if I would stand in line and pay $3 for a tiny cup again. The idea is nice though.
author: Sarah C.

description:
This really is the smoothest ice cream. Ever.

People need to get out of here with the "bad and slow service". They make every ice cream after you order it, and you're in a pretty hipster neighborhood, so you should expect that you're there for quality ice cream, not quality time. 

Only con it's like a sugar bomb in my mouth. I love this ice cream, but too much of it and I'll go into diabetic shock. I recently discovered that they have a munchkin size! I'll be ordering that every time I'm wanting to devour a scoop of salted caramel!
author: Angela L.

description:
Very cool (high tech) but very expensive. 
$11.50 for 2 small cones. Really?

Pros:
Liquid nitrogen ice cream.
Ice cream is made to order.
Flavors are unique.
Ice cream is super rich.
Cookie cone.
iPad register/paperless receipts.

Cons: 
Overpriced.
You're limited to one flavor regardless of size.
Only 4 flavors available.
Cone crumbles easily.
Long wait since they make them to order.

The ice cream was good but not spectacular. I don't think it's worth what they are charging. You can get better ice cream for less at Humphry Slocombe and Bi-Rite.

p.s.
Watch out for wind, the sand/dirt on the floor kicks up every time the wind blows. Not sure why they still haven't done anything about it. It gets in your eyes and ice cream.
author: Andy W.

description:
Only in San Francisco do you see a huge line waiting to pay for $6 ice cream on a cold 60 °F summer night. You're not paying for practicality. You're buying novelty and with it comes the cool factor (pun intended). Yes, liquid nitrogen is nothing more than an elemental cryogenic fluid that boils at -321 °F, but oh look, there's a smoky effect! I guess I'm sold.

I was torn between the fact that $6 is a ridiculous price to pay for ice cream, but damn, that was some good ice cream. Actually, want to know the real reason to come here? The $1 handmade waffle cones. These were the best waffle cones I've ever had. Truth.

I tried the seasonal specialty, which happened to be honey nectarine. The smooth texture was impressive. Everything tasted un-artificial as advertised, if there is ever such a thing. Side note: It's pretty unappetizing to actually watch the churning process sans the liquid nitrogen.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
Nostalgia is the only way I can describe Smitten Ice Cream...

The concept and origins of Smitten Ice Cream definitely brings me back to the days when things were much simpler in life. Making old-fashioned ice cream using basic ingredients with the "Kelvin", an ice cream machine on a traveling red Radio Flyer that runs on liquid nitrogen definitely draws the foodie masses. Although Smitten Ice Cream now serves their ice cream out of recycled shipping container in Hayes Valley, it still maintains its nostalgic qualities with a store front that reminds me of a lemonade stand.

On Friday, 6.17.11, my co-workers and I went to Smitten Ice Cream at around 2:15 PM and there was still a small crowd of people there. We thought by going there at an "off" time that it would be less crowded but apparently so did everyone else. 

MENU
Smitten Ice Cream's Menu changes weekly with four flavors available each day:
*THE CLASSICS: Vanilla and TCHO Chocolate (always available)
*SEASONAL: Salted Caramel and Summer Herb (Rosemary, Thyme, Basil, Mint) 

There's one mixer for each flavor with the best seller being the Salted Caramel, so expect a longer wait if you order this flavor.

When it comes to ice cream, I like to keep things simple so I ordered a Small Vanilla with Cocoa Nibs Praline ($4.75 + $.50). CC's are accepted. From start to finish, it took about 15 minutes to get my ice cream. While waiting, it's was very cool to watch the ice cream being made Kitchen Aid like mixers with clouds of smoke emanating from the bowls like a science project. 

VANILLA ICE CREAM w/ Cocoa Nib Pralines
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mMiOVbGovegeBg-6YyqDxA?select=av9lykHVVQjDP4TS5bhmoA
Unlike other ice creams, you can taste the absolute purity of Smitten Ice Creams with no remnants of any ice crystals. The vanilla was ultra smooth, creamy and slowly melted into each of my taste buds. You can really taste the milk, cream and sugar in its unadulterated form. The Cocoa Nib Pralines gave it a crunchy bittersweet bite. The vanilla was a little too sweet for my taste and got even sweeter towards the end, so the Cocoa Nibs Pralines are a must to help cut through some of the sweetness. 

It's not the best ice cream I've had, however, the cool concept alone makes it a must try for any foodie or ice cream aficionado. It is expensive at almost $5 a scoop, but it's a small price to pay for a taste of PURE nostalgia.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Wow, ice cold goodness in your mouth!
Great flavors like mint chip and salted caramel. 

The mint chip was so fresh and minty! While the salted caramel was just the right amount of sweet and salty, as well as creamy.

The best part of this place? They make it fresh after you order. It's a great place for kids as they can watch their ice cream blend as they wait!

4 STARS
author: Karen L.

description:
To be honest, I was a bit skeptical trying out a nitrogen-based ice cream venue as I wasn't too fond of Portland's own version of nitrogen ice cream =X

Recommended by my dear friend Shirley W. I decided to give "nitrogen-based ice cream" another go and convinced my cousin to explore this ice cream parlor with me after dinner. 

[devour]
Your scoop of ice cream is made to order! (**gasp**) so expect to wait a few minutes (depending on how many orders there are before yours) as they process your delightful treat right before your eyes.

*VANILLA + chocolate sauce (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/smitten-san-francisco?select=FjlPy0SvGEJ8F_ZXct3ClQ#Q7UEj1B2pQNFgylqHMutmg)

*STRAWBERRY WHITE BALSAMIC (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/smitten-san-francisco?select=FjlPy0SvGEJ8F_ZXct3ClQ#zlE1qePW1tT7msMVFXikng)

Both flavors were pretty delicious! Both were unique in it's own way. If I were to come back again, I'd like to try out their other flavors as well!

$4.75 for a 4 ounce scoop is a bit steep (and that's the smallest size). But pretty darn tasty! The 4 ounce was a good amount to eat, especially after having a big dinner! Expect to spend at least $5 or more at this establishment! It'll be extra if you add their toppings as well. 

FYI =
-Parking on the street (and is hard to find)
-4 flavors offered daily
-Classic flavors (always available) = Vanilla; TCHO 60.5% Dark Chocolate
-Daily flavors are posted on their Facebook and Twitter accounts
-They use iPads to process your order
-Vegan popsicles and handmade waffle cones available
-They use simple, natural, local, sustainable, and seasonal ingredients (this place would totally fit into PDX)
-Environmental friendly 

The verdict - I'm quite smitten with SMITTEN'S NITROGEN-BASED ICE CREAM! (best Nitrogen-based ice cream I've had! *smiles*)

Yelp 2013 100 for 100 Challenge - Review #96
author: Kristen M.

description:
$4.75 for a single scoop of ice cream? These people are smoking something-probably the liquid nitrogen flowing out of their ice cream machines. The LN2 creates a fun show but the machines aren't impervious and the one making vanilla unfortunately broke down and those who ordered vanilla (me) had to wait even longer for our ice cream, after getting through the already long line. 

That said, it's delicious ice cream. Does the LN2 actually create smaller ice crystals ie smoother ice cream? Not sure. It IS smooth though. Just don't think it matches up to Bi-Rite, AmIRite?
author: Monte H.

description: It's not a gimmick, it's great! I had the salted caramel ice cream with the spicy caramel sauce. Doesn't get any better than that!
author: Rob B.

description:
Nitrogen-infused ice cream! This stuff is good and it stays cold. The menu is simple - 4~5 flavors per day. It's more than i would pay for ice cream normally (hence the 4-star), but Smitten is pretty unique joint in SF. I really enjoyed the butter corn flavor which is not available everyday.

Smitten is an outside stand in Hayes Valley. Lines can be long and order may take a bit of time since the orders are made on the spot for you.
author: Suji C.

description:
Smitten is an adorable little science experiment. I ordered a small salted caramel and watched the magic show that is Smitten's way of making ice cream. A small is certainly enough, and the salted caramel is perfectly smooth, but it melts pretty quickly, so don't linger!

My friend's chocolate ice cream was equally delicious. We'll be back!
author: Christina S.

description:
I love that this place is so random.  It is located right next to a park (without hobos!).  The ice cream stand is cute and modern.  I love the light wood details and it's defiantly a plus that you can watch your ice cream being made in front of you.  For some reason ours took a little longer but, they apologized for the wait and asked us if we wanted complimentary syrup on it.  Score, because the syrup alone was around $1.25!  Yes, this place was defiantly on the pricier side and the wait was pretty long, but it was worth every minute because our ice cream was DELICIOUS!  

We came here on a cold Sunday night.  Once we got our ice cream we ran into the car and blasted our heater.  Let me tell you... eating ice cream in front of a heater is THE BEST feeling.

BTW, we had the salted caramel with raspberry caramel syrup drizzled on top.  If I had one word to describe it?  HEAVEN! ;)
author: Lynn L.

description:
On the fence with this review...

Some of the best ice cream I've ever had, but the price is so crazy for it, as is the line.

Definitely worth a try, but I probably won't come back due to the price and the wait unless I was in the area (jeez, parking is a zoo around here!).
author: Timothy L.

description:
This is artisan ice cream taken to such an extreme level that it makes me long for a frozen quart of Lucerne ice cream in one of those square cartons with a coating of freezer burn around it. I didn't know this was going to be made-to-order ice cream. Well, slap my belly and call me Elsie the Cow. Otherwise I would have brought my Kindle to pass the time. Apparently salted caramel is one of their more labor-intensive concoctions as it gets churned in a high-powered Kelvin mixing machine a lot longer than the other flavors. They have four of them going, guns a-blazing.

Each one requires a staff person to make the machine whirl and produce the tailor-made liquid nitrogen ice cream. That means it takes a village to accommodate the waiting throngs waiting for their cups of creamy confection. No wonder it costs a whopping $4.65 for a small cup. I must be paying for all their health benefits. The result? It was honestly so sweet and thick, the Salted Caramel was just too sugary and already melting fast to be entirely satisfying (see photo). Jamie W. tried the TCHO 60.5% Dark Chocolate, which tasted like cake batter before it made it into the oven (see photo). There appears to be a fan base for their product, but I just feel this heavily staffed operation does not give me a reason to be, well... smitten. 

ICE CREAM - 3 stars...heavily produced artisan stuff for fans only 
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...like a boxy Quonset hut 
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...certainly friendly enough 
TOTAL - 3 stars...quite a production if you want to stick around for it
author: Ed U.

description:
Tried the salted caramel, blue bottle coffee, and tcho chocolate flavors, though the flavors were good I was disappointed in the texture. Being that they use the liquid nitrogen method, I thought the texture would be just as smooth as my other experiences at other ice cream shops that use this method. Unfortunately, in my two times coming here the texture of my ice cream was icy (both times) and not as smooth as other similar places I have tried. 
For $5 of icy liquid nitrogen ice cream and a long wait in line, im alright with passing on this hype.
author: Julie B.

description: The best mint chocolate chip ice cream I have ever had!
author: Lynn T.

description:
Date & Time:  Saturday April 30, 2011 @ 3pm
Estimated Wait Time:  30 Minutes
Companions:  Michael & Jack
Scene:  Groups of Hayes Valley 20-30 Somethings- Girls in Fitted Tee's, Jeggings + Flats & Guys in Graphic Tee's, Skinny Jeans + Chucks & Young Families w/ Tots in Fiddlesticks & $1000 Bugaboo Strollers
Vibe:  Fun
Decor:  The First of Four Recycled Cargo Containers in The Future Hayes Valley Beer Garden Slated to Open the End of May
Service:  Friendly Girls in Smitten Tee's
Devour:  Liquid Nitrogen Cooled Ice Cream in Chocolate, Green Tea & Salted Caramel
Total:  $16.50
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
The Smitten kiosk has a stylish, industrial look and the perfect location next to the park. Peruse the day's flavors on the chalkboard menu. They usually have four flavors a day.

Flavors of the day:
* Tcho dark chocolate
* Brown sugar
* Vanilla
* Fresh mint chip

The ice cream is made before your eyes with liquid nitrogen. I've tried liquid nitrogen ice cream several places and Smitten's is my favorite. It's expensive but also super fresh and the toppings are gourmet and delicious. You can also get hand-rolled pizzelle cones.

Prices: Kid size $3/ Small $4.75/ Medium $10

* Brown sugar ice cream with almond toffee http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/smitten-san-francisco?userid=NOUfyJW-BAo_-Cbfo8edww#BZjJAMgZWiEIFfRXqe1K0Q: Their delicious ice cream is ultra creamy, smooth and not too sweet. The housemade toffee was buttery, crunchy, and chewy - yum. 

A cup of ice cream or an ice cream cone would be perfect for strolling around the park. Best nitrogen ice cream I've had.
author: Lolia S.

description:
What a fun place.  Don't be afraid to walk to the opposite side of this metal shack as you'll find there is more to this wonderful little ice cream shoppe.  the opposing side has a coffee bar where you can order your favorite cafe drinks and enjoy the park next door.

The salted caramel is delicious and the the Summer Herb is a flavor to be reckoned with. You'll walk away feeling satisfied, refreshed, and happy.  The wait isn't too long of a price to pay for fresh ice cream but the price is a bit hefty.  That being said, it's totally worth the experience.
author: Kevin J.

description:
This place is pretty cool in the sense that they make your ice cream with liquid nitrogen, but I wasn't a huge fan of the mint ice cream, which makes me pretty sad. The ice cream literally tasted as if you bit into a mint leaf. I was burping up mint even by the end of the night. 

My sister had the dark chocolate ice cream. I'm usually not a huge fan of chocolate ice cream but I wish I had gotten this instead! It was really creamy and good!
author: Cathie N.

description: They currently have rhubarb which was delicious! I've also had earl grey at the Los Gatos location which I liked too. However they've switched their rewards program from Stampt to Belly and wouldn't let me transfer my points :(
author: Diana B.

description: The ice cream I had was incredible. I know there are so many reviews before me saying the same thing but I had the crime fraiche with pear caramel. I loved it and my baby did too. I highly recommend going here. Only issue for me was there are no bathrooms in the vicinity.
author: Steph P.

description:
If you've ever though you've had good ice cream before, think again. With Smitten, you're in for a sweet (and crazily smooth) treat. 

I came here for the first time the other day and was very pleased with what I got. A friend and I shared the honey nectarine and the fresh mint chip. I swear to god, I think I saw heaven! The honey nectarine was sweet, smooth, and delicious! There were little bits of nectarine in it as well, which was an awesome surprise! The fresh mint chip was also, seriously, amazeballs. Though there did not seem to be any mint leaves in there, you could literally taste it with each and every spoonful. 

It's a little bit on the expensive side but it's worth every penny. I'll definitely be visiting again!!
author: Tiffany T.

description:
Don't get me wrong I've had my fair share of gallivanting, in silver lake, melrose, los feliz, and the haight , but hayes valley spells hipster right off the bat for me. My friends and were walking from alamo square and found that smitten was not that far along.

We got there, no line at all, so we took a moment to decipher what exactly was on the chalkboard to our left. TCHO ??? a locally made brand of ice cream of the purest form? 

They make the ice cream right in front of you which I thought was super cool! The ice cream was sooo smooth and tasty. I had the tcho chocolate with spicy caramel , which was awesome!

I tried some of my friends salted caramel and my other friends mango squash both pretty good as well!. 

This is definitely a spot i would come back to try, just because of the novelty of seeing your ice cream being made right in front of you. 

I'm most definitely a fan.
author: Mike P.

description: I don't know how I've lived in the neighborhood for over a year and hadn't been to Smitten before last night. The liquid nitrogen process is cool to watch, and definitely leads to some of the creamiest ice cream I've ever eaten. I had the TCHO 60% dark chocolate with TCHO chips, and my friend had the cookie dough with pretzels topped with brown caramel sauce. I'll be coming back, more often than I should.
author: Patrick F.

description:
3 of us came here on a sunny Sunday afternoon... After having run the SF Rock n Roll half marathon, we wanted to treat ourselves with ice cream...

Me: Rhubarb Crisp - loved it.  
BFF: TCHO chocolate - he loved it.
BFF partner:  Salted caramel on a cone - that took a while... guy said it's the most popular item on the menu and was tricky to make; and it was worth the wait.

Minus 1 star bec of the we must have waited for the Salted Caramel for 20 mins.  My friend and i were done with ours before it was ready.
author: Margaret W.

description: My tastebuds are so smitten with this place! They have a limited selection of flavors per day but it changes all the time so it's basically endless. I got the earl gray with chocolate chip and I was super impressed with the texture as it was smooth, light, and creamy at the same time! It's not overly sweet and doesn't melt super fast and I love the quaint/modern vibe of the shop. I wish there was one in SoCal so I can try all the flavors!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I tried it once and that's good enough for me.  Like other reviews, the ice cream is just too sweet.  It's very smooth and rich, but cloyingly sweet.  

Some other nitpicky things.  2 basic sizes: 1 scoop or 3 scoop, they don't allow you to try multiple flavors with 1 order.  really no good. 

Line moved at a reasonable pace.  However once we ordered, my ice  cream came out immediately, and the partner ordered a sundae, they were also out of whipped cream.   I was finished with my ice cream, before the sundae came out.  hum.
author: Alex S.

description:
Not impressed. 

I'm willing to spent $5+ for a bomb scoop of ice cream. You'll find me happily giving Bi-Rite and Humphrey Slocombe my credit card without hesitation. Unfortunately, Smitten gave me buyer's remorse.

I got the Salted Caramel, which was far too sweet. The Rhubarb Crisp tasted like extra tangy mayo. The Brown Sugar w/ Cinnamon Cookie was good but not good enough to raise my rating of Smitten. I do appreciate the use of premium organic ingredients, but the flavors fell flat for me.
author: Lauretta L.

description:
Do you remember mom telling you not to play with your food? Well, molecular gastronomy introduced fun into food and cooking and the genie is now out of the bottle

However, given that Ferran Adria, the godfather of molecular gastronomy has now shut his legendary El Bulli restaurant, is that whole fad over?

Bearing that in mind and the fact that liquid nitrogen is all over our TV screens and dry ice is even now easily available to the amateur experimental home cook, can businesses like Smitten deliver on ice cream other than the novelty of seeing it made with liquid nitrogen

Don't get me wrong. I'm a sucker for the plumes of vapours and the whole theatre of seeing your ice cream created but I don't really buy into the 'faster freezing leads to smooth ice cream' line that they peddle. You can get some amazingly smooth ice cream without the need for instant freezing

Smitten is housed in a tin mini house, which is quite fun and quirky. They have a limited menu of flavours but my main problem is that it's expensive for a small cup of ice cream

In a town with businesses like Humphry Slocombe which offer more choice and better value for money, Smitten will be filed under my list of fun experiences which won't be repeated
author: Yee Gan O.

description:
I had no idea Smitten's location was as close to my old workplace and I totally missed out on a treat when I used to work in the city. Came across it looking for a late night snack on a chilly night in the Hayes Valley area. Parking is kind of iffy because of the location but you can find parking around it on surrounding streets. BTW, On a sunny day it's beautiful in this area. I tried the TCHO and the Cookie Dough. I can say that I loved it enough to return and find out that the menu changes daily. No problem thought because I'll for sure come back for the cookie dough. The texture of the ice cream rides the line of solid thick to soft. It's the perfect texture. The cookie dough though has an almost cereal milk tast to it that I love. The TCHO is definitely good but is pretty rich and if you don't like really rich tasting/flavored things the TCHO might not be the one for you. There's areas to sit inside the area they serve the ice cream and at night they pull down the wind guard and turn on the outdoor heater so you aren't completely freezing while enjoying ice cream on a brisk SF night. Regardless of the chill factor, I LOVE IT. 

I for sure will be back to stuff my face with that cookie dough ice cream!
author: Jay V.

description:
Really quite good. I love that they have artisanal ice cream in this area. It is a fitting location, Hayes Village. 

My thoughts on the service: 
Very helpful
Great suggestions and knowledge
Didn't ask for a sample, not sure if they give them because they seem to make batches of the ice cream as they go, but I'd have liked a taste offered. 

The Ice Cream:
Wish they had more flavors, or more diversity of flavors. Particularly mint chip. :)
The Lemon Gingersnap was just as good as I imagined. Topped it with Proseco Strawberry syrup. The sweet comes solely from the ice cream. The topping was tangy. It was really a wonderful blend of flavors. 

The Space:
Cute, but small. Plan to sit at the park or somewhere in the area and enjoy the day and ice cream!
author: None O.

description:
Always order the flavor you think you'd like the least. It'll probably surprise you! Came in when they had the sweet corn flavor,and I first thought how they could pull off such an odd flavor.. But I also added their recommended toppings and such and it was probably by far one of my best ice cream moments.

Trust them with your taste buds!!
author: Audrey G.

description:
You need to go and try Smitten. 
Literally, the best ice cream I've ever had. It is so smooth and creamy, yet light and refreshing. Be prepared because they always have a line. 
It is a little more expensive than your average ice cream, but believe me it is worth it.
They change up the flavors very often and there is always room to try new things. 
Location- I love Hayes Valley! It's a great area to pick up some ice cream and take a stroll, go shopping or hang out in the park literally right beside Smitten. Parking is a little difficult so be prepared to park a few streets down with a meter. 

My friends and I all got different flavors and tried each others- all yummy: Cookie dough, coffee, and mint chip. The way they make the ice cream (not entirely sure of the process, but I know it's with liquid nitrogen) makes a unique texture that you really need to experience. I can't say it enough. Go try it!
author: Rebecca C.

description: Very good and freshly made ice cream. There were only 4 options, we tried the Creme Fraiche W/ Pear Caramel and 60.5% TCHO Chocolate. Both were delicious. Quick service too.
author: Suresh S.

description:
Similar concept to The Ice Cream Lab in Beverly Hills (which I haven't had a chance to try yet). 

My friend and I shared a small Tcho chocolate and it was nice and creamy and cocoa-y! Really enjoyed it! I would have enjoyed it more if the weather hadn't been about 60 degrees (in August!) The line was curving out the door when we got there around 7PM on a Saturday but it moves really fast and the people are super nice! 

PLEASE PLEASE listen for your names when your ice cream is ready! One worker was yelling Thomas for FOREVER and I KNEW it was the guy who had ordered in front of me, so I just pointed at him and the server yelled directly at him lol. Still had to yell his name about three more times though. 

I am definitely going to try Ice Cream Lab now to do a comparison!
author: Yenny D.

description: A novel idea, this ice cream sure is tasty. And super cold. It almost feels like your tongue is getting frostbite. The texture of the ice cream is especially smooth. Be prepared to wait a while for your ice cream, as they make it on the spot for each customer.
author: Nat W.

description:
So delicious. 

Smitten has a great concept and a fantastic product. I went in at about 9:30 pm Friday night, and there was a pretty long line, but it moved fairly quickly. I got the brown sugar ice cream with cinnamon shortbread, and it was just amazing. Perfectly creamy and sweet, and I loved the cinnamon chunks inside. A cup of heaven!

Consider me smitten.
author: Kelly R.

description:
One may describe Smitten as novelty dot com placed in a fantastically designed package worthy of Disneyland patronage.

As trendy as nitrogen ice cream goes, I still cannot fall in love with the flavors. They're all rather plain-jane in comparison with all the other offerings in the city. However, their waffle cones are rather delicious and will surely get you through a hot Summer day in the ever-popular Hayes.

Will I be back? Surely, but for the fun, not so much the flavors.
author: Anthony N.

description:
Very tasty ice cream! I ordered the balsamic strawberry with salty carmel sauce. The one downside was that I could not taste the balsamic aspect of the ice cream. 
Definitely a fun vibe and there is a great little park to enjoy your ice cream and people watch. It's also really interesting to watch them make the ice cream.
author: Anya A.

description: While I love their ice cream, no Amex or NFC in 2016 is rather offensive. Really? No amex for ice cream that starts at $5? Please get your stuff together.
author: Han L.

description: The ice cream is super flavorful and very creamy. It tastes superb. But is it worth the higher price ($6 for two small scoops?!) just because it's made with nitrogen right then and there? I'm not so sure. To me, it tastes like great gelato--which some shops do well and at a lower price.
author: Peg C.

description:
My root beer float was to die for. They gave me two large scoops of smooth vanilla ice cream and a bottle of jones root beer. And it was whipped up super quick and fresh to order. 

Even better was that they had an enclosed patio with heat warmers so I could enjoy my treat in comfort. This was my second time here and can't wait to come back again!
author: Christopher S.

description:
Yes I am smitten for sure. Strolling around Hayes Valley, came across this unique structure of a storage container-turned-ice cream shop on a corner. On one side is a list of the featured flavors of the day, the main area has three odd-looking contraptions that look like if a Kitchen Aid Mix Master  + the flux capacitor + the device that froze Han Solo had a baby, this device would be that love child. 

Ice cream is created on the spot. There are four featured flavors of the day and they make it while you wait adding fresh cream and other ingredients. I found the sequence of when you got your order to be based on whether or not people ordered two of the same flavors, etc. I don't recall all the flavors except the TCHO chocolate and the blood orange. The couple who ordered their TCHO chocolate after me got theirs first while I had to wait a little longer for my blood orange with pistachio shortbread. It was worth the wait, by the way. The subtle blood orange flavor counteracted the crunchy pistachio shortbread; the texture of the ice cream was velvety smooth.

There isn't a table and chairs seating area, but there are some bench-type spots inside and of course the park that is nearby. My small ice cream was $4.70, but hey, I don't mind paying a bit more for quality ingredients and watching the magic at work.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Liquid nitrogen ice cream (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/smitten-san-francisco?select=Q8oaFLrZ00WPoKZG3OwmUQ#Q8oaFLrZ00WPoKZG3OwmUQ), made fresh to order--an awesome novelty, which results in extra smooth and extra rich ice cream! 

They had three flavors today, which included classic vanilla, fresh mint chip, and salted caramel. I went with salted caramel ice cream (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/smitten-san-francisco?select=FjlPy0SvGEJ8F_ZXct3ClQ#b9-YOOl6T730dmrRYAauWQ) with TCHO chocolate crispies and the beau went with mint ice cream with TCHO chocolate drizzle. They were serious when they said that fresh ingredients were used, because the mint ice cream literally tasted like fresh mint leaves. The fresh minty flavor was just too overwhelming in my opinion, I'd probably stick with the classic flavors. The salted caramel was more salty than sweet, which was okay, but the ice cream was just way too rich that I could barely finish the small scoop that I ordered.

It was incredibly crowded on a Sunday afternoon and it was about 70 degrees outside. Prices are pretty steep, it was about $5+ for the small. I'm glad that I gave it a try, but it's just one of those places that I won't come back to unless it was convenient.
author: Lien T.

description:
We lined up here waiting for Smitten to open its doors Saturday morning with about 10 other eager customers. The shop is a transformed recycled shipping container. It looks like a modern canteen tuck shop.

I love the concept. See fresh cream, milk, sugar & other delicious organic local ingredients churned & frozen right in front of your eyes in a couple of minutes in Smitten's custom ice cream machines using liquid nitrogen. Fun for kids to watch the mist spill out. Each customers order is made separately.

Limited to about four flavors available but they do change daily. We tried the TCHO 65% chocolate - was the favorite, glossy, dense, incredibly silky. Added spicy caramel sauce. 
We also got the Salted caramel which my foodie buddy & I found to be lacking in flavor & didn't have that same delicious denseness that the chocolate flavor had.

I am tempted to give it 3.5 stars but feel that would be unfair until I have tried more flavors then just the two I have had. It's certainly quality ice cream and if it wasn't for the chocolate flavor I would be disappointed. I love the cute shop, lovely staff & the concept is fabulous. Worth trying once for fun! 

Although since there are so many amazing ice cream companies in SF, I still choose Humphrey Slocombe, Bi-Rite & Three Twins as my favorites in this city.
author: Jessabelle R.

description: How fun! I loved checking this place out. We got the TCHO chocolate, but unfortunately it really didn't hit the spot for me. I did love the texture and creaminess of the ice cream, though, so I'll be back to check out other flavors. A must visit in Hayes Valley!
author: Kendra N.

description: I went on Monday, 9/5/16 around 4pm.  The guy working the register was extremely rude.  Good ice cream, but I can do without the cocky attitude.  Bi-Rite has great ice cream, and their employees are very down to earth, which creates a truly pleasant experience.
author: Eric C.

description: Freaking love this place. Every time I want ice cream it's always gotta be this place. My favorite hands down is sweet corn w berry compote (or jam??) Anyway. It sounds weird but it's so good so don't knock iy! Also love the strawberry with likr a vinegar or white balsamic. Forgot which one it was but I know when I see it. This place rotates flavors Sooo you're always going to want to come back for more!
author: Sarah N.

description:
What's cooler than watching ice cream get made right in front of your eyes? Honestly not much especially if it's as tasty as smitten. 

Great seasonal flavored, toppings, and amazing waffle cones! 

This is a must visit ice cream spot if I have friends or family visiting.
author: Sam L.

description:
Yes I must admit this ice cream is a bit pricey. 

BUT it definitely makes my SF top 5 ice cream places. The ice cream is so creamey and I love that all the flavors are quite simple. I am not a huge fan of candy filled lumpy ice cream with names that make no sense. It is always a treat to go here because I love watching them make ice cream and I love the light hearted environment. It is a funny thing when you see adults waiting in line for ice cream because you realize that we all don't really change much. 

If you are looking for a different experience when it comes to your ice cream this is the place to go.
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
Let's be real, hipsters of San Francisco, is the ice cream really that good??

When I first heard about Smitten's opening in Hayes Valley, I was intrigued. They had all this concept art around Patricia's Green about the space and a charming story about how the founder of Smitten carted around her nitrogen in a red wagon. How could you not be intrigued? And when Smitten opened, it did kind of feel revolutionary, with Proxy just starting to get cool with the Biergarten, food trucks, etc. And it IS fun to watch the ice cream getting made right in front of you. 

But the ice cream itself? Just meh. Truly mediocre I think. There are so many fantastic options in the city that I find it really hard to get excited about my $5 from Smitten. I also think that the flavors can be super hit and miss. Sometimes they're flavorful and interesting, and other times they're just straight up boring. 

I would go around the corner for some Ritual Coffee and head to Schulzies for some bread pudding if you're craving something sweet.
author: Kate M.

description:
I had the chocolate and it was great, very cool to see it made... Minus the fact that my "chef" took a very long to make the chocolate, whereas my friends getting other flavors got theirs much more quickly.

My only real complaint is the price-- one scoop in a cone is over $5; this is good but not that good.
author: Amelia D.

description: The concept is fun but we've had 2 flavors that were unappealing (rhubarb-not even a bit tart and mission chocolate, too spicy and salty). They don't give tastes, which is annoying when you're spending 6/7 dollars for a cone. And the workers are rude and not friendly. Change the service model. Too much competition in the neighborhood to be so precious and snooty.
author: Malena W.

description:
In the area for lunch at Chez Maman, I finally made a point of striking Smitten off my list, especially after several friends countered my recent proclamations of "Mr & Mrs Miscellaneous has the best ice cream in SF!" And, after a bit of deliberation through the afternoon, I've decided my statement still holds true.

Now, that's not to say the ice cream here at Smitten is bad: it ultimately comes down to what you're looking for in your ice cream. The texture of their ice cream is actually really nice, with a smoothness that falls somewhere between standard ice cream and soft serve - personally though, I prefer mine just a bit harder than this. 

And their flavor options are pretty limited, serving no more than three or four flavors at a time (two when I arrived, though), but offering up a variety of high-end toppings, for those so inclined. That said, the strawberry white balsamic I tried today was tasty, with actual chunks of strawberries in the ice cream, and a flavor profile that was both light, yet flavorful, albeit not as much so as I'd like.

So, fans of incredibly smooth, and not overly sweet ice cream, Smitten is definitely your joint. I can see myself dropping by if I'm in the area, but, otherwise, I'm sticking with the Mr & Mrs. Even more so when you consider that the price of a small at Smitten (a whopping $4.75) will get you twice as much at Mr & Mrs! 

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - An outdoor open air stall of sorts, you shouldn't really have much trouble getting in and out, aside from having to get past the mobs of people.

Bathroom - I highly doubt they have a public one.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Decor: 4/5
-Long bench to sit and eat
-Ceiling suspended heaters for the cold weather
-Love the rotating four flavors menu

Service: 4/5
-Super friendly

Food: 2/5
-Neat concept with the liquid nitrogen
-Wasn't a fan of the consistency or taste of the Earl Grey, in fact I didn't get the urge to want another bite
author: P H.

description: Nice ice cream texture! Different from anything I've tried before
author: Vii L.

description:
What's not to love about freshly made ice cream? Smitten's has taken ice cream to the next level. They usually offer about 4-5 different flavors per day. Vanilla, Tcho Chocolate and Fresh mint chip seem to be there "usual" flavors. Then, there's always a monthly seasonal flavor. Currently, it's the nectarines n' cream, which I had today. It was good but you can't taste much of the nectarine, it's very light. One star off because $5 for a single scoop is a little steep. On top of that, you have to get their fresh, daily house-made cones for an additional $1 something and a topping for 75 cents. It's still delicious enough for me to come back though! 

Most importantly, in August they serve my favorite flavor. Sweet corn with berries sauce! Ugh. Why can't they serve this all year long?
author: Laura T.

description:
First time I went here, we came 15min before they were closing and had an absolute HORRID experience. We waited in line for our turn, but when we finally got to the front of the line, it was closing time and the cashier refused to place our order. I understand if we had just walked up to the line, but we were patiently waiting for our turn and the guy decides to tell us then that he wouldn't take our order. ABSOLUTE DEPLORABLE SERVICE.

As to the ice cream, I had the unfortunate pleasure of going back because an out-of-town friend (and foodie) insisted on going here. I reluctantly obliged and had the fresh mint chip because they ran out of the brittle for the sundae (another negative point for them). I love mint, but this pretty much tasted as if you ground up mint and ate that. In addition it was on the icy side.

It was cool watching them making the ice cream, but you will never find me back there again. Just a novelty. There are so many more better ice cream shops in the city with better service, flavors, and product.
author: Kitty K.

description:
ice cream that is made to order - an interesting concept, though a little deceiving. there are limited options on flavors - the night i came, there was vanilla, lemon, and salted caramel?....i was sadly shocked that there was no chocolate option. As a chocoholic, i think having a chocolate flavor should be a staple at all ice cream parlors, no matter how small the joint. in any case, i asked for the chocolate sauce as a topping - they  skimped on the portions....1/2 tsp was not worth the extra 50-75 cents, considering the ice cream is already pretty pricey to start with. 

As for the ice cream, i thought it was just a-okay. I had the simple vanilla, and well, it tasted like an incredibly creamy vanilla. It's not really that frozen, and so it melts pretty quickly, though I actually liked that part. the liquid nitrogen is pretty cool and fun to watch the liquid mix turn into a frozen treat. 

in any case, i'd be willing to come back to try a chocolate version and see how it holds up. But nothing i'd be racing over for.
author: Asmita J.

description:
I really liked the concept of making ice cream with liquid nitrogen, and watching them make it in front of you was definitely a treat, but the product was definitely not the best ice cream I've ever had. They only had three flavors when I went, none of which stood out to me, so I got the Earl Grey ice cream. It was really good but melted in a weird way that made the texture rather gritty, which is very unexpected and unwelcome in ice cream typically.

I would probably recommend a friend to go check it out but will not return again, especially with other such great ice cream places in the area.
author: Johanna T.

description: Why not try a new ice cream when in San Francisco ? Pick the flavor and they make it deliciously right in front of you ! Four stars because of the challenge to find parking, and not on the cheap side...but worth trying :).
author: Luminita P.

description:
It is really fun to watch them make the ice cream in front of you using liquid nitrogen. Although this is more of a novelty than anything else. The ice cream does taste very smooth. I just wish they had more flavor choices. I do like that they have TCHO chocolate, which you can choose to drizzle on top of your scoop. 
BONUS: they are open late!
author: Nancy Z.

description:
While it may be cheesy, it's true...Smitten has me SMITTEN. Out of all the popular ice cream locales in SF (Humphrey Slocombe, Bi-Rite, Mr. & Mrs. Miscellaneous, Marco Polo, Polly Ann, etc.) Smitten kinda tops my list.

I'm not sure if it's partially psychological, but seeing my ice cream made fresh before my eyes made it taste better...somehow richer, creamier, and just all around yummier. Because the ice cream is made to order, there are no samples. However, they do offer a 100% satisfaction guarantee, although I doubt you'll need it. When it comes to ice cream, Smitten has your back. 

I opted for Brown Sugar when I went, and if it's available when you venture here, I'd definitely reccommend it. Consisting of milk, cream, brown sugar, salt, & cinnamon shortbread, it'll provide quite an enjoyable experience for your taste buds. I was saddened when my spoon finally scraped the bottom of an empty cup. :(

At nearly $5 for a small cup, it was a tad pricey. But worth it in my opinion. 4 stars!
author: Natasha H.

description: One of my favorite ice cream spots in San Francisco! I'm also a fan of Polly Ann's and Swensens, but there is nothing like Smitten's and watching your ice cream get made.  The experience itself is unique and this is our go to spot to take family and friends who are visiting. I usually get the mint chip, but my favorite is an early gray chocolate chip that they made once. I wish that was a regular menu item as I would definitely order that all the time.
author: Bella C.

description: oh, how i love thee, let me count the ways. cute name, ice cream is made to order with liquid nitrogen in a machine that's named kelvin (how cute and nerdy is that?!) they use fresh ingredients (like fresh mint in their mint ice cream) and quality local tcho chocolate!! you can add and mix any combination of flavors/ingredients they have available that day....and then watch it being made right in front of you. omg. my favorite! i love it more than the highly overrated bi-rite creamery
author: Patty W.

description:
Best ice cream in town hands down!!!! Service is amazing and The músic its great!!!
Happy customer!!! We Need one inLA!!!
Chill atmosphere!!
author: Fernanda D.

description:
I stumbled on this place while trying to find another place to eat at. There was a huge line of people so I assumed that it was good. I'm glad I wasn't disappointed. 

This places makes everything from scratch, nothing artificial. They tell you the ingredients on the wall. They usually have four or five flavors available each day. The ice cream is made with liquid nitrogen. It's pretty cool to see how they make it. 

I tried the vanilla ice cream with the cocoa nibs. I am in love with those cocoa nibs!! The girl told me they were freeze-dried cocoa beans covered in chocolate. They were the best part of the ice cream! You have to pay a little more for them, but it is so worth it! Makes the ice cream so much better. The ice cream was good, but it was a little melted when I got it. I don't like melted ice cream.

My fiance tried the chocolate ice cream. I asked him to get the candied jalapeno so I could taste them. They were basically jalapenos covered with sugary syrup. Not worth the extra money. I wouldn't get them. It was strange and something I would only try once. 

Overall, I would say you should just come here for the cocoa nibs.
author: Hang T.

description: Heard so much about this place so had to try it. You choose your ice cream and each batch is made separately which may account for the long line that is usually outside the place. But worth the wait!!!! It is cool to watch too!
author: Yejin C.

description: What a great way to get your instant on demand ice cream from scratch!! Taste very good too!! It melts little quicker but still very good!! Highly recommended!!
author: Ji J.

description:
This place deserves 5 stars if it were not for the attitude of some of the staff and how they  fail to value their most loyal customers. The ice cream is incredible, so lets talk about that first. 

Ice cream: probably the best I have ever eaten. The seasonal flavors are very good. I especially love the sweet corn and berries flavor that comes in August. The ice cream is made right in front of you fresh from all natural ingredients, and they use liquid nitrogen so the freezing process means tiny crystals and hence there is nothing as smooth. It is seriously THE BEST TASTING ICE CREAM IN THE USA! At least the best I have tried.

Here is why I am docking 2 stars from my review:
I recently threw a large party and I wanted to have Smitten Ice Cream there for everyone in our building to try (hence promoting their business). We are talking like 30-50 people. I ordered 12 tubs of ice cream and they refused to give me any type of discount! Then when I picked it all up first they refused to take a $100 bill, next when I gave a credit card I got instructed how I should be sure to leave them a tip and a dirty look when I didn't. When you call a day in advance and order a huge amount of ice cream I don't think a tip is appropriate. 

The place does have a loyalty program - an App called Belly where you get a free ice cream for something like 10 visits or "check-ins", heck the App even emailed me suggesting I write them a Yelp review. When you look up Belly you will see the owner of Smitten is spending like $150/mo on this loyalty program. I don't see why they don't value their customers more. I have been going there for months and months and sending all my friends, but this wholesale order just turned me off. 

I think the business has lost their humbleness; they know they are awesome and hence don't care too much about the customers. I'm hoping for a message from the owner that this is not the case and then I will be sure to update my review to give them the full 5 stars they could easily achieve just on the taste of their amazing ice cream.
author: Chris S.

description: They use liquid nitrogen to make their machine cold enough for the ice cream mixture to freeze. Watching the ice cream making process was really cool! Since they make it as you order. But the taste wasn't that great. It's definitely a try once, and try another place sort of experience for me. It was rather pricey in my opinion. They only have three flavors. I tried the Earl Grey (which I liked the most) and Salted Caramel (my friend got me 6oz.., it was 5oz too much..) and didn't try the chocolate one.
author: Winnie T.
