First they took forever to make mine (waited at least 15min) second, they took my order wrong (I ordered vanilla with brown sugar caramel yet ended up getting chocolate ice cream with brown sugar caramel), third they gave me the wrong size (ordered regular but got small) and finally when I got my ice cream the girl giving it to me said "is this good?" With "I'm so annoyed right now" voice tone. Now what's more wrong in this situation is that in no where did any of them apologize for their mistakes and misunderstanding 

Thought this would be the end of my poor experience at Smitten but after receiving my ice cream, within two minutes, it was melting and melting ... Then Became liquified (SF weather was in the 50s when I was there at 9:15pm)... I had to re-freeze mine so that it can actually feel like an ice cream instead of super creamy half and half 

Again .. Smitten has gone from fabulous to disastrous ... Sad story
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Ice cream made to order! 

But unfortunately you cannot sample any of the flavors and the serving size is super inky dink for the price you pay. $3 for a small scoop of ice cream? =\ I didn't like my ice cream very much. I ordered the strawberry with balsamic and it was super sour... bleh. The vinegar was definitely overpowering the strawberry flavor. 

The concept of Smitten Ice Cream is really neat! Very cute store! The simplicity of the interior reflects the ingredients used in the ice cream too! I really, really wanted to like them, but I'm just not a fan of their ice cream. I'll try giving them another chance. Maybe I just picked the wrong flavor.

My heart will forever be with Bi-Rite.
author: CeCe C.

description: Delicious! My husband my son and I all enjoy our different choices of flavors tonight! Completely lived up to its hype! Will be coming back again soon! We tried the whiskey Chip, vanilla, and cookie dough with pretzels all amazing!
author: Ashley T.

description: Love this ice cream and how they make it in front of you. You can't go wrong with any of the flavors, but I do suggest skipping the chocolate krispies and asking if they'll add extra cookie dough as a topping instead!
author: Amy Y.

description:
Oh man, I tried Smitten for the first time and I was SMITTEN. Kidding (but not really)! 

I really do love the concept of made fresh to order ice cream. Liquid nitrogen is so cool (science geek in me nerding out). All of the flavors are phenomenal. I think I had the mint the first time, and the second I had the plain ol' vanilla. 

Their vanilla ice cream is DELISH. The BEST vanilla ice cream I've ever had in my life, no joke. It tasted so fresh and yummy, no flavorings or toppings needed. 

Do yourself a solid, try Smitten. If you're in the peninsula, pro-tip, they have a location that's within the Whole Foods in Los Altos.
author: Alison N.

description: Pretty cool that they make the ice cream right there in front of you. The cookie dough is delicious but it is kind of pricey for the amount that you get. I got a single scoop and it was close to $7. Good ice cream no doubt.
author: Ryan N.

description:
3.5

Smitten, I was... at first. And, then I came back and I wasn't as in love as the first time thanks to the too cool for school service and the complete disregard for my business. Slow your roll, Smitten; you aren't the only belle at the ball.

The first time I came here, I was transfixed. Hayes Valley is already one of my favorite places to visit in SF so ice cream in HV must be just as amazing, right? Right. It was my first time (like I said) and I was completely taken in by all the bells and whistles. Even though the two cities in which I Yelp-lived (Chicago and Miami) both have liquid nitrogen ice cream spots, I hadn't been to either. This was my first trip to the rodeo. As I waited in line, I crafted my order. The menu wasn't too outrageous in terms of selection, so I was betting that execution was the bread & butter here. I opted for the TCHO Chocolate ice cream with brown sugar caramel, whipped cream and cinnamon short bread. The young lady taking my order was impressed with my flavor combo prowess. No need to be impressed, my dear; it's what I do. I topped it all off with a Fred water because I would need something to cut all that sweet and I liked the flask shape of the bottle. I came for the show and stayed for the taste. The ice cream was good, the topping were better and the experience was sound. Yay.

And, then I came back.

The lines were much longer. The crowd didn't move. The people behind the counter were completely over it all. Ruh roh. Checking to see what flavor I would choose, I decided on the earl grey. Because I'd just had a large lunch, I settled on just the ice cream. I paid. I gave my name. I waited. And, I waited. And, I waited a little more. After seeing folks who came after me get served, I asked one of the workers if my order was coming up. He rolled his eyes. Remembering that CA is a three-strikes state and I needed to be careful, I resisted the urge to 'bless' him. I asked again. He rolled his eyes again, sighed and asked what I ordered. I told him. He looked at me indignantly and said that he called my name and gave order already. Granted, my name is pretty common. But I was standing by the counter the entire time with my gaze fixed on the ice cream. There's no way I missed my name/order. The place was crowded, yes, but I was as close to the ice cream as I could be without making it. 

I told him that what he said may be the case but there I stood: name the same and no ice cream. His co-worker chuckled and said she could make me a cup or I could take a mint chocolate chip that she had ready then. 1.) If I wanted that, I would have ordered it; 2.) isn't that someone else's order? 3.) i am too old to sit here in this 2x2 space arguing over ice cream I've already paid for. I took it, left and decided that I'd probably not be back to the place that made such a fantastic first impression. A forgotten order and obnoxious service were not good complements to a small space, big crowd and high prices (it's ice cream, for God's sake). Smitten is not the only OMG ice cream in town and if my recent experience is indicative of where they're headed, they're about to learn that lesson -- intimately.
author: Johnny T.

description: The fresh mint chip flavor is to die for. I've tasted this flavor a year ago and I'm still reeling from its decadent flavor. I love the intensity of the mint, and can still remember tasting the fresh mint leaves with the chunks of chocolate chip weaved into the ice cream. It's one of their seasonal flavors I don't mind coming back for more.
author: Jodie M.

description: Flavors are limited, and so-so. However on the bright side, if you don't like the flavor, they will gladly make a new one for you.
author: Josie H.

description: Chocolate ice cream is yum!! Parking is a small struggle but when the ice cream is this good you deal with everything happily! Late night drives and stop over for ice creams is the best thing to do ever and no place better than smitten.
author: Aj J.

description:
Am I or aren't I? smitten with Smitten Ice Cream. HM

I just paid $5 for some (read: very small sized) a la minute, made-to-order ice cream!!!!!!
After I recovered from the shock of the damage, we tried the Ritual coffee flavor. It's novel, it's tasty, deep and rich in flavor... 

But it's perhaps the priciest ice cream I have paid for in a long while... trumping even the gourmand-types all over the City. Wow.

Liquid nitrogen.... working OT here! It was windy and we still got it! Couldn't resist trying.
author: Jana C.

description: Much more different and cooler than the average Baskin Robbins and Coldstones. Ice cream was better as well. Just wish that there was one located in north CA. My boyfriend and I came on a Monday night, so the wait wasn't that bad, but I could imagine how busy they would be during the weekends and now that the summer's here. Great customer service and super ice cream spot!
author: Judy T.

description:
Tasty made-to-order ice cream.  It's fun watching the machine churn ice cream right before your eyes.  I got a single scoop of TCho chocolate with spicy caramel drizzle in a cup with a waffle cone on top, and I paid around.. $7? It's too pricey for me to be a regular, but still tasty and worth trying once.

One star off for being too expensive, and for the ghetto rude chick that was working there.
author: Jenn L.

description:
Sorry, I know there are a lot of ice cream connoisseurs out there who love this place and will hate my review, but honestly i don't see the appeal. The service was horrible and it looked like the "brrista's" were in a frozen over hell. No smiles and lousy service and terrible attitudes. I'm very used to having the icecream scooped in front on me, not having to wait 15 minutes for "vanilla" 
They also don't offer you 2 different scoops... WHAT?! As for the icecream, it was like eating frozen half and half. 

2 stars for lack for food poisoning.
author: Ben Z.

description:
The line moves faster than you think.

The ice cream really is as smooth as they promise.

I think the flavors are really pretty strange. The child in me wishes they could just deliver a straightforward orange or strawberry. But the flavors are understandably hip. 

I think the real winner here is that waffle cone. You need to get that waffle cone.
author: Jay C.

description: I loved their concept and the fact that it was made by liquid nitrogen made it even more exciting to try out their ice cream! We waited (about 10 min?)  in line to order and waited even longer for get our ice creams, but the results were great. The ice cream tasted very good! The only downside is that the ice cream is a little over-priced (paid $17.95 for 3 small ice creams). I understand that it's made from local and fresh ingredients, but this will probably just be a one-time experience for me.
author: Debbie P.

description: Great service and experience. I love that the ice cream isn't too sweet or rich. It's perfect.
author: Amy O.

description:
Homemade ice cream made by using nitrogen, wtf???

Cool little homey spot, they even have the whole story posted so you can reminisce on the journey of how this little place got a little bit more known. The concept is cool but i must regress, it's pretty overhyped for what it is.

Maybe id feel better about it if it wasn't so expensive!

Still the ice cream was yummy, the service good.
author: James D.

description:
TIP #1: Only a few flavors, and the only rotating flavors are seasonal ones. 

TIP #2: A special treat at $4.75 for a small, but you get two scoops!

If you love ice cream, like me, then you absolutely must try Smitten. Mosey on up to the lean-to structure--the shack looks, from the outside, like a modern, urbanized beach shack--and order off the chalkboard menu. Then watch with delight as your ice cream is churned and frozen, right before your eyes! Those little machines, named Brrr, use liquid nitrogen to create tiny ice crystals so that the resulting ice cream is the smoothest and densest you've ever tasted. 

The cone, an extra $1, is absolutely worth it. It's crunchy without being hard, sweet but not cloyingly so, and makes eating the scoops on a hot day easier. A small vanilla cone is all I need every once in awhile to remind me what ice cream should taste like.
author: A.L. H.

description: Super cool flavors and great presentation. But it sucks that they always run out of the waffle cones... :\ if only they made those fresh too!!!  But will definitely go back to try other flavors!
author: Fanny C.

description: Last time I came here I got the Blood Orange w/Pistachio Cookie and the Salted Caramel. Such cute presentation! I really enjoyed the Blood Orange - The flavors were super fresh and crisp and the pistachio cookie added nice texture. I wouldn't get the Salted Caramel again though - a little too sweet and salty for my liking. The portions look really small but the consistency is just so dense, thick, and creamy - it's actually pretty perfect. Definitely had better ice cream elsewhere, but still love coming back for their seasonal flavors + the overall open/lax vibe of the area.
author: Christine P.

description:
I normally love smitten and go there frequently but today I had an unfortunate experience and I may not go back now. 

I ordered my ice cream and after a long time asked if I missed my name being called.  The employee accused me of having already come up and got my order-basically accusing me of lying and was being really rude to me about it. He told another to make me my ice cream while glaring at me. They normally are generous with their toppings and this time I barely got any.  I'm very unhappy and will not be going back.
author: Carla G.

description: I have the chocolate favor of ice cream . It was so good and yummy . I decide to order the large size with 3 scoops and I can finish it . I love the way they make the ice cream . It was really fresh and love the chocolate taste .
author: Isabelle L.

description:
Salted caramel is solid
TCHO chocolate one is super thick but still good.

Probably wouldn't go out of my way to try it but if you're around here, it's worth swinging by.
author: Diana Y.

description:
Smitten ice cream is super smooth and tastes ultra fresh (it IS frozen with liquid nitrogen before your eyes...which takes like 5 minutes per order so the wait can be long on a crowded day) and it is not too sweet. If you're in the mood for lighter ice cream Smitten is perfect.

There are only a few flavors at a time though, and no sampling since it's made after you decide to order it. But sampling is the best PART! *cries*

The handmade pizzelle cone (!!) gets the people going!! It is SO SO good!! It is really wafer-y and buttery, and melts in your mouth! BUT the downside is that it is so FRAGILE and cracks very, very, very easily.

Easily cracking cone + super ephemeral ice cream...is not the ideal mixture.

The ice cream melted at LIGHTNING speed. I got it in a cone and it started dripping down the cone within the first 30 seconds...and within 3 minutes when I reached the bottom of the cone (I had to eat at lightning speed to keep up with the melting) the ice cream was pure liquid. At least it was still pretty delicious. I drank it. 

I just wish I had more TIME to enjoy it, and without worrying my cone was going to crack open and ice cream was going to explode all over my clothes.
author: Jessica C.

description:
I don't even typically like ice cream (I know - almost as weird as my 'chocolate is just okay' stance) but I'm absolutely smitten with Smitten. The texture is exceptionally creamy courtesy of a special production method that involves a patented mixer, liquid nitrogen and made-to-order scoops. Sounds like a science project, but local and seasonal ingredients keep it all real and complete this chain of goodness. Something this pure requires a bit of patience, as my friend made note that it took longer to get our scoops than it did to get her warmed up slice of pizza down the street. Verdict? The ice cream is better, as was evidenced by Christy letting the slice of pepperoni go cold in order to catch every bite of ice cream before melting. We ladies have our priorities in check!

Bottom line: Meyer Lemon ice cream with batter bites, get in my mouth! I only wish the servings were a bit bigger for the price (ouch). Treat yo' self, ya hear?
author: Jelena Z.

description:
The mint chocolate chip ice cream was like nothing I've had before.  It's so viscerally MINTY; it's like you're chomping on fresh mint leaves.  In a good way.  It's also really smooth and creamy so even a small serving is really satisfying.

Fun to watch them mix up your batch individually and the servers were really friendly!
author: Erin E.

description:
Disappointing.... one favorite flavor but never available only promises that will be in at a later day.

Mint chip
author: Allen B.

description: I don't always eat dessert, but when I do, I prefer Smitten ice cream.
author: Steven R.

description:
Been wanting to try the ice cream here for a long time so I was really excited when I finally made it over here. 

They don't have very many favors every day, they have four Kelvin machines so they only do up to four flavors a day. Each flavor gets made at a little station with one of the machines, which also means it can take a while for your order to be done if it's crowded that day. I tried the cinnamon apple crisp, which was really good, but the mixed in toppings made the texture a bit spongy or airy. I tried my friend's vanilla which was super smooth and creamy. The ice cream is pretty pricey for a small portion but it's definitely worth trying!
author: Sophie Y.

description:
It was pretty empty when we got to Smitten and I got the regular sized sweet corn ice cream with berries.

It came out fairly fast and had a very smooth texture, almost like butter. I wish they had more flavors!

Two thumbs up
author: Josh V.

description: Cute, small ice cream place! There were only four flavors available the day I went: TCHO chocolate, Earl Grey, Salted Caramel, and Vanilla. I got a small cup of the salted caramel and my bf got the earl grey and added cinnamon shortbread to it. The small cup has two decent size scoops and is actually pretty big for a "small", but it was expensive compared to other places! ($4.75) The ice cream here is thick and creamy. The salted caramel was delicious and tasted pretty strong but I prefer Bi-rite's. Earl grey was also good, especially with the cinnamon shortbread! I enjoyed the ice cream here and really like the cute vibe of the place. It hasn't made it onto my list of top ice cream places but I definitely wouldn't mind coming back if I'm in the area.
author: Sandra N.

description:
I love science and I didn't quite buy the whole liquid nitrogen thing, but Smitten deserves credit for this ridiculously awesome contribution to the ice cream world. The principle is that the crazy low boiling point of N2 freezes the ice cream so fast that the ice crystals stay very small, resulting in a super creamy texture. To me, the creamier the better. Because they make your ice cream to order means there's always some line, but it moves along nicely

(+) TCHO Chocolate- maybe the best creamy ice cream I've had in a long time. The chocolate flavor is not your typical chocolate- it tastes like what a hot chocolate drink tastes like, not the true chocolate flavor. I might prefer the full on chocolate personally, but I still recommend this.

Other Things:
- They use organic ingredients! It seriously makes a difference in flavors, like the whipped cream.
- Super friendly staff
- A small park is right across the street with benches.
author: Jocelyn L.

description: I usually think ice cream shops taste the same, but my friend convinced me to try this one since she could actually taste a difference. I did, and the ice cream was incredibly creamy. I got the cookie dough and pretzel ice cream. The portion sizes are small and expensive but I guess it's worth it given that the texture is so interesting.
author: Danielle C.

description: I love this Smitten location. As I've also reviewed for Ritual Coffee right next door, they have such a great spot in Hayes Valley. The ice cream is yummy, the location is great for people watching and just relaxing, and the service is good. There can be a slight wait sometimes since they do have to make each order in their little nitrogen mixer thing (I don't know what it's called). Their setup is so cute since they're not really a brick and mortar shop. Their little kiosk with wooden benches is so quaint. The cost of the ice cream is on the slightly expensive side, but it's not so bad if you're not eating it every day. Today, I tried their Earl Grey seasonal flavor and it was so good, especially with the addition of the TCHO crispies mmM! My favorite so far is their Sweet Corn summer seasonal flavor, which I think should be available year-round because it's so delicious.
author: Becky C.

description:
Totally awesome little place, I was introduced to this adorable ice cream parlor during a recent visit to SF. Each cup or cone is made to order (in a whopping 60 seconds!) using liquid nitrogen?! -- how cool! Pun fully intended. 

I opted for the classic vanilla with a meyer lemon caramel sauce and my friend got the brown butter pecan, both were so creamy and delicious! 

The line was was super long, but it was a gorgeous day out and ultimately worth the wait. Plus you can watch them make the ice cream while you wait. Would definitely go back and take everyone I know with me!
author: Ainsley F.

description:
Had the single scoop of the Apple Cinnamon Crisp ice cream! SOOOOO DELICIOUS!!!! Not only was the texture of the ice cream so soft and wonderful, it was fun to watch it being made!!!!! I definitely regretted not getting a bigger size!

My only complaint is that I wish you could do a double scoop with different flavors! I JUST WANTED TO TRY THEM ALL!!!!!
author: Tiffany N.

description:
This place leaves you S M I T T E N that's for sure. 

While visiting San Francisco, I was told this was the PLACE for ice cream so I needed to try and by far the best ice cream I've had in my life. They have a standard of  chocolate & vanilla and then flavors that rotate as well as seasonal flavors. The standard and quality of the ice cream is high and it really is as fresh as you can get. 

As a purist I got the vanilla flavor and it is to die for. It melts in your mouth and the texture of the ice cream is perfect. THIS IS A PLACE TO TRY.
author: Angela C.

description:
Smittens operates out of a refurbished shipping container and each scoop is made when you order it with fresh ingredients using liquid nitrogen.  Delicious!  This place is best visited in warmer weather where you can lounge on the few seats there or go across to the dog park.  They have rotating flavors and classic flavors. In May they will have strawberry white balsamic.  

My current favorite flavors: salted caramel w/ pistachio brittle

With my sweet tooth and summer rolling around, I'm sure I'll be paying Smittens another visit soon.
author: Chantal T.

description: Interesting concept with the liquid nitrogen - fun for the kids to watch - and yes, another place made from a shipping container.  Had their strawberry white balsamic- you can really taste the flavorful strawberries. They used fresh mint leaves for our mint ice cream which really added a kick.  It's a good heaping scoop, 2 can share 1 for sure!  Can't wait to come back and try another flavor!
author: Karyn L.

description:
It might be a little expensive compared to other ice-cream spots, but it is well worth a try (depending on the flavors at hand) because they use liquid nitrogen to make their ice-cream. How cool is that!?! Seriously, it's difficult to find a place that makes ice-cream in that unique fashion. You can also see the process happening which can also be another cool ice-cream experience.

Since they have limited flavors using seasonal ingredients, you may have a difficult choice because some flavors just might not touch your fancy. The choices I had during my visit were: Ginger Peach, Vanilla with cinnamon, TCHO chocolate, and Very Mint with Chocolate Chip. 

I ordered a small size (enough if you're just checking the place out and want something small). I chose VERY MINT WITH CHOCOLATE CHIP and have never regretted it since! My first bite was "Oh man, am I chewing on mint leaves?" I kid you not, the ice-cream tasted like actual mint leaves (not artificial flavoring). You can also tell by the color of the ice-cream, it was white with a small green glow to it (probably the natural mint leaves). Add to that random bits of chocolate chips and you're in absolute heaven!!! The texture of the ice-cream was soft and smooth (the crisp chocolate chips gave a nice, different touch in texture whenever you bit into them). 

So yes, if you're ever in San Francisco, be sure to check this ice-cream shop at least once just to check it out. It's definitely a unique creamery with unique flavors and a unique process in making their ice-cream.
author: Diana N.

description: vanilla vanilla vanilla
author: Lauren Y.

description: Watching them make the ice cream with liquid nitrogen is an exciting experience. The mint chip is extremely fresh and minty; I personally wasn't a big fan, but that's probably bc I'm not particularly fond of mint in the first place. The earl grey with chocolate chips is really nice, but earl grey is a seasonal flavor that is only available during the winter months, I believe. Overpriced, but worth for the experience.
author: Jane L.

description:
Liquid nitrogen ice cream.
They only had 4 flavors when I went: vanilla, TCHO chocolate, nectarine, and mint. 

It was a Monday evening and there was no line. We waited about 5 minutes after ordering to receive our ice cream.

My friend and I ordered:

small vanilla  + TCHO krispies ($5.70) - the ice cream was soft and creamy with good vanilla flavor. It didn't taste artificial. The TCHO krispies are basically rice krispies covered in chocolate. Think Crunch bars. They put the krispies underneath the top scoop of ice cream which I didn't like because the arrangement made it difficult to eat the topping with the ice cream. I would have liked more krispies - especially since toppings are .75 extra. The krispies serving size was lacking.

small mint + brown sugar caramel ($5.70) - this ice cream was also soft and creamy like the vanilla, so Smitten has good consistency with their products. The taste of fresh mint leaves was evident in the ice cream. However, I didn't like this because I could taste the plant "leaf" flavor rather than just the "mint" flavor. Who wants to eat leaves?Brown sugar caramel was delicious, but again, I feel that the topping serving size was too small for the price.

If I was to come back, I would order a regular ($6) and split with a friend instead of ordering two smalls to save money. Combined we spent $11.40 for two smalls plus 2 toppings. If we'd split a regular plus 2 toppings, the cost would have been $7.50  equaling a saving of $3.90. Unfortunately, I didn't think about this while I was there.
author: Ella C.

description:
Well, this is pretty much the best ice I've ever had. Ever.

I like to keep it simple so I just got the Malted Vanilla in their homemade cone.
Everything is pretty much homemade so I guess that's obviously what separates this joint from everywhere else. The building was very inviting and the staff was nice.
I like how you can see everything going on from the entering the building, what/how to order, and the production of the ice cream itself.
Just seeing the liquid nitrogen reaction probably makes the ice cream a little better.
The transparency of what goes on further enhanced the experience.
There's lots of interesting-sounding toppings I maybe should've tried.

Lots of nice places around the park next door to sit. This spot makes Hayes St. more of a destination that before (in my opinion).
Anyway, I would come back for sure--100%.
author: Marlon T.

description:
I love the way this place is in a shipping container, so weird!
The brown sugar ice cream was divine! My friend had the toffee ice cream and that was just as delicious :)
So bright and open, it just made my day happier.
author: Lee A.

description:
As a science geek myself I recall making liquid nitrogen banana splits in a physics lab in grad school.  They were good, but not this good, so it isn't just the liquid nitrogen.

I live nearby so I may be biased, but Smitten is an important part of Hayes valley, and certainly where I go to get ice cream.  You can eat it in the sun on Patricia's Green, or you can take it home and enjoy there.  Don't freeze it though, because it's never been frozen, and it'll still taste good, but lose the smoothness that makes it amazing.
author: Travis B.

description:
WOW, I mean WOW! 

There was a line down the street for this place and it was worth the wait! SO SO good. My mom used to make homemade ice-cream when I was little and this brought me back. The flavors are amazing. 

Why not 5 stars? 
Only complaint, we ordered two pints, they charged us and then gave me a small ice-cream and my husband a pint. There were only three of them working and I didn't have the heart to ask them to correct the order. So, make sure and get a receipt.
author: D. S.

description:
Nothing about Smitten is bad; they have a cool space, friendly service, and their cones are better than any other I've ever had. But the fact of the matter is that their ice cream is good, not exceptional, so $6+ for a small serving feels like a bit much. 

That said most of us don't eat ice cream every day, so if you're out on a date or a special occasion, it's a nice experience. If stars could have been dispensed in quarters I may have stacked-up 3.75 of 'em.
author: Vivek N.

description: Fun staff. We walked in and ask them to pick their favorite flavors for us. They seemed to enjoy that exercise... The flavors delivered, the mint was pretty amazing - but the cookie dough was no slouch. Great experience to grab some ice cream and take a walk around the cute neighborhood.
author: Tom W.

description:
The short version: Wonderful concept, cute show, service is slow, workers are not friendly, smooth ice cream but has a smell to it.

The long version: This place makes your ice cream fresh with liquid nitrogen right in front of you, it's not a very common thing to see but it's good to experience it atleast once in your lifetime. I got to experience the strawberry balsamic flavor and while it was rich and creamy,  it had a nasty smell to it(courtesy of the balsamic vinegar). It wasn't that appetizing, and since I went to bi-rite first, my expectations were really high, but I was majorly disappointed. The lines weren't incredibly long and the wait wasn't too bad. The location is really nice though, it's right by a cute park, and the shop is open air. The workers are totally hipster, but they seemed as if they hated their jobs, I'm spoiled with super nice LA hipster servers who are totally friendly even though they may be fake, but whatevs!
author: Will T.

description: I really enjoy the treat that is Smitten! I live in NC so when visiting friends, I always stop in for a scoop of this creamy delight. I decided on the salted caramel in the pizzele cone. Yum! They flash freeze the ice cream per serving so it is always fresh and firm.
author: Emily P.

description:
3.5 stars, really.

I'd done the liquid-nitrogen-to-make-ice-cream thing in Las Vegas (and Toronto), and it was definitely better there because the folks at Ice Pan put on a real show and offer way more flavor/topping options. So the same gimmick at Smitten didn't really leave an impression on me.

That said, the ice-cream comes out just as cold and creamy as you could possibly desire. We tried the vanilla and salted caramel and both were tasty, though the salted caramel was definitely more interesting. It was a pretty cold evening, which made me appreciate the set-up at Smitten even more. Nice heat lamps suspended from the ceiling designed to keep you warm without melting your ice-cream. If only they'd place some over their benches, we might have been able to sit down and eat. I don't know what it is but I always seem to end up getting froyo or ice-cream when it's cold out. It's like my body lacks the ability to recognize that cold-outside + cold-food-inside-body = more cold. :/
author: Josephine L.

description: Not good. Ice cream wasn't good.  It was expensive. Ur paying for the show basically.  And who needs to make instant ice cream anyways?
author: Jon P.

description:
Smitten Ice Cream is famous for their method of making ice cream. So, I came here extremely excited to try instantly made ice cream by liquid nitrogen. 

I kept hearing about how smitten ice cream is the most texturally pleasing ice cream around. I was not disappointed! I got the vanilla ice cream with malted caramel on top. My vanilla ice cream tasted really rich and creamy. It melted smoothly in my mouth, no complaints about ice particles. I was just a little bummed that even with the malted caramel, a small order of vanilla ice cream became difficult to finish. I never have a problem finishing my ice cream. I felt ashamed to throw away half of my ice cream. 

Overall, smitten does offer that extra wow in terms of ice cream texture but their flavors are too plain and rich it's difficult to swallow down an entire small.
author: Ashley T.

description:
I always pass by this place... and never gave it any thought til my cousin mentioned that they have one of the best ice creams in the world.... Well if she had to put it that way, I had to give Smitten Ice Cream a try!

It was a sunny day, and came here after brunch from Flipper's, which was pretty near Smitten's. I got the TCHO Chocolate and the BF got the Cinnamon Toast. I was pretty amazed how they make their ice creams from scratch and how you can see everything in action.

My TCHO Chocolate was so good, one of the best chocolate ice creams I ever had, HANDS-DOWNS! And if your a chocolate-lover like MOI, you gotta put one of these in yo mouth, if not your missing out! It was so rich, fresh, creamy... just everything you would want a chocolate ice cream to taste! It was soooo good and sadly when I had finished it all... I was still scooping for lil bits of it with my little spoon -___-

The Cinnamon Toast that my BF ordered was pretty good too, it reminded me of Cinnamon Toast Crunch, but without the crunch...

HIGHLY RECOMMEND, rain or shine !
author: Johanna M.

description:
Cute little ice cream shop across the park--what else can you ask for on a nice sunny day in the city? I came on a day that PayPal was doing a promo so you could get two free scoops if you downloaded the app! I tried the Earl Grey ice cream with chocolate chips--absolutely delicious! So good that I'm bitter I had to share with my sister...should've downloaded my own app. But the ice cream itself was rich, creamy, and the tea flavor left a perfect after taste. I would come back to get this flavor again!

Tips/Comments:
+ only a few flavors a day so you might not find something that you love if you're picky on a given day
+ great ambiance and conveniently located to the park and other coffee shops/eateries 
+ liquid nitrogen concept is pretty cool!
+ watch them make the ice cream--makes the experience much more interesting!
author: Anu P.

description:
I was not smitten by the ice cream at all. 

Overpriced, long wait with a short line, and mediocre ice cream.

I generally don't give 2 stars unless it was horrible customer service.  However, ice cream in the bay area has set the competition so high with such solid ice cream joints, Smitten needs to step their game up.  

They make their ice cream to order with liquid nitrogen which seems like a cool concept at first. Until you realize you can't taste samples and more importantly, the wait for the ice cream took forever.  

We got the mint chip and the portion for a $5 ice cream was just too small.  Ice cream itself was ok. Not the same texture like a slowly-churned ice cream, but good enough.  The mint flavor was very minty and we wished we had a different flavor but they sold out the one we wanted.

The worst part was when one of the workers made an ice cream, that person already received their order. So she threw it away!  What good human throws ice cream away? 

Don't believe the 4 star hype on yelp.  Go to Mr. & Mrs. Miscellaneous or Bi-Rite for a true ice cream experience in SF.
author: Cam C.

description:
OMG! I had a Smittengasm!  I was at lunch across the street and said to my co-worker, "Is there any ice cream places around here?"  He looked on his handy dandy iPhone because I was being too lazy to look at mine and Wa-la!  Smitten came up.

We walked over and I was excited to see coffee ice cream on the menu.  I have a love affair with coffee ice cream.  It's my weakness along with cheesecake (different story).  Anywho, I got the coffee ice cream with the recommended praline nibs.  I was super excited when I saw it.  It looked like heaven in a cup.  

The taste.  Smittengasmic!  Delicious! Rich! Full! Smooth! OMG! I should have gotten a bigger size!  I think the price is well worth it for the little package I tried to eat slowly so I can savor it.  Didn't work so well.  Good thing it's within walking distance of work.  

Have you had your Smittengasm yet? Go now!  Don't walk, RUN!  Enjoy!
author: Michelle B.

description:
A and I stumbled upon Smitten Ice Cream after a relaxing hour at Taste about a block away.  They only have a few flavors each day, but they make each one to order.  You can also pay through Square, so it makes things quite convenient.  A and I ordered a small TCHO Chocolate (to share) and didn't have to wait too long for the KELVINATOR to make our ice cream.  

It IS a bit pricey for such a small portion, but the ice cream was good.  Although, we both decided that it tasted even better once it was all melted and turned into an ice cream soup.  Yes, weird, but it really DID taste better.
author: Kris L.

description: This is the creamiest, best ice cream I have ever tasted. Ever. Hands down. Jesus Christ.
author: Clarity B.

description:
When scoping out the area I'm staying in on my Yelp app, I saw that there was something listed as an ice cream "food stand." So, when I ended up nearby and saw a sizable line outside, I was a bit surprised it was Smitten since it looked like an actual little store to me (it has an entrance and closed off/seating area), as opposed to a food stand. So in a first, I guess I literally walked inside of a food stand.

The prices, relative to the sizes available, almost scared me off.  But, it's not like I'm going to be here for awhile again, so I didn't turn away.  For the size I'd be happy with, it cost $10, but I went with the $6 option instead, having hibiscus.  It'd probably be worth the $6 if it were the size of the $10 one.

It was definitely a one of a kind ice cream, and in fact is likely the smoothest ice cream I have ever had.  I would recommend coming here to give it a try and have this experience, but probably wouldn't make it a frequent stop due to the value issue.  But who knows, it might be good enough that they could get me back in with some of the other flavors they only offer on a limited basis.
author: Brandon C.

description: This is my little gem!! Selfishly I wanted to keep this great little ice place to myself but I just couldn't! Perfectly creamy full of flavor baby angels singing on your taste buds ice cream. I am officially smitten
author: Gabriela W.

description: My honey decided to take me here to try out custom made ice cream made from scratch and nitrogen. I was very impressed at how it was made. The menu was very simple. You order from the available flavors and add toppings as needed. After that, you watch how they make it  and the equipment spinning. I ordered chocolate and honey ordered peach and added a topping. The ice cream is very smooth and yummy. We would definitely come back for ice cream again and again. Thanks honey.
author: Allan W.

description: Thoroughly unimpressed. I would be fine with the trying-too-hard aspect of the dry ice show, but the fact that the ice cream itself was disappointing makes me critical of the overall Smitten product.
author: Sandy G.

description:
My visit to Smitten Ice Cream had me feeling chilly and thats not because of the liquid nitrogen they use.

I really tried to give Smitten a chance even despite seeing negative reviews from Yelp friends but I came away not feeling smitten at all but the opposite which I suppose is heightened disdain.

It doesn't help when the line moves slowly and this I had to chalk up to it being after the Christmas holiday and they were definitely short staffed. That and it takes longer to make ice cream from scratch. But it definitely didn't help that the cashier was surly about taking orders, but again she was likely stressed from having to work after Xmas. 

While I'm not opposed to the whole trend of ice cream made to order (Ice Cream Lab in Beverly Hills does a pretty good job of it), I felt like the ice cream retained too much of the frosty texture and it makes for a less satisfying scoop overall. Also, the scoop was way too small for the price. 

I guess it was a perfect storm of things going wrong because as we moved up in line, they started erasing flavors off the board. We opted for Mint Chip and it was definitely exactly as advertised but perhaps too much so. If you really love the taste of mint leaves then you'll enjoy this. If you want subtle minty flavor coupled with the sweetness of chocolate you'll probably be disappointed. That mint aftertaste certainly sticks with you the rest of the night and gives you an idea of how overpowering the mint flavor really is.

I had high hopes for Smitten but ultimately was let down on my first try here. So much so that we went to Bi-Rite after just to get a more satisfying scoop of ice cream!
author: Matthew T.

description: Delicious handmade ice cream. I got the vanilla ice cream with pistachio brittle. Both were amazing. A little bit of a line but totally worth the wait.
author: Yasy R.

description:
This place has my heart! 

Fresh Mint Chip is the best. The absolute best!! They have it every other month, & there is nothing like it. There is fresh mint in the actual ice cream & it's so refreshing, so light, so delicious, so perfect. Everyone is very personable, they remember your name. 

My friend & I come every Wednesday and it has yet to disappoint! 

I love Smitten :)
author: Jovani A.

description:
Dare I say the people behind this are marketing geniuses? I mean, who doesn't like seeing liquid nitrogen totally freeze the crap out of things? And then combine that with something everyone loves...ice cream, made right in front of you. So awesome.

That pretty much sums up my feelings at the time while I was completely infatuated with the place. But now with time and space (which is essential to evaluating any good relationship) I have clarity to see that yes it's good, but you're still paying $5 for a tiny cup of ice cream.
author: Calvin H.

description:
I live around the corner from Smitten, and it is DANGEROUS! 
Attack of the sugar, attack of the cream. 

Everything I have ever tasted from Smitten is grand.
My favorite is the chocolate base with caramel and shortbread.

Whenever I have friends and family visiting from out of town I always take them to Smitten because it is SUCH a cute little place, and truly one-of-a-kind.
The ice cream machines are definitely the highlight, watching them frost away fresh ice cream for me to indulge in a part of the whole Smitten experience.
It is pricey but the ingredients are only the best.

Sometimes the staff can act like they know everything about ice cream, but they probably do so I don't mind. I can see how some would be off put by this attitude though.

The wait can be long but the whole experience is worth it.
author: Alexandra C.

description:
I have to say this place is pretty darn cool. Every scoop is made in front of your face using liquid nitrogen. From the three flavors of the day, I picked TCHO chocolate with almond brittle as my topping. I forked $5.25 for a small. I guess they are charging extras for the cool concept.

I am not too impress with their ice cream. It melts quick, too rich, and just too sweet. I felt like I was drinking a chocolate shake from in-n-out. Bi-Rite and Humphry Slocombe are still my favorite in the City.
author: Kien M.

description:
Smitten Ice Cream is good. There's no question about it, it is good ice cream. The only reason why people disagree with Smitten is because they don't want to pay the premium for it. HULLO! This is San Francisco, the birthplace of hipsters and all things alike. 

Smitten Ice Cream has a extremely creamy consistency and the flavors are strong. Aside from tasting delicious, it's fun to watch how it's made. They usually rotate through a few flavors and I do wish they had more flavors but overall, it's good ice cream.
author: Yuxuan N.

description:
I'll have to say - half of Smitten's charm is the fact that they are located next to a dog park. But aside from that - Smitten is a great place to swing by if you're in San Francisco. It represents the epitome of trend that is sweeping the city and it's surrounded by smiling faces, beautiful weather, cute, interracial couples, oh and did I mention it's next to a dog park?

And apart from it's surroundings, and though it is a small detail, I love that Smitten is so transparent about the ingredients that are used in the ice cream and the fact that it's made right in front of you. They also try to educate their patrons with various, informational posters that are hung in the small space. 

It's a bit expensive, and because of the "making it right in front of you" approach, the taste can be slightly inconsistent BUT I honestly feel that you're paying for the experience that surrounds this establishment. For how cold Smitten's ice cream is - it's certainly a nice way to feel warm and fuzzy in the Bay.
author: Paul Z.

description: I love ice cream but this was the fattiest and least appealing ice cream I've ever had. Both my GF and I tossed them after one bite.
author: Dan V.

description:
You have to try this place at least once in your life.

Why?

Because there is something special about seeing your ice cream churned right in front of you with the help of liquid nitrogen. It is magical, just like that first time you put a penny in a specialty penny machine and turned out your first special penny. Soon the novelty will wear off and you will no longer go there, but you still have to try it the first time for that to happen.

The ice cream does come out super smooth and gelato-like, and their almond crisps are awesome. I wasn't too keen on their salted caramel flavour (trust me, go to bi-rite for that), but their mint flavour tasted just like you're chewing a mint leaf. It's light and delicious.
author: Alice C.

description:
Loved the ice cream.... super super creamy and soft. I tried the Tcho Chocolate and the Salted Caramel. Both were good. I really wanted to try the brown sugar and cinnamon one, the corn and berry or the balsamic strawberry , but to my luck they didn't have either of them .

Its on the expensive side. We paid $12 for two smalls, one in a cup and one cone. But I think the Ice creams probably worth it.

It would have been a 5 star if I had gotten to try any of the flavors I really wanted, but anyway, maybe next time :-)
author: Insiya N.

description: Very cool concept but the Ice Cream itself was just ok. It's a very small building that looks like it was made out of a shipping container. there are a lot of similar hipster type shops around it. It was neat watching the Ice Cream spin with the smoke of the liquid nitrogen coming out but when it comes down to it the ice cream taste is what's going to sell me on it. I tried the Salted Caramel and it was just ok, If you want really good ice cream I would have to suggest going to Bi-Rite.
author: Brandon Y.

description:
I love that this pop up shop makes your ice cream right on the spot. We ordered the TCHO Chocolate with almond brittle. This combo is pretty damn tasty I will admit that. The ice cream is much smoother than most and it melts in your mouth. 

I just received a coupon for the rootbeer float via BlackBoardEats. Looks like I'll be back to try that too.

Yum.

You're in for a real treat. I'm smitten.
author: Amy J.

description:
Had the Salted Carmel. Excellent flavor but is extremely rich. The portion was perfect (small) but the price was a little higher than I would of expected to see from an ice cream shop running out of an old container. 

Overall a great place. I'll be back!
author: Nicholas S.

description: Love the location, its right across from a small community park, so after my boyfriend & I grabbed our ice cream we sat on a bench there before the sun went down & it was perfect. I got the classic vanilla with tcho crispies & my boyfriend got the salted caramel with the tcho chocolate syrup on top. Both very flavorful & I love how each flavor is made fresh from liquid nitrogen. $4 for a small is still a tad on the pricier side especially for ice cream but def would still come back!
author: Moriah D.

description:
The first time I came into this little shack in Hayes Valley I was so distracted by all the smoke and the fact that we got to watch th "brrrr-istas" make ice cream that I hardly noticed how overwhelmingly sweet the ice cream is.

They offer 3 and sometimes 4 flavors: Vanilla an Chocolate are daily and the other one or two change. They also have several different toppings, chocolate fudgy thng, caramel... and I'm not sure what else. I've had the Brown Sugar, Vanilla, and Salted Caramel ice cream. No Toppings.

The ice cream is really sweet. Too sweet. I've never been able to finish a small, one scoop cup - even the kid's size!

It's pretty pricey for their very simple offerings. You're paying for the presentation. And after seeing it a few times, isn't that great. All the ingredients are already mixed and all they do is dump in the bowl and let the smoke do the rest.

Yes, the ice cream is very creamy and you're obviously not ingesting all those hard-to-pronounce chemicals, but the level of sweetness, the simple menu and the price is a turn off. I will be back in the summer to try the strawberry balsamic whatever. Sounds too interesting not to.
author: Camille R.

description:
Very good. I've tried other places with liquid nitrogen before and though this one was at par with every other place. The only thing I think is they need more flavors. They might be going for the limited, but really good flavors approach, but none of them really stood out to me as something that I "must" try. 

The wait wasn't that long considering how many people were in there. Overall a good experience.
author: Heather T.

description:
Stopped by here with the girlfriend after dinner. They make you're ice cream by pouring a liquid ice cream base into a mixer that adds liquid nitrogen as it mixes. I've never been to a place like this, so it was a pretty interesting and cool experience. She got the salted caramel while I got the sweet corn. The salted caramel was a little saltier than I'd prefer, but still good. The sweet corn was delicious and I really liked the idea of it; I used to really love eating sweet corn as a kid and was excited to see it in ice cream form.

The place is pretty nice and clean and there's a little bit of bench space inside the awnings to sit and enjoy you're ice cream. If you haven't, I'd recommend this place just to see what interesting flavors they might come up with next =).
author: Jefferson L.

description: Great icecream.  The mint chocolate was on point.     It's rare to go to a place that uses mint so wonderfully.   Lady behind the counter was awesome.  Next time I'm in San Francisco I will definitely visit this place again.
author: Andrew H.

description: A bit pricey for the quantity but that's kind of to be expected considering they make it right then upon order. Very cool and comfy setup, tasted great! Would love to come back next time I'm nearby! Definitely would recommend checking this place out :)
author: Brian T.

description:
So... I do love this place, but I live at least an hour away so I don't get here that often.  Was driving through SF tonight On my way from Santa Rosa to San Jose.  Walked up at 10:32 pm, they still had about 8 people in line, but they closed the door just as I walked up and said "sorry, we're closed."  And I understand we were two minutes late, but when I said, "oh noooo! We just drove here from Santa Rosa," the answer was "sorry."  So...
Yeah... One more customer... Really?  For two minutes?  Ice cream = awesome!  Customer service = not so much!
author: Susan O.

description:
"We don't do tastings because.." - I don't really care about the reason, no reason is valid. You're an ice cream place. Do tastings.

"We don't do two flavors on the same cup/cone" - why? I honestly don't get it.

Pretentious.

Ice cream is OK. Very expensive. Bi-rite is much tastier.
author: Elad O.

description:
After waiting in line for half an hour (it was a hot January day in San Francisco), my boyfriend asked how many scoops fill a waffle cone. Two, he was told. Ok, I'd like two scoops in a waffle cone, he told him. We ordered, paid, and waited patiently for it to get made. 

When it came out it was without a cone. Ok, honest mistake. They forgot the cone. Oops. We politely told them that we ordered it with a cone and asked if we could get one in which to put the ice cream. The man working there said he didn't think we ordered one and he had to go check. He went back to the computer and checked the log and told us no, we did not order one. Well, we explained, we did order one, it just mistakenly didn't get entered into their system, could we please get a cone. It costs an extra dollar. No problem! I have a dollar right here! 

Well, I can't take your dollar. Only he can take your dollar. The guy you have to stand half an hour in line to see. And I can't take your dollar and give it to him. And I'm not just going to give you a freaking waffle cone because we f'ed up your order in the first place like a place with decent customer service should do anyway. Instead we're going to make you lose your freaking mind while your boyfriend insists he doesn't need a waffle cone so you can leave the store before you get upset. 

Our friends did get waffle cones. One of them came literally broken with a huge piece just hanging off the side and the bottom not sealed up so ice cream was dripping out the whole time. It led to a conversation about how to make your employees care about what they are doing because these ones obviously did not give a DAMN.
author: Shushannah A.

description:
I'm putting it at 3 stars because the chocolate ice cream was very smooth and tasty. I'm putting it at 3 stars because the mint chocolate chip ice cream was a little odd.
And because I think this establishment has definitely been overhyped.  

The mint chocolate chip did not taste the way I expected it to, but I'm always up for surprises. It tasted very, very basil-y (if you've ever had Philz mint mojito coffee... this ice cream tastes just like it) and less like peppermint. Maybe I didn't pay close enough attention to the ingredients of this flavor. I'd come back just to try the Nectarine and vanilla flavors, both of which I love. 

It's definitely a cool experience watching the employees make the ice cream in front of you. Science and liquid nitrogen changing material states, my favorite things. I feel a little bad for the employees just because everyone videotapes them working the machine.
author: Vivian L.

description: Not only is the ice cream good, but watching them make it is pretty entertaining. Each serving is made fresh and you get to watch their dry-ice machine make it right in front of your face! A must have if you're in the neighborhood. Great for kids too!
author: Samara C.

description:
Smitten Ice Cream brought me back to my sixth grade girls' science club days where we made ice cream once with liquid nitrogen.

If you like the fancy smoke effects, then definitely be prepared to be amazed.  It's a little slower than your normal ice cream place since small batches are made by hand.  I tried the homemade vanilla with the almond brittle topping.  I definitely want to try the chocolate next time since it is made with TCHO chocolate!
author: Carli F.

description: Smitten is something else.  They use liquid nitrogen to make every scoop to order and it is SO COOL.  It's really fun to watch and the ice cream is amazing!  It's super creamy (like more than gelato) and really fresh tasting.  The website has a video that explains that the creaminess comes from the low temperature, which forms smaller ice crystals, and the freshness comes from making it to order and not having to add any emulsifiers or stabilizers.  They only carry about 5 flavors, but you don't really need any fancy flavors when the ice cream is that good.  I got vanilla with a seasonal pear caramel sauce and it was just crazy good.  The store is also super cute and modern and looks like a shipping container and there is a sculpture park right next to it to sit/wander through.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I live 1/2 block away from Patricia's Green in Hayes Valley, so often hang out in the park on Sundays feeding the pigeons and drinking lattes. I have a sweet tooth and want to love  Smitten, but I just can't do it. There are two issues - the lack of flavor and the exorbitant price. It is like the ice cream equivalent of ladies light cigarettes from the 1970s....like licking frozen faintly flavored air.  And $4.75 for a toddler sized serving and $6.00 for an over 18 sized serving? They are nuts.

l will gladly shell out for a mouth orgasm; I love Miette's walnut shortbread cookies, Ritual coffee, an Ice Cream Bar float ....they're worth every penny. But Smitten? Not so much.
author: Avery C.

description:
Huge Fan!

Despite all the liquid nitrogen stuff that I actually don't really care for, their ice cream is LEGIT.

I got the weekend special (i believe), Mint Chocolate Chip!!!

I guess it's because that they use liquid nitrogen instead of ice so that the ice cream is a LOT creamier than usual. Some people may not like this.

The mint was so strong. It totally smelled like they just grind fresh mint leaves in the ice cream so it actually has a herby mint flavor.

Conclusion: Def will go again!
author: Ruxin H.

description:
The nitrogen machines make this place look like a gimmick but it actually has good ice cream!

Chocolate: very high quality. You can actually taste the chocolate and not just a load of sugar. 

Waffle cone was delicious! Made fresh daily. It was still crunchy despite being later on in the day at 4pm.
author: Vi T.

description:
I like the whole gimmicky idea of watching the liquid nitrogen making your ice cream right in front of you and it is fun to watch.  But I what they need are samples to help people decide what they want. 

The salted caramel was decent but I've had better.  The chocolate is..well chocolate.
author: Kenneth H.

description:
Sweet Corn & Blackberry is amazing!  Tried that last August and it was hands down my favorite ice cream flavor so far.  I was surprised such a combo would be so flavorful and light!

Tried Olive Oil & Lavender Shortbread today and my mind was confused. I felt like I was having Italian food.  An interesting experience.

I prefer this ice cream place above the rest. Ice Cream Lab in Beverly Hills copied this similar ice cream creation style, but Smitten tastes better and the texture is creamier.
author: Rye G.

description:
I don't really get Smitten. The emotion or the ice cream. In the latter case, I at least do on a logical level but I am not the target audience:

Disposable income, check.
Youngish urban professional, check.
Seeker of superlative food experiences, check.
Willingness to pay more for hipster cred and atmosphere if the end result isn't more delicious, fail.

Smitten's ice cream produced by their unique machines and process is thoroughly decent. I've never been disappointed here in that regard but it is very expensive and one is essentially paying for the liquid nitrogen novelty. Unless there's some kind of futures market that has driven up the capital expenditure needed for their converted shipping container location?

Like most boutique products, Smitten has done an exemplary job in the ice cream world refining the story it is selling... but the story is the portion that is superlative, not the frozen dairy product. It's still a much better local experience than, say, a visit to the Ghirardelli compound, but head to Mitchell's or Bi-Rite instead. There's going to be a queue at any of them in amenable weather so might as well wait for the best.
author: Sean C.

description:
Smitten is all style no substance... but that is some damn good style.  

The ice cream isn't anything to write home about, but part of the Smitten experience is to pay by using the Square app, get rewards by using the Stampt app, watch the liquid nitro action as you wait, and eat your ice cream in recycled shipping container.  And I love their business card!

I've been three blocks away from Smitten's Hayes Valley location since its opening in April 2011... it took me a year to get over there. One reason is there aren't a lot of flavors.  On any given day they probably have four goin' on, and two of those are going to be chocolate (TCHO... but still, chocolate) and plain ol' vanillla.  I don't blame them; they have four Kelvins and it takes awhile to fire up (ice down?) the ice cream.  And possibly because they use liquid nitro, the ice cream melts much faster.  Or it could be the recipe.  Or both.

I had the rhubarb crisp (rhubarb extract blended with vanilla ice cream and chunks of Batter Bakery's cookies).  It was okay.  I was never huge on rhubarb the problem was not enough chunks of ice cream.

For a tiny cup at $4.75, I'm not dying to go back.  Four stars for style, three stars for taste and price.
author: Erika C.

description: Still my favorite ice cream.  I just love ice cream being creamy and not icy.  They ruined me!  Every time I try to enjoy ice cream elsewhere, I think of how creamy Smitten is and how badly I want to make a little trip just for ice cream.
author: Joanne H.

description:
While wandering Hayes Valley, my friend and I see no wait at Smitten and I decide to check it out. I was surprised at how expensive it was! I asked the cashier if a kiddie cup would be too small for me and he said it was definitely meant for kids. I decide on the vanilla bean with pistachio brittle and hand him a whopping $5.25 for one, teeny scoop.

Yes, I thought the ice cream was incredibly smooth, but I'm not completely converted.  $5.25 is a lot for a tiny cup! I could practically get a  full-blown sundae at Bi Rite with that much money.  It's cool to see it made to order, but I think I'd rather spend my money elsewhere.
author: Jenn C.

description: Quality Tcho Chocolate ice cream in cute Hayes Valley storefront. Ice cream good but have had better. The real drawback was the uppity yet lousy service. Obnoxious, patronizing cashier made getting ice cream not so sweet.
author: N C.

description:
My friend and I happen to work with liquid nitrogen on a daily basis and so the gimmick of watching milk and cream freeze amidst a cloud of burbling gas was somewhat lost on us.  But regardless of this, I quite enjoyed my miniature scoop of pistachio and he absolutely loved his lavender with the caramel topping (tried some, and lavender was by far the winner).  

As good as Bi-Rite?  I'm not so sure, but really not bad at all.  And ultra smooth as one would expect, given the use of temperature the ice cream is made at!  

Love the shipping crate shop too.
author: Joanne G.

description:
Yes the Earl grey ice cream is good.

Nice Staff 

Long lines !


Small place ,almost nowhere to sit and enjoy your ice cream...
author: T. C.

description:
It's expensive. 
Is it worth it the wait, price, and taste though ? No, not really. Flavors are pretty plain and uninspired. I've been there more than once so I've tried most of what they have to offer. I wasn't ever impressed. Texture is interesting but not really my thing. It's very smooth due to the process of how it's made. 

People talking about how it's made and how it's cool,well It's unique but really I'm there for the product. I guess if it's that amazing and entertaining for your dollar then by all means but if you don't like waiting 30 minutes average for ice cream then i suggest elsewhere.
author: Hiroki M.

description:
It's ok. I like Bi-Rite alooooooot better but it sure it cool seeing the concept of the shop and them actually making it right in front of your eyes!

I got the Tcho chocolate w/ pistachio brittle. The brittle was def a nice touch! The chocolate was pretty chocolatey and it was very smooth. Consistency to me was more like a froyo, maybe because of the way it's made. I prefer the texture of Bi-Rite!

BUT, definitely stop by here if you're in the area. They have a cool park right next to the area as well as a beer garden type thang.
author: Emily C.

description:
I went to Smitten with one of my best friend and we came across this cute little food stand/shop! There was a pretty long line outside because it was a nice day and right next to a park. I like how their ice cream was made to order and that everything was made with the freshest ingredients. I ordered the Fresh Mint w/ TCHO Chocolate Chip and the mint tasted as if it was straight from a garden.

However, I thought it was pricey for a small which cost $5.50. The ice cream was also melting really fast and was dripping out of my cone so I had to eat it quickly. Overall, I thought this place was okay and I definitely had better. 

The concept of making old-fashion ice cream with liquid-nitrogen was unique and different from any other ice cream shops in the city so I feel like its worth trying, but there are other better options around San Francisco.
author: Junie Y.

description:
Smitten doesn't need another review as they always have a line regardless of how chilly the day/night may be as-is but I had to write in about my semi-confusing yet helpful experience last night with the cooky cashier!

The experience goes...

Me: May I please have a small scoop of TCHO chocolate?
Cashier: *strange looks towards me*
Date: I will have a regular mint chip in a cone please.
Cashier: *mumbles to himself*
Me: *wonders if this cashier took our order*
Cashier: okay lemme clarify what I think you want...do you want a single scoop of TCHO chocolate or a small? And if you want a single scoop then you probably ordered the Mint Chip thinking it's only two scoops. 
Me: yes, I only want a single scoop.
Date: Yes okay I will take two scoops.

After devouring our delicious ice creams, I looked at our receipt and it became clear the awesome cashier was trying to telling me that there's an off the menu "munchkin" size for $3.00!!! Thanks a bunches for saving my waistline and wallet for devouring an extra scoop of ice cream!

Take away notes:
Munchkin size = one scoop = $3.00
Small size = two scoops = $4.95

Oh and hands down the best chocolate ice cream I've ever had. I would describe the TCHO chocolate like a creamy frozen chocolate truffle mousse. AhMazing!
author: Mindy C.

description:
I was super set on trying this place so we broke down and went. Although it was cold and the line was super long we waited...and then waited some more after we ordered. I would say 20 minutes (not exaggerating) I guess the salted caramel machine was out of ordered because after we got the first cup we ordered (Strawberry with Balsamic Vinaigrette, which was good) the guy dumped the batch he'd made and went to the back. 10 minutes later comes back and calls my name. 

Besides the long wait, this was the WORST salted caramel I've ever had :'( the days of excitement that ended in an ice cream that can't hold a spoon to Breyers.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
Well...I'm sort of torn about this review because on one hand, it's novel and lovely to have your ice cream made for you to order and on the other hand, it takes a very long time and it melts so quickly. 

Yes, it's organic and yes it's a local shop so those are just a few reasons to give this place at least one try. The flavors change from day to day so at least when you come back, you'll have a strong possibility of never trying the same flavors twice. There's a great amount of creaminess that balances out the tartness of the strawberries but there's not a lot of time to enjoy it as it melts so quickly!

 I'd highly recommend the strawberry if you have to do this once and if you're also dragged by your friend Gil who's (forgive the pun) "smitten" with the owner, tell him I said "you owe me two trips to Sacramento."
author: Jessica K.

description:
As one of those hallmark SF must-visits, Smitten serves up novelty as much as it does liquid-nitrogen-infused ice cream. Its claim to fame is a nifty machine called the Brrr that, by some witchcraft, uses liquid nitrogen to churn really small ice crystals, making the "smoothest, densest and most flavorful ice cream on earth from scratch." 

The dessert shop is located in a cute little park called Patricia's Green and is known for its painfully long waits, but there wasn't a single person in line when my friend and I stopped by for a post-dinner bite on Sunday night. The shop has around 3-4 usual flavor choices (Tcho 60.5% chocolate, vanilla, salted caramel, etc.), as well as a seasonal flavor (this month: rhubarb!). 

I ordered the Tcho, while my friend got the seasonal rhubarb flavor. Both were great, and the famously creamy texture is interesting (although perhaps not worth the $4.75 price tag for the smallest size). My Tcho, with gingerbread shortbread toppings for an extra 75 cents, was a good balance between dark chocolate bitterness and creamy sweetness, while my friend's rhubarb scoop had a light and refreshingly tart flavor. 

An obligatory stop for any new visitor to the area, albeit a pricey one. Make sure you press your nose up against the glass to see the Brrr in action before you leave!
author: Esther W.

description: The shop was definitely fresh and "hipster" looking with smart decorations. The ice cream was rich and thick, also had a strong sweet flavor. Their liquid nitrogen was really interesting and fun looking and floated around like a chilly cloud. Their waffle cones were homemade and tasted crunchy and sweet. It had a variety of diverse, great flavors. The people were nice and accepting. The bathrooms are not clean enough. Yet, we'd absolutely love to go back!
author: Connor B.

description:
This place is one of those pay for the experience but you get great ice cream out of it. They make your ice cream in front of you and add great toppings. It definitely has the fresh and creamy taste. They are a little pricey but do offer a $5 off your purchase if you get the PayPal app, which I suggest you to download. 

Their prices start around $5 and then additional $ for toppings. I always get their vanilla with salted caramel for the topping.
author: Brittany P.

description:
Yeah, Bi-Rite in the Mission is good, but Smitten's a worthy competitor.  In fact, probably better in my opinion.  

First of all, at Smitten, you get to enjoy the show of seeing your ice cream made fresh on the spot.  When I first came here, I was truly blown away with their nitrogen special effects.  Also, Hayes Valley is a little more cozier place to hangout, in comparison to the Mission.  But, yeah you can't be wrong with either or.  Both places are must go to places.
author: Joshua P.

description:
This concept is fun and the ice cream is good but I think the price premium is a little ridiculous. 

I had dark chocolate which was very rich and flavorful but no better than other house made ice creams I have had in the past for less dough. 

I honestly think the texture was not as good as ice cream I made in culinary school using industrial grade ice cream makers or had at other establishments that make ice cream in house. 

It's fun and intresting if you are in the area, as we were, but I wouldn't go out of my way for it.
author: Claire C.

description: Cool ice cream shop built out of a shipping container. Made to order, so you have to wait.
author: Amanda M.

description:
Since this place is literally right across from my apt, you can say it's an easy access for me.  I've been coming here ever since they opened.  Usually stop by here after a night out for dinner and I want some good quality ice cream.  Cute date spot, by the way. 

I've tried:
TCHO chocolate (too chocolately...but great for those chocolate lovers)
Vanilla with toffee
Earl Grey with chocolate mint (realllllllllllly good)
Passion Fruit (good one)
Mint (really light)
Salted caramel (Bi-Rite is probably better)
** Want to try the Rhubarb one!

I would say the earl grey is my favorite.  It's so refreshing, especially along with the texture of the mint chocolate chip.  Maybe I had it on a hot day?  Either way, I'd still order it again!

What's so special about this place is that they always change up their flavors, so you never know what they have until you're here.  They usually have 3-4 flavors for the day.  Besides the special and unique flavors, I think the main reason why people come here is because your ice cream is made to order with liquid nitrogen.  Cool?  I guess so.  I'm not a Science person, but it was nice seeing them make it the first time.  

The only bad part about this place is that it is more on the pricey side.  $3.25 for a kid (1 scoop) or $4.75 for a small (two scoops).  Never got the large, but I know it's about $10.  It is quite some money, but hey, if you want fresh, good quality ice cream, you gotta pay up!  The wait is quite long too, especially if you come at night and on a hot day.  Good thing they have benches now!
author: Nancy S.

description:
Salted caramel ice cream root beer float!

Ice cream was smooth and perfect
Jones Root Beer FTW! 

Great combo, but careful on the sugar content!  Greet glucose pickmeup
author: Alyssaaa S.

description:
On the day I first moved to San Francisco, my friends and I ALMOST went here, but we were all too full after lunch. It's been on my mind ever since then, and this past weekend I finally got to go!

So worth it! They were out of cones when we got there (about 3pm on a Sunday) but that was okay. For a tiiiiiny cup (the small size) there were two scoops that were much bigger than I expected. It was really neat to be able to stand and watch the ice cream being made so quickly. My boyfriend got the earl gray which was a very smooth, subtle flavor, and then my friend and I both got the mint ice cream which absolutely blew our mind...

MINT ICE CREAM that actually tasted like MINT? REAL mint? Not the artificial flavoring we are all used to, but mint like eating a mint leaf? Like mojito mint? Like delicious, fresh, tasty mint? Yeah, it was pretty awesome. Totally unexpected. Totally delicious.

The wait wasn't too long although it was kind of hard to hear what names they were calling because of the crowded, loud space in the tent. It's awesome that they make the ice cream right there--that's probably why the ingredients get to be so fresh. My friend said she was burping mint for the rest of the afternoon.

Overall a pretty cool place. The earl gray flavor was pretty subtle and I'm not sure how the other flavors were, but it was a really neat experience regardless.
author: Katie V.

description:
There was a flash storm last sunday but we left our sushi place unsatisfied, so we decided to end our night with some ice cream.  Boy, am I glad I did!  Even though it was raining, winds at 30mph, sand flying everywhere, we were still able to enjoy our ice cream, which is very telling of our experience.

The location, which is just a metal box hidden in the heart of Hayes Valley, is a really low key structure with simple, modern décor.  I absolutely adore the idea of using liquid nitrogen to make ice cream.  It's so fun to watch the smoke rising from the concoction as they make it and there's definitely a WOW factor when you watch them, it feels like a bunch of mad scientists inventing potions. Best of all, they make every ice cream order INDIVIDUALLY and they're probably the only place that does this.   I read on the wall which explains the science behind the ice cream that using liquid nitrogen produces smaller ice crystals, producing a super smooth texture.  Indeed, it's true; the ice cream did come out smoother than normal ice cream!

What we tried:

Vanilla with spicy caramel sauce: the vanilla was the smoothest vanilla I've ever had.  The spicy caramel sauce was good, it was just sweet enough with a kick of chili pepper at the end.

Salted Caramel with TCHO chocolate sauce: the ice cream wasn't that salty, but it was still good and the chocolate sauce was to die for!

Maple Brown Sugar Squash: This was a very complex ice cream but I loved how you could taste every component, the squash (similar to pumpkin), maple and brown sugar all stood out on their own.  They drizzle some type of maple sauce on top, which is good but dripped all over our hands because we got a cone so I'd suggest getting a cup with this

3 small ice creams with 2 extra sauces and 1 cone came out to ~$17, not cheap but definitely worth the experience and the unique flavors.

Oh, might I add, they use organic milk and locally grown ingredients? 5 STARS!!!
author: Michelle W.

description:
Not worth the hype or the wait in my opinion. But it wasn't bad. Fresh ingredients definitely a plus. Made to order - fun in theory - but the wait! And I noticed a lot of people opt for plain vanilla just so they could get ice cream in less than 20/30 minutes. 

I ordered the sticky toffee pudding. WAY too sweet - I could only finish about half of a small and I still felt like I ate way too much of it. The best part was the dates. 

Fresh mint chip was also pretty good. The mint tasted so fresh. I wish they would have a mint option minus the chocolate nibs. 

Some of the flavors for other seasons look good - so I'll have to come back and try something different. They must be doing something right with the lines they have!

Maybe I just ordered the wrong thing/ came during the wrong season.
author: Shannon H.

description:
So we stumbled into this place on accident. Out of towners, trying to find some ice cream, froyo, anything after a great dinner and we somehow end up driving by this place. Man am I glad we went and checked it out.

The ice cream is made on the spot, and I don't think you can understand just how cool it is until you place your order and then watch as they prepare it for you. I got mint, and the flavor with the cone was out of this world!

If you're new, ask the staff for advice, the guy helped craft all four of our orders and he didn't do any of us wrong on it!
author: Patrick F.

description:
What's most attractive about Smitten is its simplicity. 

There are just four or five flavors, two of which are always available (vanilla and dark chocolate, with the rest being offered seasonally). A regular, comparable to a medium, costs $6 flat. The coolheaded counter person efficiently takes your order on an iPad, then provides a charming smile. With ease, a server operates bewildering liquid nitrogen technology then gently calls your name. You taste the ice cream: it's smooth and pure and speaks to you honestly, generously, consistently. The serving size doesn't surprise you, but the richness does. You realise the ice cream has depth, that the cone has just the right crunch. You quickly fall in love and walk through Hayes Valley with a grin.

Simplest of all, this shop resides entirely in a small intermodal container. 

All you have to do is find it.
author: Brian C.

description:
OH MY GOD! A-m-a-z-i-n-g! This has to be the smoothest, creamiest ice cream I've had and that's because they use liquid nitrogen. I wouldn't pay a lot more than what Haagen Daz cost ($5) (I love Haagen Daz!) But sometimes, we absolutely have to get a Smitten Ice cream (6-10$)
