I don't like ice cream cones that much but this cone is by far the most delicious cone ever! I would just buy the cone alone and eat it. When you start walking closer to the Smitten shop, you can smell this homemade vanilla sweet aroma and I think that's the cone. 

Always a line even when it's cold outside but people know it's worth it. Try it out, and you won't regret it! The only thing that you'll be regretting is not trying it out.
author: Elaine N.

description:
ABSO-FREAKING-LUTELY DELICIOUS!

We waited over an hour. After the excruciatingly long wait, I went in thinking that the concept of making ice cream via dry ice was just to add some flair and exuberance to customers - you know, a bit of glitz and glam that would take attention away from the actual ice cream.

SO NOT TRUE. I got the blood orange ice cream with pistachios in it and my taste buds were blown away. Divine combination of creamy and tangy, and the pistachios gave it a unique texture and flavor... little green surprises you couldn't wait to find in every bite :) Since I waited over an hour to get to the pay station, I ordered a whole pint, and was so glad I did. A couple scoops of this kind of heaven just isn't enough!

Can't wait to be back! Just need to cross my fingers that my patience doesn't run out before I get to the front of the truck!
author: Chrystal Z.

description:
I've only been here once, and I'm okay with that. The concept of getting your ice cream made on the spot was very inviting, but the taste was eh...

The line was long and it took a pretty long time to get the ice cream too. Normally I like to savor my ice cream if its enjoyable, but I was actually more concerned with making it to the ballet on time. It didn't taste bad, but wasn't worth the wait and money for me. 2/4 of my party liked it and the other half could have done with or without it, so all in all, average.
author: Lisa M.

description:
I shared a cup of their fresh salted caramel ice cream with my boyfriend recently and it was on par with another famous salted caramel ice cream in the City...if you catch my drift.

The best part? You get to watch them make it in their nifty liquid nitrogen ice cream machines.
author: Liz G.

description:
Likes: Vanilla was amazingly creamy smooth but light.   Mint chocolate chip was VERY minty and tasted like the mint leaves, making me think I was at a pho restaurant where they give you that extra mint.  But as you keep eating the mint flavor softens and the chocolate they put in takes over deliciously.  Each order is made individually using liquid nitrogen in front of you.  Indoor bench seating and heaters inside too for a chilly night.

Dislikes: Mint chocolate chip was a tad bit too minty for my taste but still very good.
author: Karen M.

description: If you're considering checking out Smitten, stop what you're doing and run to Hayes Valley! This place is incredible. The cookie dough bits are especially tasty :)
author: Alex S.

description:
We all scream for instant ice cream!!
Well, some of us do, and after trying this new ice cream vendor u probably will cheer for her too.

Smitten Ice Cream debuted at Soul Cocina's fundraiser event on Precita Park, late last month. But I couldn't attend that weekend. Previously when I first heard about this upcoming vendor, I had thought that it was going to be one of those ice cream maker balls that u fill with ice cubes and salt, and then shake around to make the ice cream - glad it wasn't. Last Saturday afternoon, Robyn tweeted/twittered that she was going to be at Dolores Park in 5 minutes, so I decided to drop by.

Robyn's contraption, looks like one of those garage inventions made by a mad scientist from the 60's. This "space age" machine rolls around on top of a beautiful old-style red Radio Flyer brand wagon - this clever (and cute) combination enhances the crazy scientist appeal. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/eYKR39p9y9RrSeYu4Qilyw/l

I found Robyn and her assistant setup next to the bell at Dolores Park, together with the Chai Cart. Their table had a choice of toppings: 4 spicy chiles to "enhance" the cinnamon dark chocolate (aka. Mexican chocolate) ice cream flavor - anaheim chiles was the suggested choice. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/cXSLNRyTNXzOgErS3G3KYQ/l

The machine was recently christened "Kelvin", from online name suggestions by fans. Here's a picture of "Kelvin" hard at work, including cheesy sci-fi smoke effects - just kidding that's the liquid nitrogen that helps make the ice cream. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/hVUUxE91_BkPIVkNx0T7sw/l

It takes about a minute to make each batch, after a few minutes (there was a couple of people ahead of me), Tadaa! I got my decadent and delicious cup of chocolate ice cream with chiles ($5). The ice cream was VERY yummy!! I know, I use that word too often, but it was really good. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/1T6mfbFovUvZpuxFXe-6NA/l

Here's a video made by a fan (Aki N.) of the instant ice cream cart: 
http://www.vimeo.com/6809591

Get location updates via Twitter or Facebook.
author: Luis C.

description:
So I returned with a friend from out of town and decided to give a second try.  Had the basic TCHO chocolate (what place in SF isn't selling something TCHO-related?).  It was much better than the Olive Oil, still a little overpriced for a small.  If you want novelty and nice people watching area, this is it.  

If you want better ice cream, go to Dogpatch.
author: Kevin H.

description: Just-in-time ice cream, with premium ingredients.  There is a limited selection of flavors and they rotate over time.  My favorites are the Tcho dark chocolate and salted caramel.  It's outstanding but you're really paying for the experience of seeing your ice cream made in real time by modern-day artisans.
author: Don A.

description: Waited in a long, LONG line for a long, long time for pretty good ice-cream. The liquid nitrogen concept is really cool, but for the end product, a bit overrated. The sweet corn and berries is a unique flavor, and don't get me wrong, it was good, but for the price and the wait, I'd still prefer Bi-rite. Bi-rite just has more options, cleaner, bolder, and more unique flavors to choose from, and if you're going to wait and over pay for a scoop of ice-cream, you might as well get more choices (that you can actually sample to make sure you like before you purchase too!)
author: Evonne L.

description: I want to say that I'm forced to come here because of my kids, but I love smitten just as much as they do. I would recommend trying the vegan chocolate pops. I don't see too many people get them but are probably one of the best chocolate pops I've had. They are already made so I eat it while I'm waiting for my other orders. I've also tried the Smitten in Lafayette and Oakland. Out of all of them the cones, surprisingly, taste better at their Oakland location.   It has a nice lemon taste to it which is unlike the waffle cones you would get at the other two locations. Maybe was just the batch that was made today.
author: JJ S.

description:
Ice cream made with liquid nitrogen right before your eyes! And it is awesome. And quite delicious. I tried the Mint TCHO Chocolate Chip ice cream when I came here and it was really good! The mint flavor was strong (just the way I like it) and the ice cream was super smooth and creamy. Definitely expensive though, I'm not gonna lie, but it was worth a trip out for a sweet treat. Located right near Hayes Valley, the location is pretty neat and super neighborhood friendly - there's tons of people in the area walking around with their dogs, friends, and kids, which makes Smitten feel, to me, like a neighborhood hangout spot. 

The staff here is fantastic and the small shop where Smitten sits is cozy and can get a bit crowded when there's a bunch of people appear out of no where. However, I don't know whether I would want to pay basically $5 for a small cup of ice cream again here, but if some visiting friends wanted to get some dessert that's a little different from your average ice cream parlor, I'll probably take them here.
author: Cheston W.

description:
I've heard so much about this little place that I thought I give it a try. And for it to be done by liquid nitrogen, well, that was enough to convince me to go see it. They only have limited flavors. I stuck with the most original- Vanilla. :D The staff is pretty nice, and the owner herself was there. 

If you haven't gone here, you should at least give it a try. Ice cream are from scratch and you can see it made right before your eyes with liquid nitrogen. That's a pretty geeky way to make ice cream, and that's a plus in my book.
author: Leena N.

description: Very good ice cream made in front of you, from scratch! Order anything and you will be surprised by not only the taste but also the texture!
author: Ramoun M.

description:
Today Smitten gets a 5 from me - partly because of the fresh quality and smooth and creamy consistency and partly because I've always had really nice servers who always have a smile for me. For such small, hipster hangout (& I've seen some reviewers have gotten attitude there) I've always had a really positive customer experience. I'm a neighborhood local so I'm there enough...

Unfortunately, I can't talk about many flavors because I haven't been able to move past sea salt caramel with tcho chocolate. Other flavors on the board look good and enticing...then I get to the counter, the person on the other side smiles and no matter what I was thinking my mouth automatically responds with,"salted caramel and tcho chocolate please". Something in brain says, "Really? Again?" and I realize this is probably why I keep coming back. I'm a creature of habit. That's probably why I always get a smile...they can see the addict coming a mile away. 

So I sit outside on Octavia Boulevard, watch people with their dogs, hang out on a bench and love my neighborhood. It's just what we needed, a really quality, yummy ice cream place. Everything is good in my world.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Totally smitten :)
The vanilla with almond brittle was so good and so creamy. Loved it. The small size was just enough.
Mom tried the Quince flavor and that was pretty good as well. The Pizelle cone I didn't like so much because I was thinking it was going to be a waffle cone but it is more like a lemon wafer cookie cone.

Overall, love the concept and how your ice cream is made to order! :)
author: Angela D.

description: Great little ice cream stand in the heart of hayes valley. Their liquid nitrogen cooled ice cream is fun to watch them make and even better tasting! My creamy early grey with chocolate chips scoop was obviously made with care and quality ingredients.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Smitten is the perfect name for this place because everything about it will make you feel just that! As soon as I stepped in, I was taken away by the set-up and music. It had a chill old school but modern SF feel. It's small so it felt kind of homey to me. 

My friend ordered the earl grey tea with chocolate chips and it was pretty good! I like the mix of chocolate and earl grey tea...it wasn't too sweet but had an interesting array of flavors. 

I got the tcho chocolate - if you love creamy chocolate, this is your pick. It was pretty much your simple chocolate ice cream but so well made. 

It's also fun to watch them make your ice cream. It really does taste fresh! The ice cream isn't too unique or outstanding, but the overall ambiance and environment was 5 stars worthy. I would love to come here again!
author: Stephanie B.

description:
I wish I lived in San Fran just so that I could eat Smitten Ice Cream everyday ! 

The texture is unbeatable and soooo creamy!
author: Jen L.

description:
This is my favorite ice cream shop in the city. The ice cream is made via a special patented machine, called the Kelvin machine. Look it up! It's pretty cool! The ingredients are simple and all natural. There are usually four flavors you can choose from--you can only choose one flavor, unless you wanted to buy multiple cups/cones. They make your ice cream on the spot, and you get to watch the awesome Kelvin machines at work with the dry ice smoke flowing from the bowl.

The ice cream texture is godly. It's the most amazing ice cream I've ever had. I need to find a way to get my hands on one of those machines!

My favorite flavor so far has been the Meyer Lemon. Go!
author: Vera W.

description:
sweet corn ice cream- it's like a mild corny vanilla ice cream. cool and light with a berry topping.

only 4 flavors a day! it's in a small street. so be warned about trying to park.

next time i will try the chocolate flavor!

folks are nice here with loud music!
author: Jeff K.

description: Great location, great service and cool set up. The ice cream is creamy and tastes like it has fresh ingredients...oh and the waffle come is amazing.
author: Hela M.

description: Awesome..the cold nitrogen eliminates any detectable crystallization in the ice cream as it is made it on the spot in front of your eyes, not made somewhere else and shipped in - this keeps the ice cream very smooth...chocolate with the spicy caramel topping is unforgettable.
author: Robert B.

description:
I love ice cream and Smitten definitely hits the spot! The ice cream is good but I think what draws people to visit is the unique way they make the ice cream. It's a fun spot to take friends who are visiting to see something a little different. This location is also located next to a ton of food carts and shopping so there isn't a shortage of things to do in the area. 

Beware that the ice cream is really rich so I don't recommend getting more than I've scoop at once unless you have a really strong sweet tooth
author: Aileen C.

description: The salted caramel ice cream is tasty (not as good as bi-rite). But minus 1-star for the blatant shilling for PayPal. If they're getting money to push PayPal's service, I would hope it would subsidize the ice cream ($5/scoop). If they're not getting paid then I'd recommend removing the signage and not asking every customer if they want to pay with PayPal. Just sayin'
author: David B.

description:
As a fan of David Lebovitz, it was my destiny to go to Smitten and take my Food Science major cousin and her sister with me for some experimental tasting. 

While, there are no tastings, the meyer lemon caramel is more sugar than meyer lemon, and the ice cream isn't cheap, it's definitely worth a taste to experience the difference between liquid nitrogen ice cream and traditionally made ice cream. The vanilla reminded me almost of Christina L.'s lovely homemade ice cream except more smooth. However, both the TCHO chocolate and vanilla were super sweet, definitely leaving you craving a glass of water after eating your ice cream. 

Maybe if I'm in Hayes Valley again or I see a pistachio flavor, I might stop by, but this place didn't leave me quite craving for more. 

PS - For those who like dogs, it's totally worth it to grab your ice cream to go and then walk across the street to the dog park and watch them doggies frolicking around.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
THIS PLACE IS SOOOOO BOMB! 
i was introduced to this place by a friend and we had a hard time finding parking, but damn was it worth it!! 

i don't eat ice cream all the time but i would be willing to change that if i lived closer to a smitten! the seasonal mint flavor was definitely my favourite. The guys there were super friendly and cute, btw.
author: Ivan E.

description:
Cuteness overload! Everything about this place is just so darn cute! I do wish they had more ice cream flavors. The TCHO chocolate is absolutely overwhelming. Even as a chocolate lover, this one was way too chocolatey for me. Never thought that was possible. I wish they had more flavors served per day but I understand, they like to keep it simple and also keep in tune with local ingredients that are in season.
I've also tried their vegan bars which were super sweet and overly coconuty. I was warned that they use coconut milk.

Not my favorite ice cream place but the novelty of having ice cream made right in front of you keeps me coming back. Plus, it's just so cute!
author: Allison M.

description: Best salted caramel ice cream I've ever had! The store is small but the line moved very, very quickly. Staff were very friendly and the selection of flavors was very  unique. Definitely coming back.
author: Connie K.

description:
Smitten has such a cute setup!

I wanted to like Smitten cuz they use seasonal ingredients to make their ice cream.. but it wasn't that meant to be. We tried their olive oil w/ lavender shortbread ice cream ... kiddie size (about $3.50). Olive oil was too cloying and didn't get much of the lavender shortbread flavor. They have other flavors like salted caramel and tcho chocolate .. total of about 5 flavors. I may have to come back in spring when they have their strawberry balsamic flavor!! 

I do like that they accept credit cards though.. we were out of cash .. spent last bit at the nearby blue bottle haha
author: Mimi C.

description: pretty basic flavors, I'd like to see more creative stuff on the menu such as shiitake-wasabi or roasted brokkoli-garlic or bacon cones.
author: Mary L.

description: The ice cream was good. Unsure if I would suggest this place to visit. There was a long line, it's a bit pricey and the ice cream taste good but I don't know if it was with the wait and price
author: Kalani B.

description:
5 Stars because I did not have to pay for the ice cream. It would be 3 if I had to pay. 

The hype of having the freshest ice cream is appreciated. I gave my cousin's a lesson on liquid nitrogen. It's not toxic, has low very low boiling point, and the quick freeze decreases ice crystals that takes away from the flavor. 

We had the sweet corn and the salted caramel. I liked the corn better because it tasted very natural. I was gonna to teach my cousin how corn is very sweet and people make corn jelly from used corn husks back in the day. And stuff about corn syrup. But, I didnt want to be a jerk. Just enjoy the ice cream and shut up.
author: Chris L.

description:
I was checking out Biergarten and I saw Smitten Ice Cream. It Screams San Francisco. 

The whole proxy project is a great idea, and Smitten being a pat of that is awesome.

Like other reviews here I would say the price is a bit much and you really are paying for the gimmick of the liquid nitrogen. Cool Idea, and def a place to check out and take a picture of to post on instagram or facebook.

I had a vanilla ice cream and it was good. Not mind blowing, but above average. The seasonality and rotation of flavors would make me come back to try out other flavors besides a basic vanilla.

I would come back again but I wouldn't go out of my way to check it out. And I wouldn't come back everytime I was in the area. There would have to be a flavor on the board I really want to try or a friend who really wants t check it out

Basically, it's a great idea and I hope it sticks around, but there are definitely more bang for your buck ice cream places in San Francisco.
author: Glenn M.

description:
Okay, let's keep this in perspective. If you're more concerned about quantity over quality, you will not be Smitten. On the other hand, if you understand the concept of getting what you pay for, and you love great quality ice cream, you will be Smitten.

We had two scoops of the Salted Caramel and TCHO Chocolate with the recommended accompliments of whipped cream and Coconut Brittle Pecan Brittle. Get the brittles, skip the whipped cream! You simply don't need it!

We ordered ours in cups. The ice cream melts quickly and the cup makes it easier to "drink" the melt. The flavors we tasted were yummylicious. While limited, it's better to make a few things well and than a lot of things poorly. 

We saw one young teen squeeze his cone a bit too hard and it broke, the top part with all of his ice cream hit the sidewalk while he was left holding the bottom part of the cone. When dad showed the "kelvinator" the broken cone, a replacement cone was on its way. Kudo's to the friendly staff. Everyone appeared to enjoy their job and gave outstanding service!
author: Dexter D.

description:
I enjoyed the experience and "show" of Smitten. Is it the best ice cream spot in San Francisco? Definitely not. But as a food experience it's quite a memorable one. I felt like I was eating something created from a Nickelodeon TV show. Slime Time!

Smitten is a tiny, little, hip ice creamery open-faced kiosk. There's one liquid nitrogen ice cream machine per flavor, with about four-six flavors going at the same time. There are toppings to be added after the ice cream has been created for additional charge. They don't mix flavors or serve two flavors together, but I guess you can order two orders and smash them together. Everything is made to order. This is half the fun. Including the hipsters who look like they want to punch you in the throat.

I had the lemon meyer ginger snap cookie ice cream. I love the lemony flavor. The standout yum factor was from the still crispy ginger snap cookie crumbs. Since the liquid nitrogen creates the ice cream so fast the cookie crumbs don't have enough time to sog up. I'm on the fence about the consistency and mouthfeel of the ice cream. Even though it's a creamy consistency, it reminds me of cake batter or buttercream frosting. It's strangely almost too rich. Like butter. I still really enjoyed the flavor and the ginger snap cookie crumbs kept me happy.

___

A fun ice cream experience. The best ice cream? Nope. Still good. Keep your expectations in check and you'll do fine.
author: Michael H.

description: Seriously this ice cream lives up to it's name -- you will be 'smitten' by it. I've had the chocolate and squash blossom flavors and both are delicious, but the chocolate is my all time favorite and is probably the best I've ever had. The waffle cones are super delicious as well and definitely taste like a really yummy sugar cookie!
author: Vanessa G.

description:
I am attracted by the science behind making this ice cream! They say the idea is freezing ice cream at super low temperatures with liquid nitrogen could create a smoother product in faster time. Theres something about less ice crystals in the ice cream making the ice cream texture feel smoother. Each scoop is made to order, therefore no emulsifiers and preservatives are added creating an ice cream that does not compromise taste for shelf life.

Enough of the geek talk, lets talk about the ice cream! They have their usual vanilla and chocolate, 1 flavor that alternates weekly (I think) and 1 flavor that changes monthly, and that is their seasonal flavor. My favorite seasonal flavor is the Earl Grey with Milk Chocolate served in February! The chocolate they use are from TCHO, a local chocolate factory that I got a free tour when they were still in San Francisco by the pier. All of their ingredients are advertised as locally sourced which is great. Earl Grey with Milk Chocolate tastes like eating a cup of creamy Earl Grey tea with a bar of dark chocolate, but in ice cream form! So good. My 2nd favorite is the Olive Oil with Lavender Shortbread which is served in June. You'd think olive oil in ice cream is freaky? I had this kind of concoction the first time in a restaurant called Beretta and it blew my mind. Its hard to explain, but the olive oil brought out the fragrance and creaminess in the ice cream and the ice cream brought out the richness of the olive oil. So weird how foods like that can go so well together! My 3rd favorite is one of their weekly flavors that sometimes disappear and that is the Mint Chip! Its made with fresh spearmint leaves infused into the cream with a light green color and TCHO chocolate chips churned in! Your breath will smell so fresh for the rest of the day after eating this one. I love it! I come here often because I work closeby and its a next to a nice park where you can enjoy your ice cream.
author: Janny S.

description:
3.5 stars
this is was nice experience to have. i never knew that smitten makes their own ice cream on site, right in front of you. i opted for the honey nectarine ice cream while my friend chose the mint chocolate chip. both were unexpectedly good. i loved teh honey nectarine because there were chunks of real, sweet nectarines inside and honey was drizzled on top for added sweetness. the mint chocolate chip was different from the ones you get at the grocery store or any other place. real mint was used to flavor the ice cream, so it was like a fresh mint explosion in your mouth. both were tasty, but i wouldn't say its the best ice cream i've ever had. As a side note, the ice cream melts pretty fast even in cold weather. =( its just a great experience to see how they make their ice cream!
author: Stella J.

description:
I'm conflicted. I really wanted to give it a 5 star, high five rating.

But I dont know. I really dont know. It was great, but price tag and quality is not the best. Taste wise, I had TCHO chocolate which was THE best chocolate ice cream I've ever had. However, I feel like...emphasis on feel, the options here are very limited.  And maybe that is because they make the ice cream in front of your face. 

Ahhh I will come back again and hopefully I can give you an extra star. But as for now, its 4.8 stars, but not quite 5 stars. Love yall, please support Smitten though, awesome awesome people and ice cream.
author: Paul K.

description:
I got the vanilla with malt syrup, and it changed my life. I had no idea fresh made ice cream could taste so good! I have no regrets about standing for 30 minutes in the line that wrapped around the store.

Others are saying it's pricy, but that's seriously no concern when the cost of a cup is less than the cost of a sandwich.

I'll be back.
author: Philihp B.

description: Love this place and great to take visitors. It can definitely get busy but worth the wait. Ice cream is homemade right in front of you and is so creamy. Last time I came, the other day, my ice cream seemed to take forever. Like 15 minutes. Anyway they knew it must've been a long wait and upon getting my ice cream he immediately gave me a $2 off coupon for next time and said sorry for the wait. Great service and will continents come back
author: Emily F.

description:
The ice cream here is pretty delicious. I have tried both the Salty Caramel and the Rhubarb Crisp (seasonal flavor). I like the Rhubarb crisp a lot since it's different.

The ice cream is made in front of you by these small machines that churn and make ice cream with liquid nitrogen. If you order a popular flavor, you might have to wait while the ice cream is being made but the wait shouldn't be more than 10-15 minutes. Since the ice cream is made with liquid nitrogen, the ice crystals formed are apparently smaller than other ice cream therefore, making it smoother/creamier. I honestly can't tell the difference but still find it delicious!

The ice cream shop is located in a shipping container in the middle of Patricia's Green in Hayes Valley. There can be an obscenely long line at times, so I would only go if the line is short enough. The ice cream is good, but it's not super special that I'd wait 30 min in line for.
author: Lillian C.

description:
I had been wanting to try Smitten for a while as the concept sounded pretty cool. They had mint chocolate chip which is my favorite kind so I ordered that. I was all prepped to watch then make it right in front of me but the guy simply handed it over. I asked why it wasn't 'made to order' and he said he had some from the last batch. 

The ice cream itself was good and fresh tasting but I paid $5 for the entire experience!
author: Julia W.

description:
Bottom line at the top: my favorite ice cream in SF, and the better of two liquid nitrogen ice creams I've tried. It isn't cold at all and is very creamy so no excuses not to try it :) 
--
YUM. We originally started with a vanilla and salted caramel but loved them so much we got a brown sugar as well. For toppings we had the tcho chocolate sauce, fresh whipped cream, almond brittle, chocolate crispies, and toasted walnuts. 

The tcho chocolate sauce and almond brittle were definitely the topping winners, and the brown sugar was our favorite flavor of ice cream. They were having some machine issues and initially warned us it might be a twenty minute wait but it was super quick only took five.
author: Dahlia S.

description: I love this area of San Francisco. It is always sunny and plenty of people enjoying the day. I was amazed by the way Smitten made their ice cream. I had the Strawberry Vinegar ice cream. A bit pricey, but you get what you pay for, right? The consistency of the ice cream is very smooth and instantaneously melted in my mouth. The sweetness of the strawberry ice cream paired with a hint of vinegar is so delicious! At first I thought, "vinegar in ice cream, a bit weird?!" Boy, I was wrong! The best concoctions are always the weird ones at first. It was also an enjoyable experience since I was able to see firsthand on how it was made.
author: Karla Marie D.

description: Got the earl gray ice cream with chocolate chips, and topped it with their "pairings" of sliced almonds and brown sugar caramel. IT WAS REALLY GOOD! The ice cream was amazing, and the brown sugar caramel sauce was great (although they were a little stingy with it!). However, it was $7.50, which is just crazy. Great ice cream, but unnecessary for me to go again and spend that much money.
author: Melissa G.

description: The best thing about this place is their usage of liquid nitrogen to make their ice cream. However, the ice cream is pretty pricey but the fresh ingredients they use make it worth it. I had a double scoop of their seasonal nectarine ice cream in a waffle cone and it was the most rich and creamy ice cream that I have ever had. There were bits of nectarine and a thick nectarine syrup on top. The waffle cone was crunchy and delicious. Although it cost extra for it, I definitely say it's a must have with their ice cream.
author: Melanie H.

description:
I'm smitten with Smitten. (Sorry, too easy). Bread & butter ice cream with chunks of shortbread and topped with TCHO chocolate. 

I want it again, and again, and again. Don't stop.
author: Stan W.

description:
Oh, yes. I AM smitten..

That TCHO chocolate is HEAVEN; the pistachio brittle compliments it soooo very well. I had a bite or two of my friend's and I almost diiiiied. And I'm not that big on chocolate ice-cream. This one was a TRUE winner.

Honey-nectarine. Very fresh. Light and simple.

The Mint with TCHO chocolate chips was pretty refreshing. Tasted kind of like a mojito-type of mixture of ice-cream. My burps were very minty fresh, might I add! Lol. Very creamy and smoooooove. Hahah. Try it folks!

All I know is that the CHOCOLATE is probably my preferred choice, tho. But I still want to try the vanilla, as well.
author: Kim T.

description:
Wow another new ice cream place in the city to get to try!  My friend mentioned Smitten while we were walking in Hayes Valley, and we decided to go but I had no idea what a treat was in store.  

We waited in a line that went out the door, but it moved fast.  The only annoying part was the full menu with toppings/ice cream options is a chalkboard at the front of the line, so we stood around and then had to decide really fast what to order.  But they only have 3 flavors available so it wasn't that hard to decide. :)

It was a little expensive ($5.15 for a small scoop!) but a fun experience and the texture and taste was delicious.  They make the ice cream on the spot and you get to watch the machines in action.  And they make all their own toppings there as well.  Plus the store is built out of old shipping crates, and has a greatly unique look and feel to it.

Smitten is great, which is obvious by its line out the door even in our San Franciscan perpetual winter/spring-mashup.

Also I should mention the rose flavored ice cream was unique and delicious, I'm not sure if they'll have it again but if they do I would recommend it!
author: Gabrielle L.

description:
seriously, 5 bucks for a small? i was a little disappointed after i had quite a few friends rave about it. We went on a day where they had vanilla, Tcho chocolate, mint chocolate and moon pie. I don't know about you but i think those are some pretty basic ice creams. I know they do some really creative ones so i'll need to return at some point to make a full assessment. My ice cream was also melting as i got it so would have been nicer if it were actually cold. 

Pluses for the place itself, very cute and love that they use nitrogen and you can see everything being made. The moon pie was good and the mint actually tasted like real mint which is a refreshing change from store bought ice cream. Worth a try if you are around the area but don't think it deserves the hype
author: sasha h.

description:
I was so sure that I would get 4-5 flavors here, since I got super excited when I found out we were going to come here. What the F is nitrogen ice cream? Sounds awesome! And so we came =) Unfortunately, you can only pick one flavor. But they allow for you to trade it up if you're not happy with it.

We each ordered one flavor: the vanilla, sweet corn (special), and the salted caramel (special). Yes, they have 2 or so specials every couple of weeks, so it is unfortunate that y'all won't be able to taste either one of those for a while. 

I tried some of my friend's vanilla, and it was smooth and creamy. But I definitely did not regret ordering my salted caramel, and the sweet corn for my other friend. Both of these special flavors were amazing. The sweet corn was unique, but spot on. Not your typical ice cream flavor, but pretty much just as good as the delicious salted caramel w/ cocoa nibs. Mmmmm...

Love supporting small yet amazing businesses like these. Will be back!
author: Elaine H.

description:
It's ok. But cool concept.

All their ice cream r made to order so it's fresh. But $4.75 for a small? Kinda pricey
author: Carol Y.

description:
Early grey with chocolate chips!! Simply amazing!!! I've tried other places where they make ice cream using liquid nitrogen, but this place takes first hands down! The ice cream is creamy but it's not err powering. Earl grey was light and refreshing and I really enjoyed the chocolate chunks! The line gets long but it's definitely worth the wait! I can't wait to go back and try their other flavors :) worth going even when it's cold out!! Plus take it to the park and enjoy!

Came back for round 2! This time I tried the salted caramel!! It's sweet, a bit too sweet for me but luckily I still had earl grey to fall back on! Even on a cold day, the line for Smitten was longggg. Worth the wait!
author: Stephanie C.

description: They make the ice cream after you order! So fun to watch and even better to eat. Great concept, great location, seemingly better than Bi-Rite.
author: Justin R.

description:
Call me a regular 'ole prole, but really, no ice cream is worth this wait. I live across the street and I've been here in rain and snow, crowd and no. The usual story is a dining buddy has never been to Smitten, and just has to try it. The novelty is watching the old fashioned (and typically jamming) mixers make your ice cream batch right in front of you with liquid nitrogen.

But come on, you do realize that you could make ice cream at home with a bag of ice and vanilla mix -- it's the classic jr high science experiment. But the process is slow and non-scalable, and I don't mind that a company like Ben and Jerry's has a bigger version of this that I can't see.

I digress.

There is one redeeming factor: They have Tcho (pronounced 'cho') ice cream popsicles. This is my regular -- to enjoy a soft Tcho ice cream popsicle as my rookie companion fights their way through a stomachache of caramel-nutted-vanilla-bean.

All in all, one of the better of the 'hyped up' ice cream parlors in SF, and a fun spot for your date since it's on the border of a cool little park you can walk around. The crazy metal sculpture in the middle of the park makes for good conversation too.
author: Christophe C.

description: Absolutely unique Ice Cream stand! I love the fact that they make live ice cream in front of the customers but I'm certainly not satisfied to an overpriced mediocre-taste organic ice cream. Pretty expensive and overrated for a small amount of ice cream.
author: Dan Mark D.

description:
Delicious ice cream -- but kind of rude service. I was waiting for a while, so I asked a barrista with a hipster moustache named Michael -- who also not entirely appropriately flirted with one of my female companions -- and he responded in an completely unnecessarily sarcastic and unfriendly manner.

Tasty ice cream, but not worth the attitude.
author: Eric T.

description: So unique! The shop's aesthetic appeal (it was made out of those tin storage trailers) and the way the ice cream is made... It's a must try! Get the salted caramel... It's so awesome haha
author: Caitlin L.

description: Nectarine + cream + liquid nitrogen = great ice cream.
author: Carlos F.

description:
Four stars for novelty! This is a great experience; however, not somewhere I would frequent. Hence, no five stars.

They use liquid nitrogen to make the ice cream. It's a cool process that you get to watch while you wait. They only have a handful of flavors and they're usually classic flavors with a more natural twist. 

I had the mint ice cream and was so surprised! It tasted like it was made with real mint leaves. I actually prefer the flavor of traditional mint, but this was a neat experience for my taste buds. I would definitely recommend this to friends or family visiting the area, who might be looking for a fun place to do dessert. 

It would be great for a date!
author: Joel A.

description:
Oooh...There is another ice cream store in SF? Tell me more. Tell me more. They patented the idea of making ice cream with dry ice! Whaaatt? 

{Key things to remember}
-Located next to a park/playground (Look for a long line)
-4 sizes from kiddie to large (Take a glance here: http://tinyurl.com/7z8lekq) 
-Each scoop is made from scratch
-Use of natural ingredients  
-No more frequent paper stamp cards (Download the stamp card app when you are at the store) 
-Store hours: 12 - 9 PM every day and 'til 10 PM on Fridays & Saturdays
-Flavors change each season 
I enjoyed their tasty flavors of:  TCHO chocolate, 5 spiced banana, ginger, and vanilla. 

I love the genius idea and quality of what they serve, but the only thing that makes me think twice before consuming is the price of their ice cream.  It is a bit steep for my palette. 

I would definitely visit this twirly little ice cream store again because I love ice cream that is poured along with liquid nitrogen! 

Happy Yelping!
author: Deborah C.

description:
OH! The mint flavored icecream is not your average mint chip! The mint flavor is more like a fresh herb making it refreshing like a mojito but not really. Personally, i LOVED it that way but the chocolate chips are really hard and dark chocolate, so it overpowers the wonders of the the mint icecream base. Theres SO much of the chocolate chip that its not likely worth trying to pick out. Over all, i did like this one, i just wish i could have the chocolate chips on the side.  But there is no customization allowed.

I had the chocolate one. My first reaction.... it was like eating the center of a chocolate truffle..... it was thick and extremely rich. It didnt seem like icecream to me for the longest time. I even flipped my cup and spoon upside down and it didnt fall out or drip. dont get me wrong, it was delicious, i LOVE chocolate. But consider yourself warned if youve read my review, its super RICH in my opinion. Enjoy :D
author: Jenny L.

description: Good ice cream.  Very creamy and smooth.  However, only special thing about it is the idea of using liquid nitrogen for the ice cream, and that you can watch your ice cream being churned in front of you.  And it's too bad there's such a limited menu.
author: Karen L.

description:
The made to order ice cream concept is really neat, and watching the smoke from the liquid nitrogen wafting about is somehow fascinating even though I'm certain most folks has seen such thing before.  Quality of ice cream is top notch as well, but my 3 stars is mostly for the flavor I tried, which is probably 80% of the enjoyment factor of ice cream eating, right?

I ordered the tangerine flavor, excited to try something so unique.  Of course, the ice cream machine for the tangerine flavor breaks and I have to order another flavor.  Went for the tried and true mint chip.  The fresh mint made the ice cream taste like a mint mojito, which made me wish I ordered the chocolate instead.  In spite of this botched first attempt at Smitten, I would come back to sample the other flavors.
author: Thi D.

description:
Good novelty ice cream - worth going here once, or bringing your tourist friends, to see the liquid nitrogen cloud coming out of the ice cream machines.

However, this really is just novelty. The ice cream is expensive, and you can only order ONE flavor, regardless of the size. Boo. =(

Only 4 flavors to choose from.

As someone who lives right by this ice cream shop and wants to eat ice cream daily, I wish ANY other ice cream shop would open up instead. But for everyone else, I can see why this shop is worth visiting occasionally.

Tip: Check out Loving Cup - fro-yo place a block away. I prefer that place for the selection in flavors =)
author: Grace K.

description:
Choc ful o' mint sundae. We ordered this on a cone, so the whip cream and Krispy tcho treats came in cups with our come off I've cream. 

Chocolate sauce, OK. Could have done without. 
Krispy tcho treats great and crunchy! 
Ice cream crazy fresh, mint chocolate chip, soft and creamy. and fun to watch them making it. Wish you had a locale in the peninsula! 

Downside.... Everything with their ipads, they forgot to do or order! There were folks ordering and got their desserts immediately... We had to ask where ours was and since I didn't have a receipt he didn't believe me! Um hello?! Anyway after a few minutes and cashier saying, oh yah she did pay 11 dollars, we got our ice cream.
author: Judy N.

description:
'Scream:
Small (4 oz.) is $4.75 with fudge toppings an extra $0.50.

4 flavors available at a time: Today's were
Classic Vanilla, TCHO Chocolate, Apple Crisp and Salted Caramel.
+Salted Caramel- opted for this one with a TCHO chocolate sauce on top for $0.50 extra. It was a little too salty for my taste although the chocolate sauce was amazing and I wish they had put a little more on it.

Service:
The girl at the register was super sweet and friendly. She explained that used frozen liquid nitrogen to freeze the cream into ice cream ( i think?) so they don't have samples.

Ambience:
It's a stand alone shack thing in the middle of Hayes valley with a long bench inside (no table) to sit on. 

-Hungry Hungry Pongy
author: Sangita A.

description:
I have been here twice already!!! I love their special flavors! I got the earl tea last time and i just tried their nectarine flavor!!!!!!! AHH SO GOOD esp w/ the real bits of fruit in it! The wait wasn't that long since it was a cold day. :) But that didn't stop people from swinging by for a sweet treat. I still have to try the strawberry basil/sweet corn one day.. on the right day/month. :(

Not a huge fan of fresh mint, but all my friends go gaga for it. It does taste like you're eating a bushel of mint leaves!
author: Jenna L.

description:
Huge fan.  

Came on a Saturday night.  Yes it's packed, and there's a good reason why.  It's amazing.  

I had the mint chip.  It tastes like real mint.  Like from the garden.  Like the aftertaste reminded me of mojitos, minus the rum. 

So good.  Highly recommend!
author: Sarah F.

description:
Liquid Nitrogen Ice Cream in the H.V.?

Yes please, they could take anything (even plain old vanilla) and make it creamy and delightful again in one full swoop.

I have yet to go to Creamistry (Irvine), Chocolate Chair (Koreatown, Los Angeles) or Ice Cream Lab (Beverly Hills, Los Angeles), to make an accurate comparison between the L.N. Creameries.

However for a first impression on the alternative approach, this place has certainly bitten me with affection.

The most valuable ice cream of this mini creamery would have to go to the Strawberry Balsamic combo. Bunches of strawberries spread on your tongue like a summer harvest and  surreptitiously the balsamic flavor creeps on you like the overly attached girlfriend you can only get in the suburbs. 

The runner up goes to plain vanilla with malted caramel (adding for just enough stickiness even spider man could handle it). if you want to go the chocolatey distance adding some Tcho Chocolate never hurt anyone. Another rule of thumb, if you aren't an ice cream (or chemistry) expert, eat this quick before mother nature steals this crafty treat right under your nose (evaporation is king). 

The only con with this place is, I wish they had more flavors than three at any given time. However given their popularity and possibility of consistency, that could change in the near future.

Given all the other small neighborhood attractions (Straw, Chantel Guillon, Suppenkuche and more). I would say this place is right up anyone's alley, whether as a detour or a premiere destination spot. Cheers, 3.5 rounded up to 4 for a solid first impression.
author: Ryan M.

description:
I don't get the hype. Mitchels for instance is a much better place compared to this one.
I was very excited and drove all the way from Millbrae. Skipped the dessert at our favorite restaurant after reading all the reviews.
Meeh, nothing special. Big deal, they use liquid nitrogen, and...and that's it. nothing else to add to that. regular, OVERPRICED ice cream.
author: jamila u.

description: Expensive given the size of the serving, but I do keep coming back for the fresh mint ice cream since it's true minced peppermint in a liquid-nitrogen-frozen cream base.  Entertaining machines and freezing process that you get to see live.  Also open late in a trendy, fun part of the city which gets points with me for being an option on a night out.
author: Anita T.

description:
We ventured here on Wednesday after a satisfying dinner @ OTG just around the corner. 

I was jone-sing some Asian type ice cream and settled for the Sweet Corn ice cream with blackberry. Seeing it being made is probably the highlight of the experience...the ice cream itself- texture wise, good. Flavor-wise, not very flavorful or yummy. A little disappointed. 
However, i'll have a huge tip: Coconut Brittle should be added to EVERYTHING and ANYTHING, regardless of the flavor you settle on- its that amazing. Also, waffle cones are the way to go
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
MY 100TH REVIEW!!! Do I get a cookie?? =)

It's safe to say I'm smitten with Smitten. (cheesiness intended.) I've tried the hyped ice cream places in SF- Bi-Rite, Humphrey Slocombe, Mitchell's, etc... but none have captivated me as much as Smitten.

Reasons for its awesomeness:
_Creativity. I love that they make your ice cream to order. It's like an upscale, amazing Coldstone's. (I cringe to include that name in my review because there is no comparison.) 
_Fresh and flavorful. I tried the Nectarine and the Vanilla with cocoa nib pralines, which was suggested on the menu. The nectarines were super fresh (well, what do you expect when they probably threw in fresh chopped fruit!) The cocoa nibs were my favorite sweet in a long time- roughly chopped, crunchy, a shot of intense bittersweet chocolate, and some nutty flavor too. YUM!!
_Cool factor- I really like watching the liquid nitrogen. It satisfies my inner molecular gastronomy side. I feel like a kid at the exploratorium.

Possible avenues for improvement:
_Price- considering each cup is made to order, not that pricey... but cheaper=always better. The portions are not that big.
_More mix-ins. Nectarines would be great with some caramel or toffee or brown sugar bits. Chocolate pieces would go well too with some of the other flavors.
author: Cathy S.

description:
Service was just amazeballs :) And obviously the liquid nitrogenized ice cream too! 

I ordered a small salted caramel + tcho chips. Sure enough, a crowd was gathering by then, so I tried to keep an ear out for when they called my order. My 2 other girlfriends got their ice creams after a relatively short wait but mine never came. 

At one point, I thought my sc +tc order was ready, but some other person took it before I could claim it was mine. The Smitten staff saw the confusion and quickly UPGRADED my order to a large... with extra tcho chips might I add :) I was so touched! 

Another reason for their amazeballs service is because one of my girlfriends dropped the top scoop of her ice cream by accident, and the Smitten staff quickly made her a brand new order of her maple butternut squash + cinnamon short bread topping ice cream. 

Such kind staff .... I wish I lived in San Fran!
author: Da Hee H.

description:
I've had LN ice cream a few times before, I've even made some. The ice cream here has the characteristic smoothness and density that comes from the flash freeze. The mixing machine looks really cool and does an excellent job (anyone know where to buy one?). Unfortunately, they seem to be banking off the novelty of the method because the cream mixes they put into the machine are not up to par. 

The salted caramel was too sweet and lacked the depth of flavor found at bi-rite and lush, while the  lemon gingersnap had an unpleasant oily mouthfeel (almost like it had been overchurned, seemingly impossible for liquid nitrogen ice cream). It also lacked substantial lemon or gingersnap flavor. 

All in all, more flash than substance and for $6/two scoops, I expected both.
author: Ty Y.

description:
Another trendy, gourmet ice cream spot in the city!

Had the salted caramel & the bf had the creamy vanilla. It's been ages since I've had Bi-Rite's salted caramel, so I can't compare... but Smitten's was deeelish. The creamy vanilla was VERY creamy, so it was nice to switch off with my boyfriend so that I wouldn't get tired of having the same flavor.

It's fun watching them make the ice cream and they have various toppings and the flavors change, so it's sure to be a new & enjoyable trip every time!
author: Miss H.

description:
I tried the Olive Oil with Lavender Shortbread with brown sugar caramel sauce topping. It was delicious! The flavor is definitely unique. I wish there were more unique flavors. I will definitely be back!

The ice creams are made with liquid nitrogen. I enjoyed watching them make the ice cream in front of me. I wish there was a place like this in NYC!
author: Samantha K.

description: If you like creamy delicious ice cream, this is the place for you. Ice cream made with liquid nitrogen in a container store, what else could you ask for? I've tried most of their flavors; salted caramel is my fav, vanilla is awesome and chocolate is rich, rich, rich. Fun spot if you have a cold sweet tooth.
author: Ennie L.

description: I want to give this place more stars because of the cute location/stand idea and the unique way they make their ice cream (on the spot no less). But unfortunately this isn't the ice cream spot for me. I got a small salted caramel with almond brittle for about $5, and had no more than 10 little spoonfuls before I had to toss the whole thing out. It was just toooooo rich for me. I really wish they had a mini size or something, because then maybe I'd go back. Or maybe if I had 2 other people to share it with. But even a small is way too much, and kind of expensive too!
author: Kathy L.

description:
The idea was definetely cooler than the actual product.
They make your ice cream on the spot using liquid nitrogen ... it's pretty cool to watch with the smoky nitrogen coming out at you. The ordering system I must say is also pretty efficient and the layout of the shop is pretty innovative.

I ordered the TCHO mint chocolate flavor. I liked that it was acutally minty (as in the herb mint!) That is a rarity these days! For my taste, the ice cream was too soft ... I like some texture. It seemed kinda melty... meh! I tried some other flavors but they are all just average. Nice that they are using TCHO though. 

If you're in it for the taste, there are definetely manyyyyy other establishments in this city that can deliver better. 
If you're in the area... strolling hayes valley on a sunny afternoon... then yes, this is a good idea. I think its more of a one time experience.
author: Tim B.

description: I'm a scientist, so I would have loved this ice cream solely based on the liquid nitrogen process the founder/inventor developed to make individual servings on the spot. Of course, that means a line because it takes awhile to freeze up your ice cream on the spot. Home made cones, full-fatted but not too sweet. The quality/richness is very similar to Coldstone, except Smitten only offers 3 flavor a night.
author: MJ L.

description: Best and freshest ice cream I've ever had in my life! Would rate the ice cream (had the crème fraîche with pear caramel sauce) an A+ but the overall value as a B+/A-. It really was a bit pricey! Love the storage container aspect. Haha. Definitely something I look forward to every time I'm in Hayes Valley. :)
author: Vivian T.

description: YUMMM! An icy textured ice cream that's individually made for you and with ever changing classics, this is a great day treat stop on a long bike ride or for sitting in the park.
author: Regina D.

description:
Really? 
Ever drop a scoop of ice-cream behind your freezer and then never clean it up, then you will know what this place smells like. 
I had the vanilla, tasted ok but it gave me diarrhea all night. Save yourself $5 and go to walgreens and buy some Hagen daz and you won't have it wait in a long line just to try and look kool with your overpriced ice cream.
author: K. K.

description:
Smitten's one of those places you hear about when you move to SF, so even though I'd had liquid nitrogen ice cream before (in the course of reporting a story :), I still wanted to try it. 

Side note: I went on a Saturday and somehow there were only 3 flavors available: a basic vanilla, an olive oil-based one, and the salted caramel. You'd think on a Saturday they'd keep things stocked so they can have 4 flavors at all times. 

Anyway, I just got the classic vanilla and waited for my scoop. It was creamy and tasty, but at the end of the day...not as great as other LN ice cream I'd had before. Would I still return? Certainly. Especially with friends who haven't had it since the whole LN thing is a novelty. Is it something I'll rave about? Probs not. But that's okay. Not all ice cream can get 5 stars.
author: Rowena L.

description: It was really fun watching them make the ice cream and it definitely tasted fresher than regular ice cream shop ice cream. I had the mint and the cookie dough with pretzel and loved both flavors. The line also wasn't bad at all considering it is obviously a popular place and it was the Sunday night before Memorial Day
author: Jo S.

description:
Love the experience and looking at the ice cream made with liquid nitrogen.

Solid taste (quite dense, rather than soft gelato), the best part of the ice cream is that it doesn't melt easily due to the liquid nitrogen freeze.
author: Rebecca C.

description: Delicious!  So so so much colder than actual ice cream.  I know that sounds funny but the tip of my tongue took about 30 minutes to unfreeze after done.  Even the bird liked it!
author: Rena A.

description: Ah, the perfect spot for ice cream on a warm day in San Francisco. Plus, it's in a wonderful location in the middle of Hayes Valley with restaurants and shops galore! Yes, liquid nitrogen ice cream may be a trend, but there's no doubt their ice cream is top notch quality and taste. All of their flavors are delicious so you cannot go wrong. Happy ice cream eating!
author: Lauren L.

description:
HOW MUCH IS A CUSTOMER WORTH?

I like Smitten's ice cream.  It's a novel concept, and it tastes good.  Unfortunately, I'm rating their service one star.  My wife and I finished a late dinner, and realized we still had time to get to Smitten before they closed at 10 PM.  We jam down there within ten minutes and arrived at 9:59, only to see the door was already locked.  The side door was still open and we walked in, ready to put in our last minute order, and no other customers were in line.  The clerk says, "Sorry, we have to close at some time."  Wow.  We couldn't believe it.  

It got me to wondering, how much is a good customer worth over time?  We were probably going about three times a month, spending on average $12-15.  That's about one thousand dollars in two years.  It's sad.  That's money we won't be spending at Smitten anymore, just because they closed 1 minute early, and didn't appreciate loyal (ex-loyal now) customers who rushed to get there before they closed.
author: Ray C.

description:
June's seasonal flavor of the month

Olive Oil and Lavender Shortbread ice cream.

Da $hizzzzzzzznibble$

Ucking Fawsome

$tupendou$

Guaranteed to arouse all SF foodie types!

It is supposed to be better paired with almond brittle topping, which I passed up on. 

But by itself, is already quite sexcellent.

Ever try to take a whiff of the smoke coming out of the Kelvins while the people behind the counter are making the orders of ice cream? It's like amuse nez (not amuse bouche). Don't worry it's not like sniffing glue or anything.

This business is very successful in its own right and has found its SF fanbase.

However there are a few things that could push things to the next level.

- Rotate flavors more frequently. Look at Hong Kong's Lab Made Ice Cream
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sSm7-k6sLz8 in Tai Hang. Four flavors that rotate on a regular basis, from the wacky to the fusion to the Euro style to the Asian/HK style. Obnoxious hosts not included (especially the part where the male host is bagging on his co-host, the lady who looks like a dude, by exclaiming...."omg, you're ordering the peanut butter condensed milk toast ice cream, and your figure is already looking like THAT?", followed by his proclamation for liking the "peach and apricot greek yogurt" flavor because peach and apricot in written Chinese looks like a Japanese name, which reminds him of Japanese adult video actresses, then him remarking that his host is rather flat chested, but I digre$$. The male host even talks about the benefits of having new frequent flavors switch every 2 weeks, akin to being able to switch between different girlfriends. Then the importance of recycling the cups and spoons (which he then remarks his ugly cohost should be recycled too).

- Not that I am saying the flavors need to be wacked up, but what they have e.g. seasonal flavor of the month, is great...but hopefully there's a way to balance between not sticking with the classics all the time, and having only one flavor rotate once a month.

- Find a way to reduce making time (and thus reducing wait time).

And that's more or less it. Thanks Susy C for recommending this :-)
author: Ken K.

description:
YAY list
*awesome concept...who doesn't love liquid nitrogen?
*fun storefront

NAY list
*soft, mushy ice cream
*way too creamy, not noms
*long ass lines
*severely overpriced

I'm a nerd, so I'm all about science going mainstream ;)
But, I'm also a foodie and I am all about the taste!

Overall....good concept, bad ice cream.  Oh Smitten, I am so not smitten.  Mitchell's, Humphry Slocombe, Bi-rite Creamery, Thrifty/RiteAid....they are all yummier than you.
author: Susan L.

description:
I want to love this place. I really do. I live around the corner and I love ice cream. Sounds like the perfect match right?

Liquid nitrogen, schmiquid schmitrogen (that works right?). The process for making the ice cream is cool. Reminds me of some of my science experiments as a kid, but unfortunately it does not yield great ice cream. The texture is a little mushy, rather than creamy, and almost a little bit like toothpaste.

In terms of the flavor, I had the vanilla with olive oil. I learned that there is no reason olive oil should ever be on ice cream.. it simply does not work. That being said, the brittle was excellent and the workers there were uber friendly.

But the ice cream itself? Meh.
author: Andrew M.

description:
I loved my TCHO chocolate ice cream on a pizzelle cone topped with almond brittle. Hubby had the strawberry pink peppercorn.

Great concept where your ice cream is made to order with liquid nitrogen. 

Today they offered four different flavors which are posted on the chalkboard.  Order it plain or pair it with any number of toppings for an additional $0.25 each.

Two kiddie size scoops on pizzelle cones $8.00.
author: Shirley N.

description:
My boyfriend and I gave into the hype.. I remember when they used to just have their little wagon, strolling the park of Dolores. 

I got the chocolate with spicy caramel, and my boyfriend got the vanilla with caramel. If it's your first time, go with the smaller cup. I asked the lady about the sizes, I actually got a bigger size than I wanted, so make sure you ask about the sizes. And also go with your gut, try it plain if it's your first time so you can enjoy the ice cream without the overpowering sauces. The spicy caramel was too much for my taste, so I pretty much ate the chocolate ice cream around it. 

Is it  worth the wait? The some, yes. But it's probably better to go when there's no line. Plus, there's really great food around the area.
author: Jessica R.

description:
I don't know what type of crack everyone else is smoking but this place has mediocre ice cream at best and is totally OVERRATED!

This is based on the TCho 60% Chocolate, and the Plain Vanilla flavors.

PROS:
- The tech behind their ice cream making is pretty cool. (+1 star for the tech)

CONS:
- The consistency was mushy and soft. How do you fail the texture test when you're blasting the mix with -320 degree F liquid nitrogen?
- The TCho 60% chocolate had the same flavor as a Wendy's Frosty, which isn't bad if you're at Wendy's but this wasn't Wendy's. They also used a very high concentration of heavy cream (I make my own ice cream as a hobby), which made the ice cream super buttery and more Wendy's Frosty-like.
- The Plain Vanilla was super bland (not enough vanilla extract) and used too much regular milk to the point that it tasted like Skim Milk ice cream with a hint of Vanilla.
- I would rather eat ice cream from super overrated Humphry Slocombe than Smitten that's how meh it was.
- There was about a 30-40 minute wait but I guess that is unavoidable on a Sunday afternoon.

BOTTOM LINE:
- There are so many other places in SF that serve better ice cream it isn't even funny. Do yourself a favor and check out Mr. & Mrs. Misc., Mitchell's, or Bi-Rite if you want far better ice cream.
author: Alex P.

description:
In the heart of Hayes Valley, definitely worth a try if you're in the neighborhood!

This place is known for their liquid nitrogen ice cream making antics, which is a pretty cool concept and fun to see in person. The storefront isn't too big, but no worries for this grab and go type spot.

The ice cream here is great, I'm a big fan of the soft/creamy consistency that it brings (not sure how it all works, but I'm not complaining!) and just overall taste. They offer a few different flavors, but every time I've come here, I've gone with the vanilla (boring I know). They also have dark (TCHO) chocolate, and their seasonal flavors. You can throw on a variety of toppings too, that pair really well with your ice cream.

I'd recommend checking this place out if you ever find yourself kickin' it with hipsters and just plain hanging out in Hayes!
author: Jason T.

description:
Before this, I've only seen Ice Cream made with liquid nitrogen from my school "show" days where each department of the school does something cool to try to lure you into taking their classes.

Needless to say, this was a fantastic little store in the corner of the street, across a small park.
We ordered 3 different flavors: Mint Chocolate, Vanilla & Blood Orange.

Mint was so creamy and smooth, you can taste that the cream was infused with the mint probably overnight.  I do have to say, it made my breath smell really good for the remainder of the day.  If you're going to get it, I'd suggest getting a "small".  For me, it was too creamy to have the 2.5 scoops.

Vanilla was very good, it wasn't as creamy nor as sweet as the mint.  The flavor wasn't "punch in the face", but more like you have to savor it to taste the flavor.  I liked it very much.  If you're getting this one, go for the "regular".

Blood Orange was bordering sorbet(?) for me.  It was very sweet, very sugary and very "punch in the face" flavorful.  I'd suggest getting "small" for this as well.  It was very tasty and flavorful, but too sweet for me to eat too much.
author: Julie L.

description:
Walking around HV before dinner, I said "We have to stop here after dinner," and I'm glad we followed through on that decree. 

The novelty of *how* they make the ice cream aside, the end product is just fantastic. It's the smoothest, creamiest ice cream I think I've ever had. The price is right for the size of the portion that you get, the fact that it's essentially a "super premium" ice cream, and that it's made to order. 

It was really busy when we stopped by, but the line moved quickly and there were as many people working behind the counter as they could possibly fit back there. Generally folks were polite, and you have to give them credit, when I tried to grab my husband's order too, they weren't going to let me just walk away with it, because how would they know I wasn't swiping someone else's? 

Recommended.
author: Chelsea L.

description:
A bit of a hype for me. Came in 30 minutes before closing and their machine kept breaking down which led to about an hour wait in total. That's too much of a wait for me just for ice cream.

I wanted to try the sweet corn flavor but the machine had broken down so I had to get the Salted Caramel instead. That flavor was too sweet for my taste.

I wouldn't go again, I'd probably go to Bi-Rite instead, where the wait isn't as long and the salted caramel flavor is way better.
author: Julienne H.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday night no line or waiting. The place was fairly empty for 8pm. Ice cream time usually places are packed should have taken this as the first sign. Only 3 flavors vanilla chocolate and salted Carmel. I got vanilla small with peanut brittle topping ( extra .75 cents lame ish ) overall portion was good. Could have added way more peanut brittle for the almost dollar extra I paid. Mine an my boo thangs scoops cost me 11$



$11.75 for two scoops??? 

No thanks. Next time I stay with birite
author: Chenea P.

description: Amazing, simply amazing! The ice cream was on point and the environment in and around the place makes you want to go back again and again. Friendly employees as well and they helped me choose my treat which did not disappoint!
author: Justin G.

description:
I made a return trip to Smitten recently and was persauded by friends to give their ice cream another try.  

This time I sampled the brown sugar (yum!) and the coconut with sesame brittle.   The brown sugar was pretty good, if a tiny bit sweet.  The coconut was bland and didn't really have much taste but the overall dish was elevated greatly by the bits of sesame brittle mixed throughout.

The ice cream was meant to be eaten immediately as it does melt more quickly than standard ice cream.

Service is still friendly and I must say that it's kinda cool to be eating freshly made (made right before your eyes)  ice cream.
author: Melissa L.

description:
The staff that work here have horrible customer service skills. 

When you wait in line for 45 mins for ice cream you would think they would be a little more accommodating.   

When we received our ice cream, I had wanted more sauce on the side. It was $.50  which i had ready in my hand. The employee told me to fall back in line. Wtf? I was like seriously?? You can't just give me a side if caramel even though I have the cash right here?? Nope, dude wanted me to wait 45 freaking minutes for a freaking side of caramel. Not cool. 

The ice cream was awesome, it is pricey- $6.00+ for a 4oz (smallest size they have $4.00) on a waffle cone ($1.00) and sauce ($.50) plus tax, the wait is hella long and the people that work there are b*tches which totally ruins the experience. You can get a sundae at bi-rite for that price. So 2 stars.
author: Iel B.

description:
Mark me down as thinking that the best ICE CREAM I have ever had was from Smitten. I had the TCHO Chocolate which was one of the flavors of the day. It tasted like they melted down a chocolate bar and gave it to me in a compostable cup.

I love the feel of the experience. You are in the middle of Hayes Valley. Just walk right up and from the look at the very modern structure which you think was built 2 hours earlier you expect they would take cash only. Don't worry, this is SF. They are using SquareUp so they can take credit cards right on the iPad at the order window under a sign of a little wagon. Once you pick one of the 4 flavors which they rotate, they write your Name and Order size (I got the small 4oz size which I thought was good enough) on a posted note. I love this part, they have 4 different color posted note colors which matches up to one of the flavors of the day and just slap it on the walk behind.  After you have got your Cup of Joy you can take a walk or take a seat in Partice's Green which is right next to Smitten. On a day date or taking your dog on a walk then I would head down to Smitten.
author: Justin C.

description:
I can see why this place got subpar reviews but I think the experience itself is more fun and probably better than the ice cream so that's why people keep coming.

First, it's literally like in a tin / metal container house. It's back to back with Ritual Coffee Roasters on the otherside and has only been open for 8 short weeks at the time of this review. 

They remind me of the Chicago ice cream parlor that was on the Food Network a while back which made your ice cream AS YOU ORDERED! Yes, this mean they don't scoop it out of a tub, they literally mix in liquid ingredients with liquid nitrogen to make your ice cream on the spot. You can watch this as it is quite cool to see! 

They usually have 4 flavors/day and apparently salted caramel is the most popular but I didn't like it too much. Their vanilla, on the other hand, was well worth the $4.75+tax for a small. Lovely!
author: Lorrie M.

description:
Yum! The lines can build pretty quickly and it takes a little time for them to get you your ice cream - but that is because they are literally making it! (With Liquid Nitrogen that is!) Patience is rewarded with uber cream lusciousness. 

Unique flavors like sweet corn are there to be had alongside tried and true classics such as vanilla and chocolate. You have options to spice things up with quality toppings: shortbread, brittle and the like.

All in all a tasty treat on "warm" San Francisco summer night.
author: Sherrie D.

description:
I love the TCHO chocolate ice cream - it's super chocolate-y and sweet.  It's made with liquid nitrogen so it's smoother than smooth, but it is kinda pricy.  The root beer float is also good - super, super basic with vanilla ice cream and a fancy root beer, but it's tasty.  

There is also always long line at the Hayes valley location so be prepared to wait.  At least you get to watch them use the machines to make your serving which is kind of fun.
author: Sumeena B.

description:
So yummy! They make your ice cream to order using liquid nitrogen and only use all-natural ingredients. They only have 4 flavors - Creme Fraiche, TCHO Chocolate, Vanilla, and Mint Chip--but several sauces and toppings to add. You can not sample any of their flavors because everything is made to order--that was kind of lame b/c part of going to an ice cream shop is being able to try a bunch of flavors before committing to a big scoop (they did say they have a guarantee and if you don't' like it you can give it back). 

I had the Creme Fraiche with Pear Caramel and it was amazing.  I opted for the cone and it was a very large portion...didn't realize it would be so big--I had 2 scoops of the ice cream.
author: Maliha Z.

description: This is a small ice cream spot next to a park.  They have few unique flavors and of course the classic flavors such as vanilla and chocolate.  I had the créme fraiche with pear caramel sauce. The ice cream was good and creamy.  The pear caramel sauce was good as well. It was not too sweet. Everything was made to order.  I enjoyed watching them make the ice cream using liquid nitrogen and a small churning machine. It's fascinating!  I just wish they had a pistachio. This place gets really busy anytime. Will definitely try other flavors next time!
author: Charmaine L.

description:
I tried their fresh mint chocolate, creme fraiche with pear caramel and both were so smooth it didn't feel like it was ice cream. The order was completed pretty quickly and I finished eating the order pretty quickly thereafter. 

I plan on taking my boyfriend here when he is in town. I think it is worth trying though I think Bi-Rite's ice cream still tastes better.
author: Vicki T.

description:
Cool concept, horrible ice-cream. Tastes like the same exact thing you get at Wendy's. Very cream based... it just tastes like frozen cream and sugar (because it is). 

There is no love put into this ice cream, you can even taste it.. you lick it and you cry. 

I went all out and ordered two flavors that set me back like $10-$15 I can't remember, but when I got one of them I asked "where is the Caramel sauce?" The guy looked at the screen and rudely in one loud breath said, you "You didn't order it, so you didn't get charged, here is some anyway." I appreciated it.. I guess, but I would rather just pay for the normal amount. I let him know that I also ordered a bigger size so I hope this one is mine. How do you screw up two things on a ice cream order? The girl taking my order was a little short, I get her job she deals with a lot of stupid people but I made it very easy for her, the only hold up was that I had to take a second to process the fact they couldn't put two flavors in the same cup and I had to order (and pay more) for two separate cups.

They also (apparently all the time way too early in the day) ran out of several flavors. 

Bi-rite for the win!!
author: Tim V.

description:
Such a cool ice cream place! They make their ice cream using liquid nitrogen, so each batch is made fresh using science :).Smitten is a small ice cream shack in Hayes Valley, so there is limited seating.

Since I was indecisive, I took the cashier's recommendation of the Blood Orange with Pistachio shortbread. I absolutely love Blood Orange, but I was a little skeptical of how it was paired with pistachio. After tasting the ice cream, I was blown away. It was tarty, fruity, and the pistachio shortbread gave it a nice crunchy texture. What was great about this flavor that it was blood orange ice cream - not sorbet - which was something I've never tried before. 

My friends ended up ordering the mint ice cream. Beware, it's not the green mint ice cream we are all used to filled with sugar, coloring, and preservatives. This mint ice cream tasted exactly like fresh mint leaf - delicious and refreshing!

I will definitely be back to Smitten to try more of their flavors. Its going to be a hard toss up to decide between Smitten and Bi-Rite for my next SF ice cream treat...
author: Sandy K.

description:
This is a really awesome concept and I was super excited to try it out, but it was kind of a let down for me. The storefront is very fun and unique, with white smoke filling the air from the liquid nitrogen, but aside from that, the ice cream tasted like ice cream. 

The vanilla ice cream tasted like vanilla and the olive oil ice cream tasted like olive oil. I don't know what else to say about that. Maybe we didn't go when they were offering their best flavors.
author: Stacy K.

description:
I went on a blind date once it ended terribly, probably because the guy sucked. Regardless of the guy I was happy our date began and ended in hayes valley so I can receive my nom noms on smitten ice cream. YUM! Now I don't want to brag but as a lactose intolerant Asian (yes there are many) that eats ice cream on the daily I feel like smitten is sooo delicious. There are so many great things about this place, 
-you get to see the ice cream get made
-it's fresh
-because of the dry ice smoke you can take hipster instagram pics and say #nofilter and not be lying
-it's ice cream, whats not to like.

Anywho date sucked but ice cream completely made up for it.
author: Cristelle J.

description:
Definitely worth stopping by and picking up a scoop if you are in the area but not worth making a special trip for. On Thursday and Friday there are at least four (good) food trucks parked in the area next to Smitten so you can grab some grub and then a quick dessert.

Pros -
Good location: in the heart of Hayes Valley right next to the park and right next to the food truck ares
Cool concept: it's fun to watch them make the ice cream right in front of you using liquid nitrogen
Interesting flavors: last visit I had a spring herb blend and TCHO chocolate seems to always be on the menu
Toppings: large variety to choose from to make a different combo each time

Cons -
Variety: never more than four options to choose from
Sweet: ice cream is supposed to be sweet but if you order larger than the larger size it is difficult to keep eating after a while
Price: it is not crazy expensive but seems to be a little over priced for what you get (medium is 2 scoops for $6)
author: Frank J.

description: Freshly made daily!!! Order the strawberry white balsamic with sea salt caramel with homemade waffle cone that melts in your mouth.
author: Emily U.

description: Pretty good ice cream, though the gimmick here is obviously how they make their ice cream to order using liquid nitrogen.  It's fun to watch, but can lose its flare after a while when the price for ice cream becomes much higher as a result.  Ice cream wise, its pretty good.  The flavors seem to change constantly, but I had earl grey with chocolate chips which paired really well together surprisingly.  Also got to try the caramel which was to sweet for my liking, but was still pretty good too.  Overall, this place is pretty neat, I'll have to come back again to try their toppings.
author: Bryson L.

description: I really wish I could give this place 5 stars, but I just can't. Came here on a Sunday afternoon and waited in line for about 30 minutes. A friend took us here and we decided to get two small ice creams. I got mint chip and he got Nectarine. Ice cream toppings here are skimpy, especially when you're paying extra for them. They can't seem to make the ice cream quick enough here so not only do you wait in line to order, but you also wait for your ice cream to come up which in our case was an additional 15 minutes.
