TCHO chocolate was super rich like you were actually eating a piece of chocolate, although I like sweets a lot it was a little bit too much for me.

Really want to try all their monthly specials but sadly I will only be around for certain months :(
author: Elly Y.

description:
Unique small place by a small park. 
I had mint ice cream with real mint leave oil. Definitely the real deal. Some people would be disappointed. It is not like the mint ice cream you normally get. Very natural.
author: marlene c.

description:
A little pricey, but the novelty of having your ice cream made to order and the magnificence of salted caramel makes the extra bucks totally worthwhile. At least once in a while. 

Definitely coming back.
author: Madhur B.

description: I didn't finish my ice cream from Smitten. That never happens, but it was that bad. We tried two of their three flavors. I didn't care for the flavor or texture (too creamy) of their ice cream. The liquid nitrogen is just a gimmick. Unfortunately, I fell for it.
author: Sophia B.

description:
It was packed when I got there and the line took a pretty long time. I can totally understand why it took so long because the ice cream is made fresh to order. The whole science behind the nitrogen freezing process was really cool! (no pun intended)
Food-
I had the corn & berries ice cream and it was delicious! The corn ice cream grew on me the longer I had it and it gave me a deeper satisfaction! It was not too sweet and the corn flavor was full and tasted a little buttery.
My only qualm behind this place is the price. For $5.50 you get a small scoop of ice cream that is unsatisfying. Then again, everything is expensive and yuppified in SF and these are the portions that you usually get anyways. Honestly, at this price point, I 'd rather get Bi-Rite Ice Cream which has more varieties and is slightly cheaper (albeit its also REALLY expensive for ice cream).
author: Andrew C.

description:
I scoped out this place and waited for a visit when there was no line.
After trying this place once, I'd suggest NOT going on the weekend as in San Francisco there are sooo many other things that you could do instead of waiting in a line for anything for more than 10-15 minutes.
But if you must wait in the line, it's a fun area to be in and you can take in the scenery passing by.
I decided to stay simple and try the standard vanilla ice cream as a good base line beginning point for comparison to other places i've been.
I don't have anything bad to say about it.
Your order is prepared as vapors swirl around from the machines behind glass.
Very cool!
The service was very good, the surroundings were excellent.
As far as the ice cream goes, I can only say it was ok.
I am definitely going to try going again - as I feel that maybe I missed something - or maybe it was an off day.
author: Ted S.

description: Pretty neat place, bomb.com, friendly staff. I liked that they make the ice cream right in front of you. Little spoons, big flavor!
author: Claudia H.

description: I had Smitten for the first time on Saturday. Love the concept of having it in a shipping container and how the ice cream is churned right then and there. I got the salted caramel with cookie dough. It was delicious! While my boyfriend got the vanilla with strawberry sauce. I enjoyed my ice cream but found myself stealing some of his ice cream. Such a simple flavor just made very well. Will def get it next time!
author: Leanne E.

description: Over priced yes..but entertaining yes. Worth the freshness and quality.  I like the seasonal flavors and keep our local.
author: Sandra S.

description: Great ice cream! They make it right in front of you and have flavors that change daily/near daily. I had the sweet corn with berries which was unexpectedly delicious. It sounds weird, but it works. The ice cream is so creamy too! Definitely try this place.
author: Taylor V.

description:
Super super super rich and creamy ice cream. Smitten, housed in its shipping container, is a centerpiece for Hayes Valley. Boy, do I love that place. A small community of ice cream shops, beer gardens, and shipping container stores surrounding a grassy patch of park. 

Sit on the grass on a sunny day and enjoy your ice cream after watching Smitten's special liquid nitrogen machines produce it like magic. Flavors are seasonal and rotate, but you'll always be able to get chocolate, salted caramel, and vanilla.
author: Carolyn K.

description:
3.5 stars.

They only offer two seasonal flavors at a time, but they always have vanilla and dark chocolate. Yes the options are limited, but it is what it is. If that's not your thing there's always Birite, Mitchell's, or Humphrey...

Dislikes - no samples. For the price, I think you should be able to taste it before committing which is pretty standard for an ice cream shop. I understand they make it on the spot, but if there's some leftover in the previous batch, why can't the next customer sample from that? I'm a try everything once kinda girl so I ended up ordering some without sampling but none of my friends wanted to so they missed out on about 8 additional orders.

The experience is unique and I really liked the salted caramel, but I'd probably only go back if I was in the area.
author: Holly E.

description:
I don't understand all the hype surrounding this place.  Compared to other ice cream shops in the SF Bay Area (Ici, Mitchell's Bi-Rite), Smitten is probably my least favorite.

I had to come here last Sunday because Mitchell's was closed & I'd been meaning to try Smitten.  I ordered the caramel apple ice cream in a cone & my bf ordered the chocolate. 

My experience was very underwhelming.  First of all, the girl at the cash register was not friendly AT ALL & she seemed really frustrated trying to slide my credit card through their mobile payments system.  Second, the ice cream takes forever take make (I know I know, they make it right there using liquid nitrogen, so it can take a while to make the ice cream).  Third, the scoops were tiny. ($8.50 for two small orders). Fourth, my cone fell apart when I got my ice cream, so I had to put it in a cup.

Also, no samples?!

The only saving grace was that the chocolate was really delicious.

If I had the choice, I'm not sure I would come here again.  Maybe if I was hanging out in Hayes Valley.  Otherwise, I would take my patronage to Mitchell's or Bi-Rite where the servers are friendly & you can sample to your heart's content.
author: Grace C.

description:
Smitten...to strike or hit hard, with or as if with the hand, a stick, or other weapon...

Other weapon...ICE CREAM

Smitten yields a rather hefty ice cream weapon...I have been hit HARD with all aspects of this place!

First, it's in a reclaimed shipping container...way to recycle people! This simply adds to the uniqueness of this experience.  

Second, the ice cream is made using liquid nitrogen right there while you wait and watch - they use the freshest ingredients and make a small selection of flavors (helps with the very indecisive).

Lastly, OMFG the ice cream is AMAZEBALLZ! Seriously, they straight up slap you upside the head with how delicious, fresh and unique their product is.

Menu rotates daily - favs are the salted caramel, TCHO chocolate and the Salty and Cynical sundae...but in all honesty, everything there is so delicious (yes, I'm smitten).

Yes, lines can be long (hello, they make your ice cream when you order it!), and it can be a bit pricey, but it's totally worth it in my book.

Smitten...big time!
author: Christy L.

description:
A very cool concept for an ice cream shop. Watching them make the ice cream was pretty awesome, which made the long wait more bearable. 

The ice cream was delicious. The texture was very smooth and the flavors were very robust. I ordered the mint ice cream, which tasted incredibly fresh and had a very strong minty flavor. If you are only partial to mint, don't get this flavor. 

The ice cream is a little pricey, but it's worth a try. I've had better ice cream before, but this place has got most places beat when it comes to presentation.

3.5 stars.
author: Abena O.

description:
Ice cream created on the spot with liquid nitrogen. That means a few things.

The +'s:
+ Ice cream is freshly gassed with nitrogen and not sitting on a supermarket shelf with additives I can't pronounce and stuff like xantham gum
+ Flavors rotate and on my last visit I sampled carrot cake. Shocked to taste real bits of carrot and it wasn't bad!
+ Servings are Euro-sized meaning no massive insane scoops

The -'s:
- The frozen state doesn't hold as long as real gelato. I get the same creamy consistency but it seems to melt pretty quickly. Good thing I tend to eat fast anyways.
- Lines get long. You have to wait for your ice cream to get gassed before you can dive into it.

Overall I love the concept and that it's an alternative to pastries at La Boulangerie, candies at Miette and macarons at Paulette. It's still a welcome treat in Hayes Valley but I'm not sure I'd stand in line for it.

Cash only.
author: Yiven C.

description:
BEST ICE CREAM I HAVE EVER HAD.

If you're looking for a unique San Francisco experience, paired with a delectable melt-in-your-mouth treat, look no further, Smitten is your place.

I have been to Bi Rite, Humphrey Slocombe, and Swensen's. Not one (in my opinion at least) measures up to the heavenly status of Smitten. If you get ice cream anywhere in San Francisco, do it at smitten. Not only is the quality and flavor way more fulfilling, the experience of seeing it made before your eyes is a million times more exciting than standing in an hour long line.

Take note, there are usually long lines (still worth it), and only 4 flavors a day. I have tried about 5 of their flavors so far and am still head over heels in love with their CHOCOLATE. I'm not typically a chocolate ice cream type of girl, but at Smitten, it is all I have eyes for. Rich and decadent, one scoop of Smitten's choco ice cream is like eating creamy melted chocolate-the best damn melted chocolate you've ever had. If there is chocolate on the menu the day you go, it would be a grave and unforgivable error not to get it.
author: Rachel L.

description: Cookie dough pretzel ice cream. To die for. The pretzels are ground up creating the perfect full and salty flavor. Smooth ice cream. The waffle cone is amazing. Worth getting for sure. The mint chocolate chip is very earthy, like the herb. I wouldn't recommend that flavor if you aren't looking for a palette cleansing experience.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
Probably thee smoothest ice cream I've ever had. It was pretty neat watching them make it too!

Minus 2 stars because it was pretty pricey and way too sweet (both the ice cream and their waffle cone). I couldn't even finish mine and that's so not like me! I also got the pistachio brittle but could only taste caramel and no pistachio :(
author: V L.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Salted caramel 

SERVICE:
Workers are pretty nice. Did a small tour provided through Google, which I learned an interesting tidbit: They use liquid nitrogen which freezes and makes from scratch faster so the ice crystals are smaller thus producing smoothest ice cream

ATMOSPHERE 
Very cute outdoooor train caboose, in the middle of Hayes Valley, cute small park to sit around, people watch, eat your ice cream, and meander around Hayes' shops, restaurants, cafes
author: Angela L.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised with Smitten ice cream!  When I hear liquid nitrogen ice cream, I think of all the ice creams I tried at science classes and whatnot back in grade school.  I thought the consistency would be icy, and not thick and creamy like I like my ice cream.  

Turns out that the ice cream here has a great thick and creamy texture, similar to that of Bi-Rite's, and definitely thicker than Mitchell's or Icee.  However, while the texture is closer to Bi-Rite's, Smitten Ice Cream doesn't hold a candle to Bi-Rite, which is my absolute favorite ice cream place!

I had the creme fraiche with pear caramel, which was a great combination.  Their flavors rotate each day, so you won't always get to get the same thing as last time!  They make each individual serving when you order it, so unfortunately no samples though.

TLDR: Yummy ice cream that is thick and creamy in texture.
author: Carol L.

description: Made to order! They only have a few flavors a day. I got to try the salted caramel and the TCHO chocolate. If you love chocolate, get the chocolate one. It's so good and creamy. But the ice cream melts so fast!
author: April Y.

description:
Had a small size of the chocolate mint at the Whole Foods in Los Altos this evening... The ice cream tasted like mint toothpaste and left a greasy feeling on the top of my mouth.  I tossed it out in one of the trash recepticles in the store.  

I read all the good reviews so maybe someone new made it to be fair....but it was the worst "ice cream" I ever ate in my life...totally gross!
author: Darlena K.

description: Always love the salty carmel...how come they don't have it last week? Love love love! Olive oil lavender is cool too! Vanilla is a safe choice :)
author: Christine T.

description:
3.5 Star. 
Been there multiple times.. Hit of miss with the flavor of the month.  
Only small tiny spoon available, no bag to take your pint of ice cream to go @ $11
Ice cream making kind of gets boring after couple of times watching it.  

Service seems to have gotten worse over the years.. they need to do better job - trying to make it into more than ice cream eating process and sell on their strong point.  

B/c - for the price ppl won't come back unless - total package is there.. both good ice cream flavor + taste and experience.
author: Justin C.

description:
Sweet corn ice cream with blueberry topping. ROCKS!

Go out of your comfort zone and try something new. It'll surprise your palate!
author: Vanessa K.

description: The science behind the awesome machines and the delicious organic milk they use make it so yummy. Unfortunately I got the mint chocolate chip and it was too minty for my liking. Otherwise it's fun to watch the process and enjoy something that is freshly made!
author: Diana L.

description: Fantastic ice cream! Made using liquid nitrogen right in front of you. They rotate flavors when we went they had salted caramel, espresso, tcho chocolate and creme with caramel pear. We got the coffee break Sunday, the whipped cream and tcho crispies on top were amazing!
author: Emilia W.

description: First, location is excellent!!! Hayes Valley is buzzing with activity. Small park across the street makes their location ideal. We were their third customers of the day and when I asked for Lemon Gingersnap they said they had 'just' run out. Que! Anyway, their Brown Sugar, tcho Choc, and Cookie Dough made up for it. I feared it , Brown Sugar, would be too sweet, but it wasn't. I look forward to trying out their other flavors on my next visit to San Pancho.
author: V. M.

description:
This place is awesome! They get cool points right off for using liquid nitrogen to make the ice cream to order. The ice cream itself was creamy, smooth, and perfectly flavorful. I loved the variety and inventiveness of the menu and, really, the whole concept.

 If you have never had Earl Grey ice cream with chocolate, you have no idea what your life is missing. I'm not even an ice cream person.. I eat it maybe once or twice a year, but already, I want another scoop. So perfect, the flavors. Mmmm.
author: W W.

description:
Sorry Bi-Rite, but you may have a contender for my all time favorite, Salted Caramel. 

What a perfect location for this ice cream stand. Trust me, it's not hard to spot, it's the one concession looking stand in the middle of Hayes. 

They've figured out a way to churn the ice cream using liquid nitrogen, yes right there in front of your eyes, so that it comes out super creamy and just right. 

Check out their website for the menu, there are plenty of amazing combinations that I can't wait to try!
author: Anh P.

description:
Waited 25 minutes for an ice cream... it was worth it!!! 

Why the wait, you ask?  
1. It was a sunny and hot Sunday afternoon.  
2. The ice cream is made to order.  There was an order for several pints just before me, so I had to wait for those.  Yes, even the pints are made-to-order.

I got the Strawberry White Balsamic.  I couldn't taste much of the balsamic until the end, but it was definitely in there.

My friend for mint chip.  He loved the FRESH mint, but felt like the chocolate they drizzled on top was inferior.  It really detracted from his overall enjoyment.   

S.W.B. was definitely the winner.

Sadly they hadn't update their website, so the current flavors were wrong.  Check their website and scroll to the bottom to look at the schedule.  I'm so sad that I missed chocolate by a week.  :(  Can't wait for June (Olive Oil with Lavender Shortbread), July (Honey Nectarine), September (Creme Fraiche with Pear Caramel, October (Maple Brown Sugar Squash)... mmmm... AND DECEMBER (Sticky Toffee Pudding)!!!!!   Yes, I will go stand in line for ice cream in Dec.  

S.W.B. seems almost pedestrian now.  ;)
author: Heather C.

description:
Really cool concept and the flavors were phenomenal! I had been a follower on Twitter for quite some time and made it out one cold winter night. Unfortunately, I came so late that some flavors were sold out and the pizzelle cones were sold out. This only means I need to come back, so it's not so bad.

I decided to try the Bay Leaf with Meyer Lemon Caramel. It sounded weird and I wasn't sure if I'd like it, but it was delicious. I watched as each ice cream was made to order with liquid nitrogen. The flavor of bay leaf wasn't overwhelming and the meyer lemon caramel added a nice second layer of flavor to the ice cream. The ice cream was rich, creamy and smooth. You can tell that a lot of thought was put into making this quality ice cream.

If you're expecting a nice big scoop of ice cream for about $4, think again. It's a bit on the pricey side, but worth the it if you want to treat yourself every now and then.
author: Adelina W.

description:
What a great and accurate, in my opinion, name!

Super smooth, extremely fresh, and probably the best ice cream I have had while living in San Francisco. The flavors I've had so far include mint chocolate, blueberry and sweet corn & earl grey tea. I look forward to trying more flavors!

The portions seem pretty decent in my opinion and the price is fair for made by the order style ice cream.

The only reason smitten doesn't get a 5 star award from me is, 3 of the times I have been to appease my craving they have been closed early "due to unforeseen circumstances"  Boo  :*(      My BMI appreciates this, but my taste buds do not.
author: Brandyy S.

description:
Maybe the previous reviewers were buzzed from the nearby beer garden?

The vanilla tasted like Dairy Queen soft serve. I don't need to spend $4.75 on Dairy Queen soft serve. 

Go to Bi-Rite, Humphry Slocombe, or Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous instead. 

Or Dairy Queen if you want to save $$.
author: J. M.

description:
When old school meets innovation is when my technologically illiterate father busts out his iPhone 5.  

While I don't see him instagramming anytime soon, some interesting things happen when these two distant worlds collide.  

(Besides the occasional awkward facetime request)

As for Smitten Ice Cream, this place does a much better job bringing old and new together with their delightfully retro mixing machines being pumped full of liquid nitrogen.

The result?

Deliciously creamy ice cream that is made to order.  

There's something about the freshness of this place that makes it unique.

In a city where ice cream is taken seriously (Bi-Rite, Three Twins, Mr. Mrs Misc.), standing out is a challenge.  

Smitten stands out and stands tall.

Sure, the way they create ice cream is a gimmick, but it works and it tastes good.

It doesn't get much better than eating Smitten in Hayes Valley on a nice day.

Science.
author: Archie R.

description:
Holy cow, this place is amazing!!

I just started a new job a few blocks away, and ever since I started, I've been hearing about how awesome the ice cream is here. Because it was actually around 90 degrees in SF last Thursday (pretty much unheard of), my manager decided that our weekly team meeting would be held at Smitten. 

They post which flavors they'll be serving on their website, so be sure to check it out before heading over. When we stopped by, they were serving rhubarb crisp and salted caramel, along with their standard chocolate and vanilla. I tend to like fancier flavors, but i decided to go for classic vanilla with a brown sugar caramel topping. I'm so glad i chose it! It was simple and rich and decadent all at the same time. 

There's also a nice beer garden right across the street (you can bring your ice cream in there, just no pets!) so the whole neighborhood is a great spot to spend some time 

I plan on stopping by lots more times and you should too!
author: Renee N.

description: This place not only has amazing ice cream but they offer vegan options as well! I got the valrhona fudge vegan pop which is made with coconut milk so it was nice and creamy and very yummy! It's only $3 which makes it even better lol. One of my friends got the salted caramel vegan pop and really liked hers too. My other friends got the blood orange with pistachio shortbread (extremely delicious) and the tcho chocolate which is very good and very chocolatey. I wish I lived closer so I could come here more often.
author: Tray C.

description: The ice cream is amazing. The location is amazing. it just radiates good vibes, whatever weather. Definitely going back. I can still taste the ice cream in my mouth. YUM!
author: John C.

description:
I still dream about this ice cream! Even on a chilly January night, we were seduced by Smitten. The smoothness is amazing, and the salted caramel with chocolate sauce is to die for!!

I imagine it's really busy in the summer - I recommend a winter visit!
author: Emily M.

description:
The Good: This is the best ice cream I have ever had in my life. I do not say this lightly. I am terribly allergic to lactose, so going for ice cream means planning ahead, taking a pill, and being ready for possible fallout. I chose to try this place without all the prep-work and it WAS SO WORTH IT. We got Tcho chocolate with spicy caramel and Strawberry White Vinaigrette with whipped cream. We fought over both. The texture is soft, smooth, creamy, with the unmistakable mouthfeel of butterfat and fresh organic milk. The process is heavenly to watch, with vapor pouring off the liquid nitrogen and the careful churning of each batch. The scoops are pretty enough to take a picture and the recipe is flawless. I don't ever want any other type of ice cream again. This is the fabled heaven of dairy products, where no one is intolerant. 

The Bad: You will have to wait. You cannot mix two flavors in one cup. It is slightly pricey. NONE OF THIS MATTERS. It will be one of the best things you've ever put in your mouth. This is hand-made genius-driven bliss.
author: Meghan E.

description:
Tcho dark choco ice cream on a cone. My wad of folded-bills was $4.75 lighter. The choco taste was great, but at nearly $5 bucks? really? for artisan-crafted ice-cream? I'm in the wrong business. With my killer-smile, I could charge $7...don't hate :D 

j/k, seriously, the ice cream hit-the-spot on the flavor-meter and the gal helping me was so nice.
author: Derek N.

description:
The ice cream here is great, but damn it's pricey. I've had the fresh mint chip and the earl grey, both excellent. It's heartbreaking when you watch them make the ice cream for you, make your scoop, and not give you the rest that's still in the mixing bowl... Sigh, it's almost like ordering a milkshake and not getting the metal cup.

Also, I love their almond brittle. It is pricey as well.......
author: C. Z.

description: Liquid nitrogen allows tiny ice crystals, amazing texture, and perfect temperature made-to-order ice cream. Quite literally the best ice cream in the world.
author: Jonathan R.

description:
Pretty Pricey for ice cream  but for what you get: the taste, the originality (they use liquid nitrogen!), the show, the atmosphere, etc. 
well it really is worth it at the end!

I got the mint chocolate chip and oh boy you can just taste the freshness~ !
author: Dixie L.

description:
This place is like a kiosk built in a container truck on the end of Linden street.  Kinda cool.  Right next to the mini park at the end of Octavia, and there towering over all of us is the BRC scrap metal art piece three stories tall.  

I never saw ice cream made by hand before, they have these fancy machines that deep freeze and stir everything as you watch.  Kinda cool.  I don't know if it tastes any *fresher* but it tasted damn good.

Go here.  There are cute people everywhere!
author: Sean S.

description:
Hands down the smoothest ice cream, ever.  Scoops are hand-made to order and churned up using liquid nitrogen... Apparently this isn't just some gimmick; it's actually how you get that impossibly smooth consistency -- something about the quick freeze time making smaller ice crystals or whatever (I never did pay much attention in high school chem).

But anyway, smoother doesn't necessarily mean better.  I mean, yes, the ice cream is fantastic!  It definitely stands out from the abundance of artisan ice cream shops in SF.  But I can't say that it's *better* than the others, just different in a very good way.  

A couple of gripes, however : (1) This liquid nitrogen ice cream seems to melt at a faster rate than your normally-churned ice cream... I'm the kind of gal who likes to savor every lick of her ice cream, but unfortunately I don't have that luxury with Smitten.  And (2) It's EXPENSIVE.  I don't know about you, but $5.50 for a small scoop and a waffle cone seems pretty extravagant to me.

Tip: Get your scoop with a waffle cone -- TOTALLY worth it.  Best waffle cone I've had in my life.
author: Alice C.

description:
Fresh mint with chocolate sauce, delicate and creamy, mint was more of a whisper than a punch. Chocolate, tcho, omg so good! I'd say awesome if it didn't remind me of eddie murphy in bowfinger, awthum!!!

The custard/ice cream cannot be improved upon, nor the customer service, both so excellent. Seating would be nice, one board plank kinda small for a middle-aged butt! Oh well, maybe it's a suggestion...  That i'm not taking!
author: Kelly K.

description: We just came across this fun little place after having dinner. It is really just a stand but does have sides and heaters and some limited seating. We had the Tcho chocolate and it was creamy and delicious. It was fun to watch them make the ice cream.
author: Cindy D.

description:
Product: individually personalized gourmet ice cream- WHAT CAN I SAY ABOUT THIS PLACE BUT THANK YOU ICE CREAM GOD!  Really good ice cream, and I love that it's made to order, makes the customer feel more special like it's my flavor that was made specifically for me only.  I had the chocolate chip with crushed salted pretzels and brown caramel with a homemade waffle cone, oh man, heaven!  Thanks to the woman in front of me and my bestie who suggested our flavors I don't know who you are but you told us you go there every day for your daily dose of ice cream... Sorry I didn't catch your name but you definitely added on to our experience!  SHOUTOUT TO YOU AND YELP ME BACK IF YOURE READING THIS, YOU ROCK MISS SMITTEN! (Warning: no taste samples... BUT GOOD WARNING: if you don't like it, they make you another one for free!) so if I decide like 3/4 of the way finished with my ice cream that I don't like it.... Will they still make me a new one for free?? Hmm

Service rating - very accommodating and friendly staff.  They were kind of slow in making my ice cream, and forgot my syrup but totally made up for it with their charismatic personality, giving me a coupon for a free ice cream on my next visit, and adding waaaaaay more syrup to my ice cream cone and more syrup for my friend's ice cream cone... it's the little things that amount to so much more!  

Ambiance - not gonna lie, not gonna hate... It's hipster to the core, but I can't hate.... Ice cream is too good for words.  Plus I found my name twin who's an ice cream maker !! HEY GARRETT... Gareth with a TH says hello and thanx for making my sweet corn pint of ice cream! Haha

Recommendation - to all customers and potential customers, don't hesitate .. JUST GO! There's no second guessing or thinking... GO AND HAVE YOURSELF SOME SMITTEN, you'll be smitten by lick 1! (^_^)
author: Edgar I.

description: 3.5 stars, the liquid nitrogen is cool and you can watch your order being made. The limited flavors is a turn-off, as is not being able to order multiple flavors in the same cup. Was not interested in any of the toppings, and the price is a little high for what you get.
author: David H.

description:
Con: The most expensive and small kiddie cone I have ever had (I believe it's $3.50 for not more than 8 spoon fulls of ice cream.

Pro: Made to order and it was actually delicious. I could taste the fresh peaces that were blended in there!
author: Betty C.

description: The creamiest ice cream I've ever had. It's consistency was so smooth and perfect and the best part is that even tho it was creamy and soft it didn't melt too fast. I had the rhubarb crisp with the strawberry prosecco sauce. Delish!! My sister had the salted caramel and it was amazing. Tasted exactly how salted caramel should taste.
author: Aimee L.

description:
Ummm dang!
This was some de-lish-ous ice cream! It was super smooth in texture and the flavors just popped out bursting with goodness. I couldn't decide which flavor called my attention the most, so I had a scoop of each... Vanilla, toffee pudding and best of all... "Dant danta ran"- the Tcho chocolate with spicy caramel sauce! 
Ohh my goodness this was get in my belly good.... You will not be disappointed at all. 
This place is super unique because they use liquid nitrogen and they don't make it until you order it- how is that for top notch! Go check it out for yourself.
author: Ladybird G.

description: Their vegan fudge is so good i am writing this review while eating one. Being allergic to cow's milk (not lactose intolerant) I have always struggled to find a decent tasting non-dairy ice cream. Well I now believe in miracles and flying unicorns and it costs less than 3 bucks (not the flying unicorn).
author: Madhweep L.

description:
I wasn't impressed with Smitten Ice Cream. 

I understand the novelty of liquid nitrogen frozen ice cream, and the interest in watching the staff make your order by hand, but I can't seem to enjoy it as much as others do. 

I had a serving of the Vanilla flavor and it felt anti-climactic. The cone was tasty, but as a whole the experience was unremarkable.

The shop itself is cute, situated in what looks like a re-purposed shipping container. Seating is limited to two benches in the corner, but Smitten is located next to Patricia's Green, which provides lots of standing and picnic-ing room. If not for its location and charm, I wouldn't have much else to write about. 

Though it seems like a good business hitch, it was unsuccessful in wrangling me in as a regular customer.
author: Nicole I.

description:
5 bucks seems a little steep to me when it comes to ice cream but hot damn it is worth it!!

I got the chocolate with spicy caramel sauce, not super original but it was incredible! The ice cream is so velvety and rich that the small was plenty for an after dinner dessert. I love that you can watch the people make it right in front of you. dessert and a show :) If you have a sweet tooth definitely stop by!
author: Mimi D.

description:
Who knew that liquid nitrogen was a great way to make ice cream?  The owner of Smitten figured it out and is making a killing with it!  With just a stand in Hayes Valley, Smitten has about 4 Kelvins (the machine) that make the different flavored ice creams for the day.  Your ice cream is made to order and it's pretty awesome to see the liquid nitrogen fog (or whatever you call it) ooze out of the machine!  We ordered a kiddie size ($3) of each of the salted caramel and tcho (pronounced "cho") chocolate.  The salted caramel did not taste like what I'm used to.  It wasn't salty nor caramel-y but the hubby liked it nonetheless.  The lil one and I were partial to the tcho chocolate.  It was real chocolatey but not too sweet.  We didn't add any toppings as they were good just by themselves.  

Cash only.  They'll ask if you want it to go or eat in.  If you eat in, they're required to charge you tax (SF law or something).  So opt to get it to go if you want to save a few bucks!
author: Kat G.

description:
I got to try their Salted Caramel Ice Cream w/Almond Brittle at the Eat Real Fest and was so pleasantly surprised! The ice cream is made to order with this little hand-cranked machine and it is amazing! It is so fresh and tasty! I ate this while waiting in line for something else and gobbled it up so quickly!

Smitten, if you should happen to walk down Market St Mon-Fri during normal business hours, please don't forget to call your friend Stella. Thanks!
author: Stella C.

description:
I'm not real big on going to ice cream shops. Why pay $6 for a small scoop of ice cream? Is it for the 'ice-cream buying experience'? So I ignored this place all summer, walking past the long lines on my way to Ritual or Blue Bottle.

But on my last day in SF, I was in the area for a final cup of coffee. The sun had just come out after some morning rain, and the line hadn't caught up yet. Also, I'd heard about the liquid nitrogen gimmick. I'm a sucker for that sort of thing. So I hopped in line and got myself a small scoop of the flavor of the day -- creme fraiche with pear caramel.

It really was pretty good. Dense but soft, and very creamy. I did find a couple of icy chunks in the scoop, though. I could feel the milk fat on my tongue, but the richness wasn't excessive; maybe the slight tartness of the creme fraiche was keeping it in check. The pear caramel was just slightly too sweet for me, but pretty heavy on the pear.

Worth trying if the line isn't too crazy.
author: Nath A.

description:
Liquid nitrogen is the funnest thing to happen to ice cream since the waffle cone. Tastewise, I couldn't tell it was made differently, but it's such a fun procedure to watch that I'm willing to fork over the extra money to have that experience. There were four flavors the day I went: salted caramel (which I tried), chocolate, vanilla and the seasonal apple crisp. The ice cream itself was great -- rich, sweet with a hint of the savory salt to balance the caramel flavor.

It has an adorable little stall in a great Hayes Valley location, right next to Aether Apparel. We stopped at a cute park just steps away, which was the perfect place to finish the ice cream before moving along.
author: Allison H.

description:
Price point is a bit high when comparing to the other heavyweights in SF, but i like the novelty of the idea of making ice cream flavors as you wait. 

The ice cream is more milky and less custardy in my opinion, but the flavors (I got Vanilla) are very pronounced. I felt the Vanilla almost tasted marshmellowy and the consistency was slightly rich, but seemingly whipped, maybe due to the quick process. The caramel topping was very sweet, and took me by surprise mainly because I have been used to salted caramel/burnt caramel flavors (I like making creme brulee flavors). 

While not my favorite of SF (honor belongs to Mr & Mrs), I would rate this behind Mitchells and Birite and maybe tied with Humphry.
author: Marc T.

description: The ice cream is unreal delicious and so flavorful. I just got the sweet corn seasonal flavor that had some sort of fruit sauce on top. Amazing! But pretty pricey, $5.50 for a small scoop.
author: Ashley R.

description: After the novelty of the technique wears off, the ice cream itself is mediocre. I had the cookie dough with pretzel pieces and there were hardly any pieces of pretzel or cookie dough, just a few crumbs throughout. So, cool idea, but not worth the money or calories, at least for that flavor. I tried a bite of the blood orange too, which was fun because it was different, but also a little bland. Plus, as some other reviewers have mentioned, whatever particular cream mixture they use results in a really yucky texture after you've eaten a bit, like a film of fat on your tongue and roof of the mouth. Pretty unpleasant.
author: Emily A.

description:
Paired with a coffee place, this place is really cool.

It's really cool to watch the "Brrr-istas" (yeah, I thought that was clever too) make the ice cream in front of you. It's like a nitrogen process where it basically freezes as they make it. I don't know science, but I got my ice cream. 4oz cup for like $5, so it's kind of overpriced, but I think you're paying for the experience.

Definitely a cool spot, and I would recommend it to others.
author: Sam A.

description:
Had their salted caramel ice cream with almond brittle. Expensive $2 spent for a bite of ice cream (at the Eat Real Festival in Oakland), but I gotta hand it to them - it was amazing. The more amazing part of it is that I don't even like salted caramel! I only went here because I decided to give the place a chance to succeed. And succeed it did.

Personally, their salted caramel beats Bi-Rite by a mile. And almond brittle on top? A-freakin'-mazing. I'm thrilled to find that they're opening up a physical location soon!
author: Joanne Y.

description: Yummy! A favorite of our 17-year-olds! We tried all 3 flavored. At night the line was long but moved quickly.
author: Kathy C.

description: Omg. I am almost sad that I tried this place because I am dreaming of returning, and I don't live in the local area.  I tried the March special flavor - Blood orange and pistachio shortbread was so amazing.  You'll love watching them make this in front of you too on their special machines.  The place is cool too that it is in one of those pop-up containers nearby a drip coffee place and the Biergarten (nice neighbors to have).  I will return some day soon I hope.
author: Dan M.

description:
This place makes fresh ice cream! It's cool that you can watch them make the ice cream fresh. We came here on a Sunday around 3PM. It was a nice and warm day. The wait in line took awhile, maybe 30 minutes.

I got a classic Vanilla flavored ice cream. It was really soft and good. It's one of the best tasting ice creams I've had. However, the ice cream wasn't super cold. 

They have 3 sizes: small, regular, and pint. Small was about $4.75, regular was $6, and pint was $11. I tried getting a pint but two of their machines were out and the lady told me that they didn't want to stress the other two machines so I couldn't order a pint. 

Overall, though the ice tasted really good, the long wait in line, the fact that I couldn't order a pint, and also since it is kind of expensive, I don't think I would be coming here that often. 

Pros:
-Get to watch them make the ice cream fresh
-Great tasting ice cream, super soft

Cons:
-Long wait in line
-Since they make it fresh, may not get what you want if machines break down
author: Paul U.

description:
I loved it in the first lick.  What was not cool was that if you take your time licking, the ice cream melts faster than the wicked witch of the West having water thrown at her.

I order the small and by the time I got to the second scoop, the flavor lost its punch.

My advice to avoid the long lines is to go in the weekdays when they first open.  There were no lines and plenty of elbow space to enjoy your cone.
author: Kay Y.

description:
I don't care how damn cold San Francisco can get, this ice cream is worth freezing my ass off for. Parking is always a bitch in the city, no different in Hayes Alley, so with that out of the picture, the trek to this place is so worth it! Can't wait to go back again! It is a bit pricey, but it's not as if I'd go here on a daily basis.

The special flavors were TCHO Chocolate, Fresh Mint Chip and Strawberry White Balsamic.

I will start off by saying I do NOT have a sweet tooth. I did, however, get the TCHO chocolate, because TCHO was a local chocolate brand, and I figured, why not!? I watched as they mixed together my ice cream, and the amazing mist that flowed from the machine after the nitrogen was added. I took my first bite, and was floored at how NOT sweet it was. It was perfect, and I ended up scraping the insides of the bowl it was in.

My friend got the Fresh Mint Chip and she let my try a bit. That was the FRESHEST mint ice cream I've ever had. It was absolutely refreshing, and made me feel as if I should have ordered that instead. 

We were both very happy with our selections over all. I still am curious to find out about that Strawberry White Balsamic. All I heard around me was "MMMM" so, it must be good!
author: Jessica T.

description:
You know that when a ice cream shop with no indoor seating is packed when it is 47 degrees outside, that it has to be good.  And it is. Watching your ice cream being made on 4 liquid nitrogen machines, affectionately known as "Kelvins" and invented by the owner is awesome!

Not only the great novelty value but the ice cream itself is really good.  A bit softer and creamier but bold and vibrant flavors without being too in your face or strange for the sake of being strange.  Loved it, even in the dead of winter.

We tried all 4 flavors - Vanilla, Meyer Lemon Ginger snap, Salted Caramel and Dark Chocolate.  Salted caramel often goes overboard with salt, and ends up tasting rather like vomit. No one wants ice cream that someone has already eaten.  But, this... this is just fantastic, a hint of saltiness, no nasty "oops I left the marshmallow on the fire too long and it burnt to nothing but coal" flavor.  It was sweet with a hint of salt and some complexity from the sugars... loved it.  Topped with the pistachio brittle, it was heaven in my mouth.  The vanilla was excellent too, extremely creamy while rich flavored but not too heavy or greasy on the mouth.  Perfect for toppings.  The Meyer lemon was almost too bitter for me, but if you like lemon, get this.  The Chocolate was rich and decadent, not too sweet but also not slap you in the face with a 2x4 bitter.  Was awesome with some nuts.
author: Kit W.

description: HANDS DOWN BEST ICECREAM EVER. Love this place, the process to make it in front of you using liquid nitrogen, everything! Any time I have an out of town friend I bring them here and they also love it. Check them out! There's a reason there is always a long line!
author: Alan M.

description:
I am so disappointed with Smitten. Had the worst service ever and honestly, I don't think I would bother coming back again. 

Smitten's sign say s they open at Noon. The hub and I strolled over and they were not open, 5 min pass, 10, 15, 20, 25, finally at 12:30 they open up. No explanation at all from them and they knew we were waiting for them to open.

So we were second in line. Seriously about 25 minutes later we still did not have our order and everyone after us did, it was so weird. The guy who was first in line went to counter same time I did and we asked where was our ice-cream. We got the rudest customer service ever. I was so shocked. Whoever the girl was behind the counter with the shaved head, needs a quick reality check on how customer service works. She rudely said I KNOW when we pointed out that we were first in line and everyone had their ice-cream before us. She was not only rude to us but so rude to a guy that worked there that was being trained. Poor thing!!!

I paid $7.50 for my regular vanilla with shortbread chunks added to the top and spicy caramel sauce. You would think after waiting SO LONG, they would have been generous with the toppings but it looked like scraps. 

I hope that Smitten reads this and realizes how unprofessional their staff was and does something about it. I told the hub that I hope since they have been open for a while now, that they are not cocky and think they can treat people poorly because they have "good ice-cream". UGH!
author: Rebekah S.

description:
This place is really cute. So hipster cute -- if that's a thing. 

First off, they had 3 flavors the day I went with my mom -- chocolate, classic vanilla, and olive oil & lavender. I got a small chocolate in a cup and my mom got the vanilla in a cone. It's a pretty cool concept with the liquid nitrogen. Gotta love my science :) but it is something I have seen before. The ice cream is def creamier, but it was still pretty plain and not thatt special -- maybe because I didn't add any toppings? 

And it is expensive for that little thang. College girl's gotta have her sweets occasionally-- but have mercy on my wallet puuleaze. 

The backstory of the shop is pretty interesting so if you ever try out smitten look around the little place and get yo daily dose of inspiration!
author: Erica H.

description: If you love Ice Cream.. this is a great spot.... small selection (3 or flavors that change daily) and even order is made when you order it.. yes, you read that right... order two scooped of salty caramel, and these two scoops are made fresh while you wait with some king of awesome fast freezing system that takes a couple of minutes... smooth, creamy, full of flavor... just could eat it every day!
author: Mark K.

description: I'm so SMITTEN over smitten! My sister said they were on shark tank. The line is worth the wait especially if you're waiting on a flavor that's really popular and requested the most like salted caramel. I loved the entire experience of watching them make the ice cream with liquid nitrogen. My friend and I shared the larger size of salted caramel with pistachios as the side. Although a bit pricey, it was worth watching and soaking in this unique business. I also want to say it was hands down the best salted caramel I've had.
author: Jeena L.

description:
Been here a couple times and each time has been just as good as the last. 

I would give it five stars except for the fact that this place is so popular there is always a line, so there is always a wait...which I mean, is worth it. 

My go to, either plain salted caramel in a waffle come, or vanilla with tcho chocolate and pistachio brittle. 

It's a bit pricey for ice cream, but it i guess  you pay for what you get.
author: Mary J.

description:
TL;DR: Some flavors good, but generally overrated.

I'd been wanting to hit up Smitten for months... I finally forced myself to go because PayPal had a deal at the spot, $5 woo! The flavors available were vanilla, mint chip, and blood orange with pistachio shortbread. Note that you have to wait while they 'make' your ice cream with liquid nitrogen. 

My friend ordered a small mint chip for $4.75 and because I thought I'd get my $5, I went all out with the medium $6 blood orange with caramel sauce (+$0.50). I was confused when I was charged $7... and learned that their 'seasonal' flavors cost $0.50 extra... because they're sourcing seasonal produce? I thought that was odd since I assume produce that's out of season is more expensive. And then of course, PayPal failed to work with their system... so I paid $7 for three small scoops of ice cream. Very pricey in my opinion.

Onto the ice cream itself. First the good - the blood orange was very tasty. It was like having a super fancy creamsicle with the nice crunch of buttery pistachios and shortbread. The caramel was also good, but added too much sweetness/richness for my taste.

The mint chip though, which I was told is their most popular flavor, was interesting with its mint-infused cream. Definitely a different flavor, which wasn't bad in and of itself. The texture however was AWFUL. It was icy - more like a snow cone and the whole thing was just so watery ... it's as if they used water mixed with some cream. And I'm pretty sure it has to do with their liquid nitrogen process ... and the fact that they leave the ice cream custard sitting around in bottles... it's possible/probably the cream at bottom of the bottle began to separate, which led to watery watery ice cream.

Anyway, overall, I'd say it was pretty disappointing. Very pricey and a long wait - for ice cream that is very tasty at best and grossly similar to an icee at worst.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Absolutely a life-altering experience, as it's probably the best ice cream you'll ever taste. I sampled the vanilla with chocolate syrup, which thankfully wasn't too sweet -- dominating flavors are rich and creamy rather than sugary. 

I'm docking a star for the cone, which tasted like shortbread (doesn't quite align with my personal preference, but hey, others might like it), as well as the price. I get that it's fantastic ice cream, but $6 for an ice cream cone?! And I had to wait in line for 20 minutes to pay that price.

Still definitely worth trying, and if I'm ever in the area and craving ice cream, I'll probably return.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
This place is pretty darn unique. They make each order of ice cream individually by putting together a couple of different ingredients on the spot and pouring it into a liquid nitrogen machine. 

It's fascinating to watch them put their magic stuff into the machines and feel the cold mist of the liquid nitrogen flow out. Definitely brought me back to the good ol' days of AP Chemistry, but I don't think I ever got or made ice cream at the end of lab, so I'd say this experience was infinitely better. (Plus, I'll be honest, I was seriously terrible at Chemistry.) 

Be ready for super strong flavors though... I got the Salted Caramel and my friend got the Meyer Lemon Gingersnap, which were both just... really strong. There's no other way to describe it. I personally prefer somewhat subtler flavors which thus merits the four star rating for me, but it's definitely worth checking out.
author: Emily H.

description:
This place has four flavors a day according to the blackboard. It's a cute little stand nearby a mini park/seating area in Hayes Valley and the ice cream is made fresh in front of you! And by fresh I mean, they use Kelvin machines to freeze? and mix the ice cream in front of you.
I ordered the fresh mint chip and was a bit surprised when it wasn't green before realizing DUH, they use REAL mint, not fake mint extract. It was super creamy and left that minty fresh feeling in my mouth. Yum.
It is definitely a pricey treat ($4-$5 for a small) but it's a treat, so totally worth it.
author: Sally E.

description:
Liquid nitrogen ice cream and ice cream made to order = WOW!

I've had the . . .

*Salted Caramel - this was good 
*Vanilla - this was a bit more milky than I'd like it to be
*TCHO 60.5% Dark Chocolate - I felt like I was eating frozen dark chocolate with whip cream all mixed in ONE cup of awesomeness (THIS IS MY ALL TIME FAVORITE FLAVOR here)

Note: there's usually a wait but it's bearable and anything good around this area usually has a wait anyway
author: Crystal L.

description:
I came here for the first time when they had their soft opening several months ago and haven't been back until recently.  It's neat how they can make ice cream from liquid nitrogen, one machine per flavor.

I ended up ordering the fresh plum ice cream with a handmade pizzelle cone.  The fresh plum ice cream was very tart, and the cone soft and fresh.  My bf on the other hand got the salted caramel ice cream, and I ended up trading him half way through my cone because I thought his tasted better :)
author: Joycelyn L.

description: BEST ice cream I have had in my entire life! Salted caramel perfection!  And to make it better, they were playing my girl Beyoncé.  I wish we had this in FL.
author: Nadia B.

description:
FINALLY! I finally found Smitten after all this time and seeing all these damn instagram pics.

Location: still a bit weird since it's kind of one a weird street where you can only turn in certain spots and parking can be a pain.

Design of the spot: Interesting out-door spot made out of a shipping cart. I've seen designs before for other places but this has to be one of the best I have seen.

Onto the ice cream! Last time I came here, I had some triple chocolate type ice cream and it was SUPER SWEET, but my girl's flavor (which I can't remember) was definitely better and less sweet compared to mine. 

Another plus is that they use all fresh ingredients and they make it right there so what you see is what you get, you really dont see that elsewhere!
author: Kenny L.

description:
I adore Smitten Ice Cream! For the idea,vibe and unforgettable taste of real ice cream!
For me Smitten is  a part of Hayes Valley. I love this cozy,lovely and unique spot where Smitten family will prepare your ice cream in front of you:) It's simply delicious!
author: Aglaya S.

description: I really wanted to try Smitten because they had liquid nitrogen ice cream and that you get to see your ice cream being made. I wanted to see and taste what's so great and cool about it. So when I was around the Hayes Valley area, I had to stop by Smitten! The line was not too bad that day. I had the TCHO Chocolate with Pistachio Brittle in a waffle cone. Their waffle cones are handmade. I really liked it! The TCHO chocolate was super yummy and rich in flavor. It did melt a bit too fast though, so you have to eat it fast. The pistachio brittle was very crunchy and sweet. The brittle really went well with the TCHO chocolate ice cream! I really enjoyed watching the ice cream being made in the mixer. You get to see all the smoke coming out from it. What sucked was that the price is a bit expensive...
author: Philana C.

description:
This place is SO cool, here's why:

1. Liquid nitrogen makes everything all the workers look like food-loving-mad-scientists making ice-cream in a lab.

2. THEIR EARL GREY CHOC CHIP!!!!!!!! ITZTHABEST.  The very first earl grey ice cream I had was from ici; and you know how everything tastes best the first time? 
Well, this place topped ici, ohhhhhyeah they did. 

3. there are cute families with cute babies running around errywhere!! There's a little playground steps away, so you can watch the kiddos while you're eating.

WHATS NOT TO LIKE? NOW GO AND GET YOUR TASTEBUDS DANCE IN BLISSFUL JOY.


Comments:

**Texture**
- CREAMY, and soft. Less icy than Ici's; softer, and less dense (but not airy) than ici / bi-rite

**Flavors**
- Rich, very flavorful, deep. More flavorful than Ici's for sure; comparable to Humphrey's in terms of richness of flavor. 

**Menu**
- they have the TCHO 60.5% Chocoate and Vanilla  everyday, and then they have two seasonal flavors. When I went it was Salted Caramel and Earl Grey Choc Chip. 
- My friends had the TCHO 60.5% Chocolate, and it was the richest chocolate ice-cream all of us has ever had. It was amazing.

**Toppings**
-They had really interesting, gourmet toppings, I didn't try any though. Kinda wish I did. 

**Service**
- it does take a little longer than usual for your orders, because they make the icecream by small batches. But you spend all that time watching the liquid nitrogen does its magic, so it really doesn't bother anyone!

**Price**
-gotta admit, its more expensive than most gourmet ice-cream places. 
- the Kiddie scoop here though would be the standard 1 scoop at other places.
- the "single" is in fact, 2 scoops (and this is how America becomes obese...)
author: Noel C.

description:
one of the best ice creams I've ever had. We ordered a vanilla ice cream with multed caramel and walnuts and a vanilla ice cream with chocolate fudge. They were both wonderful. 
The way they made the ice cream was really entertaining, using nitrogen to get into 0 degrees Farenheit and yes it absolutely makes a difference in texture and taste. 
The ice cream was much smoother than a regular one and tasted excellent. Will definitely try it again, maybe chocolate next time.
author: Saeideh B.

description: omgggg soooo goooooooood. stuffed my face ahahahha. got sooooo much ice cream. namnamnamnamnamnamnamnamnamnam. peace out boy scouts
author: Vivian L.

description: Fun and cool place but think that Bi-Rite and Humphry slocombe has much better ice cream. I think the ice cream get a dry type of texture which I don't appreciate with the process when using liquid nitrogen.
author: Petter B.

description:
The olive oil & sea salt ice cream is pure deliciousness...it's so creamy and flavorful. It might sound a little strange, but it's just plain good. 

Smitten is more of an ice cream stand than an ice cream shop. There's no inside seating, but who needs that when you have that nice park next to it? Although it might seem a little pricey at $4.75 for a small, it's REAL ice cream, none of that yogurt stuff--I will come back to try more of their inventive flavors.
author: Lisa N.

description:
I'd give this place 5 stars if it was indoors. Ice-cream in SF when it's freezing is not that pleasant when eating outside, but this place is a different kind of ice-cream so you make the sacrifice! If indoors, I would have enjoyed it much more, but the whole time I was thinking, let's hurry up and eat and get back inside!
They make this ice-cream with liquid nitrogen, on the spot! And it's yummy!
LOVE IT!
author: E B.

description: I would give one more star if they had cookie dough everyday. It's my favorite flavor but they never seem to have it. Also it would be great if they could create a cookies and cream and rocky road! Until then if they don't have cookie dough I resort to chocolate with cookie dough crumbles on top. It's not the same but will have to do!
author: Lauren P.

description: Loved the cookie dough pretzel ice cream paired with spicy caramel.  Would have never found the location of it wasn't for a Google search.  It's located across from a little park which makes its location ideal.
author: Lisa G.

description:
I really the concept of Co2 Ice cream! It's really fun to watch them make the ice cream in the mixer. As for the taste, you can really tell that they make their ice cream with real fresh ingredients! My Mint Chocolate Chip Ice cream tasted like I was biting on a real mint leaf! I loved every lick of my ice cream cone! Now I know why they call themselves Smitten, such a fitting name! 

I only wished that they had a few more flavor choices, but it's understandable since their stand is quite small and they can only fit a few mixers for each flavor. (:

Def worth the experience coming to Smitten!
author: Lisa W.

description: I dropped my ice cream walking out of the store, and they made me another cone. The ice cream was great! Thanks for making my day!
author: Bradley S.

description: Whoever thought of this concept deserves a Nobel prize for deliciousness. The staff takes dessert way too seriously and I thank them for it. My trainer does too.
author: Andrew P.

description:
Talk about "Made to order!" A unique ice cream experience! 

Cute little joint on a corner. Your order comes with a show!  Place only has 4 flavors per day and they churn your scoop as you order it!  Scoops aren't that big and you can't mix flavors :( so you need to pick one and stick with it.  They use dry ice to freeze your scoop of ice cream. Honestly, I feel like they waste more on the mixer than what ends up in your cup! but it was still a great experience.  

Got the brown sugar with cookie bits ice cream. YUM!  Fancy Ice cream doesn't run cheap - $4 for a scoop so savor each lick!
author: Angela K.

description: hm...I've been really interested in typing this place.  Does liquid nitrogen change the taste, or is it just a gimmick.  Actually it makes the ingredients fresher and since it is frozen right away, it also means there is less air in the mixture.  This leads to a more natural, creamier ice cream.  I had the blood orange and with the pistachio shortbread.  Loved the shortbread, since it gave it a different feel in texture.  I do think that this is a bit pricey for what it is, although it's cool to try.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
You could say the liquid nitrogen is a gimmick, but the ice cream proved to be pretty delicious!! Not sure how delicious the vanilla would be without the cocoa crisps, but i definitely enjoyed the crispies. It's something I would try once or twice, but it definitely did not top my favorite ice cream place in SF.

A friend tried it with the cone and said it was fresh and delicious, so try it with that!
author: Minnow N.

description: Get the Tcho chocolate. It'll be the smoothest ice cream you'll ever taste.
author: Sherry L.

description:
SMITTEN ICE CREAM IS THE BEST IN THE CITY.
Pricy but worth it.

But, I can NOT say the word "smitten" because when I say the word, no one can understand what I say. I didn't realize till few days ago when I asked my son to come here.
The conversation went like this:

me, "Would you like to get a ice cream?"

my son, "Urrrr, I don't know."

me, " Oh, it's new, you'll like it."

my son, "where?"

me, " it calls SUMITEN." ( I said sounds exactly like: Su Mee Ten)

my son, WHAT? WHERE?

me, " I said SUMI-TEN."

my son, "WHAT? I don't get it."

me, "You know SUMI-TEN, means  urrrrrr, you know, when you see some one 
good lookin' gets hard on, or ...... attracts by others? SUMITEN?"

my son was like, "OMFG! Gee, Dad, you mean SMITTEN."

I was like, "Yes, that's what I said."

my son, " No, you didn't. You said SUMI-TEN,"

me, " NO! I didn't say that!!!"

my son,"Yes, you did.  It's SMITTEN"

me, " I said thet. That's what I said!"

my son, " No, you didn't"

me, "Yes, I said that."

my son,"You said SUMI-TEN, it's SMITTEN. You dumbass! "

me, "Yes, ... No,.... Urrrr, it sounds same to me."

my son, " It sounds TOTALLY DIFFERENT."

be smitten means:
be strongly attracted to someone or something : she was so smitten with the boy.

My son speaks Russian very well, and he told me that there is a Japanese-word that it's very difficult, almost impossible for Russians to say. The word is "OTOKONOKO ". It means a little boy.


In Russian, they can not say "O" more than 2 in one word.
Interesting isn't it?
I still can not believe why French can not say "H" in front of word.
There is Japanese girl's name calls HANAKO, Do they call her as "ANAKO"?
OMFG! That's like calling her as "vagina".
So, French people can not laugh like Japanese then because Japanese laugh like this, HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA!!!!

SMITTEN ICE CREAM IS THE BEST IN THE CITY.
Using a peculiar liquid nitrogen-based instant churning process that makes in a rich, smooth, custardy product unlike anything scoop from a already made bucket I've had before.
Pricy but worth it, $4.50 for small, 6 bucks for regular.
I was lovin' it.
So, When I say SUMITEN, it means SMITTEN.
OK? OK!!!
Hey, my son, are you listening? Dumbnass!

Btw, Sumiten has website, Japanese  charcoal energy company.

http://www.rakuten.co.jp/sumiten/
author: Nobu K.

description: I hate chocolate ice cream, but this place knows how to make it taste awesome that this is the only place I get chocolate ice cream from. I love how they make it fresh to order which can take some time to get your desert. On peak times there can be long lines, but well worth the wait. My friend ordered the waffle cone and she loved it. In Hayes Valley? You need to stop by!
author: Matthew L.

description: if you love ice cream, im more of a once in a while fro-yo - non dairy person -- this place is open late and offers just a few options - simple, gourmet style, local
author: Caroline L.

description:
Aside from costing an arm and a leg.....I'm Smitten for life!!

Everytime I come into town, I HAVE TO, and I mean HAVE TO get my Smitten fix. It's just a requirement...

It's my favorite ice cream place in the whole world (so far...) So cool how they make the ice cream in the spinning Kelvin machine. My favorite flavor is the Olive Oil and the Cardamon flavor. Also, don't let Vanilla fool you...Vanilla here is far from being plain, ordinary, and boring. It is silky smooth and DER-LiCIOUS!!

I would say the one flavor I was not a fan of is the Necterine, which I unfortuatnely got this past visit. SAD FACE!! I wanted to change it out, but line was too long! (As it always is) 

Can't wait to see you expand to LA!!
author: Wendy L.

description: Wow.  Amazing ice cream.  So creamy and different.  The flavors are wonderful. Definitely worth a try!
author: Yana K.

description: Wow, initially i thought this place was a gimmick, expecting it to be more of a magic show rather than quality ice cream, but boy was i wrong. Not only was the making of ice cream a scene to watch, the ice cream itself was so smooth, velvety and creamy! Eat it fast, because it does melt relatively fast. Also get the largest portion and share...much better deal that way. Definitely the best ice cream in hayes valley and arguably, sf.
author: John W.

description:
I am always down for new experiences and ME getting to see Smitten make my ice cream, right in my face with liquid nitrogen,. is pretty darn cool !

I had the mint ice cream with TCHO chocolate chip PLUS brittle covered pistachio.  

The mint ice cream, tasted really minty.  It actually reminded me of the mint leaf taste in my pho bowl. Yes, that is what the mint taste, reminds me of. The pistachio was the ADDED topping that made my ice cream taste so much better.  My brother ordered the fresh fruit ice cream and he didn't really like it, cause it tasted plain.  But he did enjoy it when I shared half of my brittle pistachio with him.  

They sell the brittle pistachio in its own bag, I will purchase it next time. Although the prices they charge are high ($5 for a small ice cream), I def recommend my foodies to try this place.
author: Chanel L.

description: The prices are through the roof for a mostly novel experience, including the roof itself--the restaurant is located inside of a converted container, which adds some hipster chic to the atmosphere, but still doesn't make those prices palatable.  That's where the ice cream comes in: they make it right in front of you using a patented machine that blasts the ingredients with liquid nitrogen, flash freezing them into ice cream.  While it's fun to watch and produces a unique flavor, it's hard to swallow the $6+ price tag for little more than a few licks of dessert.
author: Patrick R.

description: Great place to grab some dessert after dinner in the neighborhood.  I personally don't like ice cream that's rock hard and been frozen for a long time, so the made-to-order texture of Smitten's ice cream is delicious!  Last time I had rhubarb crisp, it was sweet, tart, and the crisp added great texture.  They don't usually change up the flavors the last times I've gone here, so the rhubarb crisp was a nice change.
author: Mirba E.

description:
What they say is true -- is creamier. We tried the seasonal squash maple whatever. It was really good. 

Not quite a 5 star experience because it's kinda pricey as ice cream goes. But, def. good. It's right next to a park so you can enjoy your cream in the sun 12 days out of the year, and otherwise under the clouds. The folks behind the counter were quite friendly, too.
author: Rob R.

description:
I had the strawberry balsamic and really liked it. Great texture, specially once it's melted a little. I loved the contrast the balsamic provided.

A bit pricey and the portions could be larger, so a star off. Service was friendly and since it was a weekday I didn't have to wait for more than 5 minutes.
author: Chetan G.

description: It's pretty cool watching the liquid nitrogen get mixed with the ice cream, giving the ice cream an incredibly smooth consistency. Now I've never tried liquid nitrogen ice cream so when the spoon hit my mouth, I experience what can only be described as liquid nitrogen ice cream in my mouth. The two flavors I tried were both AMAZING. It's also located in a pretty cool neighborhood so it's great to walk around the area. The only downside is the price, but it's definitely worth trying.
author: Matthew M.

description:
1. Ordered a waffle cone (one of my favorite part of ice cream experience), they ran out and offered a topping that is only .75 cents (waffle cone cosy 1.00 dollar). 

2. Long wait, liquid nitrogen process didn't seen to be that unique of a taste. Honestly, eating with a spoon from a cup doesn't feel like real ice cream. 

I guess I would like to go back, try the ice cream in a cone without any toppings to get the full experience.
author: Daniel K.

description:
Smitten has a lot going for it: interesting liquid-nitrogen ice cream process, incredibly fresh ingredients, and a nice neighborhood within which to be planted. As cool as the process is, however, there are some drawbacks: the wait is much longer than it needs to be (especially with an already long Summer day line), there are only 4 flavors, and you can't get more than 1 flavor in your cup/cone. 

Some may say these are necessary evils for amazing ice cream, but I say that the ice cream really isn't THAT amazing to warrant the long lines and flavor limitations. You may say "Well, Bi-Rite and Humphry Slocombe also have tremendously long lines!" To which I reply: "Well, I think Bi-Rite and Humphry Slocombe taste much better and there's more to choose from, which justifies the wait. At least more so than Smitten, that is."

I got the Mint w/ TCHO Chocolate Chip, which tasted phenomenally fresh. This is the first time I've had mint ice cream that actually tastes like real mint leaves, rather than artificial green-colored flavoring. It was definitely refreshing, but keep in mind that "fresh" doesn't always equate to "delicious," especially when it comes to ice cream. 

The texture and consistency is a bit too airy for ice cream -- it lacks that creaminess that puts the "cream" in ice cream. I'm sure many people will prefer it to the buttery texture of ice cream like Bi-Rite or Humphry Slocombe, but for me, it's more like the fat-free ice cream knockoffs you find in the diet section of your grocer's freezer. 

Of course, I didn't get to try any of the other flavors because of their stupid 1 flavor maximum. 

Anyway, Smitten is an interesting addition to the already saturated ice cream market in SF. It's worth trying if you like your ice cream to be a bit lighter and fresher than usual. For me, however, if I'm going out of my way to wait in line for ice cream, all I care about is taste and texture, and in that sense, there are many other better offerings in SF than Smitten.
author: Roy C.

description:
IMO: SF worthy.

TCHO Chocolate
Strawberry Creme Freche
Salted Caramel
author: James G.

description: I love smitten! It's one of my favorite ice cream places in the city next to bi-rite creamery. I tend to be a froyo type of person over ice cream but I'm always down for smitten. Watching them make the liquid nitrogen ice cream is a pretty cool experience. They don't have millions of flavors like other ice cream places but the tcho chocolate is pretty good. I recommend getting your ice cream in a waffle cone - they are homemade and taste soo good.
author: Allie M.

description:
More of a 3.5 stars.
I understand why my brother loves this place.
The ice cream is indeed ridiculously smooth (due to the ice cyrstals being smaller as the posters explain the science behind why their ice cream is different) but that also works to its disadvantage because it melts quicker. After a few minutes, the thing started melting really really fast. : (

But flavor-wise, it was great.
It almost reminded me of more like gelato than the heavier fattier ice creams of other SF ice cream places.
I loved that Smitten gives you mix-in topping options to make your own flavor combintations and vary up the texture!

I got the vanilla with pistachio brittle and maple brown sugary syrup.
Pizzete cone? So good!!! So delicate and crispy and fresh.
Ice cream wise, overall...I probably prefer Bi-Rite or Mr & Mrs M but if there was a way to keep the ice cream from metling too quickly (that is, if the first few bites of ice cream were the same until the end, Smitten would win hands down.
Plus, those pizettes!!! MmmM!!!
author: Sabrina L.

description: I try to get here every trip to San Francisco for a dish of the TCHO Chocolate. Super creamy dark chocolate ice cream with no bitter aftertaste - best I've ever had.
author: Bob P.

description: Some people like to go shopping at new stores while on vacation; I love finding new ice cream shops. I hit 5 in SF in one day (judge away) and Smitten was far and away the best. Very cool concept and well executed! I had to wait in line a bit (it was a Sunday afternoon), but the wait time between the line-my ice cream didn't feel long at all. The ice cream tasted creamier than all the others of the day and had great flavor. I raved about it to a few friends and will definitely be back next time I'm in SF!
author: Leah Y.

description: I came here on a Saturday evening. The whole idea behind making the ice cream fresh, right in front of your eyes is really cool. I got the vanilla and my friend had the chocolate and mint. The texture is really fluffy and my vanilla scoop reminded me of cool whip. The mint is actually very minty, like the herb, reminiscent of the mojito flavor. Overall and interesting concept and I wouldn't mind trying out other flavors here in the future.
author: Katya O.

description: This place just about kicks any other ice cream joints tooshy. Fresh ingredients with a lively experience. I love that you don't have to worry about overly-pasteurized and homogenized dairy. High five to the creater/owner! Keep it up.
author: Bree G.

description: They have the best employees that I've ever seen. People this ice cream shop has like the best ice cream ever. Please check out their ice cream shop. Rate them 5 stars :)
author: Johnny L.

description: The chocolate is CREAMY and, thus, dreamy.  The ice cream flavors are pre-fixed, but it's fun to see your order transform before you.  The place is pretty cozy, despite the nitrogen blasting.  It's a great place, and fun experience.  They're also generous with the brittle!  Unless you love the taste of chewing handfuls of fresh mint, I'd skip that flavor- it's creamy, but too "mint" for my taste.
author: Diane N.

description:
It's an okay good place to go for ice cream in this part of San Francisco. 

The experience of being there I think is better than the ice cream. There are only 3 different types ice creams and it's pretty cool how they mix the ice cream right there and you just wait for your ice cream to finish up.

I had the peach ice cream and it was pretty good. If you have the time and find parking you coming here is a must try. But I think there are better places to go for ice cream. Also, it's more pricier than other ice cream places I have been to in San Francisco. The price for a small was about $5.
author: Denice D.

description:
I love the fact that its fresh.  I hate the fact that you cannot mix flavors. Sometimes the flavors are awesome, sometimes the flavors are just okay. It's awesome that you can add a lot different syrup too. 

It's usually a 5-10 minute wait, not too bad. I wouldn't say its worth it if you had to wait longer than that though. Bi-rite is definitely better.
author: Mo W.

description:
Good creamy ice cream made directly in front of you. The flavors taste very authentic and not artificial - the mint ice cream leaves you with fresh breath all day!

A small scoop is $4.75. Pricey, but a fun experience to eat ice cream made with liquid nitrogen. The ice cream is incredibly smooth and creamy, but the only downside is it melts SUPER fast, so lick lick lick away!!
author: Debbie L.

description:
Thanks to Kelvin (the machine), we can now all enjoy ice-cream that is freshly made - in front of us!

Yes, line was long. And there weren't even that many flavors.....honestly, I think it's quite pricey for ice-cream. Is it worth it? Not necessary.....it's the "IDEA" that Smitten is selling.

Yes, the ice-cream did taste smoother and creamier than "normal" ice-cream. I've tried vanilla and chocolate so far, and chocolate definitely tasted better. In general, it's a bit too sweet for me after all.

Is it worth trying? If you've never had "liquid-nitrogen" ice-cream, it's worth to try. But I'm not a huge fan.
author: Louisa L.

description: Ok. I had the vanilla ice cream Not something I went crazy over. Actually threw away half of my serving bc it was too rich and felt like I was gaining lbs with each bite.
author: Sylvia K.

description: Small shop with a long line. More of a tourist attraction than anything. There are only a couple daily flavours to choose from and the cost is fairly high for ice cream. Nevertheless, it is a place to stop by to watch them make some fresh smooth ice cream.
author: Jackie H.

description: Although Smitten has a limited variety of flavors to try, the whole process of how they make them is worth the experience! Very modernistic and casual atmosphere with nice staff. I tried the sticky toffee pudding flavor and was satisfied. Portions can be somewhat small but you can always get more than one scoop to compensate. Price is okay but if you are in the area, give Smitten a try because it is worth the experience at least once.
author: Al B.

description: In a brand-new trend (that I hope catches on everywhere), Smitten actually makes your ice-cream order right in front of you...when you order it!  The dark chocolate ice cream is to die for, it's probably the best I've ever had. There's no fake food here either, this ice cream is all natural! The line is usually out-the-door, the seating is limited, and the parking is almost non-existent; but this is San Francisco, so take the BART here (it's about 5 minutes from Civic Center) and enjoy the beautiful sunshine in the nearby park while you savor some fresh-make chocolaty (or other flavor) awesomeness.
author: Brian S.

description: Ice cream was OK but for that price, it should have been spectacular.  I won't be back.
author: S.K. R.

description:
Okay, to be honest, the salted caramel was too strong. And I was really confused by the menu. But this is kinda how it works.

1.) You pick an ice cream flavor, they typically have 3.
2.) You pick some mix-in's or sauce for a little extra.
3.) The board tells you what the suggested add-ons are, just in case you need help.
4.) You order and watch the liquid nitrogen magic!

I love the idea, but the journey is way too far for something I'm not in love with. But maybe next time it'll charm my pants off. You never know.
author: Jessica H.

description:
San Franciscans universally praise Bi-Rite as THE most delicious ice cream, but Smitten is severely underrated. Its simplicity makes decision-making swift and painless, but quality is not lost at all in any flavor. The creamy texture produced by liquid nitrogen is more than satisfying. My all-time favorite remains Tcho-chocolate, the very definition of richness and decadence. 

Whenever friends from out of town are visiting, I would take them to Smitten, which is almost representative of the charmed life we're all enjoying in San Francisco - chill, tech-savvy, quality over quantity. Sure, it's kind of pricey for one cup of ice cream, but you get what you pay for.
author: Nancy L.

description:
I've only been to Smitten once but wuz gud. 
I got a single scoop. 
They're tiny.
