The employee asked if I wanted dark chocolate sau--Yes! I will always take dark chocolate sauce at anytime on anything, thank you for asking. 
It wasn't dark- did I mishear? It didn't taste like much.

Their sign said something about Tcho chocolate (I reFUSE to Tcheck the spelling). 
That name bugs me. 
A brand name you have to research to learn how to pronounce and that conjures nothing.

Is this a pretentious thing? 
I hate pretentiousness, grrrr, black smoke, hissing cats...


Anyway, it wasn't DARK. 
It was light brown and didn't taste dark. 
Take your chocolate and go away, TtCHTo, and don't Tchoke on it.
Or here's a random T, tchoke on that.

Could not detect the maple in the maple whipped-cream,
but real whipped-cream is a thing of beauty so who cares.

The ice cream was smooth, dense, comforting and jealousy-inducing. 
People walking by on the sidewalk were like, "Where you get that, bitch?"
Typical Hayes Valley.
Wear your gang colors.
 
They close at 10 pm. Nice. 
San Francisco is the city that sleeps at night, so I'm thrilled by any small food or coffee shop that's open after dark. 

Smitten has one narrow bench and heat lamps.
author: Lame Lake Meese Z.

description: Man when I first saw the sizes for the price you pay, I just about cried. But, the second I put the first bite of the mint chip ice cream in my mouth, it was worth every penny. Never had I had mint chip ice cream that tasted like actual mint, not just some artificial flavor that is supposed to resemble mint. THIS ICE CREAM IS LEGIT
author: Austin F.

description: Probably the best chocolate ice cream I've had, so smooth. It wasn't too sweet, unlike some other ice creams that make you thirsty. It's dense but not too hard. A small looks tiny but it's plenty. I got mine with toasted walnuts, it tasted like eating a brownie. So good! I would love to try another flavor, but as long as they have chocolate, how can I skip it?
author: Kathleen M.

description:
Yes I am a fan, but not too dedicated that I would rank it as my go-to place. I was initially in the area to try schulzies but to my disappointment, they were closed when they were supposed to be open according to their business hours. My bf and I walked over to smitten to check out just how smitten we would be. The line to order was not long, it was the wait for an ice cream that was long. 

We were told it would be 10-20 minutes for any flavor and deciding that I don't come to the area often, I went ahead and ordered a TCHO with spicy caramel. My ice cream cost just under $6 for a small. I waited over 20 minutes but I knew they were working the best they could. I was actually a bit annoyed because they started offering free toppings to patrons ahead of me and bc I already paid for a topping, they just handed me. I thought they maybe could have added more caramel or even add another topping. Didn't seem very fair that they offered to everyone else ahead of me and I was offered nothing, not even "thanks for waiting" as they had said to everyone else. Wompppp. 

My cup lasted less than half my wait time and though it was smooth, there wasn't enough for me to savor and remember the experience. 

I still love variety and as much as yelpers will disagree with me, I still love Joe's ice cream where I can choose more for less:)
author: Connie C.

description:
I do think the ice cream is phenomenal here. I had the salted caramel, and admittedly I do have a soft spot for anything that is salted caramel, so I just had to get it. I had it with the brittle which was really amazing, it added the perfect crunch. I do recommend following what they pair it with, but you should definitely experiment with the toppings as well. The ice cream is made fresh and it melts quickly so don't wait too long to dig in! This place is nicely located in Hayes Valley and there is a lot of pleasant outside seating. 
One issue however is that the ice cream is heavily on the sweeter side, even a little too sweet for me, and I have a huge sweet tooth.
I am amused by the fact that the ambiance is considered hipster. I second that.
It is a really nice place and I highly recommend coming here.
author: Veronica L.

description:
I went to this place because one of my friend ask me to go, and I was little disappoint about this place.  First, the line was really long, I had to wait for around 20 mins. Second, after I got the ice cream, it was different flavor. It was not what I ordered.
maybe they were too busy? will I don't know. 
But I tried the ice cream anyway, and another disappointment. The ice cream was too sweet for my taste. I had to drink water after eating the ice cream.
It was really bad experience for me.
author: Kavin H.

description: Good intense chocolate flavour. Vanilla was different from most I've tasted but pretty good. Strawberry was quite tasteless even with the balsamic. The best thing about this place was the novelty of seeing the liquid nitrogen and the machine that makes the ice cream.
author: Flo L.

description: First time here and decided to try the honey nectarine flavor with the cone. It came with a special nectarine sauce on top which added a nice touch to it. However, the ice cream was okay. The honey flavor was too overpowering and couldn't taste the nectarine. Cone was definitely different then the usual. Definitely a spot worth trying.
author: Anne H.

description:
I had a regular Earl grey with chocolate chip last night. 

It was amazing. The flavor is unique and you get to see them make ice cream in front of you immediately with liquid nitrogen... such a chic & geeky place for having ice-cream.

It's suitable for to-go and require some waiting time.
author: Krist W.

description:
It's aight...
Got chocolate, salted caramel, and butternut squash flavors.
Nothing blew my mind. All of them were overly sweet for me.
They did have a vegan pop made with coconut milk. I wish I tried it. But at least they have something for lactards.
author: David C.

description: Let's not kid ourselves. This ice cream is one of the best, if not the best. I have yet to see another ice creamery at this level in SF. The cookie dough pretzel... Worth every calorie, fat and sugar gram, carb, whatever other ingredient you're trying to avoid this week. Smitten's the real deal. Eat it with no regrets.
author: V A.

description: My boy bought a pint to bring back home to his gf  and he dropped it on the ground on his way to his car like a 5 year old boy- and the look on his face... man, if you have a soft spot for sad 5 year olds, you'd feel real bad for this 28 year old after seeing his face. i swear i saw his eyes water up but my boy is strong- sucked those tears up like a runny nose on a frosty day. He did the walk of shame back and asked the friendly staff with his sad puppy eyes if it's okay they could hook him up with another one and to my surprise they did! they also gave him a paper bag so he wouldn't drop it again. mad props to those girls working that night.
author: J C.

description:
I am smitten with smitten!
If you thought you knew ice cream and haven't been here, you have no idea what fabulous, dream-inspiring ice cream is.
I think I said, "this is sooo good" at least 15 times while eating my salted caramel.
A small serving is probably enough for most people.  It's so creamy and you know exactly what's going into your delicious treat.
Employees are very nice and you can watch as your serving is made.
If I could give 6 stars to this place, I would.

GO!
I didn't feel a hipster vide at all...and I hate hipster vibes.  I felt the employees actually cared about serving a good quality product.  

It wasn't busy at all when I was there, but I guess it could get busy.  Worth the wait.

Plenty of places outside around the back (at the coffee shop) to sit, if you don't feel like standing or sitting inside smitten.
author: Lynn T.

description:
Not a fan! Oh yea they make they ice cream fresh, BUT I don't really think waiting over 10mins for ice cream is really worth it. 

Got the salted carmel-first few bites are really good after that i felt sick. Way too creamy. The taste gets sickening after awhile. 

BI RITE all the way!
author: Karen H.

description:
I am smitten with Smitten (okay I'm probably the 200th person to say that on their review of Smitten).  But it's SO true!

-First off, it's in the Park in chic and friendly Hayes.  
-They make the ice-cream fresh after you order via a Kelvin mixer!
-I love that it's a quaint but no nonsense stand with minimal yet plenty of sitting via being in the MIDDLE OF A PARK!  *Sorry that was for those people who complain that Smitten doesn't have enough seating, when they are in the middle of a park with hundreds of grass and bench butt-parking spots.

The ice-cream itself was amazing!
We had: 
-Brown sugar with cinnamon shortbread cooking pairing.
-Mint chip with brownie type bites

The flavors were spot on, the texture was heavenly since it was freshly made and the pairings are always amazing!

I normally don't order a cone because i only enjoy a fresh waffle cone but the decadently buttery short bread cone was out of this world!

My favorite ice-cream joint in the City by far!
author: Anthony L.

description:
Okay, I've been here twice now And both times I've been officially smitten. What this ice cream shop does is they take liquid nitrogen and spin fresh ingredients to make a fresh personalized batch of ice cream just for you! It's like if you took the Philz concept for coffee and applied it to ice cream, you'd have Smitten - ice cream made to order. 

Because of they make the ice cream completely from scratch when you order it, they keep the number of flavors down to four at most that you end up specializing with various toppings. 

What you get is an extremely dense and creamy ice cream that is free of the ice crystals you find in many other ice creams. The difference is pretty evident in the creaminess of Smitten's creations. 

And FYI this is a huge stand outdoors so bring a sweater on those cold nights you are hankering for a little ice cream treat. The only thing cold should be your freshly made scoop!
author: Rajiv S.

description: I like getting the salted caramel with TCHO on top. This ice cream is good, but I wouldn't imagine myself waiting that long for it. It's in a nice part of the city that is fun to walk around after enjoying your dessert.
author: Chad C.

description:
You know the trendy it-spot you must visit before all your friends do so they can comment on your check-in like "OMG, soooo jealous!! how was it?!!1"
Smitten is presently that spot. There's no doubt that they have an innovative concept (anything with custom machinery is bound to be a hit here). The question is whether they have staying power.

They certainly do have the perfect location in Hayes Valley right next to that park with the decaying zombie cyborg woman statue. I also imagine they're not paying much to lease the parking lot land where their converted metal storage box storefront sits. Moreover, given their present popularity and prices I'm sure they'll have no problem recouping the fixed costs of the bespoke liquid nitrogen ice cream makers. Thus we come back to the question of what happens after their first summer?

Another way to phrase this would be - can the ice cream stand on its own? My answer is it's certainly good, and if I lived in Hayes I'd stop by every now and then, but sadly it's nothing I'd wait 20 minutes in line for. The flavors are intense and the texture is super creamy, but it also melts into soup super quickly (I guess that's the dual edged sword of liquid nitrogen). 

In order for Smitten to become a staple they need to enginner amazing flavors that last with the same creative vigor that they used to create their ice cream makers.
author: Max G.

description: Cool concept and a fun place to check out in Hayes Valley. Tried the vanilla and the caramel, both flavors were fine but can't hold a candle to Bi Rite. Texture was nicely dense though.
author: Philip L.

description: Straight up the best ice cream I have ever had. The salted caramel has such a strong flavor.
author: Ben Z.

description: I ordered the cookie dough ice cream, it was made in front of me and was very good. The process of making the ice cream is also super fun to watch as it is done in front of the customer.
author: Romain D.

description: This place never disappoints!  I was here exactly 2 years ago and their ice cream is still as good as ever, great consistency.  Today I ordered the Rhubarb with strawberry preserves, and oh boy! did the strawberry compliment the flavor of the rhubarb.  Its a nice little ice cream stand, where they use nitrogen to make your ice cream.  The lines can get long at times but I feel it's worth the wait.  Also you can go next door to the Bier Garden to have a few before or after!    Enjoy!
author: Seng S.

description:
Ok, first, the process is probably the most interesting part of the Smitten experience.  You get to watch the servers take milk, put it in a mixer with liquid nitrogen, and then scrape out someone (you hope it's your) icecream.  

The board claims that this "ready in 90 second" process is supposed to get you less ice crystals and thus creamier, smoother icecream.  

Well, either it was too hot that day, the server didn't do it right, or the process doesn't work, because the ice cream that came out was pretty much exactly the same, if not less creamy, than Humphry and the other places we went to.  

That said, the mint ice cream was AMAZINGLY minty--as in fresh mint.  Add to that the less sweet base meant a truly refreshing flavor that I'd not tasted before.  The TCHO chocolate topping was very meager, however, and the portion was not huge for the price.  I think it must have something to do with labor intensive process.  

Also, there were only 3 flavors--again, likely due to the labor-intense, bespoke process.  Smitten compensates by having many toppings, but not many toppings will change the fundamental flavor of the ice cream.  

The day I went, there were 2 other flavors - chocolate and a honey flavor.  We only tried mint and chocolate.  And while the mint was great, the chocolate was pretty much completely standard.  Sure it was spiced up, no pun intended, with shortbread and some other stuff, but at the end of the day, if we'd not witnessed the process, would likely not have been wow'ed.  

So, worth going largely for picture taking, and if you're in the hood.  If the mint is there, go for it!
author: Jay C.

description: Does not live up to the hype. Our one scoops were made from a previously made pot minutes before and they said they couldn't combine flavors or give samples. Decent ice cream but not worth going back/ the build up/ the price ($5/scoop).
author: Meredith C.

description: Ice cream was average. Chocolate was smooth but lacked in richness. Cookie  cream felt younger and raw. Fun experience.
author: andrew l.

description: Only vegan options they had were popsicles, so i got the Strawberry Basil popsicle. The strawberry and basil worked great together! Unfortunately, for the size of it, $3.50 just seems much too hefty of a price. I do like this place though. Worth coming if you're not a vegan or lactose intolerant!
author: Anna K.

description:
A long line out the door at 9:45 pm on a Friday!

This place makes fresh ice cream right in front of your face. The line can be a bit long, and the prices are not low, but it's worth it. Absolutely delicious!
author: Eric v.

description:
Pretty cool for the novelty of the ice cream since it's made with liquid nitrogen, but I'm more of a Humphry Slocombe or Bi Rite gal.

I will say the Rhubarb Crisp ice cream I had was really yummy. The location is nice too because you can either eat your ice cream there in the seats of Smitten or cross the street and hang out in the park.
author: Alison H.

description:
Used to be my favorite spot for ice cream and I would jump at the chance to come and get some of the deliciousness.

For some reason the last time I came here I just wasn't as impressed with it as I used to be. Got vanilla on a cone with cocoa nibs and caramel sauce. So sad...It just didn't live up to my expectations. it was super creamy, just not vanilla-y enough for me. I also used to love the toffee topping they had. Not sure i'd go out of my way to come here again
author: Bon N.

description:
Came to Smitten knowing nothing about them. At first we thought it seemed kind of pricey and then we had to wait. We didn't realize our ice cream was being MADE TO ORDER! What a concept! Anyhoo... A bit later I am being summoned and handed my fresh mint chip. HOLY CRAP! 
ONE OF THE BEST ICE CREAMS EVER! We honestly can't explain it other than its creamy, it's fresh, it's amazingly flavorful...WE ARE IN LOVE. Thank goodness we don't live closer because we would be here every single freaking day...rain, fog, or shine.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description: Using liquid nitrogen to make ice cream is a cool concept, but I found the ice cream way too sweet for my tastes. I had the salted caramel flavor, and the sweetness was almost overwhelming by the time i finished my scoop.
author: Rosanna K.

description:
I had passed by Smitten a number of times before, but had never stopped to try their ice cream. With such a plethora of delicious ice cream places in SF, I didn't really think that I needed to add another to my list.

Tonight, I changed my mind, largely because I haven't eaten ice cream in a long time and the delicious smells emanating from the Smitten kitchen were so tantalizing. The two flavors available today were strawberry white balsamic and classic vanilla. After much deliberation I decided to go with classic vanilla with the brown sugar caramel topping and the homemade waffle cone. 

The Husband was skeptical about the effect of liquid nitrogen on the ice cream. Was the difference really noticeable? Well, 60 seconds after our order we found out.

With my first bite I was...you got it, smitten. The texture of the ice cream is so rich and creamy and smooth. It's like soft serve ice cream with better texture, if that makes sense. The flavor is fantastic with the Madagascar vanilla coming through nice and strong. The brown sugar caramel topping wasn't too sweet and provided a nice complement to the vanilla flavor. The waffle cone with tasty. I liked how it wasn't too crunchy or too soft.

This is definitely one of the most expensive ice cream places in San Francisco. A small will cost you almost five dollars and a regular will cost you six bucks. This being the case, how does Smitten stack up against the other ice cream places?

Well, the comparable places in San Francisco are probably Bi-Rite, Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous and Humphrey Slocombe because of their creamy factor. These other ice cream places have more creative and interesting flavor combinations and are cheaper. I would say that Bi-Rite is the closest texture-wise but their flavors are more concentrated. What Smitten has going for it is really the liquid nitrogen factor (which really does make the ice cream super-smooth). I don't know that I would choose Smitten each time because of the price but I'm definitely going back!
author: Christine P.

description:
The science of this concept is pretty awesome. Liquid nitrogen ice cream. It reminds me of my 7th grade science class. 

The ice cream is pretty pricey but it's a lot., even for the small. I don't recommend coming here after eating a huge meal. I needed help eating it. Definitely pay the extra $1 for a cone. They make their own cones and they are so delicious. They are the best cones on this planet. If I could, I would just buy the cone. The whole ride back home was about how delicious the cone was. 

Flavors are pretty limited, but they're good! I ordered the olive oil with lavender shortcake. I thought the olive oil was too strong but the lavender shortcake bits were delicious.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
The first time I tried it was some sort of cinnamon and shortbread flavor. It was pure delight in my mouth. I kind of sad that I haven't seen it on the menu since then! I haven't had any bad experiences with it, and I'm kind of picky with my ice cream. Their salted caramel is comparable to the deliciousness of Bi-Rite, but of course they're good in their own ways. The mint with TCHO mint chip was very interesting because you can really taste the mint leaves, which I'm usually not fond of, but it grew on me. 

The workers are always friendly and patient with the long lines. They have heating lamps above at night, which helps in SF's crappy weather.
author: Kathy L.

description: Which ever ice cream you order, definitely get it with what they suggest pairs well with it. The first time I tried smitten, I played it safe and just got a scoop of vanilla, and that was it. It was strangely powdery and not smooth and creamy as all. So it totally turned me off. But I'm always one to give places a second, sometimes even third, try. I returned this past weekend and ordered the Creme Fraiche and paired it with what they suggested: pear caramel and cinnamon shortbread. It was delicious! Everything tasted so well together, never have I ever had such a great experience with ice cream toppings! I just wish they have more flavors.
author: Lina C.

description: This place gets packed once the weather gets warmer.  I like the salted caramel and classic vanilla.  They offer 4 flavors per day.
author: Michelle B.

description:
I thought $5 for a small cup was pushing it, but I really enjoyed it. I had their Creme Fraiche (with Pear Caramel). The flavor reminded me of Greek yogurt, but creamier (and fraicher).

I also tried the Vanilla and was not as impressed. Although, come to think of it, I'm not a huge fan of Vanilla ice cream in general.

If you like smooth, creamy ice cream and see a flavor that jumps out to you, it's worth a try.
author: Rachel Y.

description:
I'm sorry, did a small scoop of ice cream (which, by the way, smelled like butter.. I wish I was kidding) just cost me $4.75?

Even though there were only 3 people in front of my culinary soulmate Sara P. and me, we waited a good bit to give our order, and after that, it was about 5 minutes for me to get my ice cream (I think they make one flavor batch at a time).  The flavors today were TCHO Chocolate, vanilla, blood orange with pistachio shortbread crumbs, and brown butter pecan.

Sara P. went for the chocolate, and I opted for blood orange.  Seriously, it smelled like butter.  As in, it was kind of nasty.  It tasted delicious though; sweet, creamy orange ice cream with crumbled pistachio shortbread pieces.  I would've preferred blood orange sorbet in this unseasonably warm weather, but this had great orange flavor.

The texture of the ice cream itself is very creamy and airy.  It's probably a billion calories, and it melts quicker than I'd like.  I can see the draw in not having ice cream frozen and re-frozen, but this is in no way efficient, because if there were more than 5 people in line before me, I'd have to wait ages JUST to get my ice cream.

No thanks, I wasn't smitten.
author: Tori S.

description:
The essence:

-Long line & long wait for your ice cream because it's more or less made to order
-Liquid nitrogen & space-age machines make for the most exciting show since Dippin' Dots & dry ice in old school haunted houses
-Cool, creamy, & savory. It doesn't take much to get the job done (NOTE: there is a miniature/"kids" size with only 1 small scoop, & only $3 and some change)
-Seasonal flavors (lavender, honey nectarine, corn & berry, + some classics...)
-Beware: iciness may singe tongue!
author: Briana F.

description:
What luck! We walked right up to the counter without having to wait in line. Thirty seconds later there were 20 people behind us. 

Ice cream is not too sweet and doesn't leave you with the sugary after taste. It's a tad pricey though and you have to wait quite a while for your ice cream to be made.
author: Jeanne C.

description: Came here with some co-workers after lunch. I got a single scoop of the espresso. It was freshly made and the ice cream was good and creamy, but I think it was a bit too pricey. $5 for a single scoop.
author: Mimi K.

description:
I rarely give reviews below three stars and if Smitten's prices weren't so high, this probably would be a three-star review.

I really don't see the hype with this place. I guess it's cool how they make the ice cream with each order (a process which you get to see and witness), but I think that's really what you're paying for because the ice cream isn't that great and one scoop with toppings can set you back one happy hour drink (the one thing law school has taught me is how to value things in terms of the number of drinks you can buy).

The ice cream I ordered (the chocolate with almond brittle topping) was just too rich - it was like eating a melted down candy bar. I also found the texture to be odd. It was way too velvety and creamy. Yeah, I know what you're thinking, how could this be a bad thing? Well, it can be when you feel like you're eating cold cream butter.

Again, I would probably be more of a fun if I didn't spend $4 on one scoop of ice cream, but for the experience, I think I can pass on Smitten.
author: Linna L.

description:
I would always encourage someone to check Smitten out if they haven't already. However, once was enough for me. The little shop is adorable and the made to order ice cream set up is so unique and interesting. I loved reading about the process of kelvin-ing the ice cream and how the shop was started. But it was pricey and I didn't think it was anything super special. I had the peach ice cream with salted caramel sauce. The peach ice cream was creamy but it wasn't very peachy. The peach was so subtle I could have missed it. The salted caramel sauce was very very tasty but the consistency was too gummy. It didn't mix well with the ice cream but instead stayed separated. 

CP's mint chocolate ice cream was better than mine. The mint was very minty. It tasted fresh from the garden. I would definitely recommend this over my peach. If you do go here get your ice cream in a cone. Their cones are very cool. Almost like cookies.

All in all, there are so many wonderful ice cream shops in SF that it's hard to pick which one to go to. But maybe skip this one unless you are nearby.
author: Tai F.

description: Cute space, cute idea, good ice cream! But sort of high prices, I guess you're paying for the experience and the gimmick.
author: Jessie M.

description:
Tough to review this place. I went once and the ice cream was fantastic. Went a second time and it was meh.  It's a fun concept, so what's a girl to do?

Go a third time, of course! Smitten, I'll be back.  Three stars for now.
author: Mara S.

description:
Smitten definitely has a hip vibe, which is perfectly located at Hayes Valley. Their "factory" is inside an old shipping container, equipped with a row of gnarly ice cream making mixers. 4-6 scoops are made with each order as each machine mixes up liquid nitrogen with their daily creamy concoctions. In a big white poof of magic, my Salted Caramel was ready. I ordered it with a fresh waffle cone, which in my opinion is the best deal as it only cost an extra $1 and they give you two scoops. 

I had expected the ice cream to be more icy, but surprisingly the nitrogen kept it nice and creamy. I was also able to taste the Rhubarb Crisp, which was really refreshing.

Overall thoughts : Great ice cream and good waffle cone. It's also fun to watch them make it! The only downside is they only have 3-4 flavors a day, so the more picky patrons may be disappointed. I on the other hand, will definitely come back to visit.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
I'm sorry... I got the thin mint chocolate chip with pistachio brittle. The thin mint didn't top my childhood favorite Swensen's ice cream. It wasn't as tasty, or as creamy, or as thick. It also tasted like basil!! 

The pistachio brittle was delicious though. But the ice cream didn't do it. For 5.25? And it was tiny!!
author: Kayla O.

description:
Concept: brilliant.
Price: hurts.

While the concept of a made-to-order ice cream is quite novel, the price just doesn't back it up for me.  The ice cream itself is not bad.  But for $6+ for a single scoop of ice cream, no cone, it's a bit pricey for the average Jane Doe.  I'd try it once and maybe again if friends were new in town, but I'd rather get a pint of Three Twins Ice Cream, thankyouverymuch.
author: Tori Q.

description:
Oh so yummy!

I love this science experiment, using liquid nitrogen to male ice cream! What they say is true: it is creamier ice cream than anywhere else I've been (and I've been to a lot of ice cream places!) 

Yumm..thinking about going tonight now!
author: Clara N.

description:
I got Crème Fraîche with Pear Caramel with their housemade cone. 

It was good but I would recommend NOT getting the cone if you choose this flavor as the caramel leaks from the bottom :(

The pear caramel was DELICIOUS! Oh my goodness, you can seriously taste the pear!!!! 

I highly recommend it :D The FRESH Mint Chocolate Chip was amazing too!
author: Lisa H.

description: I love the blood orange. Wasn't sure if it would work so well as a citrus fruit in ice cream but it was excellent. Better than the mint chocolate chip and chocolate.
author: Xteethx B.

description: Ice cream was The Best! All natural ingredients. I can still taste the fresh mint today. It was a cold windy day but the people kept coming, a  testament to the quality.
author: Matthew H.

description: Had the lemon gingersnap in a cone with the brown sugar caramel sauce. Delicious. I get that every serving is made-to-order, but I wish they were a bit faster (though, granted, it seems only one person was working in the middle of the day).
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Very nice and friendly staff, guided us through all the way. Their ice cream is very special, the taste is unique & absolutely perfect.

Highly recommend.
author: Nejc T.

description: I wanted to like this place but it was just ok.  They only offer 3 flavors  a day & they are made fresh & to order for each customer. We tried lemon ginger which wasn't bad but wasn't great. The salted caramel was kind of flat, didn't taste the salt & the caramel flavor was lacking.  The pistachio brittle topping that we got for the  salted caramel was DELISH!!!  I would just get a bag of that to go.  Also, pricey for a small scoop.  I would much rather go to Humphry Slocombe for some ice cream
author: Deborah B.

description:
I was more impressed with the cone than the ice cream.
We all got chocolate and it was very tasty.

The multi colored hair hipster beyotch at the register couldn't have seemed less interested if she tried.
Kind of a bum out.
It's an ice cream place lady! It attracts kids and their goofy relatives.

There is a playground across the street which is nice to sit and let your kids play or just sit on a bench and chit chat.

It was a pleasant experience but I could do without the 'tude.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Mmm nerdy ice cream.

I tried the small mint chip ice cream. Over $4 for the small... but I guess I'm paying for the experience of eating ultra fresh nitrogenous ice cream. And this was extremely fresh mint goodness right here. The flavor was so natural and refreshing... artificial mint flavors just don't taste quite right anymore. However, I wasn't a huge fan of the consistency since it melted really quickly and in the end I was just eating mint flavored cream.

Worth a try at least once in your life. Long wait if you're up for it.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
The good thing about Smitten is very creative business idea. I like how we see the icecream made from raw ingredient (milk, vanilla extracts, cacao, ect) happened before my eyes and only within couple minutes. However, the time you wait in line takes a while. It's pretty cool that they are frontier of the idea using mixers to apply liquid nitrogen to cold and finish the ice-cream (these information you could get by reading the summary process written on the boards at the store while waiting for your turn). 

The creamy texture is very smooth n silky, but it also melts very quickly, therefore you should get the coup instead of corn, otherwise I guess you have to bite as fast as you can or it will make a mess. Their menu is different every of weeks (I am not sure), but my fav there is vanilla with lavender shortbread and graham crackers. 

Given small amount, the price is very costly, I only recommend you to try if you haven't tried it, but for usual place to eat ice cream? ~ I don't think so.
author: Hallie N.

description:
It was pretty good... but I don't think it was better than the now closed Ice Pan in LA as some reviewers stated. 

Also just tried the Ice Cream Bar in Cole Valley tonight and I have to say that the Ice Cream Bar was better too. 

Smitten was just too sweet - I had fresh mint. And, I'm sure it's different by flavor... but I wasn't impressed... fresh mint should be bright and refreshing... not sweet and cloying. That said, I'm impressed by their concept, decor, and it was fine. Just not that great, especially considering the price.
author: Hannah K.

description:
My knees go weak for Smitten Ice Cream. 

If you're a first-timer, you'll wait for more than anticipated, but you won't be let down. The ice cream is so creamy and smooth.

I'm not going to be that guy who compares all the creameries in the city with each other because they all bring something unique for me to love. 

My favorite flavor is the Salted Caramel, but be warned: because of the salt  in the ice cream, it'll be super dee duper colder than the rest of the flavors! still delicious, though....
and as if my knees weren't weak enough for the ice cream, they freakin' collapse for the pizelle cones.

You'll find me on the floor at Smitten sometime soon. I guarantee it.

Favorite employees here are Tamika and Ryan.

Edit: I forgot Joe. He made me a fortune cookie out of the pizelles once. Sweetheart with a handlebar mustache.
author: Nathan V.

description: Smitten Ice Cream is a gamechanger. It beats every frozen yogurt/ice cream/custard/gelato place I have EVER had. The first thought I had when I tasted the Salted Caramel was, "desserts are never going to be the same for me from this point forward". I think that's how people feel when they fall in love.
author: Melody Y.

description:
TCHO chocolate with brown butter caramel? Oh yeah, I'll take one of those. 
Wait, a small is $5?

I don't know if the wait time and the price is worth the end product. I liked my chocolate and I could definitely tell by taste that it was made with butter and cream (I'm not sure if that's a good thing or a bad thing). 

I'll be back only if I'm in Hayes Valley on a sunny day with my sugar daddy.
author: Sara P.

description:
Fun and delicious 
ice cream freshly made by liquid nitrogen...how cool is that? haha
my favorite flavors are Ginger Lemon and Balsamic Strawberry 
they both are little tart, full of flavors and creamy.

i also had traditional chocolate, vanilla and salted caramel
however, I am a big fan of sour tartness kind of ice cream. so, those 3 flavors are just okay.

waiting in the line is necessary at most of the time. be paitient and enjoy the ice cream
author: JustinE Y.

description: I had TCHO ice cream in a cone and it was delicious!  They actually run out of cones if you go too late; we went around 8pm I think, and I had the very last cone. They have different flavors each day/week and offer only a select few at a time, so it's like a new experience with every visit!
author: Jennifer I.

description: So smooth it's like eating frozen butter. Nitro ice cream places are cropping up everywhere these days, but nobody does it like Smitten. Try the Mint!
author: Kawai M.

description:
While I do think the idea of this place is a nice addition to Hayes Valley, I feel that there needs to be some better management.

Each time I have visited, about three times now, they seem to be out of something. Two of the times it was the cone, one time it was both the cone and the topping, and this last time, they were out of an ingredient for the ice cream, so therefore it can't be ordered. 

And to Vicky L., down below, yes, you did just spend a fiver on a small ice cream...two scoops...and yes, it did smell like butter. On that note, the last time I was there, I asked how many calories were in a small. The people working had no idea. 

And to my Yelp friend Cherylynn below, I respectfully disagree. This place is not nostalgic (for me at least). My childhood consisted of a forty-cent ice cream from Thrifty's. Or, on a special occasion, a $1.25 ice cream from Swenson's. Can I exchange my childhood for yours? My mother would have made me homemade ice cream when hell froze over, the world was coming to an end, and I cleaned my room, all on the same day.

I think it's novel that the ice cream is made right in front of you, but beware, this means you have to wait around for it. My wait times have averaged about 10 - 12 minutes. It also depends on who has ordered ahead of you of course, too. 

Anyway, this review is getting too long and besides the point. It's cool once or twice and then you're over it. That's my summary for this place. Sorry, but I just can't be that impressed, especially when the line takes forever, the creation of the ice cream is slow and inefficient, and the ingredients are out of stock most of the time.

Oh, FYI, if you're pregnant, this place rocks apparently. A female friend went bonkers for this stuff.
author: Mason K.

description:
This place is AWESOME!!!!! I don't know how I didn't come here more often. In case you're wondering what this place does. They make ice cream from scratch, instantly right in front of you. I got the apple cinnamon crisp and all that went into the ice cream was a chunky apple sauce, cookie crumbs and milk. Mix with a blast of liquid nitrogen and BAM. All natural amazing ice cream. They also have mint chocolate chip (fresh mint), classic vanilla, and come kind of chocolate. This is the craziest thing I've ever seen. I'm so glad I live 6 blocks away.

If you are in the area, you MUST come because it seriously a great experience. The ice cream wasn't the best I've ever had but the process of making it, and knowing exactly what's in it is amazing.
author: edward k.

description: First off, let me preface that I am not a sweets person so I don't go gaga over ice creams, cookies, macarons, etc. We came here on a Friday night after drinking since our friends were raving about the ice cream. Yes, the concept is pretty cool that they use liquid nitrogen but other than that it was ok. We had the fresh mint chip and I could only think that I was eating a mojito drink. While I do enjoy a good mojito to drink, don't think I want to eat the leaves used to make it. It was ok, but not exactly something I'd crave in the middle of the night. Maybe it was the flavor I tried, but iono if I'll want to stand in line for 10 minutes for two scoops of ice cream again.
author: Yvonne T.

description:
Charadaar and I just came up with our niece and auntie date for a Sunday Funday. My oh MY has Hayes Street become such a happy place to be! Restaurants all over the place, good crowd we are all for the same purpose ICE CREAM!

With a new property-ish theme, taking large steel shipping containers and recycling it into making into mini buildings, WOW! San Francisco, CA does love recycling thing to invent new ideas, im all for that. With coming here it made me appreciate the city I live in even MORE! 

Charadaar got vanilla and it had some almond brittle YUMMY! it wasn't funky or wasn't blah it was great! 

I got the flavor of the month, blood orange with short bread. Let me tell you I was surely huuuuuu-ing and ahhhhhhhh-ing as I ate my ice cream. 

Good for date nights, great location don't have to worry about getting robbed or jumped. Can't go wrong, love everything about it.
author: Conchita B.

description:
If there's anything I've learned here in San Francisco, it's this: they know how to make damn good ice cream.

Smitten is a little pop-up "tent" in Hayes Valley that makes ice cream to order in individual batches. It's definitely a unique way to experience a classic: after you order, you can stand along the counter and watch the little mixers bubble and brew your sweet treat using liquid nitrogen. 

They have one specialty flavor (which changes every month), along with their three constants: vanilla, TCHO chocolate and salted caramel. When I stopped in, they were offering earl grey with milk chocolate chips. I tried the salted caramel and earl grey, and got one of their homemade waffle cones. The ice cream itself is super creamy, and the flavors were INSANE. I liked their salted caramel here better than Bi-Rite (it tasted less burned), but the star was the earl grey. It was so delicious! The waffle cone was great too.

It's also worth mentioning I came in with a friend who has severe food allergies (gluten, dairy and soy), and she was so happy with their vegan ice cream pops that she stood in line again for the other flavor! It's great that they cater to all types of eaters here.

The only frustrating thing I found with Smitten was that you can't order two flavors at the same time. By that I mean you can't have one scoop of one and one of the other: to get two flavors you have to order two separate scoops in different cups. A little silly if you ask me.  

But, no matter - Smitten is one of the most unique and delicious ice cream places I've ever been to. You only wish they had more flavors at a time!
author: Sarah S.

description:
Just loooooooove their ice cream here!
This freezing process at very low temperatures creates smaller ice crystals.
The result: a super creamy ice, churned just for you (made to order).

It also allows Smitten Ice Cream to use only natural ingredients: organic milk and cream from a local farm, sugar, salt and a bit of egg yolk are at the base of each recipe.

Add to that local organic ingredients (saw with my own eyes: the arrival of 9:30 AM of 4 flats of fresh strawberries from Swanton Berry Farm, which are then pureed for use on the same day), the amazing confections (chocolate sauce of the local company TCHO, lavender shortbread cookies from Batter Bakery, pistachio brittle made in-house...), homemade cones baked each morning and you get a competition ice cream!

Smitten Ice Cream summarizes it as " new, old-fashion ice cream ".
This is new in the way of making ice cream with liquid nitrogen, but also the old way with 100% natural recipes.

Opened in Hayes Valley in a repurposed shipping container fitted since April 2011, Smitten Ice Cream offers 3 or 4 flavors each day (today vanilla, chocolate and strawberry) and works with only 4 machines.

The menu rotates every week with at least one new flavor. Always one watchword for Robyn Sue Goldman and Executive Chef Robyn Lyn Lenzi: Continue to provide made-to order ice cream using local, organic ingredients.

Complete review (in French and in English): http://blogs.lexpress.fr/styles/french-foodies-chronicles/2012/05/17/passe-dabord-ton-bac-a-glaces/
author: Chloë O.

description: Liquid nitrogen ice cream. Love the concept and experience but didn't like the mint chocolate flavor.
author: Vanessa Y.

description: Awesome. Been there just once with family. Everyone loved their flavors and topping. I had the chocolate with spicy caramel. One of the best chocolate desserts I've ever had.
author: Wyman L.

description:
Individually made ice cream seems like a great idea until you have more than three customers in line. 

I can't believe I waited 45 minutes for horrible butter pecan ice cream. Tasted chalky and grainy. I actually threw it away after four bites.
author: Jake R.

description: I heard about Smitten because I thought it was a really cool concept: Liquid nitrogen created ice cream. We got there right when the shop opened, so we didn't wait too long to order. But it took forever (about 30min?) to actually get my ice cream... Maybe because they were just opening and setting up shop for the day?? I got the Vanilla with the homemade almond brittle. I usually would have gotten a more unique base ice cream (probably the brown sugar w/ shortbread), but unfortunately, you can't sample taste because everything is "made to order". I thought the ice cream was really smooth, but maybe a lil too smooth for my liking; I didn't really care for the texture of the ice cream. It also started melting really fast, and I felt rushed to finish it before it became a puddle. :(
author: Sherri C.

description: Unique concept of instant ice cream by way of liquid nitrogen freezing. I tried the Lavender flavor with olive oil. The ice cream was decent. The cream itself was a bit too creamy, but not bad. The parking in this area is super hard. The place is located in a covered outdoor booth with only bench seating, no tables. This gets uncomfortable on a cold night. This is something I'd have again only if convenient.
author: Ali F.

description: If they have it on the menu on the day you go here I highly recommend ordering the mint chocolate chip. The mint is REAL FRESH mint!!! The taste is mind-blowing. The girls who work here are very nice. I originally ordered some sort of pumpkin flavor, which was too sweet, and they happily exchanged it for chocolate, which was good. I took away a star because there is a bench but not a good place for seating. This looks more like a ice cream shop that you might see on a beach.
author: Audra M.

description:
With only four choices on the board, you'd think I'd have an easier time deciding what to order. My friend and I couldn't decide between the TCHO chocolate ice cream and the ginger peach. The cashier said that this would be the BEST chocolate ice cream we'd ever had. In my head I'm thinking "no way, the best? i'm sure it's goooood, i don't know about the best though." So we order a scoop of each, and pistachio brittle to go with the chocolate ice cream. One bite and my brain was screaming chocolate food-gasm. This chocolate ice cream is so smooth, so creamy, so rich, so chocolatey, it's like....a rich chocolate mousse but in ice cream form. "Okay, he was right."

The only downside is that the ice cream melts super fast.
author: Grace C.

description: Love the idea that the ice cream is made by using liquid nitrogen. I got the salted caramel ice cream. A little bit too sweet for my taste. But I don't like sweets in general. I tasted my friend's pumpkin flavored ice cream and I wish I had gotten that one. haha.
author: Andrea C.

description:
Came back because my friend hadn't tried this place. They had usual vanilla, chocolate and salted caramel flavors, plus seasonal: earl grey w/ chocolate chips. I always get uncommon flavors and it was the Earl Grey and my friends also got salted caramel.

Salted caramel was pretty good, not as strong as Bi-rite's but I like it that way better.

Earl grey ice cream has well-defined bergamot which I really enjoyed. Chocolate chips didn't really add anything. I find it a bit different than Early Grey _tea_ flavor I'm used to (and make regularly). 

If the Earl Grey flavor is not seasonal and if they have more uncommon flavors, this place is easily 5 stars but otherwise, it's only 4 to me.
author: Agustinus T.

description:
The Good:
Creamy! 
TCHO chocolate! 
Fun to watch the machine SMOKE!

The Bad:
Melts quickly.
Pricy ($3 for one tiny scoop).
Can only get one flavor. SERIOUS STAR-DROPPER.

Also, long(ish) lines. But then again, this is San Francisco, where doesn't have a long line?
author: Talia G.

description:
Best ice cream I've ever had!  Smooth, creamy, perfect temperature, fresh, made-to-order, and creative toppings.  

I got the TCHO chocolate with Almond Brittle... it was SO good!  Worth every penny... yea, it's expensive, but you get what you pay for... so you cheapasses, get over it and treat yourself!
author: Sammi N.

description:
A bit pricey ($6+ for a small with TCHO sauce) but you're paying to see the ice cream made from scratch as you eagerly and painfully watch the clock for 60 seconds to pass as the ice cream is churned and frozen.

They don't provide samples, so you'll have to take the plunge, but they do offer a flavor switching guarantee in case you end up hating what you ordered.
author: Calvin W.

description:
Smitten Ice Cream has a lot going for it.  

the GOOD:
+ ingredients.  You know exactly what's going into your ice cream, and in some cases, where that particular ingredient came from.  Plus, TCHO chocolate?  Yes, please. 
+ freshness.  Liquid Nitrogen!  Ice cream made in front of your eyes within a matter of minutes.  The mint ice cream with TCHO chocolate chips was really refreshing.  Can honestly say I've never tasted mint ice cream like that, where the mint is super fresh and not some imitation green color.  
+ location.  Its neighbors are Blue Bottle, Miette, and Ritual Coffee Roasters, to name a few.  

the MEH:
- pricey.  I can appreciate fresh ingredients, but still hard to justify the higher price tag. 
- no mix & match.  I'm one who likes to try everything if/when she can.  The restriction on one flavor per cup/cone is a little weak. 
- portion.  For $5+ I'm expecting more ice cream.  It's a bit disappointing when you're watching this creation being made, the billowing smoke only increasing your anticipation, then your cup/cone comes out and your first (or maybe second) reaction is, "That's it?" 

I'd still encourage people who haven't tried Smitten to definitely check them out.  If your'e in the neighborhood, even better.  Could be worth the drive to just experience fresh, liquid nitrogen-made ice cream.  Just because you can.
author: Shereen R.

description:
The liquid nitrogen sounds like a gimmick, but it's really kind of amazing. The ice cream is the smoothest and creamiest I've ever had. Get the salted caramel and follow the board's directions and pair it with the coconut brittle. It's so delicious and definitely rivals Bi-Rite's. 

I've had the honey nectarine and mint chocolate here too before. The mint taste was very fresh, but I personally found it a little overpowering. The honey nectarine, which my friend got, was good too, but the salted caramel was superior, as my friend agreed. I would've offered him more, but was too selfish to share. 

The cute set-up in the storage container is unique and makes it the perfect place for capping off a night in the lovely Hayes Valley.
author: Steffi L.

description:
finally got to try it out, before hitting up Biergarten. portion sizes are pretty small, and the wait can feel ridiculous. But come on, it's made to order...it's definitely one of the smoothest ice creams I've had. 

After examining the menu I quickly determined that the sundae was the best deal, which included poached cherries, cinnamon caramel, graham cracker crumb and almond brittle. For two scoops, it was well worth the $6.50 I paid. Which considering some of the other ice cream shop options out there these days, is not a bad deal at all. 

If you can hit this place when the lines aren't maddening then it's worth it, but I can see how the frustrations of wading through the crowd can be a deterrent.
author: Phuoc K.

description:
Okay, seriously... how many of you have had the privilege of having fresh ice cream that's made right in front of you.. No, right!!!???? Unless you're in San Francisco! Hell yeah!!!! Only in SF.

I am so smitten by Smitten, that if Smittens (my kitty) was here, he would Meeow with joy!

Located in Hayes valley, it is a perfect spot, where you can hang while enjoying your sinfully delicious ice cream and then maybe grab a bit to eat near by or start pre-partying at the bier-garten or some coffee from a coffee truck nearby. 

Whatever your reasons, you must try out Smitten if you're in the 'hood.
author: Kinjal S.

description:
Okay, so my partner and I had finished a dinner at Van Ness and Market, and we both had serious craving for dessert. Specifically, ice cream. We googled, it, and there was only one ice cream place in a short radius, and being as we live in the Castro, it made sense to walk a few blocks out of the way to Octavia and Hayes.

BEST.
CHOICE.
EVER.

There were only a few people in there. And it was damned freezing outside. But we wanted ice cream, and we were going to get ice cream. They only had a few flavors, which was entirely satisfactory. As many others have stated, their innovative Brrr machines are quite clever and do indeed make a superior ice cream. 

The employees are fittingly called Brrristas. Which makes so much sense. It is definitely worth noting that we were there at 8:30 on a Tuesday evening, and the ice cream shack was blasting the Backstreet Boys and Spice Girls. And to make things better, not only were my partner and I singing along, so were all the employees, and all the other customers. It was pretty magical.

I ordered mint, and the machine that made mint broke. But we were all having such a good time, I didn't care. I do think that the chocolate, which I ended up getting, was a better choice anyway. My partner got the caramel, which was also excellent (just not my favorite flavor).

Awesome.

One teensy little thing. If I pay 50 cents extra for chocolate sauce on top, please give me more than a small drizzle. That is all.  That said, I'll be back.
author: Alex L.

description:
Creative concept of flash frozen ice-cream made with liquid nitrogen.  The flavors themselves are quite good.  Not amazing but very fresh.  I had a mint chocolate chip and my companion had a strawberry with white balsamic.  I enjoyed the mint chocolate chip very much. The fresh flavor of the mint really stood out and compliment the TCHO chocolate chips that were mixed in.  I was not amazed by the strawberry unfortunately.  If I have to make a comparison, I feel the  "Three Twins Je Ne Sais Quoi" is a much better flavor and price ratio. Granted you didn't get to watch the ice-cream being made with Nitrogen but trust me, you would be better off.

In summary, yes to visit, gawk, and try the ice-cream flavors. If you like mint-choco chip than please do. They also have Vanilla, and TCHO chocoate. I'm not sure what is seasonal or what is standard on their menu.
author: Eric T.

description: Smooth ice cream. They frequently mix up and change around their flavors every few weeks. Love the cookie dough ice cream.
author: SJ B.

description:
I'm a self confessed ice cream lover who happens to be a geek. This place is incredible. Choose your base ice cream flavour and they make it from scratch with liquid nitrogen. You can then add tasty extras on top. Cause it freezes really quickly, the ice crystals are smaller making it extra smooth.

Super smooth, super yummy!
author: Gordon N.

description:
I love how the ice cream is made right there when you order it. I had the mint chocolate chip and it was good! (to me). The mint flavor was strong and fresh!! A little too strong for my company.

Just love the idea of fresh ingredients made right then and there!
author: Mai H.

description:
Since this place is nearby and had good reviews we decided to stop by here for dessert. First off, the place is quaint and I like their cute, informational boards they have up. And you can watch them make the ice cream. 

We ordered the TCHO 60.5% dark chocolate flavor with the recommended almond brittle on top plus the creme fraiche with pear caramel. They were each about $5 and the portions are pretty tiny. The ice cream was good, no doubt about that, and very smooth. The chocolate flavor was rich and the almond brittle was a nice compliment, though they definitely could be more generous about the topping. The creme fraiche was on the plainer side, though still good. You couldn't really taste the pear caramel at all till the end though. 

It's a place to try but to be honest won't be coming back. It's too expensive for the amount that you get. And while other people may like this ice cream texture, I like mine to be more firm. Especially since otherwise it's melted before you're halfway done! Personally not my thing.
author: Jenny C.

description: It's cute. The ice cream is good. You would think that it's impossible to mess up ice cream, but some places actually do, so thankfully Smitten is doing it right. I already forgot what I ordered -- something like caramel and cinnamon cookie bits -- but it was really delicious and not disgustingly sweet. And it came out fast. Got lucky and and made it in before a long line accumulated. Anyway, minus one star because of the price... It's the most expensive ice cream place ever for the littlest cup. And it's almost a whole extra dollar for a little drizzle of caramel sauce on the top... Like .000000005 ounces. It really is a treat to eat here, which sucks, because it is just ice cream... There are better things to drop $5 on, like a whole gallon of ice cream from the supermarket. But hey, for a one time thing, by all means go for it. No regrets!
author: Elle T.

description: Scoot and Smitten for the win! Here's to eating local and fresh while saving the earth! Loved how the cookie dough had real chunks of crunchy pretzels and tasty choco bits! Talk about forming great partnerships! ;)
author: Catrina G.

description:
Look out Humphry Slocombe and Bi-Rite!  I have a new favorite ice cream.

What makes Smitten so special is the patented process they use to make the ice cream right in front of you.  For less that $5, you are handed a fresh made cup of ice cream that is the smoothest ice cream of your life.  No more nasty ice crystals.  

I tried the salted caramel, normally my favorite flavor over at Bi-Rite.  Here the flavor is saltier and less burned.  Much yummier and creamer.  

The only bummer is that they typically only have a few flavors to choose from.  There is always chocolate and vanilla and two other flavors.  last night Early Grey rounded out the mix.  Not sure if they will give you a scoop of two flavors or if you have to order two separate cups.
author: Nicole R.

description:
I'm an ice cream snob. Humphry Slocombe is my favorite in the city (so far), but Smitten is right there with HS. I think it might actually be a tie for my favorite ice cream in the city.

I got the brown sugar ice cream and it was AWESOME. Luckily, everyone in my group got something different, so I got to try the chocolate, mint, & blood orange as well. They were all excellent. The mint is definitely an acquired taste as they use actual mint, not peppermint extract. I can appreciate the flavor, but I personally wouldn't order it.

Just go here already, it's delicious (and fun to watch, too!)
author: Cookie H.

description: Delicious, smooth, ice cream with fresh clean flavors. I ordered the mint chip.
author: Danny G.

description:
Smitten has been on my  bookmark for a while! I was sooo happy when we accidentally found this place! 

Flavors of the day was chocolate, peach, mint, and vanilla. No samples since everything is made FRESH. We saw how they made it and it was pretty cool. Where can I get one of those machines?! We decided to go with the mint and it minty! Like eating a mint toothpaste, ok not that gross. But I mean you can taste the fresh mint. They added chocolates on it too and it was yums. Get it on their bomb waffle cones! Comes with 2-3 scoops. $5.50. SO YUMMY!
author: Natalia H.

description:
LOVE the style of preparation, though the flavors, not quite. 

As others have mentioned, Smitten makes ice cream using a peculiar liquid nitrogen-based instant churning process, which results in a smooth, custardy product unlike anything I've had before.  

The only downside are the flavors -- my Tcho chocolate was bland and even a bit salty, somehow.  Also had oatmeal raisin, and it was just weird, with slimy bits of oatmeal creating an unholy alliance with ice cream.  I think the process would really be ideal for fruit flavors, so I'll still be checking them out, hoping for strawberry!
author: Daniel S.

description:
Hands down best ice cream I've ever had. 

Only down side is the line was about 25-30 minutes long, but let me tell you it was well worth it! 

I had the plain vanilla ice cream (which is not my norm) because it was the only flavor I liked out of what they were serving and like I said it was the best I've ever had. 

TIP: Make sure you get a waffle cone! They are cooked fresh! SO YUMMY
author: Tori E.

description:
Best ice cream I've ever had.

Housed in a renovated shipping container, Smitten looks very inconspicuous. There are no fancy decorations, no bells and whistles. But the ice cream needs none of that. Made from ingredients that we actually know and can pronounce, the ice cream here is frozen on the spot with liquid nitrogen, resulting in a texture that is so smooth and creamy. 

Must-have if you are ever in the area!
author: Joan W.

description:
Definitely a unique concept - made to order ice cream scoops from a liquid nitrogen homemade machine. I love the concept, and I love the storefront (simple, very unassuming), and DELICIOUS ice cream. It definitely is creamier and smoother than other ice cream. I got the salted caramel (YUM), small, and it came out to 4.75. Definitely more expensive than other ice cream places for the two small scoops I got, but since the ice cream is so rich, it fills you up (and also puts a slightly guilty feeling after eating it, but that's my problem, not yours)

Definitely try it - see if you think it's worth the money, but it's a must try if you're in Hayes Valley.
author: Stephanie H.

description: I'm surprised that there's anything less than 5 stars for this place. It truly is the best ice cream I've ever had hands down. I don't usually prefer chocolate ice cream, but the Tcho chocolate ice cream at Smitten is blow-your-mind, melt-in-your-mouth chocolate ambrosia. So good. 5 stars easy. And they even took a pre-order call from me so I could get my ice cream before they closed. Cheers Smitten, I appreciate it.
author: Eric M.

description: Oh Smitten Ice Cream.. you are a pretty unique concept. It's ice cream made with their special machine that uses liquid nitrogen. There's an entire science behind this ice cream making process and somehow you get SUPER creamy ice cream (I say go check out their website for the science). Basically, you get freshly made to order ice cream, so you can see the ice cream being made right in front of your eyes. I got the TCHO chocolate ice cream with no additional toppings and thought it was pretty good, but in retrospect, I think I should have gotten it with some topping to add some texture and crunch. I'm a fan, because I think liquid nitrogen is cool. I'm looking forward to their Rockridge location!
author: Cassy H.

description:
Style over substance. Smitten's ice cream is tasty but other than the way it's made, there is nothing special about it. If you happen to be in the neighborhood it's worth a stop but not worth making a trip just to come here.

The gimmick here is the ice cream is made with liquid nitrogen to order. Because of this they only make as many flavours as they have machines and there is very limited selection of flavour usually only with 4 offered. On the plus side if you come with a group you can try everything.

The price is high with a small ice cream being over 4 dollars and only being one flavour. If you want two flavours you have to pay for the larger size. 

The chocolate is made with Tcho chocolate the favorite chocolate of local hipsters and it tasted fine. The vanilla had way too much vanila in it. The chai on the other hand was underseasoned and bland. We also got the pistachio brittle which was better than the ice cream.
author: DeathandFood H.

description:
Located in a re-purposed Shipping container in Hayes Valley's Proxy....exists Smitten (cue lightening bolts and angle harps)

This ice cream can not be rated or compared to other mere mortally created ice creams. 

people will probably give it less stars for price, number of choices and all the usual pitfalls of grading this as simply ice cream.

This is a whole unique and ethereal experience, of a poetic and delicious nature. 

Spun from the ingredients of Gods and mixed with the elements of the heavens...an indulgent creation that is more enjoyable with every bite. 

I highly recommend indulging...it's absolutely worth it!
author: Daniel D.

description:
After hearing so much about it, finally got to visit - and was sorely disappointed. The only flavors they had were vanilla and chocolate. Really?! So I opted for the Peaches and Cream popsicle as recommended by the staff.

After a couple of licks and a bite or two I threw it away. It was flavorless and just sweet. Almost would have preferred a supermarket popsicle (if I would ever eat one). Where the heck was the peach, or for that matter the cream?

I really wanted to like the place but with the difficulty of finding parking and tasteless offerings, I'm a bit turned off. There are so many better options (favorite is Gelateria Naia so far).
author: Noriko W.

description: YUM! The lemon ginger snap has to be the best ice-cream I have ever had. It was so good that after sampling mine, my significant other decided she needed her own cup of deliciousness. That was after she had the cookie dough and pretzels which was great too. It's intriguing to watch it being made - like witnessing a science experiment, with all the swirling liquid nitrogen moving about. It isn't cheap, but it is good quality, so you don't need a lot to feel satisfied. Worth a try...potentially addictive.
author: Allison C.

description:
Today I witnessed the ingeniousness of Kelvin at work.  Using liquid nitrogen, Kelvin is able to cool the ice cream mixture quickly, which results in very small ice crystals (aka very creamy and smooth ice cream).  In about three minutes, Robyn Sue and her team is able to churn out a made to order cup of delicious ice cream.

Today's flavor was Malted Vanilla with Cocoa Nibs Praline.  OMG!  It was crazy delicious.  I had originally headed out to the Mission with Humphrey Slocombe in mind but after sharing a cup of Smitten's ice cream, it was impossible to even think about having ice cream elsewhere.

Even at the steep price of $5 a scoop, I think it will be hard not to be smitten with Smitten's Ice Cream after trying it once ;)
author: Katelynn L.

description: Balsamic Strawberry ice cream. Mouthgasm defined.
author: Katie C.

description:
Walking into Smitten's little ship in SF is a bit of a trip.  I did not know whether to be scared or awed... The first thing you notice is that there is a lot of noise, many machines that look like torture devices, and a lot of smoke/fog (it looks like a mad scientists laboratory).  But getting over the initial shock as you wonder, "This is an ice cream shop?!?!?", you are truly amazed.

Ice cream here is made to order... MADE TO ORDER (let the caps text sink in for a bit).  This is utterly amazing (and explains all the smoke/fog from the dry ice).  This in itself is amazing already, but the ice cream screams wonders (and causes multiple foodgasms).

The texture is silky perfect bite after bite.  The top notch premium ingredients sing with every spoonful.  And the flavors are AMAZING!

You actually taste the mint leaves in the mint chocolate chip (it's almost like eating a mojito ice cream).  The TCHO Dark Chocolate has a great hit of bitterness that compliments the sweetness and creaminess of the ice cream.  And the vanilla.... Oh My Vanilla!  The vanilla is absolutely perfect.  This is how vanilla ice cream should taste and is second on my list of vanilla frozen treats (behind Nielsen's in Vegas).

Smitten is a place I would drive an hour for again and again and again... Hmm, this weekend is looking free.  See you soon Smitten!
author: Thomas N.

description:
Who knew you could get fresh hand-made ice cream on the spot?

The ice cream is very creamy and smooth and melts quickly but it's not hard finishing it fast because it's delicious!

I loved the salted caramel. You can taste the high quality, fresh ingredients.
author: Jenn S.

description: Yummy! Creamy, smooth, delicious, flavorful and fun ice cream. A definite must in Hayes Valley!
author: Aedyn H.

description:
overrated, not worth the price.

We went yesterday, when the weather was beautiful. Surprisingly, there wasn't a line. The location was cool, my friend and I enjoyed walking around into the little shops in the area. The building it was in was cool too, I liked the open glass feel. 

The process is pretty cool and unique, and they make it to order right in front of you. To me, it's kinda like benihana's: It's cool to see their cooking show once, but that's about it. I probably won't be going back here, but it was great to try. The ice cream was comparable to bi-rite's, but bi-rite has waaay more options and it's cheaper, so why pay more for smitten?
author: Nick B.

description: Ice cream made out of liquid nitrogen! I got the salted caramel and it was a little too bitter.  It tasted like the caramelized sugar in flan.
author: Danny N.

description:
This is the best ice cream I've had in my life, no lie!
It's a little pricey, but it's worth it to watch them make the ice cream in liquid-nitrogen churners, the smoke going everywhere - it's so cool! The ice cream is so smooth and creamy and absolutely amazing - I tried all the flavors (tcho chocolate, vanilla, olive oil) and loved tcho chocolate the most - it's so rich!
author: Catherine Y.

description: This place is truly a unique experience. Tried the blood orange flavor and it is definitely a flavor to remember! This is a great treat on a Saturday night and I'd recommend this place to everyone with a sweet tooth.
author: Joseph C.

description:
While technically "ice cream," this is really an entirely new category of dessert. Owing to the way  it is made, the composition of entirely natural ingredients, the custom-servings and of course, the unable-to-be-compared-to-any-other-brand-of-ice-cream taste that ensues.

This is what Icarus was reaching for.

I've had the chocolate and the vanilla and last week, I had the immense pleasure of indulging in the Meyer Lemon Ginger ...zomgsssss. The lemoniest lemon, the perfect amount of ginger crunch....I was transported to an embryonic state of pleasure and contentment. I didn't want it to end.

Who cares if it's cold in Hayes Valley and the lines are long? This is an unreal experience.
author: Diane B.

description: Very overrated.  I rather have more choice in flavor AND a reduced wait time over watching them make my ice cream in front of me any day.
author: Kelly M.

description: I purchased the minty TCHO chocolate chip ice cream w/ the chocolate cream. I enjoyed the organic twist to the ice cream creation and it was pretty cool seeing it made with the liquid nitrogen. I didn't really think the chocolate cream was worth it. I did however enjoy the pistachio brittles! The chocolate TCHO was pretty good as well. Venue is small. Definitely easier to access via public transit. It's close by a permanent food truck place and a beergarten open on Wednesdays and Sundays. The cute park next to it is pretty charming.
author: Emmanuel C.

description:
Perhaps my expectations were too high, but this was not the best ice cream I've ever had.  I ordered vanilla and salted caramel.

Well, for $5.50/cup, I would expect a lot.

Good: cryogenics novelty factor, right softness (you don't want rock hard ice cream right out of the freezer), rich, no additives

Not so Good: Not the smoothest texture (I felt small ice crystals in my mouth, or perhaps they were undissolved sugar), expensive, too sweet (for my buds)

I like the concept, and I am willing to try again because you can remedy the shortcomings easily  (except the price, perhaps).  For now, it's not worth going to San Francisco just for their ice cream (like I did).
author: Wesley S.

description: Ice cream made to order almost unheard of.  The liquid nitrogen freezes the cream so fast that ice crystals don't have the time to form...so you get a smooth result and you can make more adventurous flavors.  Plus, they do this infront of you, giving you that ice cream parlor meets meth lab kinda view.  The problem, it just wasn't as tasty as some of the other ice cream makers in SF.
author: David S.

description:
This is -- quite possibly -- the best ice cream I've ever had in my entire life. 

Be forewarned; this is not some run-of-the-mill scoop-'em-out joint like Baskin' Robbins or Ben & Jerry's. Smitten is a radical take on the "ice cream parlor" in that the ice cream you order is custom made after you order it, using a patented process involving liquid nitrogen (LIQUID FREAKING NITROGEN!). While the portions are not "triple scoop" in volume, Smitten (for my money) is about an experience in gourmet tasting, not in appetite satisfaction. 

The staff is always friendly, courteous and swift; each and every scoop I've ever had there is magnificent -- and Smitten appears to fit in very nicely with the evolution of San Francisco gastronomia. I'm obviously a big fan, and I hope they're around for decades.
author: West R.

description:
In concept the idea and science sounds great. Unfortunately seeing the ice cream being made was the highlight of my eating experience.

I tried plain vanilla and coffee flavors and honestly it only tasted slightly better than McDonalds soft serve. I don't mean that as an insult as I think McD's ice cream is great for what it is, but it is not gourmet ice cream like I expected and paid for from Smitten.

Overall I think there are better options around SF if you want amazing rock your teeth off tasting ice cream.
author: Chris I.

description: I love that there is a storefront, well not really "store"front? Kiosk?  I don't know what to call it, but I LOVE IT!  The last time we came, I had the passion fruit and it was soooo good!  I love when passion fruit things actually tastes like passion fruit and their ice cream definitely did!  It also wasn't a sorbet, it was an actual ice cream... SO GOOD!  The hubby got the spicy tcho chocolate, and it had a good kick to it.  It's always fun to watch Kelvin make the ice cream too.  It adds excitement to getting your ice cream.  It was the hubby's first time seeing Kelvin in action and he looked like a little boy all amazed.  You definitely know that the ice cream is fresh. The workers are also friendly and all smiles.
author: Kymberli C.

description:
Came to Smitten on a Sunday afternoon. The line was absurd, but we figured that since there are only four flavors, it must move very quickly. Wrong. Somehow it took 30 minutes to make our way to the front of the line. 

We orded two small (4oz):
Tcho 60.5% chocolate with salted peanut brittle.
Salted caramel with brown sugar and caramel sauce.

5 minutes later the chocolate came out. I began to eat it because I didn't want it to get soupy. Then it became apparent that the salted caramel was going to be a while. My girlfriend got hers about 10 minutes later. The way they make the ice cream is cool, with each person in charge of one flavor, and using a cool machine with some liquid nitrogen to cool it down. But the system is so inefficient that it made the experience just annoying. 

Despite frustration with the wait and the inefficiency of a place that only has four flavors, and the fact that they don't understand that people who come in together as a group likely want to get their ice cream at the same time so that they can eat together and not cramped in a space with other people having the same problem - the ice cream was in fact delicious. It was very creamy, rich, smooth, and flavorful. i wanted to give the place 5 stars just on the ice cream alone, but my girlfriend insisted on dinging them until they get their system in better shape.
author: Alden Q.

description:
Tis the season my friends!  Stopped in here yesterday for Small Business Saturday, which Smitten was honoring by including a free topping on your 'scoop.'

Five stars for originality, or at least 'first to market' for Smitten.  Smitten is a hip ice cream stand perched in an alley in Hayes Valley.  Poetry aside, this place reminds me more of a country fair than a neighborhood lemonade stand.  Even in the cold, I was taken back to childhood romance where eating ice cream outside under a spotlight was a glamorous summer night.

Smitten however, is far from your neighborhood scoop.  Each serving of ice cream is made to order by pouring milk into a liquid nitrogen contraption at one of four stations.  Choose from dazzling flavors like lavender batter, vanilla, pistachio, or Tcho chocolate, all written out with care on a magnet board, with cartoon drawings of each flavor's ingredients.  Organic to the max.  

Sprinkle with almond brittle and eat from a compostable container and a tiny spoon who's tea service elegance brings plastic up to date.

Each bite is delicate goodness.  Rich, creamy, and savored in tiny spoonfuls.  Smitten, I'm smitten.
author: apple r.

description: The line was long but it moved pretty fast. The Salted-caramel flavour is as good as, if not better than Bi-rite..the spicy caramel sauce is a killer.
author: Joelle K.

description:
Pretty expensive so it's not a regular type of desert place, but if you want to treat yourself this is the place to go! I LOVE the classic vanilla, with walnuts and brown sugar caramel. So simple and so yummy. 
The staff are really hard-working and have to deal with a lot since they are making the ice cream to order and the lines have been known to get extremely long, so if you have some time on your hands, some extra money, patience, and a sweet tooth Smitten is the way to go!
author: Mitch M.

description: This was our first time here and as I was ordering the worker Anthony made a comment under his breath: omg , because  I was looking at the menu. I didn't end up ordering anything for myself but everyone else said their ice cream was good. I will not be coming back. I'm sure I can find another good ice cream shop
author: Crystal C.

description:
I ordered the vanilla with their seasonal peppermint bark. I loved the texture of the ice cream. It was so creamy! The bark, thin pieces of dark chocolate mixed with crushed peppermint, was a nice crunchy addition to the ice cream.

I went on a cold rainy night, and there were a handful of people inside eating dessert under the heat lamps. It was neat to watch Kelvin and the liquid nitrogen do its work. Smitten is a cute place to go on a date or catch up with friends.
author: Elise N.

description:
We were driving in the Market District looking for a restaurant, when we came upon this place.  In the middle of a darkish neighborhood, this "ice cream shop" looks like a glowing shipping container, packed with people around it.  It piqued our curiosity, so we stopped to see what all the hubbub was about.  And yes, it is built out of a shipping container.   Well this ice cream shop turns out to be a bit gimmicky, i.e., they make their ice cream on the spot using liquid nitrogen to quick freeze your ice cream.   When they make the ice cream (right in front of you), the gas from the liquid nitrogen quickly engulfs the machine, like dry ice gas would when dropped in water.  This is fun to watch, and the idea of having your ice cream made right before your eyes is also cool.

However, I have to tell you very honestly that their ice cream is...  just ice cream.  Nothing over the top special, although it is good.
