I made the terrible choice of the mint chocolate chip. It was disgusting, and I am a non-picky, ice cream lover, so that's saying something. It tasted like I was eating mint gum. So so minty. Never again.
author: Emily D.

description:
Anytime im in Hayes Valley, I always want to stop by this place and check out what flavors they have. The only flavor Ive tried here so far is the burnt butter ice cream. The first bite was amazinggg but as I went on, it got too heavy for me, and by the end, I was good with ice cream for awhile. I kinda wish they added some chopped nuts of something to it. 

This place is super unique, and I love how they show the ingredients they use to make each one.

This review is mainly on the ice cream I had that day! I'll be coming back to try their other flavors!
author: Isabella L.

description: The over cream was sooo good and can't get any fresher. Really cool to see it beingmade onthe spotwith liquidnitrogen.  Get the waffle cone.
author: Jeffery H.

description: Cool concept, but I really don't get what's so great about this place.  It might have just been what I had ordered, but it was way too sweet.  I was only able to eat about half of my salted caramel ice cream before I had to down a bottle of water and throw it away.
author: Tina L.

description:
The concept of made-to-order ice cream is nifty. But many ice cream shops make daily batches of  ice cream and I think that's fresh enough for me. 

On my visit, 3 flavors were offered (vanilla, salted carmel, strawberry). One large scoop of ice cream was $5.50 and I waited about 15 minutes for my order to be filled. The ice cream was creamy but the salted caramel was much too sweet. The strawberry was bland and the flavor was no longer available by the time I left. Because of the length of time that goes into each order and the line that gradually forms, most people could not afford to leisurely watch their own ice cream being made. 

Sure, try it if you are an ice cream lover walking by and there isn't a long line.  But if what you value is taste and choice, Smitten is one creamery you can skip.
author: Gina D.

description: I was craving ice cream, so check the website. Open until 10pm. Sweet. I take the walk over, arrive at 8:48pm. SIKE! Closed.
author: Charles G.

description:
Pros: friendly service
         Salted caramel ice cream

Cons:  tad bit too sweet
author: Bayarea K.

description: We got lucky - no long line for us!  The vanilla was better than the white balsamic strawberry.  The caramel toppings were awesome.  Would we come back?  Sure - if we can find parking!
author: Vicki V.

description:
I've been here a couple of times now. It's a cute ice cream place (more like a truck or a stand than an actual restaurant/building), where they make all their ice cream to order with liquid nitrogen. It's quite fun watching the ice cream being made with their special Kelvin machines.

And the taste is really good! Very smooth, very creamy, great texture!! 

The problems with this place however is that on a nice day, the line can get LONG, and unlike the other popular ice cream places in the city, the line just dragggggs on and can take upwards of 1 hour. Which, for ice cream, is a little ridiculous - and I'm a huge avid ice cream fan. I understand that the wait comes because they're making the ice cream right then and there, but still. And it's not just the line that takes forever - the time when you put your order in and wait for your ice cream is fairly long too.

The other issue is the price! For a fairly small scoop of ice cream, to charge that much is a little too much. I suppose you're paying for the novelty of it ....

Also, they are limited to only 4 flavors everyday which they'll rotate from day to day, and whether I'm a fan of those flavors can be hit or miss. The first time I went, their flavors were fairly boring (vanilla, malt vanilla, Tcho chocolate and one other thing), which was disappointing. Again, I understand WHY they do this (they only have 4 machines, and they can't mix flavors while making the ice cream), but it is still an inconvenience. 

... which also means you can't taste ice creams because, obviously, they make it to order. But it sucks to order a super expensive scoop of ice cream only to find that flavor doesn't really jive with your taste buds. 

Overall, I want to give it a 4, but all the little complaints I have knock off a star. Worth coming to once though, for the novelty! Afterwards, stick to the other great ice cream places in the city!

PS: Smitten ice cream is #10 on the 7x7 Big eats 2012 list.
author: Lena Y.

description: Very cool and fun experience. They mix ingredients and make the ice cream in front of you. Good flavor and friendly staff. Gotta try it.
author: Haleh H.

description: I've only had Smitten once, but that's all it took to really hook me. Best ice cream I've ever had. I got the TCHO dark chocolate and it was just amazingly rich and smooth. Simple but clear flavor with the option to add some toppings for more flavor or texture. Watching the nitrogen ice cream machine churn the ice cream was mesmerizing. An absolutely delightful experience. Can't wait to go again!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
Okay...rating is some where between 3.5

This place is probably a place to go for the experience but for the price, its quite expensive.  For a regular scoop, its $4.75. 
I got the mint with tcho chocolate chip.  It was pretty cool to read the story of how smitten was created, the use of liquid nitrogen to make ice cream, and the freshness of mint in the ice cream, BUT the wait for the ice cream was not worth it.

Granted it was a nice Saturday afternoon, but it wasn't extremely busy.  I waited for about 5 minutes for my order, before I heard them call my name, I went up to the counter and they gave me the wrong order.  
Okay, I'll wait for them to remake it, but in the time it took for them to load the canister in place, mix all the ingredients and put in the liquid nitrogen, it became a 10+ minute wait.  
To top it off, their system of "ipads" is a little flawed when it comes to them making mistakes with orders (there was another girl waiting for her order to be remade).  They end making new orders and completely forget about remaking orders.  If my boyfriend didn't ask for my order I was going to request for my money back.
The only upside is that they gave me a complimentary topping, it was some sort of chocolate sauce, which was just a little drizzle, market price was $0.25-$0.75

I wouldn't come back, but it was worth it to try it once. 
tip: parking around this area is pretty hard to find, try the alley ways.
author: Steph Q.

description: Awesome ice cream. They don't have preservatives in anything and make stuff fresh. I think the liquid nitrogen makes their ice cream creamier. Good stuff.
author: Matthew P.

description:
I know San Francisco is all about the overpriced food that takes forever to prepare after you've already waited too long to even order it.  But Smitten Ice Cream takes it to a new low.  

Smitten served me a half-scoop of salted caramel for $3.75, and it was cloyingly sweet without tasting like anything.  Whoever says this place "puts Bi-Rite to shame" doesn't know the first thing about flavor.  (Although they're obviously impressed by shiny machines.)

Does Smitten's ice cream have more sugar than Bi-Rite?  For sure.  Is it a better value than a pint of Ben & Jerry's?  No way.

Do yourself a favor: The next time you hanker for ice cream in Hayes Valley, go to a corner store and get yourself an It's-It.  You'll be happy that you did.
author: Dan S.

description: The wait can be long, but OMG, the TCHO chocolate with almond brittle... there are simply no words.
author: Vivian H.

description:
I'm not sure if I can recommend Smitten over other creameries in the city such as Humphrey's or Bi-Rite.

With three flavors to choose from, I went with their chocolate selection. The one neat thing that Smitten has going for them is that they make their ice cream right in front of you. While this makes your wait a little longer, I can't say that it makes your ice cream any better. The chocolate was just way too rich and sweet and made it very difficult to eat. Plus the utensil that they provided was this tiny dink of a spoon and I could barely scoop anything. Lame.

Perhaps it was a bad day for Smitten or I need to choose another flavor, but with many other great ice cream places (with more flavors to choose from) to choose in the city, I don't envision myself coming back anytime soon.
author: Tom P.

description:
I want to love this place but I can't. I like the creaminess of the ice cream, I like watching them make the ice cream, but my main problem with Smitten is consistency. When its good, it's good, but they don't stick to one recipe, so you never know what you'll get.

Case and point, their Salted Caramel (which doesn't even come close to Bi-rite's). The first time it was super sweet. The second perfect, and the last time I had it it tasted like straight vanilla. I asked them about this and they told me each batch is different depending on what ingredients they have on hand. That's cool and all, but don't say it's the same flavor if its not going to taste the same.

My other problem with them is the small batches thing. When there aren't many people around it's cool, but they don't really customize each scoop so when there are large crowds there is no reason they shouldn't go ahead and make as much as they can in each bowl. The ice cream is not worth waiting 40 minutes just to get a kiddie sized scoop. They only have 3 flavors at a time, so predicting demand should be fairly easy. It also seems like they lose money that way.

Don't wait in line for this, during the week it's quick, but I think Bi-Rite and Mitchell's is better.
author: Miss S.

description:
Another in a night of novel things.

Apparently Smitten owns the first 4 Kelvin machines ever made?  It was pretty cool watching them churning out all the ice creams, but man, Smitten really needs to work on speeding up the process.  We waited around 20min for a small scoot of the night's special (vanilla ice cream with brown sugar caramel & cocoa nib praline).  I understand that each order is prepared in real time, but... that long of a wait for a single scoop is pretty ridiculous.

The decor/ambiance is really cute, clean and modern, and the staff are quite friendly.  The small heated tent space was also poppin' on a Friday night.  Flavors were alright; I didn't get to try the flavor that sounded most interesting to me (Coconut Lime) but we did try the Salted Caramel (ok, I prefer Bi-Rite's version) and the aforementioned vanilla sundae.  The texture of the ice cream is quite unique-- creamy (small ice crystals due to the liquid nitrogen churning process) but still light.  Oh and FYI, you can only get ONE FLAVOR per order.  They can't combine different flavors because by the time they finish making the second flavor, the first will have melted (gives you an idea how long it takes to churn out your ice cream).

OVERALL: I'm glad I got to try it, and its a fun place to witness the entire process behind making your icy treat, but I doubt I'll be returning.
author: Susanna W.

description:
With savories, bakeries, and fine dining well represented another focus of my San Francisco snacking would be ice cream - an area where Humphry Slocombe still reigned supreme as my favorite ice cream of all time despite being from a place many consider to be one of America's Ice Cream "capitals" in Columbus Ohio.  Beginning first with the novel preparations of Smitten, a relative newcomer to the scene based on owner Robyn Goldman's liquid nitrogen small-batch/from-scratch concept I arrived at the small...shed...late in the afternoon to find a small line.  Taking my place in the queue and reading the signage about Smitten's concept of "using only the freshest, purest, locally sourced and seasonal ingredients" while hoping that what they lacked in ambiance was made up for in taste I made my way to the front of the line where I placed my order, paid my $4, and proceeded to wait perhaps 10 minutes for my cone.

Seeing others receive their product before me - a selection of four rather standard flavors with some outlandish toppings including candied jalapenos - I had to admit I was excited when my name was finally called as everyone really seemed to love what they had ordered, yet when I finally received my selection of TCHO Chocolate on a pizzelle cone I was instantly of mixed emotions because although good and certainly chocolate I guess I expected more both in flavor and in portion.  Beginning first with the ice cream - a bit of a misnomer as what Smiitten is serving is more like cold pudding in texture - the flavor was fine, but for $4 and a 25-minute wait I could have had twice as much ice cream (and two different flavors) elsewhere with less "technology" and just as fine of ingredients.  Moving next to the cone - actually the star of the show - the hand made pizzelle was actually fantastic with a crisp exterior and just a bit of "chew" supporting the small dollop of ice cream.  

Overall it was worth the try and I'd consider going back to sample some of the more esoteric fruit flavors, but considering the quality of The Bay Area's Ice Cream scene I most certainly wasn't *sorry* smitten with Smitten.
author: Michael U.

description:
You had me at TCHO Chocolate.

We got here about 5 minutes before closing, and we were the last ones allowed in.  Get here early enough, because they will run out of ingredients!  My friend ordered the Tcho chocolate, and there wasn't enough for a full serving size of chocolate for me, so I ended up getting 2 different ice cream flavors for the price of 1!  Half of a chocolate, and a full sized rhubarb crisp!

There's some things that are different about this place versus the others (BiRite or Humphry Slocombe):
--- There are only 3 flavors to choose from on a daily basis, but the options do rotate.
--- Each order of ice cream is individually made.  There are three liquid nitrogen machines, each dedicated to one flavor.  Each order takes about ~ 1 minute to make, so expect a long wait.
--- Because each is individually made, no tasting/samples beforehand.
--- No combining of ice cream flavors in one order.
--- Prices are more expensive:  $3 for a kiddie, $4.75 for a small...
--- This will be the smoothest ice cream that you will have ever had.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
I really wanted to like this place more. The concept was unique, and as a foodie, I was beyond excited to try made-to-order ice cream. I was with two of my friends, so we each had all three flavors of the day (salted caramel, strawberry, and vanilla). 

Salted caramel got old after a few bites 
Vanilla was a rich true vanilla flavor, but just vanilla 
Strawberry had a very light and subtle flavor 

I went a few days after they had opened, and we waited in line for 15 minutes, and then another 40 for the ice cream (only waited about 10 for the strawberry and 15 for the vanilla, since there weren't as many people ordering that flavor). Way too long for ice cream. Also, I'm not sure if they have fixed this problem, but the consistency was not smooth. There were severely frozen chunks that stung our tongues... kind of like sticking your tongue to a frozen pole. Not at all pleasant. 

With Swenson's only a few blocks away from my apartment, I will not go back to Smitten.
author: Amanda B.

description:
cool hipster ice cream spot in the lower hayes made via liquid nitrogen. interesting concept eh?

$4.50 for a scoop but its a big scoop and full of flavor!

I chose mint chip and it tasted very strong of both mint and chocolate, very fresh, with good quality choco bits.

worth every penny and the show you get when they make your ice cream is neat too!

I wouldnt go here everyday but nice to bring out of town visitors or a weekend splurge.
My GF had the summer peach flavor and it was amazing too!

foodie must hit!
author: Petri Y.

description:
Not sure I'm smitten with Smitten.  

Tried the rhubarb crisp and the vanilla on Saturday afternoon.  Ordering was a snap, but waiting for the ice cream to be served was another story.  Apparently no one likes rhubarb because that one was up in a jif, but the vanilla was a 7 minute wait or so and the poor souls waiting for the salted caramel were there a good 10 minutes.  Probably need to streamline part of their process or scale up the number of machines to deal with the higher demand.

The ice cream itself was great.  Not terribly "customizable."  If it had been, I would have tripled the amount of crisp in my rhubarb (bigger pieces would have been better).  Good flavor though on both, good texture, not too rich, not icy at all.  I liked it.

But did I like paying $3.75 for a children's size that was about 8 tiny mouthfuls worth?  Not so much.  $5 for an adult is outrageous, I get that its a special concept and I salute you for it (hey, I'm a scientist, I love liquid Nitrogen), but I can buy an entire overpriced carton of Ben and Jerry's at a bodega for $4.99.  No way I'm paying that for one flavor (the two flavor single at Bi-Rite is a much better deal).

Agreed that they need to do something about the dusty gravel, its not appetizing.  Although the general look of the place is sweet.
author: Kristin P.

description:
Okay, ice cream made in front of you using liquid nitrogen.  Sounds like a gimmick, right?  I was expecting gimmickry but was surprised with the fresh taste and silky smoothness of the dark chocolate ice cream.  

Using fresh cream and the other ingredients, the magic machine does a quick freeze right in front of you, complete with the "dry ice fog".  I can taste the freshness of Smitten versus the ice cream made days or weeks ago from other shops.  A good show and very fresh tasting ice cream.
author: Hugh Y.

description: I'll say it - you haven't lived until you've tried a taste of Smitten's. Offering only four flavors daily, this tiny little shop is able to focus intimately on ensuring that EVERY single order is prepared fresh. Nowhere else can you see ice cream being made THAT quickly right before your eyes and have it taste AMAZING. The texture is unreal and melts in your mouth perfectly (especially the salted caramel) and I don't know how to ever go back to buying regular ice cream ever again. Yet another wonderful Hayes Valley treasure that has ruined other places for me haha
author: Savanna W.

description:
love me some some bay leaf flavored ice cream topped with cinnamon shortbread!

first off, the ice cream is made fresh to order using a liquid nitrogen machine. there are several machines behind the bar, each tailored to making a specific flavor. the kelvinistas (what they call the ice cream makers behind the bar) pour a cream mixture into each machine. and poof! a few clouds of wispy smoke later, out comes the ice cream, ready and waiting to be devoured.

price breakdown: Junior= $3, Small= $4.75, Regular= $6, and Large= $10.
it's a bit on the pricer side, but i guess it costs more to watch wispy liquid nitrogen smoke instead of an employee scooping endless ice cream scoops into cups/cones.

what i liked the most was the texture of the ice cream. it was very creamy and smooth throughout, without the usual ice crystals found in the everyday ice cream. the flavors are unique, and definitely had me making a mental note that i would have to come back and try these other flavors. it's definitely an experience worthy trying, but i'm not sure if it's a texture of ice cream that i would enjoy on a regular basis.
author: Caitlin C.

description: Fresh ice cream made as you watch. Only certain flavors per day but always interesting and unique combos. Chocolate with tcho cocoa nibs, yum yum.
author: Martha E.

description:
I'm probably going to be a bit unfair here, as I've only heard good things about this place, but the sweet corn flavor is utterly disgusting to me. Smitten uses liquid nitrogen to freeze the ice cream right in front of you, and to lessen the ice crystals so you'll have a much smoother ice cream, but I couldn't feel any of that. Now, my ice cream might have been grainy due to the corn, but all in all I didn't enjoy the flavor, and threw it away after 5 small forced bites. 

I'm also used to waffle cones, so I didn't like the cone that Smitten had. It just crumbled away, whereas I'm used to waffle cones cracking off. 

If they had any original flavors in the day I went, perhaps I would've have immensely enjoyed my experience. But they didn't, so I didn't.
author: tim w.

description:
My friend and I were taking a detour into Hayes Valley when we stumbled on to Smitten. It being a rare hot day in SF, we threw caution to the wind and got buck wild and ordered olive oil/lavender/sea salt and a scoop of the wild herb. Well, ok. First off, as many have noted, this shiz is pricey. A small "kiddie" scoop was three bones. I believe you are paying for the novelty of the thing though I will say that the ice cream tasted fresh...which makes sense since you wait there as the ice cream technician mixes it right before your anticipating little eyes.

I do like the almost obnoxious green-ness of the place. I compost the hell out of anything that rots, so I appreciate the effort. 

Flavors.  The olive oil/lavender/sea salt had some kind of cookie mixed in for some nice texture.  I liked it ok--the olive oil actually has nice flavor (couldn't taste much of the lavender or sea salt though). In the end I was glad I had gotten extra small mini because I got bored mid-way through. My pal's garden herb was interesting.  I used to eat mint out of our garden as a kid, so this brought me back to a simpler time. When ice cream was like $.35 at the Thrifty.
author: Katherine P.

description:
The first time I had this ice cream was at a yelp party a couple years ago when the owner was still making the ice cream out of her homemade ice cream machine in her Radio Flyer wagon. From then on, I had already declared that I was smitten with this ice cream!!!  No pun intended. What a transition from that to an actual shop with three of these machines just walking distance from the pad. Yaayyy !!!!!

     So this ice cream..... it's just heavenly. Extremely creamy and smooth. Each scoop is made to order, therefore no additives are needed because they use  fresh and local ingredients to ensure the maximum tastiest flavorful ice cream ever. When making the ice cream, they use as little ingredients as possible to ensure it's raw,  beautiful, simple flavor from this unique machine straight into your mouth. And that unmistakable creaminess, is because it is churned by liquid nitrogen which helps to chill the ice cream uber cold causing it to create small ice crystals resulting in the the unruffled texture you reap when you enjoy it.

I'll tell you about the flavors that I've had:

Malted Vanilla: That in itself is a staple and one can really taste the simplicity and quality of the flavor. 

Chocolate with Tcho chocolate chips: Yummy when you need that chocolate fix

Mint Tcho chocolate chip: For all you mint lovers, this tastes like the actual mint plant. The flavor stays with you for a while so be prepared

Mint, Rosemary, Thyme: If you can get pass thinking of savory foods when deciding to choose  this, then this flavor is definitely a must for risk takers but required for all you fellow herbalists

Ginger/Peach: These two blend together so nicely, you'll think it just  peachy

Salted Caramel: Just like it sounds, it tastes....so good!

     Theses are but a few that I've tasted and there are more that I'll be looking forward to. And don't forget to try their handmade pizzelle cones. A nice complement to this delicious treat!

     Hands down this is one of my favorite ice cream places!!! I hope it will soon be added to that Modern Marvels Ice Cream documentary because it is the latest and most innovative  ice cream making invention no doubt!
author: Granolia G.

description: Fad food. The show is the best part. Strange flavor...So-so ice cream over all. Good location, that's why there are so many reviews. Tourists love everything.
author: Sam S.

description: Smitten was just featured on KGOTV's 7 Live, so apparently the word is starting to get around. if you don't know by now, their ice cream is made with liquid nitrogen (that's LIQUID NITROGEN!; pretty crazy, huh?! ). the menu differs from day-to-day, but the ice cream...the ice cream is made to order and will blow your mind. i felt as if it was some sort of scientific taste-test gone right...if that makes any sense. the thing is you can't eat this ice cream expecting the same taste and flavor as ice cream as you know it. in other words, eat this ice cream with an open palate and an open mind. the staff is extremely friendly; the person who helped us and i broke out into a discussion on English Premier League soccer. also, it is a food stand, which is kind of important cause parking is a pain.
author: Mike C.

description:
I like many people, went to Smitten to try their ice cream after the deluge of media coverage of it. I was pretty skeptical going in. The whole nitrogen freezing process seemed like a gimmick, and there are already many great ice cream places in SF.  

Boy was I wrong. Smitten is truly a top notch ice cream shop. As gimmicky as the nitrogen freezing process is, it actually works. You get to eat great ice cream while watching a pretty entertaining process. I love that they serve seasonal items and source most of their ingredients locally. 

Smitten is now on my list of places to bring friends and visitors that are new to the city.
author: Arun V.

description:
Their ice cream flavors are great and the made to order factor is not only fun but ensures a rich creamy (not icy) texture.

I have tried the brown butter with cinnamon shortbread, strawberry with pink peppercorns (needed more peppercorns) and TCHO chocolate.

One star off for disappointing candied jalapenos. They were neither spicy nor candied. I am not sure their process but judging by taste and texture they just sit in simple syrup zapping all spice and not really making them candied just sweet and mushy.
author: Sara K.

description: The place makes their ice cream with liquid nitrogen. *mind blown* =P One of my friends order the mint ice cream. The ice cream literally tasted as if you bit into a mint leaf.   I got a fruity ice cream which tasted good and the chocolate one was good too.  The place is expensive but definitely worth trying once.
author: Jason L.

description: OK, I don't get how people can eat here and honestly say that they can't tell the difference. This is the CREAMIEST ice cream i've ever had! At first I was a little bummed at their limited flavors, but their simple chocolate flavor is enough to make you cry. I had it when it was cold enough outside to refreeze the ice-cream, and it was still amazing!
author: Carol C.

description: Ice cream made with NO2. Unique. They make fresh ice cream right in front of you so you know you are getting something fresh. They also switch up their flavors frequently which is good to know for when you come back you can try something different. I ended up ordering Mint ice cream and added a chocolate sauce on top. My girl ordered the blood orange with shortbread cookie mixed in. Both ice creams were very smooth and creamy and highlighted their flavors very well. It was unmistakably mint and blood orange flavors in each of our ice creams. The layout is cool and their employees are called "brrrristas." It's a fun little shop in the city but when it's busy good luck getting parking. It's a small shack located outside and there are long benches to sit on but most people will be standing around so eat it there or take it to go on a walk or something and you have yourself a tasty treat. I would love to come back again and see what flavors they have in store next time. Fresh, creamy, smooth ice cream that tastes what it's suppose to taste like and those flavors are fantastic. It beats the traditional get a scoop of ice cream that might have been sitting there for days before you came to order. Come here and see the difference yourself.
author: Jeromy G.

description: Uhh..can i get the shortbread flavor..that's a topping, uhh..can i get caramel..that's a topping..yes!! I was the idiot that did that but luckily the girl laughed it off with me, that's good customer service! I figured out there are only three flavors, i got the regular salted caramel on a cone. Best cone I've ever had, BUT!! They need to learn from the drumstick company, the hole on the bottom tip of cone needs to be plugged up! Ice cream dripped all over!! Hot mess. On another hand the hot mess of saltes caramel ice cream had great texture and it was full of flavor, yum yum.
author: Karen T.

description:
Expensive for a little bit of ice cream.. but its made to order and delicious, smooth, and extremely creamy so really I wouldn't want to over-do it because its so decadent. 

Their "Tcho" chocolate is amazing with the brown sugar and caramel topping.

Definitely a treat to yourself or your date- or a great place to bring visitors from out of town. Staff is young and friendly and location is great.
author: Drew C.

description: Salted caramel with almonds and pistachio was delicious. The layout of the cafe was so cute.
author: StylesUlove F.

description: OMG yes, I haven't had ice cream with this consistency since Venice Italy 1987! Really special. Favors match other handmade creameries in town.
author: Alison B.

description:
worth the experience but i think it's overhyped. 

i've gotten the lavendar and one other flavor. 
i would come again as a pit stop while bringing tourists to hayes but wouldn't be dying to come here again on my own.
author: Janet Y.

description:
Great concept!

Ice cream made in Nano batches so that it is pretty fresh when you order it. I had the Cardamom ice cream w/ Meyer Lemon Caramel and some kinda brittle. It was some kinda AWESOME!

Also tried the TCHO Chocolate w/ Almond brittle, but preferred the first one. Would definitely come again strictly for the entertainment factor.

This was the 2nd time I've been here. It is a lot more organized than before as there is a new build out, which helps organize the line. It did seem a lot more crowded than the last time I was there, which was last year.
author: Andy L.

description:
Aite here's the dealio.

Smitten has been Hot on Yelp for MONTHS without having an actual storefront so it has been generating a lot of eager anticipation on my end. Needless to say I had very high expectations. Luckily I managed to come on a sunny day when there were only a handful of people waiting for ice cream ahead of me. Score! 

Out of the 4 flavors they had available (60% dark chocolate, vanilla, rhubarb, peanut butter?) I went with the dark chocolate. Obviously. They have a cute little menu where they have pictorial representations of the ingredients in each flavor. I recall seeing some weird stuff listed in the chocolate row, like coffee, egg, and salt amongst the expected things (cream, cocoa, sugar). 

I just got the kiddie size, one scoop, $3 in a pizelle cone, .75 extra. I totally got sold on the cone because the smell was just so tantalizing. MISTAKE. 

Of course the novelty of Smitten is that they make the ice cream on the spot. I don't mind paying a little extra or waiting a little longer for my dessert. 

The dark chocolate flavor was admittedly delicious. This is about all I can say and where all the stars come from. 

Here are the issues: melts really fast. Maybe there's something about the technique in making the ice cream, but it was NOT a hot day and I can't imagine how fast you'd have to gobble down your scoop if it was any warmer. My ice cream was dribbling before it was safely in my hands!

Second, the pizelle cone is thick and crumbly. Maybe I shouldn't compare it to Ici's, but the cone at Ici is many times better than Smitten's. Perhaps they are trying to go for their own style, but it ain't cuttin' it. How can I eat my ice cream when the cone is flying everywhere? When breaking off a piece of the cone takes so much effort? WHEN THERE IS NO CHOCOLATE AT THE BOTTOM TO BLOCK THE DRIPPY ICE CREAM FROM LEAKING OUT OF THE UNCLOSED CONE HOLE?

Third, I can't imagine what the wait would be like on a weekend day in the summer. With only 5 people in front of me, I saw a couple walk around the block with coffees in hand, with ample time to retrieve their cones. And I assume this was a relatively light business day. I fear for the good days. 

Anyhow, Smitten was good. I enjoyed my ice cream and felt that the price for a single scoop wasn't as ridiculous as I expected it would be. The flavor was strong yet not overpowering or overwhelmingly sweet. It was fun to try and good to know what's in my ice cream but I wouldn't jump at the chance to come back.
author: Lydia W.

description:
04/28/2012

Met up with a friend who desired the quickly churned ice cream of Smitten, and was not disappointed.

Even though liquid nitrogen (when used in food) is safe, my friend still believed that she herself would be frozen from eating Smitten's ice cream. Silly isn't it?

My friend had ordered their strawberry balsamic - strawberries and balsamic vinegar are such a great match. Watching the liquid formula quickly churn into ice cream from liquid nitrogen from a machine that resembles a stand mixer - was amazing; a total new way to make ice cream instantly.

I had their cardamom ice cream - no it was not vanilla infused with the spice. Actually, it contained no eggs, all it contained was cream, cardamom, and sugar. It was delicious, and tasted like fruit loops - well the after taste, I suppose that's what cardamom tastes like.

Both flavors we tried were so creamy - all this from liquid nitrogen, wow!

Next on my list, gotta try their TCHO chocolate. 

Häagen-Dazs and Cold Stone, be on the look out.

MMMMM.
author: Alex C.

description:
Soooo good! 

We ordered the chocolate and the vanilla, and both were so creamy and tasty! I think this is the best ice cream I've tasted. 

No need for the fancy toppings when the ice cream itself is so good. Plus there is a little city park next door where you can sit and enjoy, or stroll and check out the shops on Hayes.
author: Hanna A.

description:
Had this for dessert after a good meal at Suppenkuche. They had 4 flavors on the menu and it turns out that they switch out their flavors about once a month. What makes this place so particular about their ice cream is they use liquid nitrogen to make their ice cream. You can watch them make it in front of you since everything is made to order.

We tried two flavors: mint chocolate chip and creme fraiche. The mint chocolate chip was really a pleasant surprise as I have never really been a big fan of the flavor, but they used REAL mint leaves to make the ice cream. It tasted refreshing and the sweetness was just right. I didn't feel like my teeth were going to fall out from too much sugar. The creme fraiche had a perfect layer of pear caramel. The defining feature of this flavor was definitely the caramel. It was a little sweeter compared to the mint chocolate chip, but it still held its own pear fragrance. Both ice creams were very creamy and just melted in your mouth.

I would recommend trying to get a smaller portion. The smallest cup they have is already $5. It not for cost, don't let the smaller portion fool you, the ice cream being as creamy and rich as it is, will fill you up much more quickly than you think! Also, they have nice little benches for you to sit and enjoy your ice cream in their little street shop. Ambiance is nice.
author: Kerri L.

description:
I finally gave this place a try and am not impressed by the fancy Kelvin technology gimmick. First off, made-to-order ice cream sounds like a great idea in theory. Then you witness the ice cream maker's frustration having to repeatedly wrestle with the bowls of the patented Kelvin machines, as they keep flying off into the glass of the counter. Talk about a Sisyphean task that kind of harshes your happy-ice-cream-experience.

Second, the technology doesn't seem to work as my serving of mint chip ice cream never even got close to a frozen consistency -- it was more like vaguely cold thickened cream. Does it only work on cold SF days?

Which leads to the next issue -- poor execution of service. Melty /never frozen ice cream + no gourmet version of a milk dud at the bottom of the homemade waffle cone = sticky ice cream dripping all over your hands and clothes. An old-school solution would solve that problem in a heartbeat.

I will say that the waffle cone itself is truly superb and the flavors are obviously crafted with care. I'm sure they will continue to thrive in Hayes Valley, especially since it is in a great location that is starved for artisan ice cream. However, the reality of made-to-order ice cream is not worth the time or money for me.
author: Janice A.

description:
I am not new to liquid nitrogen ice cream but I do agree that it is fabulously smooth, and flavorful ice cream. The most important part of this review is obviously the ice cream. I ordered the classic vanilla with malted caramel in a waffle one. It had a great flavor, which I think is awesome considering vanilla is a hard flavor to get right when using your own, fresh ingredients. I would have preferred the ice cream to be a bit creamier than it was. The caramel was a good addition if you like sugar overload but, on second thought, I could have done with out it. The waffle cones are made fresh, daily and they were absolutely delicious. I would recommend the cone over the bowl any day. I thought the process were a little high ($5 for the small) but it is plenty of ice cream and there was no need to go bigger but it did seem like you get more ice cream in the cone than in a cup, in my opinion.

As for the experience of Smitten, I really liked the outside, stand-like atmosphere but on a really windy day it might not be ideal. The staff didn't really seem enthusiastic but they got their job done, which is the important part I guess. The coolest part is that you can see the ice cream being made with the liquid nitrogen through the glass. I have seen other people complain in their reviews about there only being 4 flavors but that is the price you pay for nitrogen liquid ice cream, as it has to be made fresh and in its own mixer. Overall, it's solid ice cream and a solid experience.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
Liquid Nitrogen!? The science geek in me has been insanely excited for the past year since I've heard of this place. I was FINALLY able to go check it out during my first visit in Hayes Valley - which was coincidentally on one of the hottest weekend in SF, so it was just perfect.

Though I've heard that the best flavors are the truly unique ones (white balsamic vinegar + strawberries, rhubarb crisp), I ended up getting the TSCHO chocolate one.

Thank god I got the kiddie version - while simply DIVINE, it was too thick and creamy for me to have downed any larger size.

What a great concept which such an amazing outcome! I'd probably compare it to the likes of BiRite's thick, creamy ice cream (though BiRite has a much better selection on any given day). 

Definitely would go again if I was in the area. A++ on originality and creativity! Perhaps next time I'll try some of the mix-in's

Tip: They tell you not to mix scoops of different flavors since the ice cream melts a bit quicker than usual and it isn't so tastey when flavors mix!
author: Shephalie L.

description:
I am glad i visited Smitten Ice cream and got to see their fun ice cream making technique but I don't believe this place can compare with any of the amazing ice cream shops we have in this city. Nor do I see the point of returning. I am sad that there aren't more ice cream shops in Hayes Valley for me to stop at on my walk home from work. 

I think this place is fun to go to once and to see how they do things but their inventive flavors aren't executed as well as they could be (i have visited a few times and have received under processed ice cream 2 out of 3 times). Furthermore, their prices don't measure up to their portions. I appreciate a small ice cream portion but the price should come close to matching it. I guess their technique is expensive but I don't think it is a sustainable business model? 

Either way I hope that Smitten Ice Cream can stay open so people can experience their novelty but the shtick wears off on a returning customer. Next time I want a sweet in Hayes Valley I will go to Chantal Guillon , Miette, or a neighborhood bakery.
author: Leuwam T.

description:
While the experience was super cool (one of the few reasons I like science), I'm not sure it's worth the cost. 

I had the mint chocolate chip which was pretty good. It had real mint in it which made for a refreshing taste. I just thought it was a little too pricey. I also didn't like the cone that you paid extra for. It was kind of disappointing and was too crumbly. 

In the end, it was just ok. I think I'll stick with my other ice cream options.
author: Kim J.

description: Not only is the concept super cool but the ice cream was really really good!  This is such a great place to grab an ice cream on a hot day and just chill at the park across the street.  If you have kids and you want to really impress them with the weird science you should definitely bring them here!  It's good for grown ups too
author: Kirsten M.

description: Love their ice cream! I would definitely recommend getting the chocolate mint if its on the menu for that day. Love that they have rotating flavors. The ice cream is very rich and it is very cool watching them make it. The only thing is that waiting for your ice cream can take some time because of the method they use to make it. However, the wait is totally worth it. Would definitely go back!
author: Arda S.

description: The BEST ice cream around town, hands-down. It's rich and creamy; you will feel like you're eating cloud (but better)!  Liquid nitrogen adds such amazing texture.  The fact that you're eating ice cream that was made right there for you is an amazing experience by itself.
author: Lindsey O.

description: I finally went here.  The first time that I heard of this ice cream shop was in a similar shop in redlands, ca. But I was really excited that I am  finally trying the liquid nitrogen ice cream that i talked about with my friends with a lot. I got the chocolate flavor. It was creamy and good. There were only four flavors that changed reguarly. But it was good. Next time I will know not to get the chocolate because the chocolate was a little too sweet for me. I tried my friend's salted caramel and it good. can't wait to come again!!! :)
author: Karena C.

description: I waited for this place to open for going on a year. It finally opened. I was sort of expecting a line at 830 on a Saturday night. Is it wrong that i was disappointed by the lack of one? Anyhow, it was cool. Veeeeery creamy. The vanilla was reminiscent of when you eat frosted flakes with whole milk or cream and down the remainder of the sugary milk from the bowl. Not awesome but delicious in its own way.
author: Andrew K.

description:
came here for the overpriced ice cream. i guess their cost of ingredient is on the high side due to their use of organic stuff and therefore they gotta charge us more.

they got these machines were they churn ice cream as you order them.

small cup costs 4.75!!! wholly bejesus.
If it wasn't for paypal's $5 promo i would not have came.
the ice cream is yummy and i can taste the difference against others but not at 5 bucks, sorry.

good luck finding parking here as it is right next to a very busy intersection and a park.
author: Kai G.

description: Ok ok I'll be brief. Great ice cream. Extremely creamy. Both the chocolate and vanilla were great. Downsides: pricey and 30 minute wait. Enjoy! But getting some froyo probably wouldn't be much different.
author: Alex W.

description:
I'd heard so much about this place for months and was so excited to finally try it, maybe without the expectation I wouldn't have been somewhat disappointed but no one in my group was too impressed either.

Small cups and pretty expensive for ice cream but I definitely would say the jam packed flavor didn't leave me needing more. All flavors are extremely rich and the consistency is thick and very creamy. We definitely got the salted caramel, tcho chocolate, and I think the vanilla. The vanilla was the most subdued but even with 'superior' texture it didn't make an impression. I really don't like chocolate ice cream but it's definitely better than any I've had but no one thought it was great, just a little interesting.

Salted caramel I've heard glories about and was surprised at how strong flavored it was. Definitely very in your face and almost as sweet as just eating spoonfuls of caramel. Could not have finished that on my own and probably would have appreciated a bottle of water for sipping between spoonfuls.

Good but toning down would probably do wonders.
author: Sam H.

description: Been there a couple times. Limited flavors, but a myriad of toppings. There's a little bit of a wait on the weekends, but for all natural ingredients and fresh ice cream, it's totally worth it!! Plus, it's very cool to see the ice cream - making process!!
author: Zeenia I.

description: I get it. Ice cream made in front of me like my latte's novel. Ingredients appear to be fresh, too. In spite of the concept, I did't like the taste of my mint chip. Had a strange undertone  . . . like Lipton tea? I've taken friends here and they were underwhelmed, too. The Emperor has no clothes but quite a line of patrons. Keep up the concept and raking in the cash. God Bless America!
author: Charlie T.

description:
I feel like the idea of Smitten is awesome, but that the ice cream in general is just okay.  

I think it's amazingly cool to be able to watch my ice cream being created right in front of my eyes, I don't think that it's any better than Humphry's or Bi-Rite.  I've been to Smitten three times now and had a different flavor each time.  It's neat, and I always tell people they should go watch their ice cream being made, but it's not where I send people for the best ice cream.
author: Margaret I.

description: It's ok...the setting and set up is cool how you can see them make it. But I prefer bi rite much more
author: Katerina K.

description: First time I had it was the best. I would give it a 5 star if it they had kept the coco nibs praline topping. I had that with some coffee flavored ice cream that was so rich creamy and flavorful. I thought it was amazing as well as visually appealing as it was made to order with liquid nitrogen. On those cold days I wish it wasn't outside...
author: Bryant L.

description:
My friends and I were not planning on going to Smitten. However, we actually visited this place on accident after resting at a small park that was right next to Smitten. At first, I was wondering what was this place where I saw liquid nitrogen flowing out of these machines? These machines were making the ice cream right when you order! I was amazed. I do not know any other place that does that.

We decided to get TCHO chocolate and salted caramel. Both of the ice cream tasted like what they were suppose to taste like. The texture of the ice cream was the smoothest and creamiest ice cream I have ever eaten. Using words just isn't enough to explain the difference between freshly and already made ice cream from the freezer. You need to try the ice cream from here. I understand you want to enjoy every bit of ice cream, but you got to eat quickly since it melts faster than usual!

I can't say that this is the best ice cream I have ever eaten, but it is still good. I can say that it is pretty neat watching the people use the Kelvins to make the ice cream with liquid nitrogen flowing.

I want some ice cream right now.
author: Jason C.

description:
I have to say I'm surprised this place only has 3.5 stars. but then again, I didn't have to wait very long, which is fortunate considering how many of their negative reviews are based almost entirely on wait time. 

the ice cream itself is pretty delicious. I got the blood orange with pistachio short bread and WOW! it tasted like I was eating an actual blood orange. the short bread was so good, a perfect compliment to the tanginess of the orange. 

downside: this place is definitely pricey. $3 for what seems like half a scoop of ice cream. (I thought the ice cream place I work at was expensive!)

would i wait an hour to get this ice cream? no. however, if you come at the right time, you won't have to and you'll get to experience the delicious experience.
author: Alyssa L.

description: I really like the Salted Caramel with almond brittle. Whatever flavor of ice cream you decide on, however, make sure you get it in a HOMEMADE CONE. Its the cone that is MAGIC. It has a very nice texture with a hint of lemon. I basically go here just to eat the cone. This place is a tad pricey, but the cone is like a pastry in itself. And the way they make their ice cream looks all scientific and crap. The location is in a prime spot, too. Right across the street from Stacks!
author: Krystal A.

description: Been meaning to try this place out since I saw it awhile ago when the bf and I were taking  walk through Hayes Valley after brunch. And yesterday happened to be the day while my friends were waiting in line at Biergarten, I decided to grab some ice cream to kill the wait time. The concept is cool and the the simplicity of the menu is appreciated but I wasn't sold. I was actually slightly disappointed I couldn't get 2 flavors in the small size and had to order 2 kiddie sizes to try 2 flavors, malted vanilla and the strawberry with myer lemon caramel. The malted vanilla was good but nothing to rave over. And the strawberry ice cream was nothing special. Overall, I can say I've tried it once but probably won't be returning.
author: Sarah L.

description: Five stars for the Salted Caramel, which is amazing here!! 3-4 stars for their other flavors. The only sad part is that they don't always have salted caramel available since they rotate their flavors monthly I believe. They pretty much make their ice creams to order, and all have that super smooth consistency since there are no preservatives or additives. The downside is that you usually can't get a sample before you make your decision. The other negative is that there are only 3-4 flavors at this location, so if you don't like vanilla, chocolate, mint, or the seasonal flavor, you're out of luck! I got to try the Sticky Toffee Pudding (seasonal flavor for December), which was good, but there were too many raisin pieces for my liking. I also tried my friend's Mint, which was really really minty- a little too minty for my liking so I wouldn't order this flavor again. The lines can get quite long during the summer months, and parking can be difficult in this area. There is some bench seating that is covered, and you can sit at the benches in the park across the street. Overall, Smitten is definitely worth a try if you haven't had ice cream made with liquid nitrogen before, and/or if you love salted caramel anything!
author: Amy D.

description:
I'm not one to order strawberry ice cream.  Ever.  But I saw that bucket of strawberries that was about to become ice cream and I was powerless against the urge.  GOOD CALL.  I am now reconsidering strawberry ice cream as a life choice and a food group of its own.

The science that goes into making the ice cream at Smitten is super cool, and you watch it happen.  Bonus.  Delicous, fresh ice cream?  Soooooooo goooooood.  Also had some of my friend's salted caramel ice cream- I don't even know what happened in my mouth.  It was incredible.  There are no other words.

I would have liked to have known that there were two sizes when I ordered so that I could have gotten the smaller one (the adult size is pretty big, and I AM lactose intolerant...), but I was pleased and amused and excited by my experience at Smitten all at once.  Will definitely go back, and I am excited to try their future flavors (chocolate is debuting tomorrow).
author: Nora S.

description: I had the vanilla with peanut brittle caramel on a waffle cone.  Nice and creamy.  The waffle cone was delicate and not overly sweet.  Definitely good stuff.  I'll knock them down a star because they only have two flavors, the other one besides vanilla was something with lavender.  Also, its a bit pricey and the line gets really long.  After ordering we waited about 15 minutes for our ice cream.  They make it fresh to order.
author: Kai K.

description: Let me summarize this place: it's all about the smoke (of which there's plenty), not the product which is quite blah.
author: Mike B.

description: I gotta say, I wasn't totally sure what to expect.  However after watching the process of them making my ice cream in front of my eyes and then tasting it, it wasn't too bad.  However, it's the price that will kill you: a small with a 'drizzle' of chocolate sauce puts you back $5.25.  yikes.  not sure I can completely say that I would go back. I'm happy to say that have tried liquid nitrogen ice cream.  Its a novel idea. that's about it. There are other places that serve better tasting ice cream for a lot less.
author: Steven D.

description: Salted Caramel got me smitten
author: Donna A.

description: Very disappointed by this ice cream after waiting in line for over 30 mins. I got the rhubard and thought it tasted so strange. Afterwards me and my friend got stomach aches from the ice cream.
author: Nina M.

description: First time ever coming here for ice cream and I can honestly say I loved the ice cream I really did and if I may add I'm an ice cream lover the fact that they prepare it for you on the spot is awesome i had the salted caramel on the cone .... the cones are also freshly made daily another perk but the reason I gave them 3 stars is because the customer service was that bad not including the homeless guy harassing us inside of the location while waiting in line and the staff is totally cool with it. Yes your ice cream is good but don't be rude to your customers make them want to come back.
author: Raquel S.

description:
The salted caramel was fantastic! The chocolate was incredibly creamy but nothing terribly special.

$5.50 is a lot for the amount of ice cream you get, but getting a scoop and sitting in the park across the street is a lot of fun.
author: Ross A.

description:
Alright Smitten - it's time.

Things I like about Smitten:
- Hayes Valley needs more "stuff," and I totally back the entire suped up shipping container idea.
- Watching the nitrogen seep out of the bowl, through the mesh and onto the sidewalk for each made-to-order scoop makes me feel like I'm paying for a show in addition to my scoop.
- The flavors are cool - coconut brittle, olive oil with lavendar shortbread, brown sugar
- They use that new square thing to swipe your credit card into their iphones. soSFomg

Things I don't like:
- It's expensive for what it is
- They haven't quite nailed the quantities yet so 3 out of 4 times I've been they are already out of one of the 4 flavors.
- Seems like the concept is getting a littttttle bit overrated - I'm not convinced that the texture is that much better than regular Italian gelato.
author: Joanne S.

description: 3 daily flavors, all made to order instead of straight outta the bucket.  Love love love!!
author: Tadaa T.

description:
CREAMY and DELICIOUS!  You must try Smitten Ice Cream!  I tried it today and have to say this is the best ice cream I have ever tried.  I even liked it better than my aunt's homemade ice cream.  

I got the chocolate ice cream in the kiddy size and it was the perfect size.  I enjoyed it until the last bite.  I even considered licking the bowl.  It was so creamy and the flavors were so fresh.  Believe me!  Go try Smitten Ice Cream.  You won't be disappointed!
author: Sooner S.

description:
This is only in regards to their service and website. 

I've heard a lot of positive things regarding this place when it was just Brrr..., and wanted to check it out. Googled it under Brrr and the site link was broken. Called the phone number using then iPhone call feature and it was programmed for an out of the country number. Finally found it under Smitten. Called at 8pm for their Sunday hours and the guy who answered the phone stated they were open till 10pm. Arrived at 8:20 and they said they were closing due to technical difficulties ALTHOUGH they were still in the midst of processing orders and using their machines. 

It "appeared" the staff just wanted to go home early.  In addition, they were not at all apologetic--just plain snarky.  At this point, they could have the most spectacular ice cream in the world---which I doubt--the dry ice concept is not new (remember DOTS) yet I would not patronize them for this reason. 

Went to Mitchell's and "yummed" it up with their ice cream!
author: Alex A.

description:
Freshly made ice cream, in front of your eyes! I had the sea salted caramel in a cone. I could really taste the caramel. Total cost was $5.75...very pricey, but they only use a few ingredients, and it's as fresh as they come. The price for a 'small' is $4.75 ($1 for cone), but I got two gigantic scoops, and I barely was able to finish it. It got to be a little too sweet, too. I wish they had a 'junior' scoop for a smaller fee or something. 

Service was friendly. I would come back to try their other flavors.
author: Aiko L.

description:
YUM!!  I love ice cream and I loved the Rhubarb Crisp from Smitten!! The Rhubarb Crisp was creamy, tangy, and delicious.  It was a rhubarb ice cream with chunks of crushed cookies  My man got the TCHO Chocolate, which was rich, creamy, and almost malty.  I did love the chocolate, but I feel eating a lot of it would be too much where as I could eat a gallon of the Rhubarb Crisp.. in one sitting.  The way the ice cream is made with liquid nitrogen really makes the ice cream smooth.  The stuff just melts in your mouth and there are no chunks of ice. 

Our service was spectacular!  The cashier, Joe, was personable and very friendly.  I obviously liked him since I remembered his name.  He says he keeps thinking people are calling him when they say Tcho; funny man. Joe took my boyfriend's money instead of mine (even though I was faster!) because my bf mentioned it was my birthday.  When we got the ice cream, mine had a candle in it!! (Awww) 

I do love this place, it's charm, and it's ice cream.  I only allotted it 4 stars because the ice cream is quite pricey (Junior= $3, Small= $4.75, Regular= $6, and Large= $10), it doesn't offer many flavor options, and the wait during busy times is long (understandable given the concept and production process of the product though). 

You're definitely missing out if you don't at least splurge and give this place a try.
author: Nikki L.

description: This is a great place! Loved the location, employees and of course the ice cream! The chocolate was good, but the vanilla had such a unique taste! I would recommend the vanilla!
author: Hannah M.

description: Fresh cream ice cream with freshly added ingredients in front of our eyes.  Smitten has ruined it for me- I can never go back to processed ice cream again!
author: Irum M.

description:
Strawberry with olive oil topped with coconut brittle. AHHH-MAZZZEEEEE-Balls!

It's definitely as good as it gets.


Everything else... is decent, just depends on what they have that day.

Note:  When you go to pay, and they ask, "For here or to walk?"  Always say "To walk" that way they don't charge you tax!
author: Trisha S.

description:
Phe.no.me.nal. 

Beyond awesome. I got the peanut butter with honey and my friend got the apple with caramel and while I gained about five pounds in five minutes, I'd continue to gain it if it meant eating there every.day. 

I'm obsessed with sweets and love sugar like the rest of the fatties of the world-and trust you me, you WONT be disappointed!!!! 

Holla
author: Stefani K.

description: Smoothest ice cream ever with extremely fresh ingredients! Great service too. Lines can get long, but there are almost 1,000 reviews here so you already saw that coming.
author: Aileen M.

description:
Yesterday afternoon, I sent Brian and Kevin over to Smitten while I sat in the park across the street, finishing up my lunch from O-Toro. They had a flavor on the menu that I hadn't tried yet, Spring Herb. I figure, "Eh, might as well live a little and try it out," since I already had the other flavors on the menu.

A few minutes later, my friends come back with a big serving of the Spring Herb and asked me to taste it. I honestly didn't know what to expect because in it was mint, basil, thyme and rosemary (a lot of herbs, right?). The ice cream was a pleasant surprise to me. I could definitely taste the herbs, but I could still enjoy the sweetness of the ice cream. I would definitely get another order of this again!

Robyn, sorry, I was supposed to come by and tell you about how much I liked it, but you had a long line of customers, and we were already running late on our lunch break. I'll definitely be coming by again (this was my 4th visit!). 

About the rest of the ice cream... I've had salted caramel (it definitely rivals Bi-Rite's), TCHO chocolate, rhubarb crisp and spring herb. I can definitely taste the freshness in the ice cream because it's mixed RIGHT THERE IN FRONT OF YOU. Yeah, awesome watching your ice cream made for you on the spot! (Now... I wonder if I can toss in any random ingredients I might want... ;)

Also, I love the location of this place. It's such an easy walk over from the many restaurants of Hayes Valley. And its proximity to work gives it another thumbs up from me!
author: Melissa D.

description: Interesting flavors, some changes everyday. Luckily they had ritual coffee. Fresh ice cream made fresh in front if you it's pretty awesome watching them make it with tons of cold smoke coming out of the machine tasty!
author: Linh D.

description:
I am intrigued by the Kelvin and mesmerized by the liquid nitrogen. Isn't it sexy to observe a guy use  a high end appliance/instrument  to make fresh ice cream?

That being said, I ordered the kiddie sized vanilla ice cream on a cone. The cone is tricky to eat as it crumbles in the process. Your mouth is a nimble ninja in order to lick the ice cream and nibble at the cone. 

The pistachio brittle is sweet loving in your mouth. Definitely try it on the vanilla ice cream or on its own. I am curious to try the cocoa nibs and the olive oil flavored ice cream.
author: Sophie C.

description:
Tasty and novelty at a premium.

They rotate 4 flavors a day- i've had the tcho mint chocolate chip and the nectarine and nibbled on the tcho chocolate. The tcho mint chocolate chip was very good- you can really taste how fresh the mint is (also a bit herbally). The necatrine was ok, the flavor was subtle and the chunks of nectarine. The chocolate was thick and creamy, almost a slight hint of malty taste (not really sure). You have to eat fast because it melts easily.

Their homemade cones are delicious! Very soft and crumbly. Worth the extra $$? Only if you feel like splurging. 

The ice cream is good but melts too quickly. Its just neat to watch them make your order on the spot and the liquid nitrogen "clouds" move about. It is pretty pricey (high prep $$) for smalls coops of ice cream. I've definitely had better and more for cheaper elsewhere.


3.5*
author: Christina C.

description: My friends and I came and we tried 3 of the four flavors: malted vanilla, tcho chocolate and salted caramel. They all taste amazing, but I don't know if I like this freshly made ice cream concept, as my scoop was reduced to soup by the time my friend recieved his ice cream. It was still good, but I don't know if a 4oz is really worth 4.75.... I wish these flavors could just be at a normal ice cream shop, not saying the gimmick isn't cool! I liked seeing it happen, but there is something off about it that is just not working quite right. I hope they work out the kinks soon.... I'll come back for more... when I get a real job so I can afford a $5 scoop of ice cream.
author: Samantha D.

description:
Came here with my friends after dinner on a cold day and experienced minimal lines. The four flavors of the day were Malted Vanilla, Brown Sugar with cinnamon shortbread, Olive Oil with lavender sea salt shortbread, and Tcho Chocolate. None of us got the olive oil :( The flavors were all very intense and I got a kick out of taking a scoop of both the malted vanilla and chocolate together "Like the Whoppers candy!!!"

What I actually don't like is that the ice cream here is VERY rich and... heavy. In Korean I would say it's neuky. I LOVE ice cream; I finish my friend's cone at Ici (excessive, I know), but Smitten's was too much even for me. You get tired after a few bites. Perhaps if they had lighter flavors like fruits or mint, it would be better. I saw on the website that they're working on just that, so maybe I'll be back for the ones with berries. The cone, while freshly made with a cool design on it, was no Ici cone. Kinda bland and got soggy quickly.

Basically three stars for the cool concept, and to say that I've had liquid nitro ice cream.
author: Leah C.

description: The ice cream is fabulous. The consistency is the gold standard for ice cream; perfectly creamy, not too melty, not too firm and not gooey. The flavors aren't always my cup of tea, and I wish there were more than just 3 at a time - but they are always done well! I wish you could sample, but given the nature of the ice cream creation, its understandable that you can't!
author: Lauren D.

description: Best Ice Cream Ever.  Super smooth and fresh tasting.  This is not Baskin Robbins with 31 crappy flavors, it's only 4 quality flavors, and that's the way to do it.  If you're going to indulge in dessert, you may as well have great quality and make it count.  I recommend Smitten to everyone who doesn't have a lactose intolerance.
author: Jessica D.

description:
They only have 2 flavors, and both were excellent and prepared with liquid nitrogen right in front of us, batch by batch.  

I loved the classic vanilla.  Perfect!

This is only a walk-up stand in a bunker.  Limited seating and no bathrooms, so be prepared.  :)
author: Angela L.

description: This place rules. Smack in the middle of the adorable Hayes valley neighborhood (my favorite in the city) lays this little tent of amazing-ness. They make every cup of ice cream to order using a liquid nitrogen process. You can add in as many toppings as you like to customize any order and they are always great at recommending which to try. Their flavors are always changing but I do have to say that my favorites to date have been the salted caramel, earl grey (omg YUM) and a buttery cookie crumble one I cannot recall. The ice cream is creamy and delicious. Super close to blue bottle if you also want to snag a great cup of coffee to go with your snack.
author: Michelle R.

description: Cute foot cart-esq stand in a great neighborhood with a park to sit in while you enjoy your ice cream. The flavors change seasonally and there is not much to chose for. If you are after variety this ice cream is not for you. They make it right there in front of you and then essentially you pick toppings or sauces to go with it. I had vanilla with cinnamon shortbread and it was delicious.
author: Monica S.

description:
More for the experience and freshness than consistency or flavor. (See my quick tip.)

Only 4 flavors (one changes) and only one flavor per item ordered, regardless of size/# of scoops because it's work-intensive to make to-order I.C. in small batches.

Overall, glad another different culinary experience has been made available to those who like it. Also located on cute Linden Place Lane, close to the delicious Blue Bottle's latte and sweetened New Orleans iced.
author: Dennis W.

description: I mean.... they make your ice cream in front of you w liquid nitrogen. That's some pretty coo stuff. Bit pricier and bit of a wait but worth it.
author: Audrey Y.

description:
Maybe I was there on an off day, but everything that Smitten had to offer was just alright for me. Tried their classic TCHO dark chocolate and made it "hot" but never received the candied jalapeño pieces. We also ordered the strawberry, which was just okay. I was hoping a packed strawberry flavor, and it just wasn't there.  What may have taken away from the ice cream was the extremely long wait, and there didn't seem to be much folks visiting at all. 

Will I visit Smitten again? Definitely, but I wont be going out of my way for their a-ok ice cream.
author: David M.

description: If old fashioned rich creamy ice cream is your thing, this is your destination. Located on Octavia in a nice little area, Smitten is a great local ice cream store.  They have 4 flavors a day, along with different add ons.  They also sometimes have other daily treats such as dairy popsicles or root beer floats.  Come on down for some good ice cream.
author: Brian C.

description:
Smitten is very good and the staff is friendly, but you will pay for the experience. (Which you may or may not deem worthwhile.)

If you go, try the TCHO chocolate, but for the price a tiny thimble of ice cream may not be worth it.
author: Sara D.

description:
Totally expensive ice cream but the softest ice cream around without any freezer burn as it is made on the spot with the Kelvin machines.

If anything, Smitten is great for visitors as it is rare, if ever, you get to watch your ice cream be made.  The flavors change almost daily but do the Lemon Meyer with cookie bits if you can.  Tcho chocolate is the dream for chocolate lovers.
author: Chad S.

description:
Second time around and, oddly, not as impressed.  Maybe it was the fact that there was no crowd this time (sometimes the anticipation and the wait heightens the experience).  Maybe it was the wrong choice of ice cream this time around (Malted Vanilla - nothing special).  Or the fact I had no toppings this time around.

I haven't given up on this place just yet ... but compared to the amazing experience last time, I'm just a little let down. 

Hmm..,
author: F. P.

description:
A bit of a splurge for ice cream, but it's all made fresh in front of you, the machines are cool to watch and the taste is incredible!! Had the vanilla and the salted caramel - wow - the best ice cream I've ever had. I took off one star for the price, and that you can't combine different flavor scoops due to the process.
Melts fast since it doesn't have any of the thickening/gelling agents found in store-brand ice creams. 
Hopefully next time I go, they'll offer the Peanut Butter - good god, i must try some.
Note that this is not a storefront building - it's a large booth structure w/an overhang; walk up, order, and enjoy your treat in the little plaza next to it. Nice to watch people, their dogs and pigeons while you eat ice cream!
author: Barbara K.

description: Wow the ice cream was amazing. I had the mint chocolate chip, my mom had the vanilla with carmel topping and my dad had the TCHO chocolate with carmel topping. All three were delicious and the texture was so thick, rich and smooth. We got the regular sized cup and it came with three big scoops! I felt it was a good portion for the price and you eat it slowly because it is so thick and rich! I look forward to going back.
author: Megan B.

description:
Made to order ice cream heaven.
They make it right in front of you  with fresh ingredients.
Lines are long but its worth the wait. try the chocolate Tcho
author: Saran N.

description:
ice cream: 5/5
service: 5/5 (cashier only)

Smitten is a large ice cream stand in the Hayes Valley. I came here on one of those rare sunny San Francisco weekends and I had to wait 20 mins to get my ice cream. There is usually a shorter line, I think the average wait is 5-10 mins to order and get your ice cream. They have rotating flavours so you never know what you are going to get. The small cup is $4.75 and the regular cup is $6 (3 scoops). I consider it a little expensive but all the ingredients that they use are so fresh that you dont need a lot to be satisfied. I got the regular and it was more than enough for me. The ice cream is very creamy and the flavours are very unique. I would definitely come here again, but not too often because of the price.
author: Cecile S.

description:
First time I got the to go container of  olive oil ice cream with lavender sea salt.  I liked it.  But some friends at work did not. Acquired taste... 

Next time I got the TCHO chocolate on a cone that they make.  This time the ice cream had some ice crystals in it and the cone wasn't crunchy.   A disappointment.

Flavors are limited by the number of machines they have.

Good place to try because you get to watch them make your ice cream in front of you with liquid nitrogen.  Is this a must have?  No...
author: David L.

description: The concept is very cool and the ice cream is creamy.  I came here with two other friends and I got to try their salted caramel, chocolate, and green tea.  I must say that the flavors of ice cream have been done better at other places like Bi-Rite.  Each order is made to order so it takes a while to get a scoop of ice cream.  Each person behind the counter is assigned to specifically make one flavor.  So if you wanted two flavors someone else has to make it on another machine.  I ordered only one scoop and there were a couple orders in front me and I waited 10 minutes.  I was also taken back when I was told the price of my single scoop on a cone.  I think it was $6.00.  So with that price I don't suggest you take your kids or family.  It's an adult ice cream for foodies. The 2 stars is for their home made cone and the cool factor.  Their "home made" cone reminds me of a butter cookie.
author: Eileen B.

description:
Textures varied from flavor to flavor and I'm unsure yet if it varies from order to order. Some were very smooth and other were more consistent with standard, non-nitrogenated ice cream. The smoother flavors tasted much like a very cold pudding, or the melted edges in that pint of ice cream that you leave out to melt. 

Flavor-wise, nothing out of the ordinary. You're coming here for the texture. 

Favorite item: 60% Tcho Chocolate. Very smooth chocolate, but substantial compared to the two flavors below. One of the best chocolate ice creams I've had in a long time. 

Acceptable: Vanilla and Salted Caramel. These both had textures of very cold puddings, so they seemed like once they got on the tongue they were melting. It's almost like you're trying to eat these before they melt. 

Pass: Strawberry. If you would rather not taste your strawberry, this is the way to go. Very creamy, with a hint of strawberry flavor. Texture was similar to the standard ice cream.
author: David G.

description: God like ice cream. No lie.
author: Connor N.

description: was pretty yum.  I think it was Brown Sugar ice cream with tcho krispies topping on the waffle cone?
author: Rrrona 7.

description:
I was pretty excited when I first heard about Smitten, but after the less than stellar Yelp reviews, I tempered my expectations.

Honestly I have no idea what you haters are talking about because I loved this place. The freshness really does make a difference. The salted caramel was unlike I had ever had before. It was incredibly rich and each taste had so much buttery caramel flavor. And I'm not sure if it's the method they use to make the "ice cream" but it had a texture and consistency that was more like frozen soft serve.

I, for one, plan to go again soon.
author: Cristofer P.

description: It was for the experience and I got it. Would I come back? Probably not. The ice cream is just simple ice cream, it's just seeing the creation was cool.
author: Mandy D.

description: went there recently and they offer four flavors a day as they only have 4 machines....don't ask about getting two flavors together and don't bring a Hunde...as they don't have change or take CC either!  So it is the Ice Cream Nazi of SF with enough 'Tude' to keep the tips your cream stiff.  The soft-serve thing is getting out of hand and to that point this is a good one, rich almost too rich but seriously are we this bored to have 1500 reviews on soft-serve?  Guess I am too in this overcast summer of ours to write about it....sad....I have become a Yelper.  Please stop them before I go mad!
author: Gregory C.

description:
I may have a natural penchant for all things Hayes Valley since I'm a local, but everything is truly soooo much better here and I'm even happier now that Smitten Ice Cream has taken a corner - it certainly raises Hayes' street cred!
 
*Fresh ingredients (you see them add them as they go)
*Frozen right before your eyes
*I'm lactose intolerant, yet I can eat this with no side effects!

The Salted Caramel flavor is uh-amazing and it puts the Mission's Bi-rite's to shame. 

Say YES to HaYES!
author: Helen L.

description:
I do like ice cream and Smitten has a really cool vibe.  It reminds me a lot of summer time, lemonade stands, and childhood.  

The ice cream itself, though, could be hit or miss.  I've tried a few flavors here and have a few good experiences.  I like the salted caramel and the dark chocolate (although my friend thought the chocolate one tasted like pudding), but I did not like their minty/herb flavor (which was a special).
author: Carrie L.

description:
We stumbled upon this place as we were walking around the city one night.  The boyfriend was really excited to check it out since he's a big ice cream fiend.  We decided to go with the standard, vanilla and chocolate, since really...if you mess that up, you need to go back to the drawing board and work on your recipes.

Ok, delicious!  It's certainly not the typical ice cream, but the flavors were good and it was nice and smooth.  I still prefer Mitchells, but I definitely think this is the best "new/novelty" ice cream.  I probably won't make a special trip just for this, but if I'm ever around the area, we are definitely going to stop again.
author: Quynh-An P.

description:
Yummy made to order liquid nitrogen ice cream. Yummy. They usually have four flavors you can choose from. You can really taste the actual flavor of the ice cream. The ice cream melts kinda fast so make sure you eat it fast. haha. 

Order and sit at the park next door and people watch!!
author: Cynthia C.

description: It took me forever to finally try some and so perhaps I hyped it up too much in my mind...I wanted the ice cream to sell itself aside from all the sauces and toppings, and while it was really yummy, I think there's better flavor at some other SF shops. But still on the top 10!
author: jenn w.

description:
This is not just a kitchy thing, which I was worried about. I don't give a damn if ice cream is made by liquid nitrogen or buried in the ice by Eskimos. I just want good ice cream. Smitten is good ice cream.

Some general commendations/suggestions:

The vanilla malt is heavenly
The gravenstein apple was like pie in a cone. Luscious. 
The sticky toffee pudding needs work. Low in flavor. Neither sticky, nor toffee, nor pudding.
author: Matt C.
