but in person, it was okay. yes, watching the liquid nitro make my ice cream was very cool. but the ice cream itself gets really melty really quickly, and it was a regular cold and windy sf evening, not hot enuf to make my cone drip instantly! and then i swear, it was extra cold on the inside and little crystals of liquid nitrogen froze my tongue.  

and their cone needs some work. it tastes good, more cookie like, but it is not functional! take a note from the europeans and throw some chocolate in the bottom to stop it up.

and then only three flavors. i love a communist selection, keeps me from getting overwhelmed. but i want an amazing three to choose from. vanilla, green tea and salted caramel, meh. and it's def on the rich side. but not in a good way. also the green tea was kinda salty.

i'll give them another chance. maybe in the summer when their flavors will have more summer fruit. hopefully by then they will have a better situation then the screen covering their shipping container (recycle to the max!) storefront. or maybe they'll pave the front. cuz really, screen + dust = gross. and that little park area is already chock full of bad combos... park + traffic, scary rusty chain art + children, etc.
author: Wanda D.

description: Wow!  Wow for Smitten Ice Cream and a second Wow in that they received anything less than a FIVE!   This is always a stop for my friends and I if we are in the neighborhood although I know others who will make a special trip just to get their ice cream.   The novelty of it all is fantastic, first of all.   I've never had a bad ice cream there, ever.   And I love ice cream.......often!   The basic flavors are always good but think out of the box and try their "specialty flavors" because they will NOT disappoint you.   Yes, the wait can be longer but just remember that "good things come to those who wait"......and Smitten Ice Cream is definitely worth the wait!  Just GO!
author: Michael S.

description: You gotta try this once atleast! I live in the bay area and everytime I am in the city I always go for this. Great find of one of my friends the ice cream just melts in your mouth
author: Sonal U.

description: Tasty stuff. Pricey but tasty. Sure it's a little bit of a gimmick but still it clearly produces a different consistency.
author: Mark C.

description: This place is absolutely fantastic.  It's basically a unique merging of street food and ice cream.  They come up with three or four unique flavors every day and they cook ice cream to order on the spot using mixers and nitrogen! The wait can be long, but it's hard to find better ice cream in the city
author: Joaquin E.

description: Impressive production!  I'd say it's more a success of original design than an amazing ice cream shop.  It's worth a visit to see the spectacle, but I'll probably just go to Three Twins for my day-to-day ice cream needs.
author: S C.

description: Yum... I would have given it four stars but I am a stickler for price.  I tried the vanilla ice cream with choc. pralines inside that had me licking the bottom of the bowl.  I am a big ice cream eater and the only problem I have is the small portions mixed with the big price.  What happened to the days of ice cream cones for less then $7 for one scoop?
author: Jasmine D.

description: I don't care how this ice cream is made - on the spot or otherwise.  All that matters is how it tastes (and it's nice that it doesn't have chemicals, etc.).  So how does it fare?  Pretty darn good.  i wish there were more flavors to choose from, but the 60% dark chocolate was really tasty, as was the salted caramel.  I agree the caramel was a bit too sweet, but the flavor was much more intense than Bi-Rite's.
author: B. Y.

description: This had to be the creamiest ice cream that I i have ever had in my life.  Today, Boom Boom and I dropped by after a ramen lunch.  We shared a crispy rhubarby flavour and a salted caramel and yummed up both of them in a matter of seconds (well seconds after they were delivered out of the special Kelvinator).  I little spendy for an ice-cream, but well worth it for the special creaminess factor.
author: Adrian L.

description: I can not stop thinking about the Tcho chocolate ice cream I had 3 WEEKS AGO. Come East Smitten. They'll love you here. I can't really comment on the price of ice cream. An experience like this is priceless to me.
author: Tamar K.

description:
I really wanted to like this place.  I am a huge believer in supporting local small businesses; loved the story about the owner.  So I was really excited when I noticed that the owner was working behind the counter.  I ordered the strawberry ice cream.  Since this was my first time here, I wanted to watch everything.  I saw a batch of strawberry ice cream being made by a young lady and thought that was probably mine.  I watched as the  mixing blades quickly swirled around and around.  Then my friend and I noticed that a chunk of ice cream was coming out of the bowl.  We knew it was going to fall out.  Sure enough it did.  We watched as the young lady manning the machine picked up the chunk that fell on the counter and then put it back in the mixing bowl.  We thought for sure she was going to throw the batch away, but then watched in horror as she scooped the ice cream into a cup.  She called my name.  I didn't want to make a scene, so when I approached the counter I discreetly asked her  if she could make another batch because we saw what had happened.  She got very defensive and told me that their counters were "100% clean".  Seriously???  Then she started to say that she had thrown the bit that had fallen on the counter in the trash.  We told her we were watching her the entire time.  At that moment the owner quietly reached over and took the bowl of ice cream that this girl was trying to push on me.  She pulled the girl aside and then they went in the back and didn't come out for a while.  When they finally emerged, I received no apology.  The owner never made eye contact with me, just went back doing whatever she was doing.  The girl didn't apologize.  It turns out another customer was also watching the same batch we did because he had also ordered strawberry.  Because of the owner's lack of concern over the situation, he stepped up after the owner returned from the back and explained what had happened.  Maybe he thought she didn't have the whole story.  Well, she got the whole story.  Again, no apology.  It seemed like she didn't even care.  I was still willing to give the owner the benefit of the doubt.  I finally got my ice cream after a looong wait.  My ice cream was handed to me by a completely different employee.  Again, no apology from the owner or the girl.  Well, that sealed it for me; I'm never coming here again.

I really wanted to like this place.  I left with my sad $6 cup of ice cream feeling jipped.  If you do decide to try this place, keep an eye on your ice cream.  And don't expect much in customer service.
author: Saori M.

description: Very unique concept where the ice cream joint is actually outdoors in a park and located within a old shipping container. Smitten's uses liquid nitrogen to make ice cream, which is made to order. I was disappointed to see that there was only four flavors a day, but will have to return when there is Strawberry. I got the Vanilla Ice Cream, which seems traditional but was very rich and tasted like Vanilla Bean as the vanilla extract flavors were strong and rich. To make it more interesting, I asked for cocoa nibs to be added, but sadly they couldn't mix it into the machine as they said that the cocoa nibs were too tiny and would not blend well.
author: Angela M.

description: It was way too busy on a Saturday evening: we waited 15 minutes to order. After ordering we waited 35 (!) minutes to get our ice cream. Normally I wouldn't mind the wait, but it was so loud in the Smitten space that it was not pleasant to hold a normal conversation. The ice cream tasted all right.
author: Peter A.

description: I've never been when there was a huge queue, its expensive but incredible worth a bit of a wait.
author: Jade H.

description: I've been there twice and thought the same thing both times: BEST ice cream I've ever had. Chai with pistachio brittle and coffee were both yummy!
author: Phillip O.

description: ohmygod. probably one of the best ice creams i've ever had. they make to order, but it still comes out pretty quick. the ice cream does melt quickly but it is so rich and creamy that you'll finish it before it even melts too much. bf got the mint ice cream which was unlike any i've ever tasted. it wasn't the bright food coloring green you normally see and it actually tasted like mint. like the plant. the actual freaking herb. it's also conveniently next to biergarten, so you can come here after..or before..or both...
author: Veronica L.

description: I had liquid nitrogen ice cream before somewhere else it was great and I happen to pass by smitten and wanted ice cream after a nice lunch.Their ice cream is okay.It really could be better,but it was a little too sweet.Service was bad.i don't think I will come back.I would say stick with Mitchell's for ice cream.Mitchells ice cream have the best ice cream.
author: John P.

description:
I had been hearing about this place for a month now.  My boyfriend had gone there while I was away on a trip and raved about the concept, as well as the taste of the ice cream.  Being a self-defined connoisseur of ice cream, I was very excited to try this ice cream.

I had the Moon Pie.  The board described it as TCHO chocolate and marshmallow- sounded delicious.  I also thought I'd try their version of a cone as well.  I can think of no better adjective to describe the two minutes following receiving my cone- DISAPPOINTMENT.  The ice cream was actually a vanilla base with chocolate chips and moon pie pieces.  It probably was not nearly as bad as my first impression, but when you are desiring one taste (per the advertisement) and what you get it totally different, it lends itself to disappointment.

The concept of the ice cream is interesting, the surrounding neighborhood and park is great, but the price, wait, and lack of correct advertising was a bummer.
author: Jeff B.

description: lavender ice cream with olive oil? wow that was very very unique! but again i came here kinda drunk from the giant boot beer in Suppenküche...all my friends liked it so i assumed the alcohol did not ruin my taste of ice cream haha
author: Louis O.

description:
It was pretty hot yesterday and after months of biking by smitten ever day without stopping, I felt the heat justified a stop. I waited in line put in my order, was shocked by the price. Sat and waited a while for it to be made. When my order came, it was huge. The ice cream melts fast and I ordered the cone, it was already dripping from the corner when it was handed to me (which continued to happen until gone and all over my clothes too!) 

It was definitely minty. I was glad they used real mint, and didn't use neon food coloring. Having grown a variety of mint I know there are a number of different types. Somehow this one had kind of an overwhelming after taste, which I could not get rid of the rest of the evening. The chocolate bits were really good.

The process definitely makes for a softer, smoother texture, but it was so cream laden and melting so quickly it basically tasted like mint flavored butter. I had gotten a regular which was definitely more than I needed (regardless of taste), but it was so heavy I ended up having popcorn for dinner my belly felt so full. 

The cone itself almost overpowered the ice cream, it was very cookie like and a bit too sweet and flavored for my taste. Would probably have gone better with a chocolate or vanilla flavor as opposed to the mint.

Kind of a bummer considering my love of ice cream and that it is conveniently located on my commute home.
author: Kristen N.

description:
As others have said here, it's fine.  $4.75 for two tiny scoops, even if made there on the spot, is worth it once.  The architecture of their shack (with the adjoining Ritual Coffee on the other side) is worth checking out.  I dug the gravel surrounding of the floor, too.

Bi-rite, Ici, and Humphrey (yes, we're on first name basis) win over this one.

But it is cool.
author: Rob P.

description: If you don't mind the wait, this is possibly some of the best ice cream that you will ever taste. The owner made and patented her very own machine that makes this ice cream some of the creamiest you will ever taste.
author: Clay M.

description: Incredible ice cream.  I mean-probably the richest smoothest ice cream I've had.  I had the TCHO chocolate with jalapenos.  Cone was delicious too. Guy behind the counter was so nice and informative...just a perfect experience.  I know ice cream.  Believe me.  You have no idea how much I know ice cream. This tasted like Berthillon in Paris and don't let snobs or skinny people tell you anything different.  Wish it was a buck cheaper, but I don't mind paying it.  I wanna sell my place in SOMA and move to Hayes Valley.  Boxing Room, Smitten, Patxi's, Dark Garden...what a great 'hood!
author: Jason G.

description: Our favorite ice cream outfit in the city - fascinating made-to-order process, adorable cart right next to the vest pocket Hayes Valley park to eat your treat in, nice staff, inventive yummy flavors!
author: Leslie B.

description: It's good ice cream but not sure the taste : price ratio is really worth it.  NIce to enjoy in the sunshine if the nearby park is not too dogged.
author: Dave B.

description: Delicious!!! I had the vanilla with bits AND (!) salted caramel and both flavors were spot on, plus the creaminess is unbeatable at any other ice cream shop in the city. This is a fantastic addition to Hayes valley.  I love it!!!
author: Hilary S.

description: Not only I loved the flavor, but the process of making is simply fun! I waited for 5 min or so, but didn't even care... If you wanna have a after dinner sweets, this is the place to go.
author: Takahiro K.

description: It was my first time trying it. I tried vanilla with salted caramel. I thought it was alright. It was good but not like woww good. I liked how they make it with liquid nitrogen.
author: Rey A.

description: The ice cream here is very good, but I was still a little disappointed with my experience. So maybe I've been spoiled by all the great ice cream in this city, but I just wasn't blown away. Having watched a lot of Top Chef over the years, I was first lured in by the gimmick of making ice cream with liquid nitrogen. It's a neat process, but I just don't think it added anything. I got the rhubarb crisp and I tried my friend's salty caramel. Both were very smooth and creamy. I spent a few dollars more than I would at most places, which is probably because the overhead is higher than a normal ice cream joint. You also have to wait while they make it, which isn't that bad considering there is a line in front of all the other ice cream places in town. It's worth while to check it out, but don't expect to be blown away.
author: Jeremy J.

description: really awesome concept- the liquid nitrogen makes the consistency of the ice cream REALLY cold and therefore a little more on the harder side. the flavors are unique and the waffle cone is DELICIOUS
author: Allison Y.

description: this place is great and right by my friends house. if your in the area get some.
author: Jake C.

description: Very yummy but a little on the pricey side. Tcho chocolate ice cream is my fav!
author: Pauline L.

description:
1 - Don't order different flavors if you are with friends.  They make four different flavors and depending how many orders are ahead of you, you might be finishing your flavor, while your friends are still waiting to get their ice cream.
2 - I found it overly rich - but that's just my opinion (TCHO Dark Chocolate).
3 - Don't order the cone.  It will collapse as you are eating it, and leave your hand full of ice cream.
4 - Expensive.  Paid $12.50 + $1 tip for two medium servings.  
5 - Pro's:  The Park across the street, so you can sit, relax and eat your ice cream (if it's not a cone).
author: Dave K.

description: Just as I began to think that every new ice cream place in the cit was going to try to be the next Bi-Rite, along comes smitten.  This place serves really unique ice cream.  It is made to order via an unusual process using liquid nitrogen.  This give the ice cream a ridiculously creamy texture.  Placed in one of their soft, home made cones, it is simply wonderful.  Can't match the experience any where else in the city, or state. My only complaint is the cones leak.  They should try the old trick of putting a malted milk ball in the bottom of the cone to catch the inevitable drips.
author: p w.

description: Wow. I was visiting SF and just happened upon Smitten. I had the mint chip In a cone (with fresh spearmint). I think this was the best ice cream I have ever had in my life.
author: Carla C.

description:
I would probably give 3.5. I think it is partly yelp's fault - if 4 stars doesn't translate to "I'm a fan", i might be a bit more generous in rating. 
We've heard about this place for a while. Since we happened to be nearby today, we gave it a try. The line wasn't super long. It was probably 10 min to get our orders in and another 10-15 min to get our ice cream. We ordered Tscho chocolate and salty caramel. The salty caramel flavor came first. It was tasty - but we did have larger crystals, so we weren't too blown away by what they advertised. 
The consistency of the chocolate flavor was much better, but it was quite a wait - we almost finished our caramel (regular size) when the chocolate flavor was ready. 
Overall, it was too sweet for our taste. Although they recommended almond brittle to go with chocolate ice cream, we had walnut as topping - just plain walnut, not roasted nor sweeten. There was a little piece of almond brittle mixed in so we had a taste. It was way too sweet - so glad we didn't follow their recommendation.  If the line was really short when I pass by next time, I might do it again. But I probably won't travel there just for the sake of it nor wait for 20-25 min for my treat.
author: s c.

description: When my coworker (in Sacramento) told me that she often thinks about driving to SF just for Smitten ice cream, I didn't believe ice cream could be that good.  The website shows how liquid nitrogen is used to make the ice cream fresh in front of you so that there are fewer large ice crystals and it tastes smoother.  Pretty cool that you get to watch it being made, but that also results in long wait times.  I tried the TCHO chocolate, salted caramel, and rhubarb crisp (the seasonal flavor).  Rhubarb crisp was the favorite!  The machine/operator consistency may cause the ice cream to be a little too melty or a little to cold (tongue burn!) but the flavor and concept are amazing!  There is a nearby park where you can sit and eat (since this is just an ice cream stand with no seating).  I wouldn't drive all the way from Sacramento for it so it doesn't quite live up to the hype, but it was worth circling the area for parallel parking :)  And Smitten is such a nice way to describe how you feel after eating this ice cream!
author: Kryssi W.

description: I have absolutely fallen in love with this place. I haven't tried their ice cream but they have vegan popsicles that are to die for. I'm had vegan ice cream before and its just ice flavored to taste like chocolate or vanilla. Kind of a bummer. This tasted like a chocolate fudgecicle. It was great. My boyfriend and his friend did order ice cream and that is where the fun begins. They mix all of the ingredients in front of you and then they pour it into a machine called the Kelvinator that is a quick freeze ice cream maker. It mixes it and freezes it with liquid nitrogen.  Yea Science!!!!! All of the ingredients are listed on the wall for you to see and there is nothing artificial in the ice cream. The shop is a really cool layout and design and I thought the people working there were really awesome and informative. It was a good experience all around.
author: Jennifer B.

description: There was a long line and it took a while to make the ice cream. The freshly made ice cream was expensive although it was delicious, a new taste for me that differed from ice cream bought from stores and restaurants. Cashier was friendly though and overall it was pretty good.
author: Wesley H.

description:
Smitten is hands-down the best ice cream in the Bay (yes foodies, I would argue better than Chez Panisse's ice cream). 

Their flavor profiles and add-on combos will intrigue food lovers of all types and throw anyone's taste buds into over drive. The ice cream is creamy and rich with subtle flavor traits that put a unique spin on ice cream. 

Is it worth the wait? A resounding yes. Patrons of all ages are kept entertained as they watch each order being custom made in front of them. Liquid nitrogen helps create an ambiance of getting a sneak peak into a "ice cream lab" as you eagerly wait for your order.

If you are a foodie or you just like ice cream, you need to check out Smitten.
author: Shannon R.

description:
The rhubarb flavor is the best ice cream I've ever had, you can clearly taste the fresh rhubarb flavor in it. 
Yes, the prices are sort of high but it is hand made on the spot, not mass produced, in my opinion well worth it. Really it is no more expensive than the cup of coffee you'd get at Ritual on the other side of their wall.
author: tea k.

description: Decent ice cream -- come here mainly for the schtick of seeing your ice cream made in front of you.
author: Jack K.

description:
me and my girlfriend tried this type of ice cream and loved it! 
tastes healthier than regular super market brands sold in freezers. we love the FRESH and LIGHT feeling it has but doesn'  t get away from its delightful taste. just a few to choose from every week but somethings always different.

we will definetly be revisiting.! 

p.s. only neg is the price for the portion, but its worth going back.
author: Brandon W.

description: I love this place. Ecologically conscious, Smitten is housed inside a repurposed shipping container. They also use compostable cups and spoons and offer compost onsite. Your ice cream is made to order! That's liquid nitrogen freezing your cream, sugar, eggs, and ice cream flavor. Who doesn't want to watch their ice cream being made with liquid nitrogen? Although I haven't tried their regular offerings of chocolate and vanilla, I had rhubarb crumble flavor recently and found it tasting just like rhubarb pie a la mode. YUMMY YUMMY YUMMY! Everyone should try Smitten!
author: Lydia L.

description: Definitely some of the best ice cream i've ever had. So thick and creamy! :)
author: Steph M.

description: When I stopped by they were featuring vanilla bean and green tea ice creams. I thought the whole concept was pretty cool in itself. i favored the green tea while the rest of my party liked the vanilla overall. Excited to try future flavors and I'll definitely be back.
author: Christopher T.

description:
First off, the ice cream here is absolutely delicious. 5 stars for that. 

The operation, not so much. After the guy at the counter told me to wait 2-3 minutes for my order, I waited a full 15 minutes. AND they got my order wrong! They only have 3 flavors and 2 sizes. How hard can it be to get the order right? 

Other places in the city, like Mitchell's and BiRite, also have 5-star ice cream and they run a much more well-oiled operation, and you come away with a better experience. 

If you're in the area, definitely try it once. But at $5.50 for a little tiny cup of ice cream, I'd hardly consider this a regular spot.
author: Cathy A.

description: Smitten is still in soft launch - no mix-in/toppings yet. Super-creamy and rich. Be patient though, it will take time to make your scoop. Yeah it's more expense than crack, and for some of you that's going to be a problem. Overall though, a welcome addition to a great neighborhood.
author: Michael M.

description: My 6 year old daughter and I finally got to try Smitten today and it was soooo yummy! She had the Classic Vanilla and I had the mint chip. Hers was slightly better but I can't complain about mine. The service was really good and they were extra sweet to my daughter when she was ordering and picking up our ice cream. I saw a girl drop her ice cream and they immediately cleaned it up and got her a new cone. I can't wait to try some of the other flavors here!
author: Keromi K.

description:
I went today to get some Patxi's Pizza and i have to wait 40 min so i told my cousin that there was a new Ice Cream place that had just opened. So we went to Smitten Ice Cream just a block away from Patxi's Pizza. So when i got there it wasn't that full they seved us pretty fast i got a single Strawberry and my cuosin a Kiddie chocolate. We waited for like 6min which is not bad and thank god we got there at the right time there was a big group that came after us.  So i been wanting to taste this ice cream for a pretty long time, when i first got my ice cream i notice that it was a small portion for 4.65 ?? so yeah i took the first spoonful of Strawberry ice cream, " mmmmmHMMMmmm huh?" It was creamy, fresh, and think but i really didn't tast the flavor that much ?, it fel like i was eating a diet ice cream, it tasted more like milk, cream and sugar. The straberry flavor was not overpowering which made it feel weird I did like the pieces of strawberry  thats was good but it was nothing special especially after trying a lot of popular ice cream places in SF.  My cousins chocolate ice cream was better i liked it a little more but still it felt plain. It was a three star for me, my cousin loved it idk why she was like having a Ice cream orgasm ?? so idk  it might depends on the person yet again she hasn't tried good ice cream places like MItchell's or Bi-rite so yeah hahaha. 
Its worth the try but i might come again to try that Salted caramel .
author: THe real TrUth D.

description:
Cool idea and definitely good, creamy ice cream but 30 minutes to get a half scoop is ridiculous. This will get old fast and is novelty ofr novelty sake. You can get great artisanal ice cream from Buy Rite, Humphrey or Tara's without the 30 minute wait. 

p.s. Also think its lame for Ritual to move right onto the alley that launched Blue Bottle, but that's another topic.
author: Paul P.

description:
Sadly, I'm not smitten with Smitten.  I wanted it to work out so badly!  It was going to be the perfect relationship.  The location--right by the Hayes Valley Park.  The name--so cute!  

Got the Salted Caramel.  Oh why do I have to compare you to my first love, Bi-Rite?  Its way too sweet and too rich.  

The cone?  Too sweet with a hint of lemon and vanilla and there's a hole on the bottom where the ice cream leaks onto you!

The wait... pretty cool to watch it being made, but I want my ice cream now!

$6.50 for a scoop with ice cream... kind of pricey.  I'd rather travel further for my first love.
author: F S.

description: Ice cream is definitely unique and it's fun to watch them make it to order. You can taste the quality ingredients.
author: Liz H.

description: we came here around dinner time last night (before actually going to dinner), so there was no wait.  i tried my friends' scoops of creme fraiche w/ pear caramel and the cinnamon toast.  both were pretty good but i didn't particularly love the texture.  i felt like both flavors had a bit of grittiness to it, but that is probably b/c it's so fresh that the brioche from the cinnamon toast was completely frozen over.
author: Helen T.

description: Cool spot to take visitors. Ice cream is light and served fresh to order.
author: Jenny J.

description: The ice cream here is SO CREAMY! They have some interesting flavors that seem to change frequently. I can't wait to go back and try another flavor! They use liquid nitrogen to make their ice cream which is why the ice cream is so damn creamy! I think this it the only place in the Bay Area that does it. So yes, it's more expensive than other ice cream places, but you're not going to be able to get this type of ice cream anywhere else, so you get what you pay for.
author: Christine L.

description: I am totally SMITTEN with this extraordinary ice cream delight!  The service was fast and efficient even with a crowd of people waiting and the vanilla with TCHO (favorite chocolate) and the caramel sauce was so creamy and smooth!  I would highly recommend this to all!
author: Michael W.

description: ok. i get it. this place is special and unique-makes me proud to live in sf where crazy cool shipping containers are made into ice cream shops. im now totally smitten with liquid nitrogen ice cream. each scoop is made fresh in the moment. creamy texture unlike anything ive ever had. the temperature is absolutely perfect, nothing has been frozen or crystalized in a freezer leaving the ice cream to taste like creamy air.
author: Emmie B.

description: nice! well done..now I have to hit the treadmill for an hour. But it's decently priced and good for a dessert place. See ya next week!
author: Emmanuel C.

description: Best ice cream ever! Yes, the price is a little high, but it is absolutely worth it for a scoop made to order with locally sourced fresh ingredients. Seeing them make the ice cream with liquid nitrogen right in front of you adds to the experience. I had the TCHO chocolate ice cream last night and I can't stop thinking about! I am looking forward to trying more flavors!
author: Kathryn S.

description: best ice cream in the city, perfect texture.  Worth the price and the wait.
author: Briana B.

description: smooth and fresh.  awesome watching them make the ice cream.  they are a little limited in the flavors they can make for the day, but they try to change it up all the time so you can keep going back.
author: Wayne L.

description: The best vanilla I've ever eaten. Such a cute storefront too. I got to talking to the employees and they were great. I think this place is top-notch!
author: Jen A.

description: Yum. Fresh ice cream. Yeah, it's overpriced. But it's cool that they're hand making each serving of ice cream. The mint flavor is excellent and tastes like fresh mint. They always have a selection of 3-4 cool flavors.
author: Lina L.

description: Yummy and super creamy, worth it if you are in the neighboorhood. And always interesting flavors.
author: Amanda P.

description: ice cream is always good, but their innovation is even good-er.  we had the ginger peach and it was pretty tasty, i didn't really taste the ginger in the ice cream but if we did it prob wouldn't taste as good huh....i love watching them make ice cream using the dry ice its def fun bringing you kids here to watch it being made =)
author: Shirley H.

description: I love this place. The method for making the ice cream is genius; the ice cream is so smooth and creamy. It's also just fun to watch them make it.They could use more flavors but the ones they do have are great. Fun toppings too.
author: Davin A.

description:
I truly wanted to like Smitten Ice Cream.  I heard about the concept and thought it was a great idea.  I make ice cream regularly at home, and, since I've started, I've been disappointed by most commercial ice creams.  I love the simplicity of homemade ice cream--a few ingredients, a little time swirling in the frozen canister, and . . . you've got a delicious treat!  In my experience, however, the best part about homemade ice cream is not the initial, partially-frozen, somewhat droopy product, but rather the smooth and creamy FROZEN dessert that most would recognize as ice cream.  This, of course, takes a little time in the freezer.

Smitten Ice Cream specializes in that in-between product.  They make ice cream to order, or, more accurately, they freeze ice cream to order (the base is pre-made ahead of time, but probably the same day).  This takes a lot of time because they can't simply scoop some ice cream once you order it.  Although the flavor is perfectly fine, I had expected their process to yield very cold ice cream because of the liquid nitrogen they use.  Today was hotter than usual, but, as others have mentioned, the ice cream melted very quickly.  My very first bite was not very cold, at all.  After waiting for nearly 30 minutes in the hot sun, I was more than ready for an ice cold dessert.    

Which raises another point:  the wait time.  After I ordered, I waited about 30 minutes!  When I arrived to find only four people in line ahead of me, I thought "looks like this won't take that long after all."  I was wrong.  Generally, I do not mind waiting for great food.  I'll stand in line for over an hour at Dottie's.  I love Brenda's.  I'll wait for Tartine bread, for god's sake.  But this ice cream is, sadly, not worth the wait--or the price.  At $5.50 for a slightly-larger-than-average scoop, it's a little too steep compared to the other, wonderful ice cream shops in SF.  Bi-Rite and Humphrey Slocombe are less expensive and, even with a long line, they don't take as long.  (As an aside, I fear the prices are high because the wait is so long; they can't sell that many cups, so they need to charge more for them.  I bet if they could speed it up somehow they could charge a little less.)  Now, as a purveyor of an "artisan" product, I did not expect a drive-through level of efficiency.  The problem is that, with ice cream in particular, there is a level of instant gratification going on.  It's hot, you want something cold and yummy, so you order an ice cream cone.  You don't call a place, make reservations, look at a menu, order, and eat it in three courses.  It is usually a spontaneous event, and the experience is at its best when eating the ice cream takes longer than getting it.  I'll wait a long time for Dottie's because, once I'm inside, I can have the leisurely brunch that everyone else was having.  With ice cream, you don't typically spend enough time eating to justify a long wait, so when you have to wait for a long time to get something that takes only a few minutes to devour, it feels like a let down.

Despite the temperature, time, and cost problems, I still wish Smitten the best.  I think, with some simple changes, they can succeed in SF's competitive ice cream market.  Here's a few tips that I believe would improve the experience:

1.  Show off your amazing, scientific, patented process!!  If I did not know in advance, I would not have realized the method used to make my ice cream.  Make a sign that describes the machine and how it works.  If you're going to insta-freeze ice cream like magic with liquid nitrogen right before our eyes, make sure we realize it!!  It would help to justify the price.

2.  Tell us what is in the ice cream.  If pure and simple ice cream is the concept, explain that.  Today there were three flavors available on a large sign with plenty of space to list the ingredients for each flavor.  If you're using organic, local, sustainable, etc. products, tell us!  It would be great to know exactly what is (and isn't) in our ice cream.  It would also help to justify the price.

3.  On that note, tell us the price!  And the sizes!  You have two cup sizes and a cone option.  There are three different prices to list.  Doing so will speed up the ordering process.

There you have it.  Three steps for a smoother operation.

At this point I'm not smitten.  I'm sure some people love it, but I did not.  Smitten Ice Cream is just starting out, so hopefullly these suggestions will help.  I really hope that Smitten streamlines their operation, finds a way to cut costs without sacrificing qualtiy, and makes getting fresh ice cream a little easier.  Hayes Valley needs it!
author: Matthew A.

description: overpriced and overrated. worth checking out once, but that's it. mitchell's, bi-rite, three twins reign supreme over this place. tastes more like whip cream than ice cream and it melts really fast.
author: Inna L.

description: i get the kiddie size and it's very expensive for the amount you get. earl grey was great and i would get it again, unfortunately it's one of the varying flavors. tcho chocolate is nothing to rave about. avoid the pizzelle cone, not worth the extra cost because it doesn't complement the ice cream very well.
author: Ann B.

description: their ice cream is good & their service is excellentworth the parking trouble, definitely
author: Feed Her O.

description: I stopped by Smitten in August 2012 during my visit to SF. The ice cream is delicious. I tried the salted caramel flavor, which tastes as good as it sounds. I paid with my credit card and my receipt was emailed to me. It felt very high tech and I didn't have another receipt cluttering my wallet. The ONLY issue was the wait to get the ice cream, which was about 10 minutes. They make the ice cream right in front of you so it makes sense that it takes time. 5 stars for everything else, 2 stars for the wait. Overall, I recommend it to all.
author: Ellis K.

description: I was so excited to try and I thought it was pretty good.  Not much an option but I can live with it.  Definitely overpriced. Just cool to see the ice cream made right in front of you. Service is great.
author: Han C.

description: Wow! Came here with friends after dinner and it was tasty! Their unique method of preparation was on display during the production of the dessert. Their flavors are definitely unique. I chose the Fresh Mint Chocolate Chip and mint flavor was very strong. Would definitely return again.
author: Nikhil V.

description: I think their TCHO chocolate ice cream is one of  the best choc ice cream I've ever had. Other flavors I tried were peach and mint choc chip, and they were okay. I love Nitrogen ice cream, as it is so smooth with no ice crystals. It is not cheap, but when I know ice cream shops somewhere like Fisherman's Wharf charge more than that, it is not expensive at all when I consider their quality. And also I have to add that their service is not so great.
author: Foomin U.

description: Alright, so it's expensive. But I was on vacation and $5 for ice cream seemed pretty steep, but my friends were all aghast at how delicious it was. I'm lactose intolerant. So I got the vegan fudge bar. Now that was delicious, arguably one of my favorite vegan desserts I've ever had. And it's always very fun to see the way the ice cream gets made. So innovative and interesting, it's cool to see someone reinvent such a well-known food.
author: Ashley P.

description: This might be the best ice cream I've ever had. It is rich and smooth and not too sweet. I always get the smallest amount and amazingly enough am satisfied with the tiny scoop. Order it "to go" or they'll have to charge you sales tax.  Indeed, I am "smitten"...
author: Priscilla C.

description: Smitten takes the idea of "street food" to a whole new level. Robyn spent 2 years concepting and masterminding her ice cream making machine, aka "Kelvin". the fruits of her labor are the 1 minute it takes to make amazingly fresh and super tasty ice cream anywhere she can pull up her wagon. for $5 you get a huge scoop that rivals both Bi-rite and Henry Slocombe products. Robyn with her smitten sweet demeanor and  "Kelvin" strapped to his red Radio Flyer wagon you've got a recipe for street food success.
author: casey c.

description: The chocolate ice cream was salty.  It was honestly the worst chocolate ice cream I've ever had.  Maybe the saltiness works for some of their other flavors, but avoid the chocolate.  The ice cream was also room temperature.  I love chocolate ice cream, and I took 4 bites hoping it would get better.  It didn't and I threw my $5 cup of ice cream away.
author: Chris T.

description: Bummer of an ice cream stand. Wait to order and then wait to get one scoop is lame. Ice cream was ok, not great, no Bi-Rite. Tasted like safeway brand ice cream but triple the price and quadruple the wait. Unfortunately, this place is a no go.
author: Daniel B.

description: no additives, emulsifiers, preservatives, or stabilizers = awesome!  i love this place and its ice cream!  when i'm in the city, I actually drive out of my way to pick up a scoop!  love the fact that they use new technology to make ice cream (I'm a nerd and always support innovation!) and that they use Square for payments!  Yay!
author: Eddy B.

description: My boyfriend and I come here weekly and this place has ruined all other ice cream for us. When I go to brunch or dinner in the area I save room just so I can run over to smitten after to appease my craving for their creamy perfection. The flavors are simple, healthy and delicious and they often rotate with yummy new surprises. I have seen people on yelp complain about the ice cream being too creamy and delicious, I just don't see how you can give a bad rating for that but apparently people do? Other people give this place bad ratings because of the price but I would pay anything for this amazing ice cream.The staff is always so friendly and the box car is super cute and charming. After having fresh ice cream I just can't go back to generic sugared, artificial ingredient ice cream.
author: Ki G.

description:
it's just OK. the coolest thing is the modernist ice cream aspect. fog and stainless steel tubing etc.

flavor 4 stars
variety 1 star
ice cream in a flimsy paper cup  zero stars.
author: Richard D.

description: friendly customer service and yummy ice cream made right in front of you! i've been here twice and both times the staff was very friendly, making conversation and i felt very welcome. the ice cream was delicious too! i got vanilla on a cone both times. thank you!!
author: Kristen F.

description: I wanted to love Smitten but I'm only in like with it. Today's flavors were a bit limited- nectarine, vanilla and lemon verbena. I went with the nectarine while my friend ordered vanilla with candied jalapenos. I was a little shocked by the sizing; usually I can get a kids size at say Humphrey Slocombe or Bi-Rite and be totally awesome, however the kids size here was about very very tiny. We both went with smalls, which would be kids size elsewhere, and it came out to $9.75. Very pricey for the size. It's worth noting that ice cream does not come out in the order that it was ordered, I'm not sure what their method is for getting out orders but we had to wait a bit while people who ordered after us were enjoying their ice cream. The nectarine was decent and had a very creamy texture. My issue with it was that it was very flat tasting, it reminded me exactly of eating yogurt with fruit bits. My friend's vanilla was however superbly flavored with vanilla bean and the candied jalapenos were delicious.
author: Cori W.

description: Fun set up and location for ice cream on a sunny day. My tcho chocolate with coconut was really yummy,not as impressed with my husband's cocoa nib with caramel. All in all a great ice cream experience.
author: Kaye M.

description: AWESOME!!!  You get to watch the whole process!!  And it's delicious, wow, sooooo good.  Definitely try it for the novelty!
author: Allie L.

description: A friend told me that there is nothing better than ice cream that is made fresh and consumed immediately. As I just don't have the equipment nor skills (not to mention room in my fridge!) to make my own ice cream, when I came across Smitten, I was very excited. And I'll admit, I'm no ice cream connoisseur -- I've had some pretty darn good ones including Berthillon in Paris -- but Smitten's is definitely special. Aside from the cool factor (no pun intended) with its liquid nitrogen and custom equipment, what keeps me coming back is the fact that their ice cream doesn't make me feel guilty. Another reviewer mentioned how they thought "the flavors were too weak" but I have to say, for me, it's just right. Coming back to my friend's original comment about made-to-order ice cream, it's exactly how I would image "fresh" ice cream to be --- just enough flavor to make me want more, yet not so much that I feel like I have to spend an extra hour at the gym just to make up for it. My favorite flavor to date has to go to Earl Grey, but certainly looking forward another flavor to best it!
author: T.K. I.

description: Tried the Lemon Verbana, Chocolate and Vanilla. It had a nice creamy texture and you really taste the fresh herbs. Very good. But it is very pricey. For one tiny kiddie scoop its $3!!
author: Juju F.

description: I eat only full fat ice creams but Smitten is all fat, or at least taste like it. Plain gross!   The flavors have very little resemblance to the source  The chocolate ice ream has an unidentifiable flavor - what a crime!   It way overly expensive due to the hype.  The line is always way too long which makes no sense to me.  The only good thing about this place is its close proximity to the most darling dog park in the area.  Swanson or ice cream from the freezer beats this one any day.
author: Freda P.

description: This ice cream is not your ordinary ice cream!  We always take out of town guests here and they are never disappointed. Its fun to take our visitors here when you know they have nothing like this at home. It's fun to watch them make the ice cream too!  The chocolate is always good, but I really like to try the special ones. The mint was amazing and they had carrot cake ice cream in the fall; and there was a toffee type flavor that was fantastic too!  Please bring these back!!!
author: Leslie M.

description: This is a tiny shack near the park at the end of octavia. I went around 5 and was told a 10 min wait plus about five min line. They have 4 flavors a day but it was late so they had 3 left, salted caramel, malted vanilla and TCHO. They told me salted caramel takes the longest but we got that first and IT WAS HEAVEN. The texture was super smooth and melt in your mouth. I have a thing for salted caramel so I was in love. I wanted to get another one right away but the line was a bit long so I was a bit sad. Then the malted vanilla was the same texture and delicious! It tasted like Horlicks. Also super yummy. I was anticipating TCHO and I was a bit disappointed. Maybe because I never liked chocolate ice cream and only eat chocolate gelato. The prices may be expensive but you are guarantee fresh "homemade" ice cream made when you order. The liquid nitrogen does its job. I am waiting to go back!
author: Shirley Y.

description: I like this place.  We went there after riding our bikes in Golden Gate Park.  I like anything that is an 'experience' to try and this was certainly an experience due to its location and kiosk-like structure next to the small park.  The ice cream didn't make me do cartwheels, but it was good and high quality.  They have interesting flavors and use nitrogen to make the ice cream on the spot.  They make their own waffle cones.
author: N T.

description: Finally tried this place. They offered different flavor each week. The ice-cream itself has good textures, creamy, and not forget to mention, it melted quickly so you better hurry finishing that ice cream. I thinks its because they made it on the spot which is quite cool using a special ice-cream make. However, here's the catch, the portion of the ice cream is compared with their price. Especially, the smallest one $3 and it was only half of a cup. It seems a bit pricey for me.
author: Immanuel L.

description: I was charmed by the whole setup.  It was so cute with the iPads as registers, the open arrangement of Kelvins churning out smooth, rich ice creams.  Aside from the novely of the storefront, the ice cream stood on its own.  I had the mint with chocolate chips.  The mint reminded me of fresh spearmint,  the chocolate just the right degree of bitterness, and the waffle cone tasted as though it just been taken out of the oven.  I loved it!  The flavors were limited, maybe three flavors?   But they really know what they're doing.
author: Betty T.

description: Great ice cream, made to order, using a chemistry party parlor trick. I'm just sorry they were out of the candied jalapeno when I was there.
author: Marvin H.

description: Brown sugar with cinnamon cookies was amazing.  The cookies added a little crunch and the ice cream was the perfect consistency.  So good that I'm not even taking off a star for the 6 dollars that two scoops cost us! It was worth it. Plus we met the owner and she's really nice and excited about her business, always a plus! The machines they use to make the ice cream are really cool; it is a fun idea to stand and watch your ice cream turn from liquid to...well, ice cream :)
author: sara e.

description: Expensive, but worth it for the novelty of watching it made using nitrogen! Great stop for those out-of-towner or out-of-state visitors you might be hosting.  Vanilla - yum! Coffee - yum! Tcho chocolate I found to be a bit too bitter for my taste, but might appeal to others. Maybe they were using the 72%. My max on chocolate preference is 64%. The employees are friendly and it was my birthday - if they have any, they'll put a cannel (Robbie Brown) in your ice cream and light it, too, if the lighter is working. It's fun to eat outdoors for a change. Waiting for the ice cream is a bit tough when the sun is blazing on you or when the weather is cold, as eating this ice cream is an all outdoor experience - bring an umbrella or wear your shorts, depending.
author: Lia H.

description:
i think it is pretty neat how they make the ice cream. 
it taste very smooth and fresh, they make it infront of you.

everyweek is different favo so is not really the same old stuff. that mean i cant really tell you "you should really try this ........"  For me i liked all the ice cream i had so far, but the cholocalate one melt a little to fast.
also, their ice cream cone taste really good it remind me of my childhood.

the price is a little to high but ill go back again to try more flavors
author: Jess I.

description: I work in Hayes Valley and have heard so much talk and more talk about this place. was it good? yeah!!! was it work the 15 Min wait? Not really.. Was it worth the $6.00 for the one scoop on the cone? Not really.. I grew up on Mitchells Ice Cream, call me old school, but its ice cream, you dont need to get all high tech and fancey with it. you dont need to make people wait 15 minuets for a scoop.
author: p s.

description: Very cute and easy setup.  If you're into very thick, mild tasting, heavy cream ice cream - this is the place for you.  I love that they use fresh, local, organic ingredients, but this is what the ice cream I made with my own cheap little ice cream maker at home tasted like the first time I tried it.  I prefer milkier ice cream to creamier, so it really is a matter of preference.  Not a quality issue for sure.
author: Danielle B.

description: I was a chaser in the "Journey to the end of the night" aka the city wide game of tag with 1000+ people and was at the third checkpoint and saw this place. It looked really interesting because of the nitrogen, so i tried it and it was great, the chocolate wasn't too rich and it was a great consistency and texture. Definitely coming back soon.
author: Alex K.

description: Yummy (esp. the Tcho Chocolate - uber chocolatey) and very fun.
author: Peter A.

description: Selection is weak, prices are astronomical, the only thing that saves it from a one star is the ice cream is decent
author: Aaron F.

description: Total gimmick, IMHO. Expensive and not nearly as enjoyable as BiRite or a pint of Three Twins. There are some things that don't suffer from being premade and ice cream is definitely one of them.
author: Susan W.

description: I waited 27 minutes for a medium chocolate.  It was NOT worth the wait.  The ice cream was good and creamy, but not worth a 27 minute wait.  Maybe if I had ordered the herb or the salted caramel, I may have got my ice cream sooner.  But again...it's not worth the wait.  Nice try though.  Good luck.
author: Steven M.

description: Interesting concept, abysmal execution. I was curious about this place and the churned-to-order concept, but having waited far too long for a tiny, overpriced cup of excruciatingly sweet green tea ice cream, and then waiting a further 10 minutes for my friend to get his cup of so-so vanilla ice cream while watching the disorganization behind the counter, I  think I'll stick to Bi-Rite. It looks like a bargain compared to Smitten.
author: Catherine P.

description: I live in the neighborhood and stopped by yesterday to give it a try.  There weren't many people in line ahead of me, but it still took over 5 minutes to get the ice cream.  I see this being a problem with longer lines.  The ice cream itself (I had salted caramel) was really tasty and creamy, but a bit expensive ($3.50 for kids size scoop).  I will definitely try it again and look forward to chocolate later this week.
author: Shannon S.

description: Ah-may-aing! Simply the best ice cream in the city hands down. I have been wanting to try this place. We ordered the salted carmel. Super rich and creamy with Big flavor. Seriously, none better. Pretty cool to be able to watch them make it as well
author: lissy L.

description: If you enjoy standing in line for 15 minutes for a $5.50 scoop of super rich ice creme, this may be the place for you.  I went when there was no line, tired the salted carmel.  I agree with some of the other reviews, good texture, but way too rich and definitely would not choose it over Mitchells or Double Rainbow. After two bites it was like eating a stick of butter.  I also don't get the made to order process, slow and basically if you buy regular ice creme and put it out on the counter for awhile you get the same texture.   Though you can't beat the location, Patricia's Green in Hayes Valley is great on a sunny day with Blue Bottle just down the road.  PS:  After my posting, Smitten's sent a nice email to me offering a free sample and stating they are working to improve their product.  I give them five stars for effort, but haven't yet returned to see if things have changed.
author: Daniel M.

description: I have never seen ice cream made like this...boy is it amazing...what's great is they leave out all the bad stuff..just pure goodness.  Haven't tried the caramel and almond brittle?? All I can say is yum!!!  I thought I could make homemade icecream fast. with my ice cream maker..but I have to admit this has me beat- by a long shot :-)
author: Heidi U.

description: i like the concept, but i wouldn't say it's the best ice cream i've ever had. yes, it's totally cool that they use liquid nitrogen to make your ice cream right before your eyes. after a while i think it'll lose it's novelty and people will just want good ice cream that doesn't break the bank. i got the mint chip and my buddy the salted caramel. it was good, but not enough for me to pay about 5 bucks for a small scoop that is honestly a bit too rich for my taste. worth a try but i'm not dying to return.
author: Yelp O.

description: I was having a gluttonous day eating French macaroons and gettin' my hair did so when I saw this bright red shipping container made ice cream stand, I went to have a looksie. Let's be real, I'm Asian and a little bit lactarded but I ended up ordering a small salted caramel (two decent sized scoops). Unaware of the gimmick, I thought I was just getting expensive ice-cream so I was surprised when the shop keeper denied my usual request to mix up one scoop of this and another scoop of that. Oh well, two minutes later my ice cream was high steaming in a metal contraption and I realized I was at a "special" ice cream stand. Was I smitten? It was indeed creamy and icy cold, dense like frozen custard. It tasted like burnt caramel hmmmmm. Yeah it was pretty good but mostly I was just smitten with the perfect day I was having and ending my afternoon with this icy goodness in the park surrounded by puppies. I knocked off a star because I was really confused with where I was and the "specialty" of it. No signs which read: warning, liquid nitrogen about to be used in the making of this ice cream. Maybe I wasn't looking hard enough.
author: Festher C.

description: I have visited Smitten multiple times and the experiences have varied from stellar to downright awful, this last time being the worst.  As my boyfriend and I were looking at the favors and deciding what we wanted, with no one behind us mind you, the lady taking orders was harsh and rushing us as if we were holding up the line...once we were ready, or as ready as we were allotted time for, we ordered.  Not having the easiest or clearest menu to read, we asked for something incorrectly and were responded with short tones that stunned me into ordering something that I didn't really want as to not have to converse with her again. Not only did I feel her customer service skills were severely lacking with ME, but as we waited for our ice cream to be ready, I heard the way she was talking to customers that came up after us that had never been there before asking how it worked and she was explaining it rudely and as if they were completely incompetent and totally wasting her time. I understand that YOU know how it works because you work there, but someone, a customer, whom has never been there, deserves a little more than was delivered.  As the gentleman left, not purchasing anything, I over heard him say, " why do I feel like the STUPIDEST person after talking to her!?"  Nice.
author: Derek D.

description: Terrific ice creams. I'm proud to say I was there when Robyn and co had this stuff in its early stages. I need to visit SF and get some more of this good stuff.
author: OLADAYO O.
